DOC.HEAD: Washington Arts Patron Dies
DOC.TEXT: David Lloyd Kreeger, former chairman of Geico Insurance Co. and longtime patron of the arts in the Washington area, is dead at age 81. Kreeger died of cancer at his home Sunday. A New York native who attended Rutgers University and Harvard Law School, Kreeger was a private attorney, with Geico as a client, when he formed a group to buy shares in the insurer in 1948. In 1957, Kreeger gave up his law practice to become a Geico vice president. He was chairman and chief executive from 1970 until his retirement in 1974. Kreeger served as president of the National Symphony Orchestra from 1970 to 1978 and gave his name to three buildings financed with the help of his donations at area cultural institutions - the Kreeger Theater at Arena Stage, the Kreeger Music Building at American University and the Kreeger Auditorium at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. He served as president and chairman of the Corcoran for 20 years. His art collection contained works of the most famous artists of the 19th and 20th centuries, including Degas, Renoir, van Gogh, Picasso and Kadinsky, but he cared most about music. Kreeger played violin in musical evenings at home with professionals and was most proud of a remark from famed cellist Pablo Casals that he, Kreeger, should practice more often - it showed that his playing was good enough so that practice could improve it.

DOC.HEAD: Banker Escapes Unharmed After Kidnapping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, ADDS byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP4
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Minnesota's second largest bank was taken captive by a nattily dressed armed man as he drove into the bank parking lot Monday, but escaped unharmed about two hours later, the FBI said. A man wearing a topcoat, a business suit and a brown tweed hat jumped into banker John Grundhofer's Mercedes Benz as he arrived for work at First Bank System Inc. shortly after 8 a.m., said FBI spokesman Jeff Jamar. The kidnapper, armed with a handgun and knife, then ordered him to drive out of the city, Jamar said. Authorities provided only sketchy details about the kidnapping and did not reveal a motive. They said Grundhofer escaped after about two hours when he was left unattended in a wooded area in western Wisconsin. He later called for help from a nearby farmhouse. The kidnapper made a ransom demand, which Grundhofer relayed to the bank from his car phone, but the banker escaped before steps were made to pay it, said Minneapolis Police Chief John Laux. The size of the ransom request was not disclosed. Grundhofer's car was not immediately recovered. ``I'm OK,'' Grundhofer told a news conference later. ``I have no idea why this took place this morning. I'm very grateful to the good Lord for me being here.'' Grundhofer, 51, was vice chairman and senior executive officer for southern California at San Francisco-based Wells Fargo Bank before hired as chairman at First Bank in January. The abductor, described as 50 to 60 years old and more than 6 feet tall, did not appear to be a professional criminal, Jamar said. First Bank, which has total assets of $19.2 billion, is the second largest bank holding company in Minnesota and the 36th largest in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Former Red Cross Worker Helps Restore War's Ruins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: George Esper, who covered the Vietnam War for The Associated Press from 1965 until its end in 1975, interviewed former Red Cross worker Cherie Rankin before her return to Vietnam. Here are her reflections of her journey into the past. ---

Like a growing number of Americans who served in Vietnam, Cherie Rankin returned there after 20 years to help rebuild a small part of what the war destroyed. In doing so, she also restored a part of her life. ``I think what it means is there's been enough distance from the trauma to make it safe for people to deal with it,'' she said. ``It means relations between our two countries are going to improve.'' For six weeks, Ms. Rankin, a former Red Cross worker, labored in the punishing sun mixing mortar to help build a medical clinic near Hanoi destroyed by U.S. bombers. At the end of October, she came home to the United States for the second time, a ``twice-in-a-lifetime experience.'' She cried for the living she left behind this trip. The last time, in 1971, it was for the dead. Two decades ago, she brought back with her the images of war, orphans scorched by napalm and blinded by bombs. This time, she came back with images of carefree, curious, clinging children who followed her wherever she went. Returning home, she clutched a hat full of love: the conical hat her Vietnamese co-workers signed as a remembrance on the day the clinic was finished and they parted with warm embraces and tears. ``There was a lot of crying that day,'' she recalled. In a sense, her return was part of a broader pilgrimage by Americans in recent years. Their return is a sentimental journey, a reconnecting with their past, when they were young men and women undergoing a transcendent experience. Ms. Rankin was only 24 then. For more than 10 years after she came home the first time in September 1971 after a year's tour, thinking about Vietnam made her sick to her stomach. She threw up at a reunion of Red Cross workers in 1984. Today, at age 44, she said Vietnam revisited has probably exorcised the demons from her mind that even counseling couldn't capture. Ms. Rankin herself is a psychotherapist. ``I think it has probably put a closure on it in a way that it hadn't before,'' she said. ``I probably will never use the word `resolve.' It's not something I want to have resolved. I don't ever want to forget the pain of the war because I might become complacent about war.'' Her return helped change the images in her mind of napalmed babies, starving children and the poverty and sadness she read in the faces of the Vietnamese when she was there two decades before. ``What I see now is ... happy children, sparkle and twinkles in the eyes of the people going on with their lives,'' Ms. Rankin said. ``There's still incredible poverty, but it's not so dirty. They're not starving because they grow their own food and are able to do that now. ``They still don't have things, still live in small homes and they don't have access to good medical care. But it's not the same kind of thing that happened during the war when they were displaced from their ancestral roots and their agricultural attachment to the land.'' Ms. Rankin was part of a group of seven American civilians and military veterans who paid their own way to Vietnam to build badly needed medical facilities. They were the third team of Americans to return under the auspices of the Veterans Vietnam Restoration Project in Garberville, Calif. Only non-governmental American organizations can give Vietnam humanitarian aid since the two governments have no diplomatic relations and the United States has imposed a trade embargo on the country. Ms. Rankin said most of the Vietnamese expressed interest in restoring relations so there could be free trade, communications and travel. ``They really are puzzled by our continued boycott of them and they were constantly in wonder of us,'' she said. ``It was impossible to walk down the street without being surrounded by adults as well as children. ``I think that I - and it's probably true for the other veterans that went with me - represented something bigger to the Vietnamese. The people we met saw us as representatives of our government. So there was a sense ... that things were softening. ... Fifteen years is long enough to hold a grudge.'' Kevin Bowen, a veteran and co-director of The William Joiner Center for the Study of War and Social Consequences at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, said Americans returning to Vietnam are finding it a way of healing some of the mental wounds of the war. ``I think for veterans in this country, it's important to get this episode behind us,'' said Bowen, who has made five trips back to Vietnam. ``We need to have different relations with Vietnam and with our past and not an angry, vindictive relationship. We're not just punishing Vietnam. We're punishing ourselves.'' Ms. Rankin returned to Vietnam with the intention of mourning the men whose hands she held as they lay dying and the Vietnamese orphans she embraced - the blind, the legless, the retarded. She had detached herself from her feelings during the war in order to do the job of building morale among the GIs. This time, work got in her way. ``I didn't really have a lot of time,'' she said. ``The work was very exhausting. We also had a lot of demands on our after-hours time, going to meet their governing bodies, to functions and to cultural events.'' But she cried when she said goodbye to her Vietnamese friends at the clinic and when she visited the grounds of the Sacred Heart Orphanage in Da Nang, where she had tended the children in her free time. The orphanage was almost exactly as she remembered it. But the children had been moved to another home south of Da Nang. In one of the many ironies of Vietnam, Sacred Heart now is home for old people who have nobody, their children killed in the war. After the clinic was built, Ms. Rankin spent two more weeks in Vietnam. She retraced her wartime steps in what was then South Vietnam, basking in the moments that almost seemed unreal - and remembering. The sites stepped out of history to meet her: Marble Mountain, Monkey Mountain, China Beach. She recognized them all. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Special Correspondent George Esper is the AP's Northeast regional reporter, based in Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Crime Increasing in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcement officials say violent crime is on the rise in some of Europe's traditionally law-abiding nations. Critics accuse them of stirring up fear to get bigger budgets. The average homicide rate in Europe remains only about one-fifth that of the United States, which has approximately nine homicides per 100,000 people each year, according to the U.N. World Health Organization in Geneva. Homicide rates for the Netherlands and Switzerland rose 20 percent and 13 percent respectively in 1989, according to police figures. Norway reported a 29 percent rise in violent crime from 1986 through 1988 and Italian homicides increased by 35 percent last year, mostly in Mafia regions. Rape and theft skyrocketed last year in Eastern Europe, accompaniments to economic instability and a deep-seated mistrust of police under the former communist regimes. In Denmark, France and Portugal, however, the low homicide rates have hardly changed in recent years. Significant declines have been recorded in Britain, Germany and Belgium. ``Our whole society is getting more aggressive,'' said Commissioner Herman Bergsma of the Central Police Intelligence Service in Holland. ``What used to end up in fistfights now ends up in gunfights.'' The number of assaults with firearms in the Netherlands nearly doubled from 134 in 1985 to 245 last year, mainly because of killings by drug traffickers, Bergsma said. According to WHO statistics, the homicide rate in this nation of 14.9 million people had been one of the world's lowest, just above Britain and Ireland. Herman Franke, a criminologist at the University of Amsterdam, believes police are classifying more crime as violent to support requests for larger budgets and more officers. ``Crime statistics are highly political,'' he said. ``They're used to influence public opinion in every country.'' In the Norwegian parliamentary elections, the conservative Party of Progress went from 2 of the 165 seats to 22 on a wave of public anxiety that followed reports of the 29 percent growth in violent crime. ``Violent crime is not increasing,'' Franke said, ``only our sensitivity to it.'' Nils Christie, a University of Oslo criminology professor, said: ``Our biggest crime problem is the unfounded anxiety people feel.'' Although the murder rate in neighboring Sweden has barely changed in years, tighter gun laws are to take effect in 1991. Total crimes reported in Poland rose from 137,000 in 1988 to more than 500,00 last year. ``The crime we witness today is a result of the political situation,'' said Janusz Wydra, deputy police chief of Warsaw. ``The more freedom there is, the less security.'' Poland has embarked on a conversion from communism to capitalism that has cost about 1 million people their jobs and driven most prices up more than 180 percent. Franke, the Dutch criminologist, argued that skyrocketing statistics in former communist countries indicate the old regimes doctored figures for political reasons, not that crime has increased dramatically. He conceded that homes and businesses in the new East European democracies are easy targets for thieves, since their owners have little experience with crime prevention. ``In Warsaw, the situation is terrifying,'' said Wincenty Grzeszczyk of the Polish General Prosecutor's Department. Stores do a booming business in window grates, auto alarms, deadbolt locks and Mace. Statistics in Czechoslovakia indicate crime has increased 400 percent in some Prague districts since President Vaclav Havel declared a general amnesty in 1989 for most prisoners jailed under the communists. The amnesty brought the release of about two-thirds of the prison population. Muggings rose 250 percent in urban areas during the first six months of 1990 and total crime was up 138 percent in the same period, according to official figures. Italy is the most crime-prone country in Western Europe. Last year's 1,295 homicides reflected a 35 percent increase from 1988. Britain tightened gun laws after a gun collector in Hungerford, 60 miles west of London, killed 16 people, including his mother, in August 1987, then took his own life. The homicide rate has fallen by half under the new laws. Most European countries severely restrict gun ownership, but firearms are relatively easy to buy on the black market. Police in Copenhagen found hundreds of hand grenades, mines, anti-tank rockets, handguns and rifles in the possession of a pro-Palestinian group that had robbed banks for seven years. Still, Franke credited tough gun-control laws with making European cities relatively murder-free - because, he said, ``people can't resort to guns to solve their quarrels.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Report: AIDS Explosion Likely In Asia
DOC.TEXT: Though less then 1 percent of all known AIDS cases are in Asia and the Pacific, the region can expect a dramatic increase over the next few years, a new U.N. report says. The study, released Monday, quoted an Asian medical journal as saying: ``All the factors that have allowed AIDS to assume epidemic proportions in Africa - poor genital health of women, malnutrition, hepatitis, intestinal worms, low immunity levels - are just as endemic in Asia.'' The report was presented to a meeting in Bangkok of the population and social development committee of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. The five-day meeting began Monday. As of February, there had been a total of 215,144 AIDS cases reported in 153 countries, but just 2,067 of them were in Asian and Pacific countries, the report says. But the Asia-Pacific figure may be low because nearly three-fourths of the reported cases are in Australia, which has one of the region's best reporting systems, the report notes. ``Many countries reported no cases at all, and in some instances this was in conflict with other evidence,'' it says. ``There can be little doubt that the number of cases in the Asian and Pacific region will grow dramatically over the next few years.'' The World Health Organization estimates there are now 500,000 HIV-infected people in Asia, the report says. HIV, or Human Immunodeficiency Virus, causes AIDS, or Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. But people who become infected with HIV do not always get AIDS, which fatally destroys the body's immune system. AIDS is most commonly transmitted through sexual intercourse, infected hypodermic needles and blood transfusions. ``HIV infection in the (Asia-Pacific) region began later than in other parts of the world, but the current growth in HIV infection in the region ensures that the number of AIDS cases will grow rapidly in the future,'' the U.N. report says. ``It is projected that 75 percent of those with HIV infection will develop AIDS within 15 years and 95 percent within 20 years.'' The report recommends stronger education and information campaigns to combat the spread of the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Companies Set Sights on Vietnam
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Japanese companies have set their sights on doing business with Vietnam, which many avoided for years in order not to upset the United States. ``It's Vietnam fever,'' said Tatsuo Torigoe, an Asia division manager of Kanematsu Corp., Japan's major trading house. ``The time has finally come for us to make a move.'' Analysts in Tokyo believe Japanese televisions, refrigerators and other household goods will soon fill shops in Vietnam as they do in other nations around the globe. They also expect Japanese businessmen to buy more Vietnamese petroleum. Oil already accounts for more than half Japan's imports from the Southeast Asian nation, which is impoverished but rich in resources. Five times as many Japanese companies sent representatives to Vietnam in 1988 as in 1987 ``and it is my impression that there will be more this year,'' said Akitake Yamamoto, a spokesman for a Kanematsu subsidiary that has traded there for more than 20 years. Until recent months, Japanese companies were either restricting business with Vietnam or dealing discreetly. Activity was dampened by their government's support of the U.S. policy of isolating Vietnam and by a 1987 U.S. Senate resolution urging Japan to prevent private companies from trading with Vietnam. Although Washington still refuses to establish formal diplomatic relations with Vietnam, there are indications it may be taking a less hostile attitude. This has helped reawaken Japanese interest. The most visible example of a thaw was the agreement reached by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam in September to cooperate in searching for American soldiers missing in action and in resolving Cambodia's civil war, in which Vietnamese troops have been heavily involved. With that and recent Vietnamse efforts to entice foreign investment, Japanese companies are shedding reservations about doing business there. Kanematsu has applied to the Vietnamese government for a license to open offices in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon. The Bank of Tokyo, which had a branch in Saigon in 1962-1975, began to consider reopening it ``when we realized the improving Cambodian situation and Vietnamese economy over the last couple of years,'' said spokesman Kazuhiro Miya. Victor Co. of Japan, which already exports television sets to Vietnam, and Sanyo Electric Trade Co., a purveyor of home appliances, both plan to open offices in Ho Chi Minh City. ``Our business in Vietnam is determined by the Japanese government's policy, which is based on the U.S.-Vietnamese relations,'' Miya said. ``When the U.S.-Vietnamese relationship improves more, we'll be a few steps ahead of the Americans.'' Trade already is increasing dramatically. Japanese exports to Vietnam reached $270 million in the first half of 1990, up 84 percent from the same period in 1989, and imports from Vietnam increased two-thirds to $124 million. Vietnam's population of about 67 million also may provide Japanese companies with a source of cheap labor. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said the government was not particularly concerned about the renewed business interest in Vietnam. Asked about U.S. reaction, he replied: ``I think we've been exchanging views.'' A U.S. diplomatic source, speaking on condition of anonymity, noted that the United States has yet to lift restrictions on Americans doing business with Vietnam. ``What other governments do with their business people is their business,'' he said. ``I think the government of Japan is aware of our view that relations should not be entirely normalized, that we cannot conduct business as usual'' until the Cambodian conflict is resolved. It is not yet business as usual between Tokyo and Hanoi, but relations clearly are improving. In October, Thach became the first Vietnamese foreign minister in 12 years to pay an official visit to Japan. Japan promised him a $180,000 grant for Vietnam's national television station, the first major economic assistance since 1978, the Foreign Ministry said. Japanese corporations believe they can help Vietnam's backward economy enter the modern world. Torigoe, the Kanematsu official, said his firm plans to renovate Vietnamese factories and equipment to help make the country's products competitive. ``We are not doing this for charity,'' he said. ``We don't mind extra investments, considering Vietnam's potential and its location close by. Vietnam is that attractive.''

DOC.HEAD: Syria Believed to Match Iraq in Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Syria, a newfound U.S. ally against Saddam Hussein, has a chemical weapons arsenal at least as dangerous as Iraq's, U.S. experts say. The two nations are believed to be the biggest producers of chemical weapons in the Mideast, creating hundreds of tons of the deadly gas each year. World attention has focused on Iraq's chemical capability in the three months since its unprovoked invasion of neighboring Kuwait. Washington's relations with Damascus, strained for many years over Syria's support for international terrorism and its hardline positions against Israel, have warmed in recent weeks since the Syrians joined the anti-Iraq coalition. Syria has promised to send 15,000 troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Iraq in Saudi Arabia. U.S. officials say they are concerned about the Syrian chemical weapons production and have tried to prevent Syria from obtaining the materials necessary to produce such arms. The United States is part of the Australia Group, named for the country that initiated the international effort to stop the proliferation of cheical weapons - the poor man's atom bomb. The 16-nation group tracks companies that sell components for the production of nerve and mustard gas, and encourages governments to tighten their export control laws for such chemicals and to prosecute violators. At least five Arab countries manufacture chemical weapons: Syria, Egypt, Iran, Iraq and Libya. Israel also is known to have a sizable chemical weapons cache. Syria's chemical warfare program has been a cause of concern to its biggest arms supplier, the Soviet Union. In 1988, the head of the Soviet chemical warfare corps, Vladimir Pikalov, visited Syria to find out what it was up to, said Seth Carus, a modern warfare expert. ``The Soviets believed the Syrians were lying to them about not producing'' chemical weapons, said Carus. But attempts to stop Syria have largely failed. Syria, like Iraq, got most of its help in setting up production facilities through German companies, although other Western European firms also were involved, experts say. Damascus received its first chemical weapons from Egypt in 1972 in the form of chemical-filled artillery shells, but did not use such weapons in its 1973 war with Israel. It acquired production capability in the mid-1980s, concentrating on the agent Sarin, which paralyzes the human nervous system, said Carus. Syria is believed to have two production facilities - one just north of Damascus and the other near the city of Homs. The program is run by CERS, a governmental scientific research authority. Syria produces several hundred tons of nerve and mustard gas every year, said Carus. Iraq is believed to produce an estimated 800 tons of nerve and mustard agents every year. But Syria is believed to have more accurate means of delivering the chemicals than Iraq does. Israeli experts who track the Syrian program believe Syria has equipped Soviet-made SS-21 rockets with chemical warheads, said Leonard Specter, an arms control researcher at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. The short-range SS-21s are highly accurate and could inflict severe damage on next-door Israel, immobilizing its air force and reserve call-ups in the initial stages of a war, said Specter. Syria also is believed to have equipped longer-range SCUD missiles with chemical delivery capability. Iraq may have placed chemical warheads on some of its Soviet-designed SCUDs, which have been modified to reach targets as far away as Israel, 600 miles away. Syria also could attack Israel with chemical artillery shells, which are far cheaper and more abundant than missiles, said Edward Luttwak of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ``They have the advantage of being near enough (to) Israel to use shells and cause damage,'' he said. But most independent experts believe Syria is unlikely to use chemical weapons unless it felt seriously threatened by Israel's superior military might. Specter said: ``Some weapons are less usable because of who your adversary is. Syria would have to think long and hard before it risked retaliation from Israel or Iraq, for that matter.'' Iraq and Iran are known to have used chemical weapons during their eight-year war in the 1980s, and Egypt is known to have mounted 32 attacks with such weapons while putting down an insurrection in Yemen in the 1960s. Iraq also unleashed chemical agents against its Kurdish minority in 1988, killing and wounding thousands.

DOC.HEAD: Summit of Conciliation Opens Behind Barriers of Steel
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Along the Champs Elysees, sidewalks bustle with tourists and shoppers. A block away, a posh neighborhood is sealed off by steel barricades and riot police so world leaders can talk peace. It is one of many contrasts to be found in Paris as the leaders of 34 countries convene a three-day summit today intended to push Europe into the post-Cold War era. Throughout the area around the ornate Kleber International Conference Center are flags, tents and festive decorations. Equally evident are the manifestations of a vast, state-of-the-art security operation. Police have conducted door-to-door inspections of buildings in the vicinity, interviewing residents and issuing special passes so they can use their homes. Sewers have been checked for bombs, and sophisticated X-ray machines have been installed at the entrances of conference facilities. More than 10,000 French police have been mobilized, complemented by the secret service agents of individual leaders. While Secretary of State James A. Baker III held talks Sunday night at the luxury Intercontinental Hotel, one his agents clad in a jogging suit spoke into a walkie-talkie in the lobby. A horde of cameramen and photographers seeking to cover Baker were asked to lay their equipment on the floor. In came a hound that sniffed the cameras for explosives. Along with security, there is a strong emphasis on public relations. The French have issued mountains of press releases giving background on the summit. The Soviets opened a special press center at their embassy where the thousands of journalists on hand can pick up glossy brochures about Mikhail Gorbachev. Even the Soviet republic of Armenia, not a participant at any level in the summit, has scheduled a press conference. Parisians have been warned to avoid driving in the area around the conference center and the Arc de Triomphe. The Kleber subway stop has been closed, several bus routes suspended, and numerous streets closed off. Two taxi drivers wondered bitterly why the summit had to be in Paris, rather than one of the grand chateaus on the outskirts of the city. Said one: ``The leaders are coming to make peace, but for us, work will be war.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Ruling on CNN-Noriega Tapes Harms Press Freedom, Advocates Say
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court is condoning at least brief ``gag orders'' against the news media by refusing to let Cable News Network broadcast tape-recorded conversations of Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega, say free press advocates. They said the justices' action Sunday was extraordinary and poses grave risks to unfettered reporting of court proceedings nationwide. Attorney Floyd Abrams, who is representing CNN, said, ``The court has left an opening through which defense lawyers and prosecutors may try to muzzle news articles.'' The high court's 7-2 rejection of CNN's emergency request ``does seem to countenance brief prior restraints of a few days' duration based on almost no showing of need at all,'' he said. The court's action Sunday effectively bars CNN from broadcasting tape-recordings of conversations between Noriega and his lawyers. CNN had asked the justices to lift U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler's order forbidding the broadcasts until he could determine what is on the tapes. The network said it will now turn over the tapes to Hoeveler's court in Miami. Bruce Sanford, a lawyer who represents the Society of Professional Journalists, said, ``The Supreme Court decision is a grave disappointment that departs from existing Supreme Court precedent. It is particularly troublesome because it seems inconceivable that Noriega's counsel would ever be able to prove that his right to a fair trial was in jeopardy because of the CNN tapes.'' Jane Kirtley, executive director of the Reporters' Committee for Freedom of the Press, called the development a stunning departure that ``signals a new era in First Amendment jurisprudence. It will have a far-reaching impact in ... courts around the country.'' However, Noriega defense attorney Jon May said, ``We think it's a correct ruling. This was a major mistake by CNN, a big, big mistake. This is a case of the messenger shooting itself. To whatever extent the media may complain this is a significant adverse decision, CNN has only itself to blame.'' Only Justices Thurgood Marshall and Sandra Day O'Connor sided with CNN. Marshall, writing for both, said, ``I do not see how the prior restraint imposed in this case can be reconciled'' with prior high court rulings. He said Hoeveler's Nov. 8 order barring the CNN broadcasts is based on the ``remarkable conclusion that publication can be automatically restrained'' while courts study the basis for such restraints. The seven justices who rejected CNN's application were silent, leaving it unclear what they believe about the underlying controversy. In the majority were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter. The high court order does not preclude the justices from some day deciding that Hoeveler's order did violate CNN's free speech rights protected by the First Amendment. The court could have refused to help CNN on some narrower grounds and could review the issue at a later date if there is still a live controversy. The Bush administration had joined with Noriega's lawyers in opposing the CNN request. The Justice Department had said, ``The First Amendment is part of the rule of law, not above it. A lasting prior restraint on publication may be justified only in the most extraordinary circumstances. But the rule of law requires permitting a court to determine if those circumstances exist.'' In addition to CNN's emergency request, the court also issued a one-sentence order turning down a formal appeal filed by the cable network. CNN President Tom Johnson called the court's decision ``a loss of a battle in a continuing war against censorship.'' He said he hopes Hoeveler will permit CNN to air the tapes after reviewing them. The federal government lost a much-publicized battle over a prior restraint in 1971 when the Supreme Court allowed The New York Times and The Washington Post to publish the so-called Pentagon papers detailing American involvement in Vietnam. But some observers noted that for several days the high court itself had, in effect, blocked publication while it was reviewing the dispute. The prior restraint then was based on the government's claim that publication would hurt national security. In a key 1976 decision, the court unanimously struck down a gag order issued against the news media by a judge presiding over a Nebraska murder case. The court said then that such orders may be used only as a last resort and that judges first must consider less drastic measures. Noriega, who is awaiting trial on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect cocaine trade through Panama, is being held in a federal prison near MIami. Federal prison authorities monitor and tape-record all inmates' telephone conversations except those between inmates and their defense teams. But the CNN tape recordings reportedly contain some conversations between the deposed Panamanian leader and his lawyers. Noriega's lawyers said broadcasting the tapes would create unfair pretrial publicity, would compromise the confidentiality of the attorney-client relationship and tip off prosecutors about defense strategy.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Naomi Judd, the older half of the mother-daughter country music duo the Judds, says her religion helps her live with hepatitis. ``I believe that you can reverse illnesses by putting yourself in the Lord's hands,'' she told People magazine in its Nov. 26 issue. ``Miracles do happen and I'm looking for one.'' Judd, 44, has chronic active hepatitis, a liver ailment that can be fatal. She and her daughter, Wynonna, whose hits include ``Mama, He's Crazy'' and ``Grandpa,'' recently attended a ``prayer healing'' at their church. ``We did some rockin' and rollin' ... and I totally surrendered to God,'' she said. Judd has given up performing for now but said medical tests show she's improving. --- FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. (AP) - Bob Keeshan, television's ``Captain Kangaroo,'' says the aim of many kids' shows today is to sell toys, not nurture children. ``We don't have very much quality in the commercial sector,'' Keeshan, 62, said Sunday. He was a guest at a fund-raiser held by the Cape Fear Valley Medical Center for children's hospital services. Keeshan cited his own show, ``Mister Rogers'' and ``Sesame Street'' on public television as programs that nurture children. Many other children's programs, especially cartoons, jump from the toy shelf to television, he said. ``Captain Kangaroo'' is broadcast on more than 175 public TV stations nationwide. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Demi Moore says roles for women in Hollywood aren't what they used to be. ``Women in films used to be beautiful and smart and talented and strong and that was acceptable,'' the actress said in an interview in Cosmopolitan magazine's December issue. I want to see glamorous, smart women in movies again and I want to be part of that.'' The star of this summer's blockbuster ``Ghost'' said most movies today portray women as rape victims, prostitutes or ``the good wife.'' Moore is in four upcoming movies, including ``Mortal Thoughts,'' which also features her husband, ``Die Hard'' star Bruce Willis. --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - Ten years ago, Linda Evans was miserable, filled with self-doubt and dependent on men. Today, she has a new life and a new man. Evans, best known as Krystle on ``Dynasty,'' will appear next week in the ABC movie ``I'll Take Romance,'' her first project since leaving ``Dynasty'' 1{ years ago. ``I spent a lot of years really working on myself,'' Evans said in the Nov. 24 issue of TV Guide. ``I wanted to know where I was coming from that I would be 37 years of age, have two failed marriages, no children, and be going out for a career I didn't want.'' Evans has found love with 35-year-old New Age music composer Yanni but said she feels no need to marry him. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Rock musician David Crosby broke several bones in a weekend motorcyle accident, officials said. The 49-year-old Crosby was listed in stable condition Sunday at Cedars Sinai Medical Center. His left leg, left ankle and left shoulder were broken in the accident Saturday. Crosby is a founding member of the group Crosby, Stills & Nash, which later became Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young. Crosby, who was apparently speeding, skidded about 40 feet down a curve in suburban Encino, police said. --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - James Garner has taken life a little easier since he underwent two heart operations in 1988, but he's not out of the picture. ``I'm just not working as hard as I used to,'' the actor said in the Nov. 24 issue of TV Guide. ``I'm getting more picky.'' Garner plays a retired judge asked to champion the cause of a black veteran in the NBC movie ``Decoration Day,'' which airs Dec. 2. --- BOSTON (AP) - U.S. Rep. Barney Frank's quick response when he suffered a mild heart attack prevented more serious problems, a doctor says. The 50-year-old Massachusetts Democrat took a cab to Beth Israel Hospital on Saturday night after suffering chest pains while exercising at a health club. Doctors performed an angioplasty to clear a blocked artery to the heart, and the congressman was resting comfortably Sunday, officials said. ``I'm pleased to say treatment seems to be working,'' said cardiologist William Grossman. ``He has no other medical problems.'' Grossman said the prompt treatment prevented more severe problems. Frank was elected this month to a sixth term. Last summer, the House reprimanded him for actions stemming from his relationship with a male prostitute. --- HOUSTON (AP) - If Paul McCartney wants his birth certificate, he'll have to visit Brian Taylor - and bring his checkbook. Taylor, 26, of Washington, D.C., paid $18,000 at an auction Sunday for the former Beatle's birth certificate, sold to an American investor by the rock star's stepmother, Angela Williams. Taylor said he hoped McCartney would contact him about it, but Taylor's investment would not be handed over lightly. ``Sure, I'll sell it to him,'' he said. ``I would have to talk about (the price) to Mr. McCartney himself.'' McCartney was born in Liverpool, England, on June 18, 1942. ``I'm just a Beatles freak and I had to have it,'' said Taylor. ``It's a hobby that's gone a little too far.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Headed for European Security Summit With Elevated Status
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl attends this week's Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe with more prestige and power than any post-World War II German leader. Instead of two German nameplates at the Paris conference - one each for West Germany and East Germany - there will be just one: the Federal Republic of Germany. Seated behind the nameplate will be Kohl, architect of one of the most dramatic episodes in modern European history: German reunification. Attesting to Kohl's elevated status are plans for the German chancellor to deliver a major address on Tuesday, the second day of the three-day meeting. Kohl likely will use his address to repeat his calls for faster economic and political integration of Europe. After fusing the two Germanys, Kohl now wants to be seen as a prime mover for European unity. The Paris gathering could give him a test of his sometimes faulted statesmanship and provide signs of how Germany will wield its new might. Even before German unification, Kohl had left a strong imprint on plans for creating a barrier-free internal market within the European Community by 1992. And now his government is helping set the pace for the EC's planned economic and monetary union. At a summit last month, EC leaders agreed on a timetable for economic and monetary union that reflected German conditions. Kohl has been praised - even by his political opponents - for the way he steered Germany to unification. But he sometimes disappoints his allies on key international matters, including his reluctance earlier this year to pledge that a united Germany would recognize Poland's western border. Kohl's latest difficulties in the international arena are cropping up because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The chancellor backed Willy Brandt's one-man hostage rescue mission to Baghdad, a trip that was denounced by Washington and some European governments. Early in the gulf crisis, he also faced accusations that he was focusing on unification and other German interests at the expense of global problems. Kohl has insisted that the new, united Germany will live up to global responsibilities befitting its power. President Bush and the other summiteers undoubtedly will be keen to hear from Kohl how this will be done. In Paris, Kohl also may face questions about his ideas on the proper role of Germany's military. Kohl's defense minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, said that Germany's armed forces in the future must be ready to help resolve regional European conflicts. There will likely also be interest in Paris about Germany's ever-expanding relationship with the Soviet Union. There are worries among some in Western Europe that Germany is drifting from the West. On Nov. 9 in Bonn, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Kohl signed the most important German-Soviet treaty of the post-war period. The document commits the two nations to intensify their political, cultural and economic ties over the next 20 years. The two nations also pledged not to attack one another, and to respect the boundaries of all European nations.

The conventional arms treaty limits the non-nuclear weapons of the United States, the Soviet Union and 20 other countries, and covers European territory from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains. Here are key provisions of the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty. ---
DOC.HEAD: TANKS:
DOC.TEXT: The treaty requires the Soviet Union to reduce the number of tanks from about 41,000 before the treaty negotiations began in 1989 to 13,150. Moscow already has reduced its tank holdings in the area to about 21,000, mainly by moving its best models east as replacements for older ones. The allowable number tanks for all of Eastern Europe will be 20,000. The United States and its NATO allies also will be allowed 20,000 tanks. That will require a cut of about 4,000 for NATO, although more than 1,000 of the top-of-the-line American M1-A1 tanks already are being moved from Europe to Saudi Arabia. ---
DOC.HEAD: ARMORED VEHICLES:
DOC.TEXT: The 32,300 armored combat vehicles now deployed by the Soviets will be reduced to 20,000. NATO will not have to make any cuts in this category, which includes such war-fighting machinery as the U.S. Bradley Fighting Vehicle used to move infantry, protect maneuvering tanks and help consolidate gains in an offensive. ---
DOC.HEAD: ARTILLERY:
DOC.TEXT: The Soviets will be required to reduce the number of artillery pieces, which provide the essential firepower for a combat operation from about 52,000 to 13,175. The Soviets already have reduced the number to 18,300. NATO will stay at its current level of 18,500.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. to Continue Export Subsidies Until Others Stop
DOC.TEXT: A federal program to subsidize U.S. agricultural exports will be continued under the 1990 farm bill, and the Agriculture Department says it will be used aggressively to meet foreign competition. But Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says that ideally all countries ought to do away with export subsidies. That was the original idea going into negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. For some time, however, the United States has pushed for a 90 percent reduction in export subsidies over 10 years. Yeutter, in Europe last week, said that if the current Uruguay Round of talks fails, it will be another decade or so before GATT gets to another negotiating round. ``We have procrastinated long enough with agricultural trade reform,'' he said at a news conference in Bonn. ``We need to get it under way. That means significant disciplines of export subsidies.'' Yeutter continued: ``We would prefer to see export subsidies eliminated from the face of the earth insofar as agricultural trade is concerned, as we have already done in the GATT with industrial export subsidies.'' The 1990 farm bill is scheduled to be sent to the White House this week, where it will await President Bush's signature upon his return from Europe and the Mideast. Meanwhile, the USDA has issued a report updating the Export Enhancement Program, or EEP, as the subsidy arrangement is called. The EEP was created in 1985 to: -Boost U.S. agricultural exports. -Challenge unfair trade practices that hurt U.S. exports, particularly those of the European Community. -Encourage serious negotiations on agricultural trade under GATT. Under the program, U.S. exporters can get free surplus government-owned commodities as bonuses, or subsidies, so shippers can keep prices competitive with other countries trying to sell to the same markets. The department maintains a list of countries eligible for EEP sales, and there is a list of commodities that can qualify for the subsidies. As of Oct. 1, the department had announced 110 ``initiatives'' for selling 12 different farm commodities to 73 countries. The bonuses, or subsidies, paid to exporters since 1986 total $2.87 billion. The new farm bill - the Food, Agriculture, Conservation and Trade Act of 1990 - includes reauthorization of EEP through 1995. ``It also continues the USDA policy of not issuing new EEP initiatives that would adversely impact the agricultural exports of non-subsidizing competitors,'' the report said. Wheat is the biggest item among the dozen commodities that are currently on the EEP list, accounting for more than 80 percent of the value of sales under the program. One-half of the total U.S. wheat exports from 1985 to 1989 were sold under EEP subsidy arrangements. Of the $2.87 billion in EEP subsidies paid to exporters, wheat has accounted for about $2.03 billion. Other items and their shares of EEP subsidies: flour, $214.5 million; feed grains, $273.5 million; semolina $12.4 million; barley malt, $21.9 million; rice, $15.9 million; poultry feed, $16.6 million; vegetable oil, $67.1 million; frozen poultry, $113.6 million; dairy cattle, $92.8 million, and table eggs, $12.5 million. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association says federal spending cuts negotiated between Congress and the Bush administration will erode an already faltering rural economy if they are not reversed. ``We must seek more adequate loan funds for rural electrification,'' Bob BErgland, the association's executive vice president, said in a statement last week. Bergland, a former secretary of agriculture, said the Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 imposes a further 25 percent cut in lending by the Rural Electrification Administration, an agency of the Agriculture Department. The rural program, he said, ``has already absorbed a 40 percent reduction'' in direct loan funds over the past eight years. ``Meanwhile, other segments of the electric utility industry have been left untouched,'' Bergland said. According to the association, which is the national lobbying arm of local REA-financed electric cooperatives, its members serve more than 25 million consumers in the most sparsely settled areas of 46 states. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Field bindweed, described as an out-of-control morning glory, may be in for some bad times from an imported mite from the Mediterranean. The mite is only one-seventy-fifth of an inch long, said entomologist Sara S. Rosenthal of the department's Agricultural Research Service. But it has been cleared for attacking bindweed, which can strangle corn and other crop plants. Rosenthal, who works at the agency's rangeland weeds laboratory in Bozeman, Mont., said the mites were collected near Rome and were released in Texas and New Jersey in the spring of last year. The tiny mite previously had been found to eat the stems and leaves of field bindweed and closely related plants, none of which are farm crops. Preliminary reviews show the mite survived last winter and reproduced at both the Texas and New Jersey sites, the agency said in a report released here.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Wendell Ford is Happy to be No. 2
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in a long time, Senate Democrats have a No. 2 guy who doesn't seem to want a better job. Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, at 66, is the Senate's new assistant majority leader, replacing the ailing Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Cranston, who stepped out of Ford's way because of poor health, at one time viewed himself as presidential timber. So did his predecessor, Robert C. Byrd. And so, too, his predecessor, Edward M. Kennedy, who may still. Ford, however, has signaled no such aspirations. The third new o. 2 leader in the Capitol in less than two years - the other two are in the House - he's by far the most deferential. ``The majority leader will be the spokesman for the Senate Democratic Party,'' he said, referring to Sen. George Mitchell, D-Maine, nine years Ford's junior, who may have presidential ambitions of his own one day. A master of the inside game of the Senate, Ford coveted the ultimate insider's position which he now holds and plans to keep it inside. His hope, and that of the colleagues who elected him, is that the Senate will look a little better from the outside. It took more than two years for Ford to win the post. He started late in 1988, trying to unseat Cranston in that year's inside-the-Capitol party elections on a campaign theme of trying to make the Senate work better. Ford was soundly beaten by Cranston, who had held the post since 1977. But Ford never stopped running, and Cranston's stock went down in the wake of his ties to Charles Keating, former head of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan. Few doubt that Ford would have won last week's vote, even if Cranston had not dropped out of the race less than a week earlier. Ford managed to scare off a potential challenge by Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., and win the race uncontested. Ask Ford what he wants to do as whip, and he says he wants to do all he can to make Mitchell's job a little easier. That's the politically correct answer to give, and Ford makes it believable. Ford, a former governor of Kentucky, was first elected to the Senate in 1974. A lot of former governors find the Senate frustrating, the slow pace maddening, the inefficiencies compared to the executive branch ridiculous. But Wendell Ford found a home. Over the years, he has been most vigorous in defending his home state interests, including the tobacco, liquor and coal industries. He also is known for his hospitality when colleagues make an annual pilgrimage to the Kentucky Derby. He's the kind of guy who picks up the tab at the bar for out-of-town guests. And that's the way he does business in the Senate. Ford has a strong preference for working out deals with his colleagues before they result in full Senate blowups. On tobacco, for example, he was instrumental in working out a new price support program as part of a 1986 budget compromise that made permanent the 16-cent-a-pack federal tax on cigarettes. He also helped work out an eventual 8-cent additional increase in the tobacco levy in the latest deficit-reduction package. The increase was agreed to early in the budget talks, avoiding political bloodshed and a possible showdown with lawmakers who were demanding far stiffer taxes. Not that Ford is afraid of showdowns. In 1987, when Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., tried to end tobacco export subsidies, Ford threatened to retaliate against federal programs that help Rhode Island. From his senior position on the Energy Committee, he vowed there would be ``blood on the carpet of the Senate'' if Western states succeeded in getting a coal slurry pipeline to help deliver their coal to markets to the South and East. Those would be tough positions to defend if Ford were running for a national office. But they surely haven't hurt him in Kentucky, where he won his last election in 1986 with a state record 74 percent of the vote. Ford's style would give one the impression that he shies away from the big issues of the day, but that's not the case. Asked last week about the situation in the Persian Gulf, Ford stated his strong preference for giving the economic sanctions more time to work - lots more time, a year or more. ``Vietnam with sand'' was his description of the risk of war. Not surprisingly, Ford's position was right in line with majority leader Mitchell's, a comfortable place especially if you're comfortable being No. 2. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Killed as Police Forces Battle Over Gun Dispute
DOC.TEXT: One police officer was killed and three wounded in a two-hour shootout between city and federal police sparked by a dispute over whether federal officers could take guns into a saloon, a news agency reported. Army troops intervened and ended the battle early Saturday in Culiacan, about 600 miles northwest of Mexico City, the government-owned Notimex news agency said Sunday. Manuela Ruiz Arce of the local prosecutor's office said six federal judicial policemen tried to take their guns into a local bar and city police objected. A federal officer identified only as Francisco N. was killed and that two federal agents and a city policeman were wounded, Notimex reported. Federal police are in charge of investigating drug crimes. The agency said both police agencies have refused to comment on the matter.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Says She Doesn't Believe Gulf Crisis Will Lead To War
DOC.TEXT: First lady Barbara Bush says she believes Iraqi President Saddam Hussein will ``see the wisdom'' of withdrawing from occupied Kuwait before the Persian Gulf crisis escalates into war. Speaking Sunday with reporters on Air Force One, Mrs. Bush said she was looking forward to spending Thanksgiving with U.S. troops deployed to the Persian Gulf region - except for one thing. ``We're visiting American troops and I hate to have them see me in pants,'' she said. She said she would wear comfortable ``Kennebunkport clothes'' in the desert like those she wears at the first family's vacation home on the Maine coast. Mrs. Bush chatted as she and the president flew here from Germany, where they had visited German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. She was wearing a silver bracelet which read ``Operation Desert Shield - a Call to Freedom.'' She said it was a gift from her daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, and that she had been wearing it for the past two weeks. ``I think it's a nice reminder. It snags on everything I wear. It cuts into me at night. It reminds me. I think it's important.'' Asked if she believed the Persian Gulf standoff would result in a war, she replied, ``No. So much of the world is united against Iraq that I think he (Saddam) will see the wisdom of it.'' Asked if she were concerned for the safety of the president and herself when they visit U.S. forces so close to the Kuwait and Iraq borders. ``I honestly wouldn't go on the trip if I thought it wasn't safe,'' she said. ``We'd rather be home for Thanksgiving, but so would 200,000 other people,'' she added, referring to the troops in the region. She and her husband plan to make three separate stops to share Thanksgiving with U.S. forces, including on a naval vessel in the gulf. Did she really intend to eat three separate dinners? ``You know, I was built for the job,'' said the full-figured first lady.

DOC.HEAD: Stringent Thai Media Decree Repealed
DOC.TEXT: The government has repealed a 14-year-old decree that allowed police to summarily shut down publications in the name of national security or law and order, state radio said today. Police now need a court order. The decree was scrapped effective Sunday in an order issued by Thailand's constitutional monarch, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, and countersigned by Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan. The repealed decree was issued on Oct. 21, 1976 by the government of Prime Minister Thanin Kraivichien, which was installed by the military following a bloody coup. Journalists united to lobby for the decree's repeal after police invoked it in February to shut the Naew Na newspaper for publishing a sensationalist headline about the murder of Saudi diplomats in Bangkok. Police had argued that the headline was damaging to Thai-Saudi relations. ``The Thai press has already been known as possibly the most free in Southeast Asia, a major plus for Thailand in the eyes of the international community,'' the Bangkok Post said in an editorial today. ``This freedom is made all the more wholesome now that the most serious legal hindrance has been removed.'' It said Thailand is now in an enhanced position to become the new regional center for the printing of foreign newspapers and magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Share Prices Rise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing Nikkei, dollar. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the yen on Monday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange advanced moderately. The dollar closed at 128.95 yen, down 0.78 yen from last Friday's close of 129.73 yen. It opened at 128.95 yen and ranged between 128.75 yen and 129.17 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 346.53 points, or 1.50 percent, to close at 23,518.16. The index had shed 315.85 points on Friday. Yasushi Ueda, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, said the dollar met slight selling pressure in early trading in reaction to Friday's easing of interest rates by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board - in addition to news that Iraq will free all its remaining foreign hostages by March 25. The dollar regained some ground toward the morning close because of its actual demand, Ueda said. The official Iraqi News Agency said Sunday the ``guests,'' as it calls the captives, would be allowed depart beginning December 25 if nothing ``mars the atmosphere of peace.'' ``The announcement will not become an incentive for further yen-buying because the Iraqi move was widely seen in the market as a strategy that will not necessarily lead to a withdrawal from Kuwait,'' Ueda said. In the stock market, the Nikkei index started higher in a favorable reaction to the relaxing of U.S. interest rates and some expectations toward peace in the Middle East with Iraq's hostage-release announcement, securities analysts said. A dealer at Nomura Securities said the index rose on small-lot buying in a broad front. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was higher at 85.26, compared with Friday's close of 84.77. Their yield fell to 7.650 percent from 7.760 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Robert Hofstadter, Nobel Prize-Winning Physicist, Dead at 75
DOC.TEXT: Robert Hofstadter, who won the Nobel Prize in physics in 1961 for determining the precise size and shape of the particles that make up the nucleus of the atom, has died at age 75. Hofstadter, who died of heart failure Saturday at his Stanford home, had taught at Stanford University from 1950 to 1985 and was director of the university's High Energy Physics Laboratory from 1967 to 1974. He was honored by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for determining the size and shape of the proton and the neutron. He shared the Nobel with Rudolf Mossbauer of West Germany. Hofstadter and colleagues worked for 10 years to probe nuclei by directing a beam of electrons from a 220-foot linear accelerator. They determined that the neutron and the proton have an average radius of 24 to 32 quadrillionths of a inch. Born in New York, Hofstadter graduated from City College of New York and received a master's and doctorate from Princeton University. ``I've known people who could run rings around him in scientific arguments, but he's usually the one who ends up being right,'' 1981 Nobel laureate and former Stanford colleague Arthur Schawlow once said. In World War II, Hofstadter was a physicist at the National Bureau of Standards, where he helped develop the proximity fuse, an anti-aircraft weapon that detonated a shell when it detected approaching objects by radar. In retirement, he became interested in astronomy and contributed to a gamma ray observatory that is scheduled to be sent up in a space shuttle next spring. He also conducted research into coronary angiography, a technique to explore heart functions with radioactive substances instead of more dangerous and painful catheters. Survivors include his wife, Nancy; a son; two daughters; a brother; a sister, and two grandsons. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Wild Turkeys are Back in Massachusetts for Thanksgiving
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts hunters got their first autumn opportunity since the 1800s to pot one of the wily birds that were on the first Thanksgiving table in 1621. The wild turkey is back in the land of the Pilgrims, less than 20 years after the first were reintroduced, and last week about 7,000 hunters using bows or shotguns took part in a six-day turkey season in the Berkshires. Final totals were not yet in Sunday, but just 200 of the 8,000 to 10,000 birds now found in western Massachusetts were bagged in the first two days, said James Cardoza of the state Division of Fisheries and Wildlife. Unlike their domestic cousins, wild turkeys have sharp eyesight and first-rate hearing, and are masters of the duck and scramble. A flock that can seem to fill a clearing in a blink of an eye can disappear just as fast. ``It takes an awful lot of effort and skill,'' Cardoza said. Limited spring hunting has been allowed since 1981. Cardoza launched Massachusetts' wild turkey repopulation efforts in 1972 by trapping 37 birds in western New York. Since 1979 he has been catching and moving some of the birds from the Berkshires into forested areas of eastern and coastal Massachusetts, including Plymouth, the home of the Pilgrims. In 1621, four wild turkeys were part of the Pilgrims' first Thanksgiving feast. The birds disappeared from the state before the Civil War. A big reason for their resurgence is the reforestation of the state that had been largely cleared for farming in the 1800s, Cardoza said. ``They like mature woodlands where they can find acorns and beechnuts,'' he said. Massachusetts is not alone in its success. In 1952 there were about 320,000 turkeys in the United States. The population has increased to about 3 million, and they can be found in practically every state, Cardoza said.

DOC.HEAD: Apparent Assassination Attempt Targets Justice Minister
DOC.TEXT: Four bombs thrown by unidentified assailants exploded today at the home of the Philippine justice secretary today in what the official called an apparent assassination attempt. One struck the wall near the window of the second-story bedroom where Justice Secretary Franklin Drilon, his wife Violetta and two young sons were sleeping. The other blasts heavily damaged a wall around the house, shattered windows, overturned furniture and blasted a nine-foot-deep hole in the yard, Drilon said. Drilon said he and his family were sleeping when the blasts occurred at 4:05 a.m. in the fashionable Greenhills district of suburban San Juan, about one mile from the national police headquarters. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, and Drilon said he was unsure who threw the bombs. Drilon said at least one of the bombs contained the plastic explosive C-4, often used by right-wing military extremists. He said the bombs were so powerful that they were apparently not designed simply to scare him. Drilon was appointed justice secretary on Dec. 31 as part of a Cabinet shakeup following a bloody coup attempt earlier in the month. He had served as labor secretary since 1987. Drilon also serves as chairman of the Cabinet Security Committee, which advises President Corazon Aquino on national security issues. The Manila and The Manila Times reported today that military intelligence expects right-wing extremists to launch a new coup attempt between Nov. 30 and Dec. 10. The newspapers quoted unnamed military sources as saying the plan called for coordinated uprisings in northern and southern provinces directed by renegade Commodore Domingo Calajate, a leader of last December's failed putsch. Last month, mutineers staged a three-day uprising in Mindanao island which the military said was to have been the trigger for a series of nationwide revolts. The mutiny ended Oct. 6 when mutiny leader Col. Alexander Noble surrendered and was arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Car-Train Crash
DOC.TEXT: A freight train plowed into a car at a rural crossing, killing all four people in the automobile. The motorist drove onto the tracks from a dirt road and apparently did not see the train Sunday, despite a stop sign, said Highway Patrol Officer Lance Bourquin. The Burlington Northern train was traveling at 45 mph, he said. Killed were George Lewis Seamon, 60, and Mary Seamon, 56, both of Silesia, and Allan McPhail, 73, and Ida McPhail, 77, of Joliet.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Racism Play Staged Where Supremacist Group Started
DOC.TEXT: Some people in this tiny town would like to forget it was the birthplace of The Order, a violent white supremacist group. But Selkirk High School language teacher Eva Gayle Six won't let them. For a student production, she chose ``The Foreigner,'' a play poking fun at white supremacist beliefs. ``If we can finally laugh at these foolish ideas, that means the pain has passed,'' Mrs. Six said. About 80 people - a third of the town's population - attended on opening night Thursday, she said. ``It was an extremely receptive audience,'' she said Friday. The three-day run ended Saturday. The Order was founded in 1983 as a violent offshoot of the Aryan Nations sect near Hayden Lake, Idaho. Its members hoped to turn the Northwest into a whites-only bastion. Blamed for the machine-gun slaying of Denver radio host Alan Berg, armored-car robberies and other crimes, the sect fell apart after leader Robert Mathews died in 1984 in a shootout with FBI agents. Several members have since been convicted of various crimes. ``The Foreigner'' is a 1983 farce about a shy Englishman who pretends he cannot speak English while spending a few days at a backwater Georgia fishing resort. It pokes fun at the Ku Klux Klan. ``I don't think people could go to this play and not be reminded of (The Order), because it really did happen,'' Mrs. Six said. Most people in this community of 250 in Washington's northeastern corner do not share the neo-Nazi group's beliefs, including Mathews' parents and two brothers. His mother, Una Mathews, said a comedy about racism could help clear the air and improve the town's reputation. ``There's nothing like poking fun at something to show the absurdity of it,'' said Mrs. MAthews. She said she remains baffled by her son's actions. Others questioned the wisdom of reviving old controversies. ``It's over. It's done,'' Mayor Lee ``Teen'' McGowan said. ``Nobody cares. They've forgotten about it. ``If you want to come back in 20 years and dig it up, OK. But now, the hurt is too recent.'' Other racist groups remain active in the Pacific Northwest, and Mathews has sympathizers in the area. None protested at the play, Mrs. Six said. ``I would not have done this play six years ago and maybe not even four years ago because there was too much pain,'' she said. ``But enough time has passed now that we can laugh at the stupidity of those ideas.''

DOC.HEAD: Tenth Anniversary of Turkey Tips Hotline
DOC.TEXT: When Thanksgiving Day chefs don't want to wing it or stick their necks out, they can talk turkey with experts stuffed with the right cooking information. They can dial the Butterball Turkey Talk-Line, which takes questions from harried holiday cooks. Callers range from young brides to Army cooks to a blind man from Norfolk, Va., who was talked through the cooking steps by a hotline staffer. Forty-five Chicago-area home economists and nutritionists provide the turkey tips from an office in suburban Downers Grove. The service was started by Swift-Eckrich, which has the trademark on Butterball turkeys. ``Every year we have a three-day training session for them,'' said Jean Schnelle, Talk-Line director. ``Staff members have a notebook with 66 categories of types of questions in it.'' Since opening in 1981, the hotline has handled about 1 million calls, including 260,000 last year. ``The most common one is `How do you recommend we roast the turkey to get it picture perfect?''' she said Friday. Answer: Use the conventional open pan method, with the uncovered turkey oiled and sitting on a rack in a 325-degree oven. ``It's not only the best way. It's the easiest way,'' Schnelle said. Other questions concern thawing, food safety, meat thermometer insertion and stuffing. Some phone with colorful stories. A Baltimore woman said she had cooked her turkey without removing the plastic covering, causing it to melt into the skin. A Philadelphia woman left a red rubber glove, used for cleaning, in the turkey. A cook from Lawrence, Kan., asked, ``How do I turn my oven on?'' The hotline number is 1-800-323-4848 and is open today through Wednesday from 9 a.m. until 9 p.m., and on Thanksgiving Day from 7 a.m. until 7 p.m. It's also open Monday through Friday until Dec. 21 from 9 a.m. until 7 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iraq Capable Of Developing Nuclear Bomb Within 3 to 5 Years
With Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is capable of developing a nuclear bomb within three to five years and has between 10 and 30 chemical warheads for its ballistic missiles, a respected Israeli think tank says in a new report. The assessment is based on Iraq's possession of 26 pounds of enriched uranium that France supplied when it was assisting Saddam Hussein's nuclear program, said Danny Leshem of Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies, which published the report Sunday. Leshem said, however, that development of a nuclear warhead may take Iraq until the end of the decade. Iraq has completed the development of chemical warheads and ``now they are starting production and equipment ... this is the beginning of the equipping stage,'' Leshem said on Israel radio. Leshem said the Iraqis have between 10 to 30 units ``that they perhaps can fire.'' Iraq, he said, has two missiles that can carry chemical warheads, both modified versions of the Soviet Scud missile. ``There is al-Hussein with a range of 600 to 650 kilometers (370-400 miles) and al-Abbas with a range of 850 to 900 kilometers (530-560 miles) ... Al-Hussein was fired during the Iran-Iraq war and al-Abbas is apparently entering into service this year,'' Leshem said. Iraq has repeatedly threatened to attack Israel with chemical weapons in response to a U.S. military move in the Persian Gulf crisis. Last month, Israel began distributing gas masks to its 4.7 million citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Prices Record Biggest Drop Since Gulf Crisis Began
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline at the pump got cheaper by nearly a penny a gallon in the past two weeks, dropping to an average of just under $1.46, a national survey found. ``This is the first significant change in the downward direction since the invasion of Kuwait,'' said oil analyst Trilby Lundberg, whose bi-weekly Lundberg Survey of 13,500 stations was released Sunday. The average for all grades of gasoline was $1.45.98 a gallon, a Drop of 0.94 cents since the Nov. 2 survey. ``The biggest reason for the drop is that crude oil price cuts have been working their way into the system,'' Ms. Lundberg said. Gasoline has gone up about 28 cents a gallon since the invasion Aug. 2, according to the survey.

DOC.HEAD: Autopsy Confirms Insurance Man's Death
DOC.TEXT: An insurance executive authorities thought faked his death to avoid prosecution and collect $4 million in insurance benefits was killed in a plane crash two years ago, an autopsy confirmed. A state medical examiner said dental records Sunday proved the body recovered from Lake Martin on Friday was that of 47-year-old Blan Stewart of Huntsville, who disappeared while flying a small plane in 1988. Prosecutors had contended the insurance executive faked his death to collect some $4 million and to avoid prosecution on charges of stealing about $590,000 from clients. Insurance companies had posted a $100,000 reward for information on whether he was dead or alive. The plane and Stewart's body were found under 65 feet of water during a private search arranged by his widow, Sarah ``Robin'' Stewart. He died of drowning and injuries suffered when the plane slammed into the lake, said the medical examiner, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I assume we'll close the book on the case,'' said Larry Childers, spokesman for the state attorney general's office. Once a death certificate is issued, Mrs. Stewart can start the process of collecting the insurance money, said John Heacock, her attorney. A judge in May had refused Mrs. Stewart's attempt to have her husband declared dead. The judge heard testimony from a man who claimed to have seen the plane flying low after air traffic controllers lost contact with Stewart. The attorney general's office had said at least two people claimed to have seen Stewart in the Virgin Islands and South Carolina long after he disappeared. ``I have to assume, like most do, that people make mistakes,'' said Childers.
