DOC.HEAD: Students Will Leave Vocational School With Diploma and Warranty
DOC.TEXT: Vocational students who graduate from the Lubbock Independent School District leave with diplomas and come with warranties. Beginning at the end of this school year, would-be auto mechanics, welders, cabinet makers and cosmetologists will graduate with guarantees aimed at making them more employable. The school district promises to provide additional training if a former student is found to be lacking in basic skills within two years after graduation. Superintendent Mike Moses said he hopes the district is ``on the cutting edge of something here.'' ``We hear a lot in Lubbock that we need a skilled and trained work force,'' he said. ``We are confident our graduates have the basic skills that they need to do well on their first job.'' School officials said the greatest need for retraining would most likely come in areas where technology changes rapidly, such as automotive engineering.

DOC.HEAD: Bride Turns to the Marines to Fill Up Wedding Party
DOC.TEXT: Cata Fulkerson needed a few good men to fill out her wedding party. Naturally, she turned to the Marines. Cata and her husband, Erik, wanted to have their wedding and reception at the El Adobe Restaurant. There was one problem: The restaurant required 150 guests and the Fulkersons had invited 110. The Mission Viejo couple considered donating the extra dinners to charity, but the red tape was too much. Military officials at nearby Camp Pendleton were less daunting, allowing members of the Marines 5th Regiment to attend. The unit awaits deployment to Saudi Arabia. Forty Marines in spiffy dress uniforms went to Saturday's ceremony and stayed for dinner and dancing. ``It was a beautiful wedding,'' said Gunnery Sgt. Humberto Gonzalez. The ceremony was the second for the Fulkersons, who were married Aug. 11 in an Indian ceremony in NEw Mexico but wanted to have a party with family and friends.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Beats Rare Leukemia With Umbilical Cord Blood
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old with a rare form of leukemia once considered incurable has apparently beaten the disease after being given a transfusion of umbilical cord blood from his baby sister, doctors say. Michael Sancilio of Virginia Beach left Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore on Saturday three months after becoming the first leukemia patient to undergo the experimental transplant. ``Although doctors are reluctant to say Michael is cured, Michael appears to have defeated a rare form of leukemia for which previously existed no known cure,'' Virginia BEach General Hospital said in a statement. Doctors there had collected so-called stem cells from his sister's umbilical cord for transplant in Baltimore. Umbilical blood, usually discarded at birth, is rich in stem cells, which multiply rapidly to form bone marrow. Doctors gave Michael five tablespoons of the blood. Within one month, he began producing healthy bone marrow, doctors said. ``What we are viewing this afternoon is nothing short of a miracle,'' Dr. Leslie Wasserman Jr. said Sunday. ``God deserves all the credit,'' said Michael's grandmother, Rachel Sancilio. ``I prayed for a miracle. It was the most devastating thing. My heart goes out to any family that has to go through something like this.'' Umbilical cord blood transplants have been performed three other times, once in Cincinnati and twice in France, to treat a different disease, Fanconi's anemia. Leukemia is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. Eight months ago, Michael was diagnosed with a form known as chronic myelogenous leukemia, which cannot be controlled with drugs and usually kills within a year of diagnosis. The boy's sister, Christina, was born May 1. Michael's blood type did not match hers, but the siblings were otherwise compatible, and doctors found that he was not overly likely to reject the umbilical cord blood. Because of the procedure, Michael has ``another chance at life'' - and a new blood type, the hospital said. Doctors will not know for about two years whether the boy is cured. Christina is healthy.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 7 grafs bgng, Asked why xxx etc., to UPDATE with Bush remarks on Gorbachev, gulf.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush demanded today that Iraq's Saddam Hussein ``turn tail 180 degrees'' and withdraw from Kuwait. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Saddam ``has to be removed by force'' unless he pulls out soon. The two leaders, meeting over breakfast before a 34-nation summit, underscored their hardline stand against Iraq's aggression. The president also dismissed Saddam's proposal to begin releasing foreign hostages beginning on Christmas. ``This cynicism of starting to release them on Christmas Day will be seen by the world as a total ploy,'' Bush said. Opening a joint news conference with Mrs. Thatcher, Bush said, ``Not surprisingly, we see eye to eye on the gulf.'' For her part, Thatcher accused Saddam of ``the worst brutality and evil.'' The only way to avoid a shooting war in the Persian Gulf, she said, ``would be for Saddam Hussein to withdraw, quickly, totally.'' ``Most people understand evil has to be stopped. Either he withdraws, or the military option has to be used,'' the prime minister said. ``Unless he leaves, he will have to be made to leave by force. He plays with human beings as if they were pawns,'' she said. ``Unless you stop this man, there will be no peace in the world let alone in the Middle East.'' She said she and Bush see eye-to-eye on the Persian Gulf and the need to use force to drive Saddam from Kuwait if he does not withdraw unconditionally. ``There can be no compromise,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``You cannot reward aggression.'' Bush said he hoped discuss the Persian Gulf when he meets later today with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Asked why Gorbachev seemed to me more optimistic about a peaceful resolution of the situation than he was, Bush said: ``I will be seeing him, and Mr. Gorbachev has been very solid in support of the United Nations. So I'm anxious to know if there's something new that he's thinking of.'' He said the reduction of tensions in Europe between superpowers will help send an even stronger signal to Saddam of allied unity to drive him from Kuwait. ``You've heard Prime Minister Thatcher,'' Bush said. ``I feel the same way.'' ``The longer he focuses on holding innocents against their will, the more he points to his own brutality,'' Bush said. ``There will be no concession,'' Bush said. ``We are ratcheting up pressure on this man. And I hope that as soon as he understands that he cannot prevail, that he will do that which he did in Iran...turn tail 180 degrees and turn east.'' He was referring to Iraq's withdrawal from Iran as the beginning of the current confrontation with the West. Bush added that Saddam now should ``turn 180 degrees and head north,'' out of Kuwait. Meanwhile, Bush was asked about Mrs. Thatcher's challenge from within her own conservative party in British elections on Tuesday. ``I stay out of all this, but we have a superb relationship with Mrs. Thatcher,'' he said. Asked if she would survive the challenge, Mrs. Thatcher said: ``I most earnestly believe so.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Conventional Arms Treaty Eliminates Fear of Surprise Ground Attack
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 3 grafs with treaty signed; Mitterrand quote. Picks up 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: The arms-reduction treaty signed today by leaders of the Eastern and Western military alliances would slash non-nuclear forces in Europe and eliminate the Cold War fear of a surprise ground attack. Negotiators sought in vain for 15 years to make headway on the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, but swiftly concluded it over the past 20 months as the Soviet military empire collapsed. ``We are putting an end to the previous age,'' French President Francois Mitterrand said in signing the accord before a glittering assembly of presidents, premiers and foreign ministers at the Elysee Palace. NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators initialed the 160-page document in Vienna on Sunday, clearing the way for President Bush, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and other leaders to sign the accord at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Under the treaty, more than 100,000 pieces of military hardware would be scrapped, prompting some to call the pact the formal end of the Cold War. ``No battle in the history of mankind ... destroyed such an immense number of tanks, armored combat vehicles, artillery and combat aircraft,'' Soviet negotiator Oleg A. Grinevsky told reporters in Vienna. U.S. negotiator James Woolsey said the accord ``makes it a matter of many, many months instead of a few hours in which any country could think of a surprise attack.'' The agreement sets no limits on combat troops, because the reunification of Germany and the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact outpaced the talks. Negotiators are to reconvene Nov. 29 to discuss troop levels. Most of the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and six countries in the Warsaw Pact already have taken advantage of the reduced tensions to cut their armed forces. Bush last month announced plans to withdraw 40,000 U.S. troops from Europe, and later ordered an additional 100,000 moved to Saudi Arabia, cutting the American ground force level on the continent by half. Because most of the troops and armaments in Europe were under Kremlin control, the Warsaw Pact will register the first financial benefits. Gorbachev has presented the Supreme Soviet with a 10-year plan to make the military ``less of a burden on the state and more efficient at the same time,'' Soviet Chief of Staff Mikhail Moiseyev said in an article published by the army newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda. The massive disarmament will be carried out under the CFE treaty and the proposed Strategic Force Reduction Treaty to cut nuclear arsenals by up to 50 percent, Moiseyev said. Under the conventional force treaty, the nations will have 40 months after the last nation ratifies the accord to destroy the specified weapons. From the start of the Cold War and the birth of NATO in 1949 and the Warsaw Pact in 1955, the military landscape of Western Europe has been dominated by fear of a communist bloc ground assault. To eliminate that, the treaty limiting the weapons of 22 countries from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains requires the Soviets to drastically reduce their forces, including: -Tanks, from about 41,000 before the treaty negotiations began to 13,150. Moscow already has reduced its tank holdings in the territory covered by the treaty to about 21,000, mainly by moving its best models east. The allowable number tanks for all of Eastern Europe will be 20,000. The United States and its NATO allies also will be allowed 20,000 tanks. That will require a cut of about 4,000 for NATO, although more than 1,000 of the top-of-the-line U.S. M1-A1 tanks already are being moved to Saudi Arabia. -Armored combat vehicles, from the 32,300 now deployed by the Soviets to 30,000. NATO will not have to make any cuts in this category. -Artillery pieces, providing the essential firepower for a Combat operation, from about 52,000 for the Soviets before the negotiations, to 13,175. The Soviets already are down to 18,300. NATO will stay at 18,500. Those three weapon categories - tanks, armored combat vehicles and artillery - are especially important to the military balance in Europe because they form the core of non-nuclear offense for both the Soviets and NATO.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Lab Test Indentifies `Yuppie Flu'
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have developed a blood test to distinguish sufferers of chronic fatigue syndrome - or ``yuppie flu'' - from those feeling run-down for other reasons, a scientist says. The test checks levels of white blood cells, AIDS researcher Jay Levy said Sunday at a national conference on the chronic fatigue syndrome. He led the group that developed the test at the University of California at San Francisco. Levy said most of the 120 chronic fatigue patients tested at the university had abnormal levels of three types of white blood cells produced when the body fights a virus. No one virus was present in all the patients, but Levy said levels of those three cells were either consistently high or consistently low in most of the patients. Therefore, he said, a check of those white blood cells, plus a review of the patient's medical history, could determine whether a person has chronic fatigue syndrome. None of the 80 healthy people studied had abnormal levels, Levy said. Chronic fatigue syndrome is characterized by exhaustion, joint and muscle aches, fever and other problems that persist for more than six months and often for years. Its cause is unknown. Tens of thousands of Americans believe they have chronic fatigue syndrome, although the extent of it is unclear. It was dubbed ``yuppie flu'' because it has been widely reported among well-educated women in their 30s and 40s. The weekend conference, titled ``Unraveling the Mystery,'' drew 400 eople, including researchers and people afflicted with the ailment. Most researchers now agree the illness stems from immune system abnormalities, not depression or other psychological factors, Levy said. He called it ``the disease of the '90s.'' ``This is going to be the 10 years that we see the greatest advancement in understanding this disease,'' he said. He suggested the name be changed to ``chronic immune activation syndrome'' because research indicates that patients' immune systems are chronically ``activated,'' as if fighting a continuing viral infection. With most viral infections, such as the flu, the immune system fights vigorously, causing fatigue and muscle aches. But it quiets down when the virus is killed. In chronic fatigue syndrome, the immune system stays on the attack, causing the symptoms to persist, he said. Besides trying to determine the cause, researchers are struggling to learn how the illness is transmitted and whether it is contagious. Dr. Walter Gunn, a researcher with the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, said an inter-agency committee had been formed to determine the extent of the illness.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NATO, Warsaw Pact Leaders Sign Historic Arms-Reduction Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series, adds quotes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev joined European leaders today in signing a historic treaty that cuts conventional forces in Europe and pushes the Cold War deeper into history. ``It is the farthest-reaching arms agreement in history and it signals the new world order that is emerging,'' Bush said in a glittering signing ceremony. The long-sought agreement to destroy tens of thousands of tanks, artillery and armored combat vehicles in Europe is the most sweeping arms accord in history. It was signed as prelude to a 34-nation summit originally called to discuss European security in the post Cold War era, but shadowed by the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We are putting an end to the previous age,'' French President Francois Mitterrand declared as he put his signature to the treaty documents. One by one the other leaders followed suit, with Gorbachev the last one to wield the pen. As the treaty was passed back to Mitterrand, the roomful of leaders applauded their work. ``This reduces to practically nil the tensions that have existed,'' said Bush. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas described the meeting as the most important international event since World War II and said it will ``design the architecture of Europe for the century to come.'' U.S. officials view the summit more modestly, describing the 34-nation forum primarily as a device for promoting political freedom, human rights and East-West cooperation. With the extraordinary assembly of government leaders, French authorities mobilized rooftop sharpshooters, anti-terrorist units and 10,000 police officers to provide security - and also to clear paths for convoys of limousines. Parisians braced for severe traffic disruptions. Domestic political crises faced by some leaders offered a dramatic sideshow. Gorbachev left behind a country staggering under political and economic chaos. Prime Ministers Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Michel Rocard of France face Parliament votes that conceivably could topple them during the summit. Yet, the gathering gave Bush an opportunity to exercise his personal diplomacy to solidify support for his Persian Gulf policies. OFficials said the president would seek backing for a United Nations resolution authorizing military action to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Bush and Thatcher emerged from a breakfast meeting today warning that fighting might erupt unless Iraq's Saddam Hussein withdraws from Kuwait. Bush demanded that Saddam ``turn tail 180 degrees'' and Mrs. Thatcher said the Iraqi president ``has to be removed by force'' unless he pulls out soon. At a joint news conference with the British prime minister, Bush said, ``Not surprisingly, we see eye to eye on the gulf.'' The three-day summit will end Wednesday with the signing of an agreement to institute high-level political consultations of the 34 nations and establish a conflict prevention center in Vienna. Afterward, Bush will fly to the Middle East for a Thanksgiving Day visit with U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. On Sunday, Bush conferred with French President Francois Mitterrand and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, both of whom stress a non-military outcome to the gulf crisis. Yet, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said many countries support a military option if Iraq does not withdraw voluntarily. ``I'm not aware of any countries, going back to the very beginning of this crisis, who have taken the position under any and all circumstances that the option of force should be ruled out,'' Baker said. Bush, visiting with Kohl, said, ``We're not ruling out any options, we're not ruling any options in.'' The chancellor urged that ``everything be exhausted that there is to exhaust with negotiations.'' Baker met Sunday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Afterward, both declined to say whether the Soviet Union would back a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. Gorbachev said Sunday that ``new ideas'' are emerging to avert war. The Soviet leader, in Rome to visit Pope John Paul II, did not elaborate. Bush, hop-scotching from Czechoslovakia to Germany to France, said the arms agreement he was signing today ``seems to be overshadowed by what's happening in the gulf. But it is a significant milestone.'' His assessment paled beside that of Oleg A. Grinevsky, Soviet ambassador to the talks. ``From this treaty, the Soviet Union is ceasing to become a militarized state with all the consequences of that - economic, political and social,'' Grinevsky said. The treaty on non-nuclear forces was initialed in Vienna on Sunday by negotiators from the 16-member NATO alliance and the six-member Warsaw Pact, which is rapidly disintegrating as a military alliance. The 160-page accord limits each side to 20,000 main battle tanks, 30,000 armored combat vehicles, 20,000 artillery pieces, 6,800 fighter planes and 2,000 combat helicopters. It will cover a 2.5 million square mile area stretching from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union. The accord also regulates troop movements from both alliances and permits mutual inspections across Europe. Because of the Soviets' big edge in conventional weapons, Moscow will have to destroy many more weapons than the NATO alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Demoted For Refusing to Bear Arms
DOC.TEXT: A soldier who sought conscientious objector status was demoted and confined to his barracks for refusing an order to bear arms during training. The Army had sent 20-year-old Pvt. Alfred Edwin Escquibel from a desk job to Fort Campbell, Ky., for rifle drills shortly after denying his request for conscientious objector last month. When an instructor ordered him last week to pick up an M-16 rifle, ``I told her my story, and said, `With all due respect, ma'am, I can't do that,''' the soldier said in a telephone interview Sunday from Fort Campbell. The helicopter mechanic was demoted from private first class to private 2 during a hearing at Fort Campbell on Saturday. He was ordered to forfeit $405 a month in pay for two months, confined to his barracks for 30 days and sentenced to extra duty for refusing the order. Esquibel, a Roman Catholic from Albuquerque, said he told his M-16 instructor that for religious and moral reasons he could not bear arms. ``I felt like the only reason they were sending me down there (to Fort CAmpbell) was to get me in trouble,'' Esquibel said. ``I think they might've thought to themselves, `Let's see how sincere he is.''' The soldier said he filed a request last week for discharge on grounds of ``erroneous enlistment.'' He said he was assured he would not be ordered to pick up a weapon until his request for discharge is either denied or approved. Esquibel's unit has been shipped to the Persian Gulf as part of the U.S. buildup there. Esquibel, who enlisted in 1989, said he told his recruiter of his objection to guns and was assured he would be assigned a non-combat role after basic training. The soldier said he filed for conscientious objector status in August 1989 after realizing he would be required to use a weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Declines; Share Prices Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against the Japanese yen in thin trading today in Tokyo, while share prices closed higher for the first time in four trading sessions. The dollar closed at 128.95 yen, down 0.78 yen from Friday's finish of 129.73 yen. It also opened at 128.95 yen, and ranged between 128.75 yen and 129.17 yen. The dollar had edged up a total of 0.96 yen in the three previous trading days. Dealers said the dollar was being sold in early trading on news that the Federal Reserve eased interest rates Friday and that Iraq had offered to free all remaining foreign hostages. Lower interest rates make a currency less attractive to investors. In addition, the dollar's role as a safe haven in times of international tension would be diminished by peaceful moves by Iraq. The official Iraqi News Agency said Sunday the captives held in Iraq would be allowed to depart beginning Dec. 25 if nothing ``mars the atmosphere of peace.'' The Bush administration has dismissed the offer as a ploy. The dollar rebounded later. Dealers said the Iraqi news was not considered sufficient to trigger major dollar selling, and the interest rate easing had been anticipated. Some $8.48 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from $5.97 billion Friday. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which had shed 315.85 points Friday, gained 346.53, or 1.50 percent, closing at 23,518.16. ``News of the Iraqi move to free hostages turned out to be a good factor in the market,'' said Nobuyuki Fujimoto, an analyst with Nikko Securities. But Fujimoto added that it was hard to say whether the market had gained confidence. The recent pattern has been a gain early in the week followed by declines later in the week. A total of 300 million shares were traded on the first section, down from the previous session's 313 million shares. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 85.32 as of 3 a.m. EST from Friday's close of 84.77. Their yield fell to 7.640 percent from 7.760 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Rally of 70,000 Says Government's Time Is Up
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators angered by rationing and shortages are rallying behind opposition leaders who have told Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov to resign by Thursday or face general unrest. But Lukanov said leaving office under pressure ``would be a betrayal of democracy.'' There have been two attempted attacks on Lukanov's home recently. On Sunday, about 70,000 protesters outside Alexander Nevsky Cathedral cheered wildly as opposition leaders issued the Thursday deadline for the leader of the long-ruling party and his government to step down. The Socialist Party was created last spring when the Communist Party dissolved and renamed itself after the November ouster of hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov. The Socialists won a parliamentary majority in June's free elections with promises to abandon Marxism. But the Lukanov government has proven ineffective and his popularity has slumped with Bulgaria's economic performance. ``The government's one-year credit is up. It is now time for action,'' Petar Beron, leader of the main opposition Union of Democratic Forces, told the crowd on Sunday. He promised a showdown in the 400-seat Grand National Assembly on Thursday when a controversial budget reform package is put forth by the Socialists. ``We will wait no longer ... we will vote against the government's budget draft,'' Beron shouted from the cathedral steps. The crowd had jeered and whistled when he called for patience and a parliamentary solution. They yelled ``General strike!'' and ``Death to the Communist Party!'' ``If the government doesn't resign on Thursday, the Socialists' fate is in your hands,'' Beron told the crowd. Lukanov has pinned his political fate to the budget package, which includes sharp price rises on 21 basic goods at a time when Sofia stores are bare and electricity, gasoline and some foodstuffs are rationed. Despite his majority in parliament, Lukanov has urged also opposition support for the reforms, citing their national importance. The premier is under increasing pressure from street protests and from some factions within Socialist ranks. The opposition coalition is calling for a higher budget deficit instead of higher prices that could tax Bulgaria's consumers. Lukanov claims more government debt would devastate Bulgaria's national economy, already saddled by an $11 billion foreign debt that it is having difficulty repaying. The Union of Democratic Forces claims it would triumph if new elections were held.

DOC.HEAD: Storm in Pacific Northwest, Mostly Mild Weather Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Cold weather moved into the Pacific Northwest today, with snow forecast in Washington, Oregon and Idaho. More than a foot of snow and high winds were expected in mountain areas. Blustery northwest winds continued along the middle and northern Atlantic Coast early today, with scattered rain forecast through tonight. Partly cloudy skies prevailed in California, with colder weather expected Tuesday. Mostly sunny skies and warm temperatures were forecast from Arizona through Florida. Mostly fair weather was expected across the Midwest, with rain expected in the region Tuesday. Elsewhere, Alaska braced for more winter-like storms, while the Hawaiian islands saw high winds and scattered rain. The high temperature for the nation Sunday was 91 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. Tucson, Ariz., reached a record 86 degrees, the fifth record high for the city in the past six days. DOC.HEAD: Freedom Flight Passengers Tell of Fear, Frustration in Kuwait
LaserPhoto LON6
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tales of fear, hunger and a fading resistance in Kuwait accompanied a group of former hostages who arrived on a U.S.-chartered flight from Iraq today, leaving many family members behind. Some of the passengers said Kuwaitis and foreigners are well aware of the military buildup in the Persian Gulf, and hope for an invasion. ``People are starving and they need food, but people who have food are frightened of giving it to them because they would be accused as collaborators,'' said an American woman who believes her husband is still hiding somewhere in Kuwait. ``We prayed every night that we would wake up in the morning,'' she said. The 136 passengers who arrived at London's Gatwick airport early today had been in Kuwait since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. They included 75 Americans, mainly of Arab descent or married to Arabs. A number of women carried babies and were draped in gray blankets over lightweight clothes. Most passengers would not talk to reporters because they feared for relatives left behind. ``The time has come to give these people (the Kuwaitis) their right to freedom. All we have heard of is the peaceful solution. We are tired of that,'' said the American woman. Salameh Salen, 31, a Jordanian-born American, said the Kuwaiti resistance to Iraqi forces had been ``fairly strong,'' but is now dwindling. A Palestinian doctor, who said he had six children living in Maryland and had been working in Kuwait, described the Iraqi troops as ``tough'' and said the resistance appeared to be ``almost collapsing.'' After the invasion, he said he had been able to go out to wait in line for food. At home he passed the time listening to the radio, following developments via the BBC news. Gatwick officials said the passengers included 12 Canadians, 12 Britons, 10 New Zealanders, eight Germans, seven Irish, six Australians, two Danes, two South Africans, one Polish woman and a French citizen. ``We all went through situations where we didn't know if we would get out, particularly in the early days of the invasion and the disorder and looting,'' said New Zealander Alastair Lane. He said many reports of Iraqi abuses in Kuwait were true, but some were exaggerated. ``Iraqi troops 90 percent of the time are pretty good,'' Lane said. ``The British and the U.S. can't go outside. They've been inside for three and a half months. Some are probably at the end of their tether. They can't keep their lights on at night. They can't even go out of their front door,'' Lane said. Lane von Wessel, a Dutch-born New Zealander, said: ``The Brits (Britons) are the worst off because (Prime Minister Margaret) Thatcher talks too much on TV. When she talks about the butcher of Baghdad, that annoys those people.'' Von Wessel said it was possible to buy food ``if you have money.'' Douglas Moore, a British soccer coach who worked in Kuwait for the past four years, said he spent more than two months in hiding with very little food. ``I switched addresses five times to avoid the Iraqis, who were searching everywhere,'' Moore said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Steadies
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold steadied after dropping in Hong Kong. The dollar closed at 128.95 yen, down 0.78 yen from Friday's finish of 129.73 yen. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 128.20 yen. Dealers said the dollar was being sold in early trading on news that the U.S. Federal Reserve had eased interest rates last Friday and that Iraq had announced plans to free all its remaining foreign hostages. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: -1.4670 German marks, down from 1.4715 -1.2403 Swiss francs, down from 1.2445 -4.9555 French francs, down from 4.9690 -1.6575 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6595 -1,106.00 Italian lire, down from 1,110.25 -1.1625 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1643 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9750, compared with $1.9655 late Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $377.60 per ounce at midmorning, up from $376.75 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $376.50, up from $376.20 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $2.56 an ounce today, to close at $377.55. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.13 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $4.11.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Air Force Gearing Up for Gulf Casualties
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Air Force is setting up four contingency hospitals in Europe in preparation for a possible influx of casualties from the Persian Gulf, the newspaper Stars and Stripes reported today. The unofficial U.S. military publication said ``teams from Air Force bases in Europe began getting the so-called `turnkey' hospitals ready late last month.'' ``There's no beating around the bush about it,'' the newspaper quoted Col. Thomas M. Chester as saying. Chester is chief of medical readiness for the Air Force in Europe. The newspaper said the contingency hospitals include a renovated aircraft hangar and a former German hospital. It gave their locations as three Royal Air Force bases in England - RAF Bicester, RAF Little Rissington and RAF Nocton Hall - and ``one location in Zweibruecken, Germany.'' According to the report, some 4,500 medical personnel will be needed if the hospitals are pressed into service. The newspaper said that since many Europe-based medical personnel have been sent to the Middle East, the hospitals will be staffed by people sent from the United States, including active duty personnel, Air Force reservists and Air National Guard personnel. ``We plan on bringing them when we're directed by the European Command. Of course, as a medical planner, I'd like to see them here now,'' the newspaper quoted Chester as saying. All four of the ``adequate but austere'' hospitals can handle surgery and a variety of other specialized medical care, including chemical and biological warfare injuries, the newspaper quoted Chester as saying. Chester would not provide the total number of beds available at the four hospitals, citing security reasons, the newspaper said. It said the U.S. Army would not comment on its contingency medical plans. Stars and Stripes, which describes itself as an unofficial but authorized daily newspaper for the military overseas, is based just outside Darmstadt, about 12 miles south of Frankfurt.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Soldier on Spree With Armored Vehicle in Berlin
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet soldier took an armored vehicle on a joy ride in Berlin, roaring down the posh Kurfuerstendamm boulevard and on to Potsdam before he was stopped, police said today. Police chasing the tracked vehicle said the soldier damaged several cars and refused to halt late Sunday when they tried to flag him down. He also roared around roadblocks, police said. The joy ride lasted several hours. At one point, the soldier even sped the tank-like vehicle down Kurfuerstendamm, which bisects Berlin's shopping district, police said. The soldier eventually ended up in Potsdam, just southwest of Berlin, where a Soviet sergeant who had joined police in the chase managed to halt the armored personnel carrier. Potsdam police said the sergeant jumped onto the front of the vehicle and slammed shut the vision slit, forcing the soldier to halt. Other Soviet soldiers had also been dispatched with heavy vehicles to try to end the wild drive, police said. Police said the incident was under investigation and that the soldier was still being questioned. The soldier was not immediately identified. About 360,000 Soviet troops remain in eastern Germany where they were based under Moscow's alliance with the now-defunct East Germany. According to the agreement under which Moscow approved the unification of East and West Germany, the Soviet troops are to be withdrawn over the next four years.

DOC.HEAD: World's Oldest Pout Turns to Smile at Sight of Birthday Cake
DOC.TEXT: Carrie White, listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the oldest living person, thoroughly enjoyed her six-tiered cake and even received a call from Ronald Reagan on her 116th birthday. But Mrs. White, who was born when Ulysses S. Grant was president and Custer's last stand was two years away, didn't seem to notice the greetings sent by Governor-elect Lawton Chiles, or the tape-delayed phone call from Reagan. Reportedly, she had something else on her mind. Mrs. White had been unhappy all day Sunday, according to a nurse's aide, because she had to wait until the party for a piece of the cake. But once the cake was cut, she livened up. ``She's wide awake now,'' said Paul Allen, owner and administrator of Putnam Memorial Nursing Home. While hundreds of well-wishers gathered around Mrs. White, she continued eating her cake. The cake was covered in pink roses, matching Mrs. White's pink dress and pink corsage. Reagan called about an hour before festivities began on the lawn of the nursing home. The call was taped and played later for Mrs. White and her guests. ``I just want you to know there will be a prayer for you in my heart while I'm in church,'' said Reagan, who called from Beverly Hills, Calif., before attending church. Mrs. White was born in Gadsden County, Fla., on Nov. 18, 1874. She has been listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the world's oldest living person since last year. Most of Mrs. White's life is a sad tale. She spent 75 years behind the walls of Florida State Hospital at Chattahoochee, having been committed there in 1909. Hospital records then described Mrs. White's problem as ``post-typhoid psychosis,'' but doctors today don't recognize the term. In 1984, at the age of 110, she was finally released as part of a program to move geriatric mental patients from state institutions. Several hundred people from this North Florida town attended Sunday's party, held under a huge circus-style tent.

DOC.HEAD: University Campus Frustrated by Berendzen's Severance Offer
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lead to make it two sentences
DOC.TEXT: American University hasn't recovered yet from the uproar over former President Richard Berendzen's guilty plea to making obscene phone calls. NOw there's a new dispute over news he is being offered $1 million to sever his university ties. A firestorm of protests erupted this month when reports surfaced that the university Board of Trustees had agreed to make the offer. Some students and faculty vowed to get the offer rescinded. Provost Milton Greenberg and Edward R. Carr, chairman of the Board of Trustees, met with student leaders Friday and planned to meet with key faculty members today. Berendzen, 51, who has continued to draw his annual salary of about $140,000 since resigning as president in April, has not been available for comment. ``I have been notified by many members of the AU community that the information reported concerning Dr. Berendzen's settlement package has resulted in campus-wide frustration,'' Carr said in a open letter last week. Carr's letter acknowledged that many believe the decision to offer the settlement ``did not adequately take into consideration the input of campus constituencies, and, further, concern is also motivated over the magnitude of Dr. Berendzen's reported settlement package.'' Berendzen resigned last spring as Fairfax County, Va., police conducted an investigation of complaints that he made a series of obscene telephone calls to Susan Allen, who ran a day care service. Berendzen checked himself into a sexual disorders clinic at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. In May, he pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor charges and Fairfax County General District Court Judge J. Conrad Waters Jr. sentenced him to 30 days in jail on each charge. Waters suspended all of the jail time, provided Berendzen stays out of trouble for one year and continues treatment. Valerie B. Morris, head of the University Senate, said Friday there is a question of whether Berendzen still retains his tenured physics professorship. ``If he did, then there's a procedure to follow,'' she said. If he sought to negotiate a severance, Morris said, ``I can guarantee you that the amount at the end of (the procedure) wouldn't be approximating the $680,000 we've heard is the amount the board negotiated.'' Other reports said the board had offered $1 million. Under most circumstances, Morris said a tenured professor who voluntarily leaves gets nothing - ``You resign and go.'' She said that in a few cases the university will buy out a contract, usually paying a year's salary. A letter to BErendzen spearheaded by Professor Sanford Ungar and signed by 84 faculty members said, ``The university withstood a great trauma last April. The reports of your proposed million-dollar settlement have caused the anguish of last spring to return to our community.'' While the faculty supported BErendzen's efforts to settle his contract with the university, the letter said, ``We do, however, question your request for a `settlement' beyond the contracted severance.'' The letter urged Berendzen to ``contact the appropriate committee'' if he believes he has tenure and wants to keep teaching physics or ``sever any remaining employment relationship with the university without insisting on further compensation ....'' A key argument among students is that American University depends so heavily on student tuition - about 89 percent of the budget - that students should be guaranteed a voice. The Graduate Student Council, in a letter to Carr, noted the university has trouble paying for things such as student financial aid, library improvements and faculty and staff salary increases. The university's small endowment ``makes it even more Astonishing that the Board of Trustees would consider stripping our institution of such an amount of money to remunerate a single individual,'' said the letter. However, Samer Farha, a senior from Beirut, is convinced that most students want Berendzen to return to campus as a professor. ``I would love to take a class with him,'' Farha added. ``I think he's done an amazing job for the university, bringing it from where it was to where it is now.'' Adam Hartzell, a High Point, N.C., junior who is vice president of the Student Confederation, said Berendzen should not return. ``I think it would just further divide the community and that's not what I want right now,'' he said. ``I'd rather have an AU that comes together again.''

DOC.HEAD: Outcast Crimean Tatars Given Some Land After Sit-in
DOC.TEXT: Ukrainian authorities relinquished land to Crimean Tatars after they occupied a government building on the west coast of the Crimean peninsula, a newspaper reported today. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda used the incident last week to illustrate that no resettlement program exists for the Crimean Tatars, who were expelled from the Black Sea peninsula by Stalin and now are returning to their traditional lands. Pravda said 46 Crimean Tatars took part in the sit-in at Yevpatoriya City Hall. They demanded that the nearby area of Ismail-Bey, already home to Tatar squatters, be given to them, Pravda said. Police later sealed off the building - a move the Tatars interpreted as a prelude to violence - and 100 more Tatars gathered with gasoline bombs Nov. 11, the newspaper reported. The situation was defused when representatives of the Ukrainian government and the Soviet parliament intervened, and it was decided to give the Tatars the 163 acres of land they were demanding, the newspaper said. Pravda did not say when the protest began or when it ended. The Tatars of the Crimea were resettled in Siberia and Central Asia during World War II, when Josef Stalin expelled several peoples from their homelands on the grounds they could not be trusted to occupy strategic areas. The Tatars, among other ethnic groups, long have been agitating to return. In 1989, the Supreme Soviet legislature declared that all peoples exiled under Stalin should be considered politically rehabilitated. However, other people now occupy the lands and houses of the exiles. Several thousand Tatars have returned to the Crimea in recent years. Last month, authorities began preventing more Tatars from settling in the area after clashes between Tatars and other residents. Tent camps in the Crimea house more than 2,500 Tatars, the independent Interfax news agency reported. ``After Crimean Tatars were allowed to return to the peninsula, no one took the trouble to set up a resettlement mechanism,'' Pravda said. ``It is still unclear how many people want to change their places of residence, and the areas where the outcasts will settle ... have not been determined.'' ``This is why chaos reigns in the Crimea,'' it continued. ``Groups of Tatars arbitrarily seize farmland areas and partition cultivated fields, provoking discontent among those who use this land.'' Ethnographers estimate there are 500,000 Crimean Tatars in the Soviet Union, and another 1 million in Turkey. The Crimean Tatars' protests near the Kremlin in 1987 demanding to be allowed to return home were among the first tests of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's promises of greater democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Fatal Blast Reported at Synthetic Rubber Plant
DOC.TEXT: An explosion ripped through a synthetic rubber plant in the central Siberia city of Krasnoyarsk today, and deaths were reported, the official Tass news agency said. It did not say how many died. The blast occurred while workers at the plant were trying to fix a leak of a gas used in the production of synthetic rubber, Tass reported. Krasnoyarsk is about 1,950 miles east of Moscow. A subsequent fire was contained within two hours, the news agency said. It said a commission was set up to investigate the accident.

DOC.HEAD: 40 Killed in Clashes Around South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Police said today that at least 40 people were killed in clashes around South Africa, including 19 men who were shot and stabbed to death in a black township. Police said the bodies of the men were discovered today in Zonkwezizwe township outside Johannesburg. Some residents said Zonkwezizwe had been hit by fighting between Xhosas and rival Zulus of the conservative Inkatha movement, but others said the clashes involved criminal gangs. Dozens of people have been killed in the township in recent weeks, residents said. Police said they did not know why the men were killed and there had been no reports of factional fighting in the township. Police patrols had not detected any trouble Sunday night, when the men were killed, officials said. The bodies, found scattered around the township, had stab and bullet wounds. Fighting pitting Zulu supporters of Inkatha against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the African National Congress has killed more than 800 people in Johannesburg area townships since August. Both movements want to end apartheid but they disagree on South Africa's future. In other violence, two white police officers and a black man were killed early today in Port Elizabeth on the east coast, police said. The three apparently were ambushed in a black township, and their vehicle was riddled by automatic weapons fire, they said. Police did not say who the black man was or why he was with the two officers. The unidentified attackers escaped. Police said 18 other people were killed in various incidents in other parts of the country since Saturday but gave few details. The dead included two people killed in a clash in Johannesburg Saturday when police opened fire on a prohibited march by black activists. African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela urged supporters Sunday to step up a campaign of strikes, protests and other mass action to force an end to apartheid. ``We are a forgiving people but we are not slaves,'' Mandela told 15,000 cheering, singing people at a stadium south of Johannesburg. ``Boycotts, stayaways, strikes civil disobedieance, marches and meetings are all legitimate peaceful means of struggle,'' he said. President F.W. de Klerk's government has pledged to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution that would give the black majority a share of political power. Mandela on Sunday accused the government of calling for reform while trying to preserve political and economic power for the white minority.

DOC.HEAD: Women Thwart Rape Attempt at Clothing Store; `They Really Let Him Have It'
DOC.TEXT: Two clothing store employees foiled a would-be rapist by biting him, grabbing his gun away and beating him on the head with a pipe, authorities said. Michael Ralph Vader, 35, of Fallon was booked for investigation of kidnapping and aggravated sexual assault, and he required medical treatment, polic said. He was arrested about four hours after the Saturday evening incident. ``They really let him have it,'' said Assistant Police Chief Louis Fetherolf. ``The woman who bit his hand really took a chunk out. And the woman who hit him with the pipe nailed him in the head a number of times. There was a lot of blood.'' Fetherolf said a man entered the Lady Faire store Saturday evening and ordered the two female employees into the back at gunpoint. He ordered one of the women to stay in a back room and the other to disrobe. But as the man began to take his clothes off, the disrobed woman decided to resist. Fetherolf said she severely bit his hand and grabbed the small-caliber pistol. The gun fired in a subsequent scuffle, but no one was hit. The woman then gained control of the gun and tried to shoot the suspect, but it wouldn't go off. The other woman came to her aid and ``split the suspect's head open'' by repeatedly beating him in the head with a heavy pipe, Fetherolf said. The man put his clothes back on and rushed out the store, leaving a trail of blood. Vader was arrested without incident at a trailer park south of Fallon later in the evening.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Calls for Keeping Land from Sea to River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with comments from Egypt, Labor Party, more background on earlier Shamir comment and reaction to it. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has called for keeping all the land from the Mediterranean Sea to the Jordan River ``for future generations and for the mass immigration'' of Soviet Jews. The statement Sunday to members of his right-wing Likud bloc drew immediate criticism in Israel and abroad. Egypt accused Shamir of ``expansionist intentions,'' and the opposition Labor Party said fresh controversy over Shamir's remark could interfere with a wave of Soviet immigration. Shamir's comment was similar to a statement in January that set off an international protest. At that time, he told a party gathering that ``for a large immigration, we need the land of Israel, a large and strong Israel. We will need a lot of place to absorb everybody.'' Palestinian and Arab leaders immediately launched a campaign to block immigration of thousands of Soviet Jews. The Arabs fear the immigrants will displace Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel captured the territories in the 1967 Middle EAst war from Jordan and Egypt. Palestinians have been waging a nearly three-year uprising aimed at freeing the land from Israeli control. The United States has repeatedly called for a land-for-peace settlement in the region and has insisted on Israeli guarantees that U.S.-backed loans for the Soviet immigrants not be used in the occupied lands or Arab east Jerusalem. Shamir was quoted by Israel radio as telling a Sunday memorial service for deceased Likud politicians: ``The party leaders left us a clear message to keep the land of Israel from the sea to the Jordan (River) for future generations and for the mass immigration and for the Jewish people, most of whom will be gathered into this country.'' After the speech, Shamir denied he was returning to his earlier theme of ``a greater Israel'' - which would include the occupied territories - to accommodate the thousands of arriving Soviet Jews, Israeli newspapers said. At least 120,000 Soviet Jews have arrived so far this year, and a million are expected by the end of 1992. ``There is no connection whatever between our maintaining the territorial integrity of Eretz Israel (the land of Israel) between the sea and the Jordan River - which is a vital security necessity for the state of Israel - and the mass immigration, which is the fulfillment of the great Zionist dream,'' the Jerusalem Post quoted him as saying. In Cairo, Egyptian Foreign Minister Ismat Abdel-Meguid ordered Israel's ambassador to explain Shamir's remark. His ministry issued a statement saying: ``Egypt rejects in its totality ... Shamir's comments which indicate his expansionist intention to occupy territories belonging to someone else and this cannot help reach a peaceful settlement to the Palestinian issue.'' Chaim Ramon, head of the Labor Party faction in Parliament, criticized Shamir's comment on Israel radio: ``I am calling on the prime minister to be quiet, for heaven's sake. He is risking the chances of immigration,'' Ramon said. He was apparently referring to the controversy that erupted over Shamir's earlier comments. In the past, Shamir has sometimes made strong statements followed quickly by a ``clarification.'' In August, the prime minister hinted in a speech to American Jewish contributors that Israel would consider a pre-emptive strike on Iraq. ``In the circumstances our major task is to prevent war, or to pre-empt it and if, heaven forbid, these two fail, and there is no alternative, we have to win quickly and decisively,'' he said in his speech. Questioned later by reporters, Shamir denied Israel was considering a pre-emptive strike.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Executes Man For Slaying Of Businessman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT name to Raymond Robert Clark sted Robert Raymond; add that victim's son was among witnesses. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Clark's appeals...'. ADDS one graf that Clark was on parole when he committed murder that led to his execution.
DOC.TEXT: Raymond Robert Clark was executed in Florida's electric chair today for the 1977 slaying of a businessman who was forced to write a $5,000 check at gunpoint, then shot to death. Clark, 49, died at 7:07 a.m. EST as a handful of death-penalty protesters and several proponents gathered outside the fog-shrouded Florida State Prison. He did not make a final statement. Among the two dozen witnesses was Gregory Drake, 38, the victim's son. The governor's office had requested that the younger Drake be allowed to witness the execution, said Bob Macmaster, a Department of Corrections spokesman. Clark's appeals were exhausted when the U.S. Supreme Court voted 8-1 Sunday to reject two emergency requests for a delay. The lone dissenter was Justice Thurgood Marshall, who opposes the death penalty in all circumstances. The appeals were based on changes in the capital punishment law since Clark's sentencing. ``It's just tragic,'' said defense attorney Billy Nolas before going to the prison for a final visit with his client. Clark was the fourth Florida inmate to be put to death this year and the 25th to die since the state resumed executions in 1979. In all, 142 people have been killed nationwide since the U.S. Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976; Florida has had more executions than any state except Texas. Clark was convicted and sentenced to death for the April 27, 1977, murder of David Drake, a Pinellas County scrapyard owner. Clark and his male lover abducted Drake from the parking lot of a St. Petersburg bank, drove him to a secluded area and ordered him to write a $5,000 check payable to cash. Clark then shot the businessman twice in the head. When they were unable to cash the check, Clark and an accomplice called Drake's son and demanded $10,000 for the safe return of the victim he had already killed. Police traced later phone calls and arrested Ty Johnston, Clark's 16-year-old lover. Johnston pleaded guilty to murder and testified against Clark. He was paroled in 1987 after nine years of a 25-year sentence. ``I want him executed. He's ruined my life. He's ruined my son's life,'' Drake's widow, Donna, said of Clark last week. ``My husband didn't do anything to deserve to die.'' At the time of Drake's murder, Clark was on parole from California for the killing of a 14-year-old boy, also reported to be a homosexual lover of his.

DOC.HEAD: Gen. Sun Li-gen, Accused of Plotting Taiwanese Coup, Dies at 91
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Sun Li-jen, a Nationalist Chinese war hero who was accused of trying to topple President Chiang Kai-shek, died today of pneumonia and sepsis, hospital officials said. He was 91. Sun died at his residence in Taichung in central Taiwan, the officials said. He had been discharged earlier today from the Veterans General Hospital at his family's request, the hospital said. He had been hospitalized since last month. Sun was dubbed ``the ever-victorious general'' for his feats during World War II. In one battle in Burma, he led an outnumbered contingent that successfully rescued about 7,000 British and Burmese soldiers held by about 10,000 Japanese soldiers. He was later made a Commander of the British Empire by the British government. In 1955, six years after the Nationalists lost a civil war to Communist forces and retreated to Taiwan, Sun and other officers were accused of plotting to overthrow Chiang. Some details of the episode still remain unclear. Sun, who was Chiang's chief of staff between 1954 and 1955, denied the charge but was placed under house arrest. He was finally freed in 1988, a year after Chiang's death, when the Control Yuan, the government's watchdog assembly, released a 1955 report that had cleared Sun of involvement in the coup plot. The Control Yuan gave no explanation for delaying release of the report, but historians believe Chiang had regarded Sun as a political rival. Sun, a graduate of the Virginia Military Institute, is survived by his wife, two sons and two daughters. Funeral arrangements were pendin.

DOC.HEAD: German Communist to be Extradited Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: A German suspected of trying to transfer millions in Communist Party funds out of the former East Germany will be extradited from Norway on Wednesday, police said today. ``German police are coming here to fetch him,'' said Svein Olav Kristiansen, of the Oslo police department. Karl-Heinz Kaufmann, 42, a former East German communist, was arrested Nov. 1 while visiting a bank in Oslo and reportedly discussing transfers of $45 million. He had been sought by Interpol on fraud and embezzlement charges. Kaufmann has been an official with the Party of Democratic Socialism, which was built on the remnants of the former East German Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Communist Agents Plotted To Kill Opposition Leader
DOC.TEXT: Agents of Poland's former Communist government plotted to kill dissident writer Adam Michnik during the late 1970s, according to a report today in the newspaper he now edits. Michnik was the target of ``Operation Drone,'' linked with a wide-ranging theft and corruption plot known as the Iron Affair, Gazeta Wyborcza said. The newspaper, Poland's largest, published excerpts of reports on the operation, compiled in 1984 during an internal Interior Ministry investigation. Michnik, 44, is a leading Solidarity movement theoretician and a widely published essayist in Poland and abroad. An opposition activist from his university days in the 1960s, he went to Paris in 1976 at the invitation of existentialist writer Jean-Paul Sartre and was jailed for several months shortly after his return in May 1977. One of the Interior Ministry agents linked to the alleged plot, Mieczyslaw Janosz, was arrested in OCtober with Gen. Miroslaw Milewski, a Communist Party Politburo member and a former Interior Minister, and five others in connection with the Iron Affair, the newspaper said. According to the report, Janosz and his brother, Jan, were being trained in West Germany at the Interior Ministry's orders for an assault on an unspecified target in 1977 or 1978, Gazeta Wyborcza said. ``According to some information, the aim of the sham assault was to terminate this person,'' the newspaper said. Gazeta Wyborcza said a ranking Interior Ministry official confirmed recently that Michnik was the ``drone,'' or the target. In a commentary headlined ``The Drone Speaks,'' Michnik, editor in chief of Gazeta Wyborcza, wrote: ``I have to disappoint all my compatriots who believed the Interior Ministry would save them from the ominous conspiracy of `Drone' and his crew ... Your money, my dear compatriots, was wasted.'' The report in Gazeta Wyborcza said the target was observed for two days in Paris but was always accompanied by at least two people. The report also said Michnik did not appear at the addresses under surveillance in West Germany. According to the newspaper, Mieczyslaw Janosz, a lawyer, was arrested with another brother, Kazimierz, a ranking intelligence officer, in connection with the Iron Affair. Jan Janosz was killed in a car accident in Poland several years ago, the newspaper said. Prosecutors in the Iron Affair allege Polish intelligence officers, from 1968 through the 1970s, used insurance frauds and thefts to accumulate gold and other valuables and ship them to Poland. The 1984 investigation was quashed by the Politburo, officials said. The Interior Ministry, now largely cleared of Communist officials, has also turned up a briefly considered plot to kidnap union leader Lech Walesa during the 1980 strikes that gave birth to Solidarity.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Demands Gorbachev Consult Republics Before Implementing Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-7, with four grafs to MOVE UP reference to greater role for republics' representatives, DELETES extraneous words in graf 7. Pickup 8th pvs, `Yeltsin criticized...'
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the largest Soviet republic, demanded today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev consult with leaders of the republics before implementing his plan to reorganize the national government. In his first public comment on the Soviet president's proposals, Yeltsin told the independent Interfax news agency that he found some of them ``disappointing,'' but did not specify which ones. He said he needed to study the proposals thoroughly. ``My attitude toward them is not that simple,'' said Yeltsin, president of the Russian Republic, who is Gorbachev's political rival and frequent critic. In an effort to break what is being called a ``paralysis of power'' between the central government and the Soviet Union's splintering republics, Gorbachev on Saturday proposed dumping his embattled prime minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, revamping the executive branch and putting it entirely under his control. The Soviet parliament gave initial approval to the proposals, which included putting representatives of each republic on a main governing council. Getting rid of Ryzhkov and his Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, has been one of Yeltsin's demands, and some of Gorbachev's proposals seemed to be a concession to the Russian president. ``The president's suggestions are all aimed at strengthening the center,'' Yeltsin told Interfax. He said the Soviet leader apparently ignored suggestions from leaders of the sovereign republics before making the proposals. Yeltsin criticized Gorbachev for proposing the restructuring without consulting the republics, and said such a decision-making process is unacceptable to Russia. He said the questions involved ``are not political. These are questions of inter-ethnic relations.'' ``Before making such a decision, the president should have consulted with the leadership of all sovereign republics,'' Interfax quoted him as saying. ``And this never has been done. That means that again, knowing that the republics won't approve of it, they want to push it forward. But their reaction will be opposite.'' In an apparent reference to the political stalemate that exists between the central government and the 15 republics, Yeltsin said: ``I am even convinced that all this will only make the situation in the country worse, rather than improve it.'' Yeltsin and even Gorbachev have referred to this government crisis as a ``paralysis of power.'' Laws implemented by the central government are being ignored or overridden by many Soviet republics, which are seeking greater sovereignty and say their own measures take precedence over those coming from the Kremlin. Gorbachev urged the Council of Ministers be replaced by several bodies under direct presidential control. The principal ruling body would be the Federation Council, created in March as a presidential advisory body but which would now be expanded to iclude representatives of the Soviet republics. Gorbachev also suggested naming a vice president, forming an ``inter-republican committee'' under the Federation Council, a national Security Council and a presidential body to coordinate the activities of law enforcement agencies, including sending representatives to regions. Radical legislators generally gave qualified support to the proposals, although some said Gorbachev was trying to grab too much power and others said he did not go far enough in giving the republics full independence. Parliament will take final action on it Friday. Grigory Yavlinsky, deputy prime minister of the Russian republic and co-author with Stanislav Shatalin of the radical ``500-day'' economic reform program, also gave a somewhat positive assessment of Gorbachev's proposals. He said in an interview with the Tass news agency that Gorbachev's plans and Yeltsin's suggestion of a coalition government ``are not incompatible.'' The Soviet press on Sunday generally praised the speech.

DOC.HEAD: A&M Panel Finds No Evidence of Fraud in Cold Fusion Research
DOC.TEXT: Allegations that Texas A&M researchers spiked water with tritium to fake cold nuclear fusion are apparently unfounded, an internal panel said. The panel, in a report dated Oct. 15 and released by the university Sunday, recommended that investigations into the charges be dropped. It said the researchers whose work was questioned may have acted hastily but did not do severely substandard work. The report was written by three Texas A&M professors assigned to investigate the research at Texas that followed the March 1989 claim by scientists in Utah that they had achieved cold fusion in a beaker of room-temperature water. Such a discovery would create a cheap, clean and virtually inexhaustible supply of energy. Scientists all over the world rushed to confirm the discovery by B. Stanley Pons of the University of Utah and his British colleague, Martin Fleischmann. But the journal Science suggested in its June 15, 1989, issue that some A&M experiments had been tainted. One such experiment, conducted by A&M electrochemist John O'Malley Bockris, involved running a series of electrolytic cells modeled after those in Utah. Some cells sporadically produced tritium, a standard byproduct of nuclear fusion. The experiment was the strongest evidence anywhere for cold fusion. But critics questioned the results, saying the tritium was not accompanied by other fusion byproducts, and suggested the experiment had been spiked with tritium. The report issued Sunday concluded that spiking was unlikely, in part because scientists got different results when they tested the spiking theory by intentionally putting tritium in water. ``While it is not possible for us to categorically exclude spiking as a possibility, it is our opinion that possibility is much less probable than that of inadvertent contamination or other unexplained factors in the measurements,'' the report said. The report said that in general, the furor over the alleged discovery of cold fusion caused scientists at Texas A&M to rush their research and lose scientific objectivity, but concluded that none of the experiments was conducted fraudulently. ``The earliest attempts to reproduce those experiments were done hastily, using available material and improvised setups where necessary,'' the report said. ``This, coupled with the perceived pressures of racing against other groups, certainly led to some less than perfect experimental design.'' But the report added that even in their haste, researchers maintained generally normal standards. It also said that with the decreasing amount of attention, continuing research is being conducted properly. The A&M report noted that researchers are still trying to confirm Pons and Fleischmann's discovery, but so far have failed, leaving the general scientific community skeptical that the two actually achieved cold fusion. The internal report was written by John Poston, a nuclear engineer; Edward S. Fry, a physicist; and Joseph B. Natowitz, a chemist.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette `Shuttle' Goes Down, Cargo Pilfered
DOC.TEXT: A plane ferrying American cigarettes to Moscow crash-landed in flames northeast of Prague. The six-member crew survived, but looters made off with some of the cargo. The Tupolev 154 was carrying 15 tons of American-made cigarettes to the Soviet capital from Switzerland on Saturday when fire broke out on board, the Rude Pravo newpaper said. The three-engine Soviet plane landed in a field near Dvur Kralove, about 75 miles northeast of Prague. The jet was on fire when it landed, and it took several hours for firefighters to extinguish the blaze, another newspaper, Obcansky Denik, reported. Some of the cargo was saturated with jet fuel and burned, the paper said. ``It is incredible that all six memebers of the crew survived, nobody was seriously hurt,'' the daily quoted Dr. Jarosalv Houf as saying. On Sunday, Czechoslovak television accused residents of acting like hyenas. It broadcast footage showing dozens of people retrieving packages of cigarettes from the wrecked fuselage. ``When trying to put things right, the police heard verbal abuse impossible to use in print,'' Rude Pravo said. A pack of American cigarettes is worth 50 Czechoslovak crowns, or $2. The average monthly salary in Czechoslovakia would buy only about 60 packs of such cigarettes.

DOC.HEAD: Nationalist Parties Lead in Bosnia-Hercegovina
DOC.TEXT: Nationalists were headed for a surprise victory over communists in elections in Bosnia-Hercegovina's first free elections since 1938, according to partial results released today. The Serbian Democratic Alliance, the Croatian Democratic Union, and the Moslem Union for Democratic Action were leading the republic's communist party and federal Premier Ante Markovic's Alliance of Reform Forces. With 15 percent of the vote counted in the central republic, the Serbian party was ahead in three of Bosnia's seven constituencies. The Croats and the Moslems were leading in two each. The 240 seats in Bosnia's bicameral parliament are divided among the seven constituencies. Final results were not expected for several days. ``The communists were rejected in Bosnia's elections because of the disastrous consequences of their 45 years of monopoly on power,'' said Radovan Karadzic, president of the Serbian Democratic Alliance. ``This is a victory for democracy.'' Zlatko Lajundzia, a member of the communist party's presidium, said, `it is obvious that the nationalist parties are doing much better than we and they had expected.'' Pre-election polls had shown the communists and Markovic's reformists well ahead. The two parties had claimed victory for a nationalist party could lead to civil war. Western observers said the elections, in which about 70 percent of the electorate cast ballots, were free and generally fair. ``Except for some isolated incidences, in general the elections seem to have been carried out fairly,'' said David Evans, a senior adviser for a U.S. congressional commission monitoring human rights and security in Europe. Bosnia-Hercegovina, whose 4.2 million people include Serbs, Croats and Moslems, is geographically and politically at the heart of Yugoslavia's bitter rivalries. Sarajevo, Bosnia's capital, is best known for the assassination of Austro-Hungarian Archduke Franz Ferdinand by a young nationalist in 1914. That killing sparked World War I. Serbia and Croatia are the two largest Yugoslav republics, and they flank Bosnia-Hercegovina. They have previously made territorial claims on Bosnia. Serbia, still under communist rule before elections Dec. 9, wants to keep power centralized in Belgrade, the Serbian and federal capital. Croatia, where the Croatian Democratic Union defeated the communists in spring elections, wants Yugoslavia to become a confederation of nearly independent states. Bosnia has so far steered a neutral and independent course. Hostility has existed among the Moslems, the mainly Roman Catholic Croats and the Orthodox Serbs since Yugoslavia was founded as a kingdom in 1918. During the Nazi occupation of World War II, Bosnia was the scene of a civil war among Croats, Serbs, communists and the Germans.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
PARIS: Central Europe
DOC.TEXT: ``It is the farthest-reaching arms agreement in history and it signals the new world order that is emerging,'' Bush said beforehand. ``This reduces to practically nil the tensions that have existed.'' The leaders also signed a companion non-aggression declaration between the 16 nations of NATO and the 6 nations of the Warsaw Pact, which is disintegrating as a Soviet-led mililtary alliance. It pledged that the nations ``are no longer adversaries, will build new partnerships and extend to each other the hand of friendship.'' The document also asserted that the countries have an ``obligation and commitment to refrain from the threat or use of force'' against each other. It was clear from the outset that the Persian Gulf crisis was on the minds of many leaders. In his speech, Bush saluted those who have made it possible for Europe to end ``decades of repression to rediscover their birthright of freedom.'' In hailing the convention arms treaty, he also looked ahead to an ``open skies'' agreement permitting reconnaissance flights to check compliance with arms agreements. Then he took an abrupt rhetorical turn to the Persian Gulf, where he said the principles of democracy and freedom that guide the new Europe ``have been violated.'' Recalling that he and Gorbachev issued a joint call last fall for an Iraqi withdrawal, Bush said, ``Can there be room for any other view?...(These) principles have no geographic limits.'' Gorbachev looked ahead to negotiations still to come. He said the Soviet Union is willing to begin negotiations on reducing arsenals of short range nuclear weapons within a month or two. ``Instead of military force our world order will be based on equitable dialogue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
PARIS: he said.
DOC.TEXT: Gorbachev, who permitted democracy to come to the former Soviet satellite states of Eastern Europe, was the last leader to sign the accords. French President Francois Mitterrand, the host, had been the first, and when the documents were passed back to him, the leaders applauded their work. ``We are putting an end to the previous age,'' he said. With the extraordinary assembly of government leaders, French authorities mobilized rooftop sharpshooters, anti-terrorist units and 10,000 police officers to provide security - and also to clear paths for convoys of limousines. Parisians braced for severe traffic disruptions. The leaders of the NATO members, six Warsaw Pact countries and 12 neutral nations proceeded from Versailles to the Kleber International Conference Center to officially open the three-day summit on European security. ``Our meeting today marks the end of an an epoch and thereby a beginning,'' said Mitterrand in the opening speech. ``It is the first time in history that we witness a change in depth of our landscape which is not the outcome of a war or bloody revolution ... .'' Even as the leaders met to discuss peace in Europe, their attention was diverted to the Persian Gulf, where an international force of hundreds of thousands of troops is stationed to counter Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Officials said Bush would seek backing for a United Nations resolution authorizing military action to force Iraq out of Kuwait. In another round of diplomacy, Bush planned to meet over dinner with Gorbachev, their fourth meeting in less than a year. The Persian Gulf was one likely topic of discussion. Another was U.S. assistance to the embattled Soviet leader, struggling against economic difficulties. ``We would always be open-minded on humanitarian aid if there's a real need there,'' Bush said.
