DOC.HEAD: Bay Area Papers Reach Agreement With Unions
DOC.TEXT: Marathon negotiations produced a tentative agreement that averted a strike at the Bay Area's three largest newspapers. The 45-month pact calls for a 3.5 percent to 4 percent annual wage increase for the unions representing some 4,500 employees at the San Francisco Examiner, San Francisco Chronicle and the San Jose Mercury News. Union leaders indicated the votes on the proposed contract would be taken sometime after Thanksgiving. Employees had been without a contract since February. A strike deadline of 5 p.m. Friday had been set, but talks were continued through the night. After 48 continuous hours of negotiations, union officials announced the tentative pact about 10 a.m. Saturday. ``No strike! We have a good contract!'' union leader Carl Hall shouted as he climbed atop a table at union strike headquarters to make the announcement. Chief management negotiator Richard Jordan praised ``good-faith bargaining'' as a key to successful talks. ``I am pleased that a settlement was reached that continues successful labor relations between these major newspapers and the employees of unions that represent them,'' he said. The tentative settlement would provide $89 per week more over the course of the contract, which expires in November 1993, for craft unions such as printers and engravers, and $95 for reporters, editors and drivers. Current top scale is $801 a week for reporters and editors, $669 for clerical and library workers and $675 for drivers. The unions had sought a 20 percent wage hike. The three papers have a combined circulation of about 1 million. Doug Cuthbertson, chairman of the Conference of Newspaper Unions, said, ``At this time of terrible economic difficulties for news and other businesses across the country, I think the employers have given us every last cent they could afford to.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush, Gorbachev, Join European Leaders in Signing Arms Pact
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with Gorbachev comments on gulf
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev led European leaders today in signing a historic treaty that slashes non-nuclear weapons in Europe and pushes the Cold War deeper into history. ``What a long way the world has come,'' exulted the Soviet leader. Scarcely had the accord been signed when Bush sought to cement European support for the continued effort to force Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. ``Our success here can be neither profound nor enduring if the rule of law is shamelessly disregarded elsewhere,'' he said in a speech to a 34-nation summit called to discuss European security in the post Cold War era. Gorbachev followed Bush to the podium, and he, too, blended words of praise for East-West cooperation in Europe with the need to halt Iraq's aggression. ``We're prepared to show patience in the quest for a political solution but we remain firm and determined in implementing the will of the United Nations,'' which has demanded Iraq's withdrawal, he said. The two men spoke after a glittering signing ceremony in an ornate ballroom at the Elysee Palace. The long-sought agreement to destroy tens of thousands of tanks, artillery and armored combat vehicles in Europe is the most sweeping arms accord in history. It will alter the military balance in Europe by erasing Moscow's ability to mass huge numbers of tanks and other heavy armor in central Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Paves Way For Action in War Crimes Case
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court today gave ordinary criminal courts jurisdiction to try a former French official accused of sending 194 Jewish children to their deaths in concentration camps during World War II. The Paris Court of Appeals overturned a lower court ruling last month Rene Bousquet could only be tried by the High Court of the Liberation, formed in 1944 to prosecute officials of the collaborationist Vichy government. The court has been defunct for decades. Court of Appeals President Albert Moatty ruled today that the length of time required to reconstitute the court could preclude justice in the case of Bousquet, who is 81. With Moatty's ruling, state prosecutors can resume their investigation of evidence on Bousquet's case that was provided by Nazi hunters. Bousquet headed the national police during the Nazi occupation of France. State prosecutors in September asked that he be investigated in connection with the deportation of 194 Jewish children during the war. Should the case go to trial, Bousquet would be the highest-ranking official of the Vichy government to be tried for crimes against humanity. But Serge Klarsfeld, a lawyer and prominent Nazi hunter, has said senior government officials, including President Francois Mitterrand, appear reluctant to pursue the case. Bousquet was condemned in 1949 for his wartime activities, but the decision was reversed due to ``acts accomplished in favor of the Resistance'' - namely his decision to free some jailed Resistance fighters at the time he was ousted from his post. Human rights leaders say none of the high-ranking French political figures with direct roles in deporting and arresting 100,000 Jews during the war has been brought to justice. Yves Jouffa, president of the French League of Human Rights, has said the recent trial of the Gestapo chief of Lyon, Klaus Barbie, ``was the trial of Nazi Germany, not collaborationist France.'' A federation of human rights groups has organized a commisison of inquiry to determine why action against Bousquet and two other suspected war criminals, Paul Touvier and Maurice Papon, has taken so long. Touvier, 75, is being prosecuted for his activities as a pro-Nazi militia chief who worked with Barbie in Lyon. He was captured last year after spending years in hiding under the shelter of right-wing Roman Catholic monks. Charges against Papon, a former budget minister, have been pending for seven years. He has been accused of responsibility for the arrests and deportations of 1,700 Jews while an administrator in Bordeaux during the war.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Orders Inquiry Into Secret Guerrilla Network
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Ministry today ordered an inquiry into a secret agreement between the military and the CIA that set up a guerrilla network in case of a Soviet invasion. Current and former government officials have said the agreement was made in 1955. Members of the Greece's conservative government and of the former socialist administration have said the network essentially went out of business in 1974 and was dismantled by 1988. Reports from other countries indicate the secret network extended to most NATO members during the Cold War. It has become known commonly as Operation Gladio, the name of its Italian version. Leftist parties in Greece have denounced the secret agreement, and they demand to know whether the network was ever used for clandestine activities in times of peace. The Defense Ministry said an investigation ``was deemed necessary because of the commotion which was created and is continuing, and the different views being expressed concerning the aims of the agreement and the way in which it was implemented,'' the semi-official Athens NEws Agency reported. Radio stations reported that the inquiry will be led by a retired military officer. Current and former U.S. officials have said the CIA helped organize guerrilla units in Western Europe in preparation for a possible Soviet invasion but had nothing to do with them after the 1950s. The Italian Parliament is investigating the network in that country, and according to testimony the Italian participants trained at a U.S. base in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Plane Found Crashed in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Searchers today found the burned wreckage of a Satena airlines plane that disappeared with 15 people aboard, the airline director said today. There was no sign of survivors. The Spanish-made Casa airplane, which had been missing since late Sunday, was discovered wrecked on a Pacific coast mountainside at 11,500 feet above sea level, said Satena's diector, Luis Angel Diaz. He said in a statement that bad weather caused the crash. Most of those aboard the plane were civilians, Diaz said, and one was a baby. The air force runs Satena, a commercial airline that flies to remote regions that are not normally served by civilian airlines.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Mobilizes 250,000 More Troops to Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will send an additional 250,000 troops to Kuwait, more than doubling its military strength in the occupied emirate, the Iraqi News Agency reported today. Seven extra divisions of the regular army would be sent immediately, INA said, and another 150,000 reserves would be called to duty. The Iraqi agency report was monitored in Cyprus. The move, announced after a meeting headed by President Saddam Hussein, came 11 days after President Bush announced a U.S. buildup in the Persian Gulf that would bring American troop strength in the region to about 430,000 soldiers, Marines, and other personnel. Previously, Iraq was believed to have an estimated 10 divisions, totaling 170,000 troops in Kuwait and about 250,000 men in southern Iraq. Overall, Iraq has an estimated 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves. It claims a militia called the Popular Army has 5 million men. On Sunday, Saddam said he would free the estimated 2,000 remaining Westerners stranded in Iraq and occupied Kuwait between Christmas and March 25 ``unless something would take place that Mars the atmosphere of peace.'' Bush today dismissed that announcement as a bid to buy time. Saddam has been freeing the hostages a few at a time since his troops overran Kuwait.

DOC.BYLINE: Guerrillas Launch Simultaneous Attacks In Three Provinces ^By KATHY GANNON
DOC.TEXT: In a rare show of unity, rival guerrilla commanders launched an offensive against Afghanistan's Soviet-backed government today in three provinces surrounding the capital, rebel spokesmen said. A barrage of rockets slammed into an ammunition dump several miles north of the Afghan capital, Kabul, just before dawn, signaling the start of a blitz on dozens of government targets, they said. ``It was one of the government's largest ammunition dumps,'' said Minhaj, a spokesman for a joint rebel news organization known as MIDIA. There were no immediate reports of casualties and no way to independently confirm the claims. The rebel sources spoke from Pakistan, where the guerrilla groups have their headquarters. One Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonoymity, said in Islamabad that ``something was happening'' but that he and others were scrambling for details. Farid, a member of the Hezb-e-Islami, the most radical and anti-West of the seven major guerrilla groups, said the offensive on Kabul, Logar and Wardak provinces took several weeks to plan. ``The main purpose of the operation is to eventually take Kabul,'' said Farid, who like most Afghans uses only one name. Minhaj said sporadic and often confused reports from the battlefront indicated guerrilla fighters were launching rockets at dozens of government targets in an arc around Kabul. The guerrillas, financed by the United States, Saudi Arabia and other sympathetic Arab states, have been fighting for more than 12 years to overthrow successive communist-style governments in Afghanistan. Most of the countryside is under the guerrillas' control, and troops loyal to President Najibullah hold the major cities. The guerrillas have failed to score a major military victory since February 1989 when the last of 115,000 Soviet soldiers ended nine years of direct intervention and withdrew from Afghanistan. Instead, the guerrilla leaders once touted as an alternative to Najibullah have become bitterly divided. Najibullah has taken advanatge of their feuding to score some political and military victories in the past year. Guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, who has been criticized by other rebel leaders as brutal and ambitious, claims to be leading the latest offensive. ``All the groups have joined hands and all the field commanders are involved in this offensive,'' said Farid, a spokesman for Hekmatyar. ``They've all agreed that Hekmatyar will lead.'' However, no other guerrilla group conceded Hekmatyar's leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Six Miners Killed, Six Missing in Rock Slides
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE death toll. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Six miners were killed and six were missing after earthquakes set off rock slides at two gold mines, officials said today. Early today, a temblor registering 1.7 on the Richter scale caused a rock slide at Anglo American Corp.'s Western Deep Levels Mine west of JOhannesburg, the company said. Anglo American spokesman J.A. Du Plessis said three miners were killed and six were missing. The men were working about 3,850 yards below ground, and rescue workers were trying to reach the missing Men, the spokesman said. Three workers died at the Buffelsfontein mine near Klerksdorp, about 110 miles southwest of Johannesburg, after a quake registering 3.2 on the Richter scale caused a rock slide. The incident occurred Saturday, but the mine operator, Genmin, did not report it until today. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Pledges Soviet Move Away From Totalitarianism
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today urged a new world order in which his country would abandon totalitarianism for democracy and discard separatist passions and nationalism. In sketching his grand vision for Europe and the world at the 34-nation Paris summit, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Gorbachev made a rare reference to ``totalitarianism'' in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev deemed the 1975 Helsinki Final Act on which the CSCE process was built a human rights document ``ahead of its time.'' The CSCE, he said, enabled international relations to change in the last five years. In the Soviet Union, this meant ``a shift away from totalitarianism to a democratic system, away from the command economy ... to a state underpinned by the rule of law ... away from unitarianism to a union of sovereign states,'' he said. ``Our country has changed and will never be the same as it was before,'' he added. ``We have opened up to the world and the world has opened up in response.'' Alluding only briefly to his present difficulties at home, Gorbachev predicted with characteristic confidence that they would not affect his country's role on the world stage. ``No matter what difficulties the Soviet Union faces today, it will remain a great European power, in line with its enormous potential,'' Gorbachev said. He proceeded to outline Soviet visions for the future of Europe. Saying that the crumbling Warsaw Pact alliance intends to take important decisions at a summit planned for December, Gorbachev reiterated the Kremlin's desire to see naval weapons and tactical nuclear arms reduced by future European negotiations. Diplomats who have toiled in Vienna since March 1989 to seal the historic accord reducing conventional arms and other negotiators working on measures to reduce tension will return to the Austrian capital on Nov. 26 for further talks. Gorbachev urged that the talks include all 34 nations in the CSCE process, rather than just the 22 NATO and Warsaw Pact countries who worked on the conventional arms accord. Although generally upbeat, Gorbachev did warn of international conflicts, such as the Gulf crisis, and domestic tensions that could undo changes in Europe, particularly in the East. Rising ethnic tensions and even separatist demands to change Europe's post-1945 borders could have ``a destructive snowball effect'' if any government gives way to them, he noted. Warning against the Balkanization of entire regions in EUrope, Gorbachev urged West and East to work together to create new structures for the continent's environment, economy and technology. This constitutes ``the only truly democratic chance of asserting a positive influence on internal developments in a number of countries,'' Gorbachev noted. Most of Eastern Europe's emerging democracies are rent by economic woes and ethnic passions. Nowhere is this more evident than in the Soviet Union, where shops in large cities are barer than ever before and demands for the independence of the 15 republics and other regions from Moscow grow more strident each day.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Following is a transcript of an address delivered Monday by President Bush at the 34-nation summit of the Conference on Cooperation and Security in Europe: Mr. Chairman, this is a glorious day for Europe. This morning I signed for my country an arms control agreement which ends the military confrontation that has cursed this continent for decades. This afternoon we welcome a summit document, a Charter of Paris, which expresses the common aspirations of our society. It is right that we gather here in this magnificent city, a city of civilization, to declare our hopes for the future and to mark a grand turn in the course of history. Today we do justice to the original framers of the Helsinki Final Act. The goals they set have proven their worth, thanks to the courage of so many who dared not merely to hope but to act. We salute men of courage - Havel and Mazowiecki and Antall here with us today - and all the other activists who took Helsinki's goals as solemn commitments, and who suffered so that these commitments would be honored. And we salute all those individuals and private groups in the West who showed that the protection of human rights is not just the business of governments - it's everyone's business: non-governmental organizations, the press, religious leaders, and ordinary citizens. Their dreams are being realized before our eyes. Thenew democracies of Central and Eastern Europe have ended decades of depression to rediscover their birthright of freedom. In the Soviet Union, the seeds of democracy and human rights have found new soil, and at long last the cruel division of Germany has come to an end. A continent frozen in hostility for so long has become a continent of revolutionary change. To assure that this change occurs in a secure framework, we have completed a conventional arms control treaty that transforms the military map of this continent. We are adopting confidence and security-building measures that will contribute to lasting peace through openness. This morning, 22 of us signed a solemn undertaking on the non-use of force. But today, as old political divisions disappear, other sources of tension, some ancient, some new, are emerging. National disputes persist. ABuses of minority and human rights continue. Where millions had once been denied the freedom to move, now millions feel compelled to move to escape economic or political hardship. We are witnessing, in several countries, the ugly resurgence of anti-Semitism and other ethnic, racial and religious intolerance. Bigotry and hatred have no place in civilized nations. Minorities enrich our societies. Protection of their rights is a prerequisite for stability. Europe is entering unknown waters. The CSCE is ideally suited to help its member states navigate. We have articulated fine standards for national behavior, and now it is our task to bring CSCE down to earth, making it part of everyday politics, building and drawing on its strength to address the new challenges. My government put forward some ideas for the future development of the CSCE earlier this year, and I hope that they contributed to the initiatives that the members of the North Atlantic Alliance announced at our London summit in July, and I am pleased to see that so many of the ideas discussed there have emerged in the summit declaration that we will sign this week. Let me highlight how we think some of these initiatives and others will help the CSCE put its principles into practice. The declaration we will sign establishes an agenda to guide our work until we meet again in Helsinki. This is important work on issues vital to all of us, the peaceful settlement of disputes, the role of minorities in our societies, the construction of democratic institutions, and most fundamental of all, the enhancement of human rights.

DOC.HEAD: Rough Weather Cancels Mock Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th pvs, `Some officers...' to ADD background on winter sea conditions. Pickup 6th pvs, `On Sunday...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military today canceled a second attempt at a mock invasion on a Saudi beach because of poor weather and said it was scrapping the maneuver. The Marine assault in water-skimming hovercraft was expected to have been one of the dramatic highlights of the first joint U.S.-Saudi military exercise, codenamed Imminent Thunder. The six-day exercise ends Wednesday. The Marines had tried to storm the beach on Sunday and today, but heavy seas and high winds prevented the mock invasion. The U.S. military said there would not be a third attempt. Maj. Gen. Harry W. Jenkins Jr., commander of the Marine Expeditionary Brigade, said he thought Sunday's amphibious landing would have gone ahead in a real war, but there was no need to risk casualties for a drill. Some officers aboard the amphibious landing ship USS Gunston Hall, however, said similar conditions could thwart planned landings in actual combat. Winter seas in the gulf normally average 2 to 4 feet, but the season is characterized by periodic north winds during which waves reach 8 to 15 feet, according to Navy officials. The high seas usually occur about two times each winter, between October and January. On Sunday, helicopters from the USS Guam deposited 400 troops in the mock invasion force on a Saudi beach 80 miles south of the Kuwaiti border. U.S., British and French warplanes roared overhead, giving simulated air support. Among the troops were 36 Saudi Arabian marines. Jenkins called the exercise a success, even without the Marine landings, because it showed the allied forces could work together. ``I was pleased we've had as few glitches as we've had so far because it's tough to bring everyone together,'' he said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has denounced the exercises as provocative. Navy Cmdr. Christopher J. Ellis of Fairfax Station, Va., the U.S. adviser to the Saudi navy, said he believes news leaks caused the military to move the exercise. Media reports last week said it would be 10 miles from the Kuwaiti border. Yet it was too close to Iraqi forces for some Marines. ``I'm not gonna lie - I'm scared. But if anything goes down, I'm ready,'' said Pfc. Felipe Williams. Jenkins insisted the exercise was not meant to threaten Saddam. But Saudi Marine Capt. Muhammad al-Aseeri said he was pleased only a few dozen Saudi marines were involved. ``We don't want more troops because Saddam Hussein might take it too seriously,'' he said. Marine Maj. John Toolan of New York said he wanted to use the exercise to send a message to Saddam: ``We're ready and capable to carry out our president's orders.'' Defense analysts said Imminent Thunder's main aim is to test the air-strike capability of the multinational force deployed in the gulf following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The exercise is using 1,100 warplanes - double Iraq's air power - and represents the largest use of aircraft in an exercise during Operation Desert Shield. No ammunition is being fired. ``The aviation part has gone very well,'' Jenkins said. ``It's evidence of the flexibility we have.'' Under U.S. military rules, the amphibious section of Imminent Thunder was covered by several media pools. But there was no pool monitoring air operations. The Marines have practiced amphibious landings in Bahrain and Oman, but this was the first on Saudi soil. The amphibious assault was supposed to commence 25 miles offshore in a technique called ``over the horizon'' because shore can't be seen when the amphibious craft are launched. But winds of 20 to 25 mph have stirred up choppy waves estimated at 4 feet to 10 feet. The Marine's hulking air-cushioned amphibious landing craft are designed to skim over the waves and roar onto a beach, carrying Marines and tracked vehicles. One was launched Sunday from the Gunston Hall but it foundered in the choppy gulf, its engines sputtering and groaning. After a lengthy struggle, it returned to the ship and the seaborne assault was scrapped.

DOC.HEAD: PARIS: human rights.
DOC.TEXT: We have also agreed that we must deepen the security of our community by extending our talks on conventional forces, expanding the benefits of confidence-building measuress reached a tentative contract agreement on Sept. 17. Less than a week after the UAW-GM contract was settled, a tentative agreement was reached between the union and Ford. The UAW and Chrysler reached a tentative agreement Oct. 30. The union's contracts with the Big Three are essentially the same. In all, more than 450,000 active auto workers are covered by the three agreements. Each contract provides for a 3 percent base wage increase in the first year and 3 percent lump-sum payments in the second and third years, and increases for current and future retirees. They also call for income guarantees for workers laid off for more than 36 weeks during the lives of the ntracts from ch tive in the 1990s, especially with Japanese automakers. Union officials said the agreements provided income guarantees at a time of uncertainty in the U.S. auto industry. All of the contracts expire at midnight Sept. 14, 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Gov. Martinez Likely Will be Next Drug Czar
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 3-4, Rep. Charles, and 20-22, Bennett called, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The person most likely to succeed William J. Bennett as director of the nation's drug control strategy is Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, who recently lost his re-election bid, a White House official says. Bennett, meanwhile, is in line to become chairman of the Republican National Committee in January, Republican sources said over the weekend. He would take over for the ailing Lee Atwater, 39, who has been undergoing intensive treatment for a cancerous brain tumor. Rep. Charles B. Rangel, chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics, said today President Bush should not nominate Martinez. ``The president needs to take advantage of this opportunity and appoint to he position of national drug control policy director not someone who has lost an election, but someone who is acceptable to Republicans and Democrats,'' Rangel said. The nominee should be chosen ``not because of his political resume, but for his continued dedication and ability to be successful as a commander in the war on drugs.'' The 55-year-old Martinez ``is probably going to be the next drug czar,'' said the White House official, who spoke Sunday on condition of anonymity. ``Nobody else is being actively considered.'' Officially, the White House was mum, as was Martinez's spokesman. ``I don't have any details on candidates, I'm afraid,'' said White House spokesman Bill Harlow, contacted in Paris where he was traveling with the president. ``As far as I know, no decision has been made on that position.'' The governor's spokesman, Jon Peck, said from Tallahassee, ``At this point, everything is just speculation.'' Martinez would consider the position if asked by Bush, but ``that's not to say that it's something he has been actively working to get.'' Martinez was trounced in his re-election effort by former Sen. Lawton Chiles, losing by a 57-43 percent margin. He was only the second Republican governor in Florida since Reconstruction. His term ends Jan. 8, when CHiles is to be inaugurated. Bush traveled to Florida three times to campaign for Martinez, and first lady Barbara Bush made a campaign commercial on his behalf. Jeb Bush, one of the president's sons, was Martinez's campaign chairman. Florida has had a lot of experience with drug problems. Most of the nation's cocaine supply went through Florida until the mid-1980s, when a crackdown there pushed traffickers west to Mexico and the southwest U.S. border states. The national drug strategy compiled by Bennett's Office of National Drug Control Policy last January designated the Miami area as one of country's five high-intensity drug trafficking areas, enabling it to receive additional federal anti-drug assistance. Bennett, 47, announced his resignation Nov. 8 after 20 months on the job. He will remain in the post until Nov. 30, aides say. An administration source confirmed Sunday that Bennett - who was education secretary for President Reagan but did not become a Republican until 1986 - had made up his mind to accept the GOP job on Saturday morning. Initially, he had planned to become a fellow at a conservative think tank, the American Enterprise Institute, and write books on drugs and education. Bush brushed aside reporters' questions Sunday about Bennett taking the RNC job. ``We're not discussing that,'' he said with a smile. ``A lot happens when I leave.'' Atwater, who managed Bush's 1988 presidential campaign, will assume the title of ``general chairman'' of the party, said a senior administration official in Paris traveling with the president. Asked whether the idea was Bush's or Atwater's, the official said, ``It was both.'' A GOP source said a formal announcement of Bennett's new job would not be made until Bush returned at the end of the week from his eight-day trip to Europe and the Persian Gulf. Despite his job as Bush's chief lieutenant in the war on drugs, Bennett has spoken out on such issues as education and abortion, and he made numerous campaign trips around the country prior to the Nov. 6 election. Bennett called Rangel a ``gasbag'' shortly after announcing his resignation from the drug post. Rangel, long at odds with Bennett over drug issues, said, ``I formally welcome Mr. Bennett to the political fray. ``I am happy to see the president believes Bill Bennett is more qualified in a partisan political post than as coordinator of national anti-drug efforts,'' Rangel said. Bennett boasted Nov. 8 that the Bush administration's drug strategy was working and that Americans have turned against drugs. Reports from hospital emergency rooms show the number of cocaine-related visits have declined in the past few months. Surveys also have shown that casual use of all drugs is declining, and cocaine supplies are drying up, illustrated by higher prices and declining purity. However, violence in many large cities is increasing. Bennett has attributed the increased murder rate to drug traffickers vying for shares of the dwindling market.

DOC.HEAD: Part of Town Evacuated After World War II Bomb Discovery
DOC.TEXT: Construction workers in a town northwest of Prague found an unexploded American bomb from World War II on Monday, forcing authorities to evacuate residential areas, the CTK news agency said. The 1,000-pound bomb was found in soil brought to a construction site from the outskirts of the town of Most, about 50 miles northwest of Prague. Some people living near the construction site had to be temporarily evacuated, the report said. Experts placed the bomb on a truck loaded with sand and were transporting it to a military site nears Mimon, about 45 miles north of Prague, to be defused, CTK said. Experts said the bomb contained 660 pounds of TNT with a chemical detonating device.

DOC.HEAD: Math Prodigy, 11, Studies at University
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy whose parents come from Sri Lanka was hailed on Monday as the youngest student in a British university. Ganesh Sittapalam is at school in Wimbledon, south London, with boys of his own age, studying the usual range of subjects, but for mathematics he goes to Surrey University in Guildford. He is managing a year's work in one day a week there among students nearly twice his age. ``You can't help liking him,'' fellow student Jon Lewis, 20, said. ``He sits here blowing bubblegum while solving incredibly complicated problems.'' ``He is a very normal 11-year-old, but he has a fantastic flair for maths,'' said the boy's tutor at Surrey, DOnald Keedwell. Ganesh's parents are both mathematicians and his father, Arjuna Sittapalam, is an investment banker in London's City financial district. London's Daily Telegraph quoted Ganesh as saying: ``I like maths, computers, reading and Lego. Ambition? I don't think I have got one really. I will probably follow a career in maths.''

DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Shake Northern Indonesia
DOC.TEXT: Aftershocks from a strong earthquake jolted Indonesia's northern Sumatra region, and a 13-year-old girl was trampled to death when her family fled its home in panic, police said Monday. A police officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the girl was killed in Blang Kejeren, a remote district in the Bukit Barisan mountains, about 115 miles from the aftershocks' epicenter. No other details were provided, and no other casualties or damage were reported in the aftershocks, which began Sunday. Police said most Blang Kejeren residents have been afraid to return to their homes. The Meteorological Agency said the aftershocks measured up to 4.6 on the Richter scale and were centered about 95 miles southwest of the north Sumatran capital of Medan, or about 845 miles northwest of Jakarta. The aftershocks followed an earthquake Thursday that measured 6.2 on the Richter scale. It injured hundreds of people, damaged hundreds of buildings and caused landslides that cut traffic between the southeast provincial city of Kutacane and Blang Kejeren in Aceh province. Damage has been estimated at $2.6 million, police said. An aftershock measuring 5.9 on the Richter scale also shook the Malaysian island of Penang on Monday, said a spokesman of Malaysia's Meteorological Department, speaking on condition of anonymity. No casualties or damage were immediately reported. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on seismographs. A quake of 6 can cause severe damage in populated areas while 7 is a major quake capable of widespread, heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Invitations Sent Out For Monkey Feast
DOC.TEXT: The invitations have gone out, and hundreds of monkeys are eagerly awaiting their second annual sit-down brunch courtesy of a hotel owner. Yongyoot Kitwattanusoan, owner of the Lopburi Inn, said Monday he is spending $32,000 to throw the bash - complete with waiters, menus and napkins - for about 600 monkeys on Sunday. Yongyoot offers the meal to thank the monkeys for the success of his hotel in Lopburi, a small provincial capital about 70 miles north of Bangkok. The monkeys, who stay at the Buddhist shrine of Wat Pra Karn, are symbols of good fortune and a prime attraction for tourists. He said he sent 60 invitation cards to the monkeys, who grabbed them and leapt back up the shrine. ``We invite all the monkeys to attend a meal party on the occasion of the second anniversary of the Lopburi Inn. On Nov. 25 at 10 a.m.,'' the cards said. It will be a sit-down affair, if Yongyoot can keep the furry creatures seated at the 50 tables. ``We will serve vegetarian food, including American fried rice, vegetable salad, papaya, various kinds of fruit and dessert,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Last year, tens of thousands of people came to see the Lopburi monkeys eat the food we hosted for them,'' he said. This year, the spread is larger - Yongyoot said a count by the keepers of the temple found there were 100 more monkeys than last year.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Shopping Mall: Lingerie? Turn Left at the Electric Chair
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: When Chuck Bergensky looks at the grimy sandstone walls of the West Virginia Penitentiary, he sees thousands and thousands of happy shoppers. ``I visualize a very successful outlet shopping mall. I see things like a parking lot for 1,000 cars in the prison yard and 35 or 40 shops inside the walls,'' the city manager said. And not only that. ``We would keep some of the cellblocks to attract people and maybe put the electric chair on display,'' he said Friday. Bergensky and a group of businessmen and others have proposed turning the Civil War-era prison into a mall after it closes in 1992 under court order. The city is spending about $13,000 for architectural and feasibility studies. If the city and a state-appointed economic development group decide to go ahead with the idea, the prison will be sold or leased to developers for conversion. The maximum-security penitentiary resembles a medieval fortress, with parapets, gun slots and arches. Its 24-foot walls were quarried with convict labor. Now blackened by pollution, the walls are 7 feet thick at the base and taper to 28 inches at the top. Stuart Patz, a Vienna, Va., consultant, said preliminary figures indicate the mall could attract busloads of tourists and shoppers from Pittsburgh, about 85 miles to the northeast. He declined to estimate what the project would cost. ``All indications are that the project is feasible,'' Patz said. He said he expects to complete an analysis of the project by early December. The prison stands on a 10-acre plot in a residential area in this Ohio River town of 11,000. It still houses the gallows where 85 men were hanged from 1899 to 1949. Nine men died in the prison's electric chair from 1951 to 1959. In 1973, it was the site of a major riot. In 1979, a police officer and an inmate were killed when 15 inmates escaped. In 1986, three inmates were killed and more than a dozen prison workers taken hostage in a New Year's Day riot. Underfunding and overcrowding prompted a judge in 1983 to declare prison conditions unconstitutional. In 1988, after millions were spent on improvements, the state Supreme Court ordered the place closed, saying conditions had become too appalling to correct. The prison has about 550 inmates, down from a peak of about 1,200 in the 1970s. A new maximum-security prison is being built in Fayette County. Moundsville officials dread the time when the prison and its 300 jobs leave. They say a mall could stem unemployment and provide the impetus to reopen a factory and other businesses. ``I think it would be a great thing for the city of Moundsville to carry on with the prison and make it a place that people want to come to,'' said Mayor Dorothy Durig. ``We could even stage breakouts twice a day.'' Nanette Collins, 45, lives a block from the prison and doesn't want to see it torn down. ``It's a landmark,'' she said. ``I don't think that anyone would be bothered by the fact that it was a prison. People are curious and they'd get a chance to see what a prison really looks like.'' Not everyone likes the idea. ``I think they could find a better place to build a shopping mall,'' said Robert Leach, 33, an inmate serving two life sentences without parole for two murders. ``Considering its history, I don't know why the public would want anything to do with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Seizure at Sea: 10 Held
DOC.TEXT: Customs agents seized more than one ton of marijuana with a street value of nearly $20 million and arrested the 10 crew members aboard a ship off Scotland's northwest coast, officials said Monday. Customs identified the vessel as the Panamanian-registered Sea Ranger V, an oil rig supply vessel, which was boarded early Sunday off the Outer Hebrides. Customs refused to say where the vessel had come from or where it was heading. London's Daily Telegraph newspaper said Sea Ranger V had come from north Africa and was intercepted after a tip from French and Spanish customs. The ship was escorted to Oban on the Scottish mainland and impounded. Customs said a thorough search would start later Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Goes Sightseeing, Mrs. Kohl Jolted By Photographer
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush joined Europe's first ladies Monday on a sightseeing trip encompassing the Louvre and Versailles. It proved to be a pain in the neck - literally - for one of the group, Hannelore Kohl. The tour concluded with a gourmet luncheon hosted by French first lady Danielle Mitterrand. Among the guests at Versailles' Grand Trianon palace was Mrs. Kohl, whose meal ended prematurely. As photographers rushed to take pictures of Mrs. Bush, one of them accidentally bumped into the wife of German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The French photographer's camera and heavy lens grazed her neck as they slipped off his shoulder. Mrs. Kohl winced and began rubbing the wound while Mrs. Bush expressed her concern. Mrs. Kohl excused herself from the table after being hurt. The photographer said he was unaware of the incident when it happened, and he later apologized to the GErman leader's wife. Raisa Gorbachev, soberly dressed in a navy blue and white pin-striped suit, high-necked white blouse and spiked heels, was the last to arrive - skipping the guided tour of the Grand Trianon, built in pink marble in 1687 by Louis XIV to accommodate his volatile private life. She exchanged warm greetings with Mrs. Bush, who wore a black and white houndstooth suit, a paisley blouse and her trademark double-strand choker pearls. The group enjoyed a four-course meal prepared by one of France's leading caterers. The menu included coquilles St. Jacques and shrimp mousse, roast beef, vegetables, cheese, fruit and chestnut Ice cream, all washed down by three vintage French wines. Earlier in the day, Mrs. Bush inspected I.M. Pei's tall glass pyramid which caps the new entrance to the Louvre. The small group, which included SUsan Baker, wife of the Secretary of State, and Mary Curley, wife of American Ambassador Walter J.P. Curley, saw the highlights of the Louvre's vast renovation program. Recounting the history of the museum, built by King Philippe Auguste as a fortress in 1200 to protect Paris from invaders, Louvre director Michel Laclotte took Mrs. Bush through softly illuminated underground displays of the medieval tower base and thick walls unearthed during recent excavations. She appeared fascinated with a solid gold helmet, dug from a latrine dating to the 18th century when city life centered around the Louvre. Mrs. Bush's next stop was the Nissim de Camondo museum, a reconstitution of an 18th-century private home. Recently refurbished for $16 million, it houses a priceless collection of period furnishings, tapestries, china and antiques that exemplify pre-revolutionary French luxury. ``Isn't this the darndest place you ever saw?'' she asked as she climbed a spiral staircase. ``It's hard to think of children charging around this house.'' Asked if she thought President Bush would like the oval-shaped wood-panelled library, she rolled her eyes and grinned. ``He'd be tasteless if he didn't love it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-five Workers Injured In Channel Tunnel Accident
DOC.TEXT: A work train loaded with construction materials for the tunnel beneath the English Channel collided with a rail car Monday, injuring 25 workers. Officials for contractors working on the tunnel to link Britain and France said six of the workers were injured seriously and were hospitalized in Calais. The others suffered cuts and bruises and were treated at Sangatte, the main construction site for the French side of the tunnel. The accident happened several hundred yards below the ground's surface in the access tunnel leading to the portion under the channel, the officials said. The two trains were on the same rail line, and the one carrying the workers crashed into the one carrying cargo after the latter ran out of fuel, they said. Eight workers were injured in a similar accident Oct. 30, the day workers sent a 2-inch probe through the last 100 yards of chalk separating the British and French halves of the project's service tunnel. The link-up marked a turning point in the financially plagued project. The Channel Tunnel is scheduled to open to rail traffic in 1993. In all, eight workers have died on the project, seven on the British side and one on the French.

DOC.HEAD: DeConcini Complains of `Disgraceful' Conduct by Senate Counsel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with 7 grafs to UPDATE with DeConcini's statement completed; picks up 7th graf pvs, DeConcini also...
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dennis DeConcini today strongly defended himself against wrongdoing in his dealings with savings and loan owner Charles Keating Jr. and accused the Senate Ethics Committee's special counsel of relying on ``lies ... and hearsay.'' ``I submit this is disgraceful. I submit there is a bias, and I think it is unconscionable,'' DeConcini said of allegations by the Senate committee's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, who is presenting the case against the so-called ``Keating Five.'' DeConcini, an Arizona Democrat, was the last of the five senators to offer an opening statement defending himself to the ethics committee. He said Bennett's evidence ``contains hearsay ... contains rumors, unfounded allegations about all of the senators.'' The other accused senators, Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats Alan Cranston of California, John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan, offered emotional personal statements on Friday against allegations they improperly intervened with federal regulators on behalf of Keating, a financial contributor to their campaigns and causes. DeConcini read from a prepared statement and stopped often to read from letters, memos and other evidence he said Bennett had left out or used selectively in his presentation. He denounced ``derogatory information, lies and allegations and hearsay that Mr. Bennett goes out and gets people to give.'' DeConcini concluded his statement on an emotional note, calling for reform in the campaign financing laws but insisting he had nothing to apologize for. ``To do other than dismiss the charges against me is unjust,'' DeConcini said. ``I broke no law. I broke no rule. I broke no standard. I committed no improper conduct. ... There's been no unethical conduct by this senator.'' DeConcini also complained that he had been treated more harshly by Bennett than McCain, his Arizona colleague, and said the relationship between Bennett and McCain was ``kind of cozy.'' He said Bennett had failed to ask McCain about his wife's investments with Keating, and without pressing him on family vacations the McCains took at Keating's vacation spot. Bennett mentioned both last week but dismissed them as without serious consequence. special prosecutor.'' DeConcini said it was ``ridiculous'' for Bennett to suggest that campaign contributions from Keating or any other constituent were tied to his efforts to help those with ``a legitimate beef'' with the federal government. ``They have a right to ask for your intervention,'' DeConcini said. He said federal regulators and bureaucrats ``often are wrong'' in dealing with constituents, and ``somebody ought to stand up for'' them. At the time, Keating was an Arizona businessman and owner of the Irvine, Calif.,-based Lincoln Savings and Loan, whose 1989 collapse and federal seizure is expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion. DeConcini said he did no more for Keating than he would for other constituents, without regard to campaign contributions. ``I'm accessible. I talk to constituents. I call them back on the phone myself if I can,' he said. In defending his involvement with Keating, DeConcini said Keating ``is a different person than he is perceived today.'' He said Keating had contributed substantially to Mother Teresa, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her work with the poor. DeConcini also attacked the motives of Common Cause, the lobbying and public interest group whose original complaint sparked the ethics panel's probe into the five senators. ``I can tell you what they're trying to achieve - they're trying to raise money. They're trying to damage the reputation of a number of senators. ... I think it's a travesty,'' DeConcini said. After DeConcini's opening statement, Bennett was to begin presenting evidence and calling witnesses. Bennett's case centers on meetings between the five senators and federal banking regulators as the regulators were preparing to recommend criminal investigation of Lincoln by the Justice Department. Keating, who faces criminal fraud charges in California and is the object of civil fraud suits, said through his attorney he wants to testify before the committee, but only if he receives immunity. The Keating case presents the Ethics Committee with the difficult question of what actions by senators on behalf of political contributors are improper. Among the five, Bennett has suggested that DeConcini and Cranston were most deeply involved with Keating. Evidence shows DeConcini ``was asked repeatedly to perform services for Charles Keating, and that Senator DeConcini almost always honored Mr. Keating's request,'' Bennett said. Bennett said an April 1987 meeting that four of the senators held with Edwin Gray, then top bank regulator, was organized by DeConcini ``with the intent to place tremendous political pressure on Chairman Gray to achieve a specific outcome desired by Charles Keating.'' In that meeting, Bennett said, DeConcini proposed a deal to drop a proposed banking rule that Keating opposed, while in exchange Lincoln would make more home loans. He also said Keating ``enlisted Senator DeConcini in his effort to drive Chairman Gray from office.'' Bennett said DeConcini continued trying to assist Keating even after the senators were told on April 9, 1987, that bank regulators planned criminal referrals involving Lincoln. DeConcini's efforts, the counsel said, included calls in April 1989 in an effort to persuade bank regulators to allow the sale of Lincoln, after Lincoln had learned that results of a new bank examination ``were going to be disastrously negative.'' DeConcini received $48,100 in contributions from Keating and associates for his 1988 re-election campaign, which he later returned, and $33,000 for his 1982 campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Reveal Extent of Drug Abuse, Vow To Join GLobal Fight
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A deputy interior minister revealed Monday that more than 1.5 million Soviets use illegal drugs, a figure nearly five times higher than previous official statistics on drug abuse. The sale of illegal drugs, mostly marijuana and hashish, also contributes $1.8 billion a year to the Soviet Union's flourishing underground economy, Sergeyev Troshin said on the first day of a conference of heads of European anti-drug agencies. He said the problem will worsen as the Soviet Union loosens border restrictions and increases contacts with the West. Troshin did not give figures on illegal drug use from previous years, and it could not immediately be determined which forms of drug use had increased in the country of 285 million people. Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin last summer had said there were 220,000 ``drug abusers'' and 40,000 ``addicts'' in the country. Soviet authorities once maintained that social problems such as drug abuse and alcoholism were mainly products of capitalist systems, and they did not release such statistics for the Soviet population. Troshin was elected chairman of the five-day conference, the first time drug agencies from Eastern and Western Europe have come together to combat drug trafficking across the continent. Representatives from 28 European countries, the United States, Canada and the United Nations were attending the gathering. ``If we take into account the expanding contacts (with the West) and the forthcoming emigration bill which will bring about increased contacts, we must presuppose that the trend will get worse,'' Troshin said at news conference. The Soviet legislature has been debating a bill to allow Soviet citizens free entry to and exit from the country, but has not set a date for a vote. ``The development of events in our country and in Europe in general has shown to everybody that it is necessary to join efforts in the fight with the plague of the 20th century, which is the illegal trafficking in drugs,'' Troshin said. U.N. undersecretary-general Margaret Anstee, who coordinates the organization's drug-abuse programs, said the drug problem was worsening in Western Europe. ``But as the government of the U.S.S.R. has recognized, the tentacles of this problem are also stretching eastward and it's becoming an increasing concern to the authorities here,'' she said. Troshin said 80 percent to 90 percent of illegal drug use in the Soviet Union involves products of the cannabis plant. Opium is the second most popular illegal substance, followed by narcotic medicines, he said. Also, alcohol is abused by 20 million to 25 million Soviet citizens, he said. ``We have to join our efforts because of relationship with Europe is on the increase and the flow of immigration is increasing and we already know of cases of smuggling of drugs,'' Troshin said. Mrs. Anstee said she hoped the meeting would come up with concrete proposals ``as to how cooperation can be strengthened in the fight against illicit drug abuse, illicit drug trafficking, all over Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Bill Cosby accepted an honorary doctoral degree from Rust College, then bestowed it on a student who overcame dyslexia to earn a graduate degree. During a speech Sunday at the northern Mississippi college's 124th Founder's Day celebration, Cosby gave Rust graduate Troy Brown his royal blue hood in recognition of Brown's academic achievements. ``He came here with an awful lot of differences - about himself and about his family. This school took him and showed him love and understanding,'' said Cosby, 53. Brown overcame dyslexia with help from faculty at 1,000-student Rust College and went on to earn a graduate degree from Alcorn State University. Brown is now working toward a doctorate in educational psychology at the University of Mississippi. Cosby urged young people to look to their parents, grandparents and teachers for role models: ``They're the ones who read you the Bible and the old people who tell you the truth. Your role model on TV doesn't even know you.'' --- LAGUNA NIGUEL, Calif. (AP) - Who better to invite to a champagne festival than Robin Leach, who has made a career out of purveying dreams of ostentatious wealth. Leach was the guest of honor at the Tete de Cuvee Champagne Brunch at the fifth World of Wines Festival on Sunday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel. The host of television's ``Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous'' and several spinoffs joined about 450 others at the festival to quaff 420 bottles of champagne, each selling for $60 to $100 each. ``It's an extraordinary elixir,'' Leach said of the bubbly. ``The breakfast of champions.'' The former Fleet Street reporter received the festival's first Bon Vivant award, represented by - what else? - a crystal champagne cooler. ```Champagne wishes and caviar dreams' seem to very aptly and succinctly sum up an attitude we have toward life,'' Leach said of his trademark phrase. --- SPARTANBURG, S.C. (AP) - Squealing little girls and a high school pep band greeted Gina Marie Tolleson on her triumphant return home as the new Miss World. ``I'm just really, really touched to see all my family and friends here,'' the 21-year-old University of Georgia student, who returned home to celebrate Thanksgiving in Spartanburg, said Sunday. She was crowned Miss World on Nov. 8 in London. Spartanburg Mayor Pro Tem Chester Brown, after awarding her the city's Distinguished Citizen Award, said that next week would be officially declared Gina Tolleson week. Miss Tolleson's studies at the University of Georgia at Athens are on hold during her reign as Miss World. She is seeking a broadcast journalism degree. ``I'm not interested in being a movie star or film star. ... I'm determined to go back and finish my education,'' she said. --- SANTA BARBARA, CAlif. (AP) - The children in the audience had no idea who he was, but their parents eagerly listened to Peter Noone reprise his 1960s hits. Noone, the handsome crooner known as Herman of the British rock group Herman's Hermits, performed a benefit concert Sunday for El Montecito Early School. Noone's daughter, 4-year-old Natalie, attends the school for children in pre-school through third grade. ``Aren't we lucky?'' Noone asked. ``I know everybody here. It's like playing at your sister's wedding or something.'' VH-1's ``My Generation'' series on cable television.

DOC.HEAD: Police and Protocol: Prerequisites for a Smooth Summit
DOC.TEXT: Police perched on rooftops, posed as streetsweepers and escorted motorcades atop glossy white motorcycles, minding both men and manners Monday at the landmark European summit. Up to 10,000 police fanned out over Paris as 34 heads of state and government, 1,000 delegates and some 5,000 journalists gathered for the three-day meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Authorities sealed off an entire neighborhood near the Arc de Triomphe where the meeting was held, banning traffic, closing a metro station and diverting 15 bus lines. They had spent a month combing the streets of the posh quarter, interrogating residents and shopkeepers and even installing barbed wire in strategic parts of the city's vast sewer system - a historic haunt for ne'er-do-wells. On Monday, the eyes of the law were everywhere. Sharpshooters perched on rooftops, legions of riot police surveyed the streets around the Champs-Elysees while collegues scanned the city from armchairs in a newly modernized surveillance command post at police headquarters. Police spokesman Marcel Vinzerich confirmed a report that some undercover police took up the green brooms of the city's sanitation department or posed as merchants in the strategic triangle sealed off around the Kleber International Conference Center. ``Lots of preventative measures have been taken.'' said Vinzerich in a telephone interview. He noted, however, that the 10,000-strong force is only half the size of that deployed in 1989 when France hosted a summit of the world's seven richest nations amid gala celebrations for the bicentennial of the French Revolution. ``This is a big job but this time we don't have the crowds to handle,'' said Vinzerich. All 34 leaders were invited to speak at the plenary sessions, and the order was decided by draw, said an official of the Foreign Ministry's Office of Protocol. Nothing in the domaine of protocol is accidental, and observers noted with amusement the seating arrangement for the leaders' first lunch. With due logic, Finnish President Mauno Koivisto, in deference to the 1975 Helsinki Final Act which started the CSCE process, took the place of honor at the table, across from President Francois Mitterrand of France. But at the right of Mitterrand, Cypriot President Georges Vassiliou faced Turkish President Turgut Ozal, despite the long conflict involving the two nations. And U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar had at his left Arnold Koller of Switzerland, the only CSCE country which is not a member of the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: No Hard Feelings: Berlin Wants to Ship Cold-War Provisions to Soviets
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Berliners who fearfully stockpiled tons of meat, milk and grain to guard against a four-decade Soviet threat now want to ship the stored food to people who really need it - the Soviets themselves. Former West Berlin, once pushed to the brink of starvation by a Soviet blockade, has asked the German government to use the old emergency provisions to help ease dire shortages in the Soviet Union. The federal government is expected to make a decision this week. ``The material is not necessary any more, the situation has changed,'' Juergen Varnhorn, a Berlin government spokesman, said Monday. ``So why not help the Soviet Union?'' Berlin's plan to ship supplies to the very nation that made such emergency stockpiles necessary is yet another of the ironies that have followed German unification and Soviet disintegration. Germany now is paying Soviet troops based in eastern Germany and will finance their withdrawal over the next four years. One of those soldiers ran amok early Monday with an armored vehicle, roaring down the Kurfuerstendamm, the main shopping street in former West Berlin. It would have been an international incident during the Cold War, but now is a local police matter. The scores of fortified storehouses stuffed with canned vegetables and fruit, powdered milk and coffee are true relics of the Cold War, and a direct result of the Soviet blockade of West Berlin three years after Germany lost World War II. The Soviets, who had control of the east side of the city and the surrounding territory that was to become East Germany, closed roads, waterways and railroads leading to West Berlin in 1948 in an effort to drive out the Western Allies. West Berliners were confined to the city for 36 days without food and coal. The Allies then launched the famous Berlin airlift, flying 1.8 million tons of goods into the city and breaking the blockade. The Soviets lifted the blockade on May 12, 1949, but tensions worsened and culminated with the construction of the Berlin Wall in 1961. West Berlin, meanwhile, stockpiled enormous quanities of food, clothing and medicine as a hedge against the chance that the Soviets would launch another blockade. That threat evaporated with the opening of the Berlin Wall last year and German unification on Oct. 3, sweeping changes wrought by the reform policies of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Berlin Senate, in a gesture of goodwill, voted to ask Bonn for permission to send the food to the Soviets one week before Gorbachev's Nov. 9 visit to Germany, the first anniversary of the opening of the Berlin Wall. Finance Minister Theo Waigel, in a interview Monday with the German newspaper Die Welt, said the government was considering the proposal as one of the ways Germany could provide relief to the Soviets during what is expected to be a dangerous winter of severe shortages. The supplies include hundreds of thousands of tons of sugar, milk, toothpaste, grain, coal, heating oil and other provisions worth up to $1.6 billion. Varnhorn said only the food supplies would be sent to the Soviets. No decision has been made on what to do with the medicine, clothing and cleaning materials still in storage. Food already is being rationed in several Soviet cities and rationing is to begin next month in Leningrad, the nation's second-largest city. President Bush said he would be willing to provide emergency food supplies and humanitarian aid to the Soviets, and other Western nations have said they also may provide aid to get the politically torn and economically reeling nation through the winter.

DOC.HEAD: 45 Million Turkeys Go into Ovens on Thursday
With AM-Thanksgiving Travel Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many people cook an elaborate feast just once a year, on Thanksgiving. Anthony Dias Blue and his wife, Kathryn K. Blue, think about that dinner all year long, and they have written a book, ``Thanksgiving Dinner'' (HarperCollins), about it. ``This is 20 years of fine-tuning our techniques and dealing with what our children will eat,'' Blue, a widely syndicated wine columnist, said in a recent interview. ``Thanksgiving is not a potluck dinner; it is a complex feast that requires organization and considerable precision,'' the Blues write. And they plan ahead: a menu by Nov. 1, all staples bought two weeks ahead and kept in separate boxes, fresh turkey ordered ahead. On Thursday, an estimated 45 million turkeys will be cooked, and family after family will confront the age-old conundrum of whether to stuff or not. Rick Rodgers, author of ``The Turkey Cookbook,'' recommends roasting a turkey with onions, celery and carrots in its cavities and cooking the stuffing - or dressing - on the side. Although an unstuffed turkey cooks faster and more evenly, and the Blues ``have been on both sides of the big stuffing question'' over the years, Blue said he finds the ``synergism between the turkey and stuffing'' to be more important. The Blues will roast two turkeys, both stuffed, for the 22 people who will be at their dinner Thursday in their home in San Francisco. One turkey will hold a sausage-crouton stuffing, the other an oyster-cornbread stuffing. Their table also will hold a root vegetable puree and other vegetables, cranberry relish, prune chutney, steamed persimmon pudding, pumpkin flan and gingerbread bread pudding. ``There are certain things in every family that have to be made,'' Blue said, adding that for his family, it's Schatze's corn pudding, which his mother made for decades. ``It has things I don't approve of - canned corn, evaporated milk,'' Blue said. But when made with fresh ingredients, it wasn't as good, he said. ``My kids absolutely adore it,'' said Blue, who usually passes it by. But one of the advantages of Thanksgiving dinner is that there are choices. The cook need not double or triple recipes; instead, make more dishes and let people pick and choose, Blue advises. said. ``That's what this is all about - the feast of the harvest. I would never have a strawberry dessert,'' because the fruit is out of season, he said. And he frowns on chocolate for Thanksgiving, although there are three desserts that call for it in his book - the carrot torte, chocolate pecan pie and chocolate-chestnut mousse. On his radio program, Blue said, he once ``tore apart'' a caller who suggested asparagus, fresh in springtime, for Thanksgiving. ``Our delivery system has gotten too good. It takes a little bit of the joy out of the seasonal changes of eating.'' The Blues include 150 recipes from appetizers to leftovers in ``Thanksgiving Dinner.'' They include many from friends in California, but evidence that Thanksgiving is a family holiday include recipes named for their children: Amanda's chocolate carrot torte, Caitlin's potatoes, Jessica's caramelized apple tart and Toby's instant replay sandwich. Thanksgiving certainly is tradition, but not one that officially dates to 1621 and the Pilgrims, the Blues write. The Pilgrims, and others who followed, had meals of thanksgiving from time to time. But a regular, national Thanksgiving holiday began in 1863, when President Lincoln was persuaded by Sarah Josepha Hale, author of ``Mary Had a Little Lamb,'' to declare it so. Under it all, what's so great about Thanksgiving? ``You get to eat a lot and you don't have to give presents,'' Blue jokes.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Ratifies Contract with Chrysler
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union has ratified the last of its three-year contracts with the Big Three automakers, overwhelmingly approving an agreement with CHrysler Corp. The agreement, covering about 63,000 active hourly and salaried workers, was ratified in voting last week by a margin of better than 4-to-1, UAW spokesman Bob Barbee said Monday. Precise figures were unavailable. The union initially focused its bargaining efforts on General Motors Corp., and bargainers reached tentative agreement Sept. 17. Less than a week later, a tentative agreement was reached with Ford Motor Co. The UAW and Chrysler reached tentative agreement Oct. 30. Each contract provides for a 3-percent base wage increase in the first year and 3-percent lump-sum payments in the second and third years, and increases for current and future retirees. They also call for income guarantees for workers laid off for more than 36 weeks from factories closed by sales slumps.

DOC.HEAD: Police Use City Bus to Handle Arrests at Party for Juveniles
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested so many people at a weekend party, including 43 juveniles, that they had to borrow a city bus to carry everyone to jail. The party Saturday night was so big that it spilled out of a house belonging to 53-year-old Hazel Bell and into the street, police said. ``It appears that the kids were being charged $2 a head to get into the party,'' said Police Lt. Bernard Stahl. Neighbors said Ms. Bell often held large parties. Police arrested 43 juveniles, who were charged with curfew violations, and 59 other people who were charged with disorderly conduct, Stahl said. Ms. Bell was charged with contributing to the delinquency of minors.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says It Will More Than Double Troops in Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with detail on Iraqi announcement, Pentagon statement. Pickup 3rd pvs, `On Sunday...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it will send 250,000 more troops to Kuwait, more than doubling its military strength in the occupied kingdom. President Bush dismissed Iraq's promise, made a day earlier, to free all foreigners by March. The troop buildup was announced by the Iraqi News Agency 11 days after Bush said 200,000 more U.S. soldiers would be shipped to the region to bring the American force to 430,000. Previously, Iraq was believed to have about 170,000 troops in Kuwait and about 250,000 men in southern Iraq. President Saddam Hussein and his military commanders met and decided to send seven extra divisions of the regular army and another 150,000 reserves and draftees, the news agency said. ``This means the United States will need to mobilize a 3-million-strong force with similar equipment and armament to our forces'' if it is to attack, the news agency said. In Washington, Pentagon spokesman Lt. Col. Rick Oborn said the department would have no comment on the Iraqi report. On Sunday, Iraq said it would free the estimated 2,000 remaining Westerners stranded in Iraq and occupied Kuwait between Christmas and March 25 ``unless something would take place that mars the atmosphere of peace.'' Saddam has been releasing Westerners a few at a time, and scores of freed Americans flew home from London today. Bush called the Iraqi announcement a bid to buy time. ``This cynicism of starting to release them on Christmas Day will be seen by the world as a total ploy,'' he said in Paris, where NATO and Warsaw Pact leaders signed an arms reduction treaty. Bush used the gathering of 34 leaders to try to win more support for a U.N. resolution authorizing an attack to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Some U.S. allies in the Persian Gulf crisis, including the Soviet Union and Germany, expressed concern that Bush was rushing toward war. But Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain reiterated her support for Bush's position, saying that Saddam can avoid war only by withdrawing quickly from Kuwait. ``Most people understand evil has to be stopped. Either he withdraws, or the military option has to be used,'' she said after seeing Bush in Paris, where NATO and Warsaw Pact leaders signed an arms reduction treaty. However, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he was sure a way could be found to avoid war and that he would offer ``new ideas'' in a meeting with Bush today. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany told Bush on Sunday that all options short of war must first be exhausted. Analysts have said a military strike against Iraqi forces is most likely in winter because of lower temperatures and generally calm weather. Sandstorms usually occur in April. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has met in the past week with foreign ministers from many of the 15 members of the U.N. Security Council, seeking support for the resolution endorsing a military assault if the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq fails. Some diplomats say the proposal could be made before the end of the month. In other developments today, high winds and rough seas forced U.S. Marines to cancel a second attempt to storm a Saudi beach in an amphibious landing exercise. Similar conditions forced the exercise to be scrubbed on Sunday, and officials said no further attempts will be made. Scores of Americans stranded in Iraq and Kuwait left London for Washington today. Seventy-five Americans were among the 136 former hostages freed Sunday by Iraq and flown to London on a U.S.-chartered flight from from Baghdad. Most of the passengers were wives and children of Kuwaitis. ``For four months we have been in hiding,'' said an American woman who would not give her name. ``People are starving and they need food, but people who have food are frightened of giving it to them because they would be accused as collaborators. ``We prayed every night that we would wake up in the morning,'' she said. Douglas Moore, a British soccer coach who worked in Kuwait for four years, said many of those in hiding hope for an invasion. ``The feeling of those in hiding is that the military should come and do something for God's sake. They cannot hang on,'' he said. The Saudi government announced that more than 300 Iraqi officers and soldiers have defected to Saudi Arabia since the invasion of Kuwait. It was the first time that Saudi Arabia had officially confirmed defections. Some defectors have been reported to include Iraqi soldiers with their tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Even Heads of State Have Their Little Troubles
DOC.TEXT: Even heads of state suffer through life's little aggravations. The limousine carrying Hungarian Prime Minister Jozsef Antall to the 34-nation summit cruised grandly down the street - with its national flag upside down. President Bush had a little limo problem too. The door handles on the armored car, flown in from Washington, were torn off when the driver turned a corner a little too tight at the U.S. ambassador's residence Sunday night. New handles were rushed by plane overnight from the United States. When Bush arrived at the Elysee Palace for lunch, it required considerable jiggling to get the door open. Bush waited inside the car as two security agents struggled to open the door. ---= When presidents, prime ministers and premiers gather for a summit, it's a sure bet they'll pose for an official portrait. It's called the class photo. Together, the 34 leaders here may rule much of the world, but it's a real question of who's really the boss. Maybe it's the photographers. The leaders snap to attention at a mere shout from the cameramen. At one point during the shooting of Monday's class photo, the leaders started leaving their assigned positions, apparently having had enough. But the photographers, in unison, shouted ``No!'' Hurriedly, the leaders returned to their assigned positions. Bush and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl finally decided it was time to leave and walked away, so French President Francois Mitterrand, the host, ended the photo session. ---= ``Marvelous,'' President Bush said Monday. ``The Czech guys estimated 750,000.'' It was just an offhand comment to Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers, but it gave voice to a heated debate among White House officials. White House imagemakers are furious about press estimates of the crowd that jammed Prague's historic Wenceslas Square to hear the president on Saturday afternoon. By every account, it was a huge audience. Most press reports put the number at more than 100,000. But White House officials, perhaps sensitive about Bush's sagging popularity at home, were insistent that the audience was much larger. White House press aides said the Secret Service estimated the crowd at more than 1 million, but these same officials said they really didn't believe the Secret Service number. More like 750,000, they suggested. Yet, that estimate was laughed at by veteran crowd counters in Prague, who have watched the square through a year of revolution, demonstrations and celebrations as democracy triumphed. Even when political passions were at their height, the estimate never ran above 300,000 people - and that was when the crowd stood shoulder to shoulder in the long rectangular boulevard. When Bush spoke, the back of the boulevard was empty and there was plenty of space along the sides. Shortly before Bush spoke, Czechoslovak state television estimated the crowd at 100,000; later it said 15,000 more people had arrived. Disbelieving White House officials, however, have been singling out reporters to complain that they short-changed the president. ``An insult to the people of Czechoslovakia,'' one official fumed. Bush's comment to Lubbers apparently puts the argument to rest - at least in the White House.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Leukemia Victim Whose Father Fought for Bone Marrow Transplant Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old leukemia victim whose father waged an unsuccessful legal battle for a potentially life-saving bone marrow transplant died today, a spokesman said. Jean-Pierre Bosze of suburban Hoffman Estates died this morning, said Edward Jordan, the Bosze family attorney. The child's father, Tamas Bosze, sought a landmark court ruling to force Nancy Curran - his former girlfriend and the mother of Jean-Pierre's 3-year-old half siblings - to have the twins tested as possible bone marrow donors. Curran opposed testing the twins, saying the transplant procedure would be too painful. In September, the State Supreme Court affirmed a lower court's ruling in favor of Curran. Bosze insisted the 3-year-olds would want to help their brother if they were old enough to decide. Bosze never divorced Jean-Pierre's mother, and had twins with Curran while the married couple was separated. Jean-Pierre's doctors, meanwhile, had warned that his condition was worsening. Bosze initially petitioned the courts in June. In the initial lower court ruling, Cook County Circuit Judge Monica Reynolds held Sept. 6 that forcing the twins to take a blood test to determine whether they could be marrow donors for Jean-Pierre would violate their constitutional right to privacy. Bone marrow donations can save the lives of victims of leukemia and other diseases if a donor with closely matching tissue types - usually a relative - can be found. Bosze approached Curran after tests showed that he, Jean-Pierre's mother, Jean-Pierre's brother and another half sister were all incompatible. The marrow is extracted from the donor by inserting a long needle into the hipbone or breast bone. A motion for the Illinois Supreme Court to reconsider its decision was pending.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp
Kuwaiti Emir Warns Paris Summit Time Running Out
DOC.TEXT: The exiled emir of Kuwait sent a message to the summit of 34 world leaders in Paris on Monday, saying time was of paramount importance in removing Iraqi troops from his country. The continuing occupation of Kuwait will eventually jeopardize world peace and security, Sheik JAber al-AHmed al-Sabah said in the message reported by the Kuwait News Agency. ``At a time when the world is laying the foundations of a new international order based on justice, peace and detente, Iraq has dealt a deadly blow to these principles by its occupation of an independent state,'' said the emir. The 34 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe are meeting to discuss the shape of the world now that Cold War divisions have ended. But the summit, at which the Western and Eastern military pacts also signed a treaty relegating thousands of their weapons to the scrap heap, has been overshadowed by the Persian Gulf crisis. Presidents Bush and MIkhail Gorbachev, along with the other leaders, are discussing how best to get Iraq out of Kuwait. Iraq's aggression has been directed at citizens of the nations represented at the Paris gathering, said the emir, ``using them as instruments in a humiliating exploitation of human dignity and rights.'' President Saddam Hussein is holding hundreds of Westerners hostage. ``It has thus become clear that the effects of the Iraqi aggression have not stopped at Kuwait, but have exceeded it to hit at the world peace and security,'' he said. But the Emir said he was satisfied with the ``courageous, immediate and decisive'' stand taken by the international community against Saddam. The Kuwaiti government has been residing in the Saudi Arabian mountain resort of Taif since its members fled the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
