The official news agency also is operating in exile.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Man Sought Since 1979 For Stealing Ancient Objects
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday announced the arrest of a 59-year-old German archaeologist wanted since 1979 on charges of stealing ancient objects. Police said Stefan Martin Gericke was arrested Sunday after police found 33 ancient objects in his Athens apartment and trailer home. Included were a prehistoric stone head, a bronze urn from the fourth century B.C. and a wine vessel dating to about 1450 B.C. The most recent items were from Roman times. Gericke refused to answer questions, a police spokesman said. ``Undoubtedly, he is the biggest, most dangerous and most Ruthless antiquities thief ever to pass through Greece,'' the spokeman said. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Gericke was sentenced to 8{ years in prison for stealing antiques in 1968 and was held for another 18 months in 1979 on similar charges. He was released before trial and disappeared. ``He was able to evade arrest for so long because of his ability to disguise himself with wigs, beards, false teeth, and so on,'' the police spokesman said. Police also found false identity cards and a false driver's license and credit card in Gericke's possession, the officer said. He said Gericke had large bank deposits in several countries, including Switzerland, Germany, and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 60 Children Taken Ill In School; Apparent Carbon Monoxide Leak
DOC.TEXT: More than 60 children were evacuated from a grade school today after complaining of headaches and nausea apparently caused by leaking carbon monoxide, authorities said. Students were being taken to hospitals in Newton and El Dorado to be examined, said Ron Morrison, a Butler County undersheriff. Some of the children lost consciousness but were revived outside the school, he said. Morrison said. Those who were most seriously overcome were taken to hospitals by ambulance, Morrison said. School buses were being used to transport the others, he said. Emergency workers were called to Potwin's elementary school about 11:45 a.m. Potwin is a town of about 550 people in south-central Kansas.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Dispute Adds Drama to ELection Campaign Dominated by Kohl
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Less than two weeks before national elections, Chancellor Helmut Kohl is being toasted as a statesman in Paris - but reviled by some at home over possible tax increases. Opposition leaders claim Germans soon will be paying more to the state to finance the costly merger of the two Germanys, despite the chancellor's pledge to the contrary. The dispute has added some drama to an election campaign that many had figured was decided even before it started. Polls indicate Kohl will win a landslide victory on Dec. 2 in the first all-German elections since 1933. A new poll by the ZDF television network indicated that Kohl and his conservative party allies would win 45.5 percent of the vote nationwide - more than enough for his Christian Democrats to form another strong coalition with the centrist Free DEmocrats. ZDF said the pollsters questioned 1,000 people in former EAst Germany and 1,000 in former West Germany at the beginning of this month. Kohl's prestige has been bolstered by a continuing round of international attention. He is representing the united Germany at the 34-nation summit in Paris. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush have each come calling at his home in the village of Oggersheim in recent days. And it's been less than seven weeks since Kohl led the solemn unification ceremonies at the stately Reichstag, as the German flag was hoisted in the light of hundreds of glittering fireworks. But uncertainty over the merger costs has many Germans worried. The West German national debt stood at $647 billion in June, even before the East German debt was added to it. The euphoria over the fall of the Berlin Wall a little more than a year ago has given way to the harsh reality of what it will cost to overhaul the former East Germany. Some estimates have put the Private and public costs in the hundreds of billions of dollars. And in a country where ordinary workers pay more than 40 percent of their wages in taxes and other government-mandated social benefit programs, the talk of higher taxes has many up in arms. Even Kohl has been talking about the possibility. He told the Stadtsanzeiger newspaper of Cologne that Germans soon will have to pay more ``in one area or another'' in the form of taxes or ``fees'' collected by the government. Kohl said he had never said there wouldn't be tax increases - just that there wouldn't be any increases specifically to finance German unification. HIs finance minister, Theo Waigel, in an interview with Der Spiegel magazine, mentioned ``fees in the environmental area.'' Such fees, as yet not precisely spelled out, would be aimed at cutting down on motor vehicle pollution and raising revenues for ecological clean-up projects, among other things. Oskar Lafontaine of the opposition Social Democrats, the challenger for the chancellor's job, seized on the remarks, saying Kohl was trying to hide the costs of unification. ``Now the cat is out of the bag,'' he told reporters Monday. ``No one in Germany believed any more that the exploding national debt could be tamed without taxes and fees being raised.'' Lafontaine said he would seek a parliamentary debate on the tax issue on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 40 Reported Hurt As Police, Demonstrators Clash
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators demanding the resignation of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad staged protests in three cities on Monday, and police and news reports said at least 40 people were hurt in clashes. In Dhaka, thousands of protesters marched through the streets urging the resignation of Ershad, a 60-year-old former army general who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982. Police in the port city of Chittagong said anti-government rallies erupted in violence and at least 10 people were injured. At least 30 people were injured in the city of Bogra, 100 miles northwest of Dhaka, when government supporters attacked opposition workers, United News of Bangladesh reported. Opposition parties say a caretaker government should replace Ershad and hold elections within three months of its installation. The opposition says all elections held under his Ershad government Have been rigged. The president has promised to hold presidential elections next year under the supervision of foreign observers. Addressing a rally of about 50,000 people in an industrial suburb of Dhaka, Ershad accused the opposition of ``terrorism and Destructive acts.'' The campaign against Ershad is being led by the Awami League party led by Sheik Hasina and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party of Khaleda Zia. The two leaders have apparently put aside political DIfferences for the time being to join forces in the anti-Ershad campaign. The opposition has called a 24-hour strike starting at dawn Tuesday to press for the president's resignation. The strike, originally planned to last two days, was curtailed to allow the army to celebrate the 19th anniversary of its founding on Wednesday. On Sunday, supporters and opponents of Ershad fought each other with crude bombs, guns and rocks. The clashes left at least 29 people injured, doctors and news reports said Monday.

DOC.HEAD: 5-Year-Old Wakes Up to Find Drunken Sailor in Next Bed
DOC.TEXT: What do you do with a drunken sailor? For a 5-year-old boy who woke up and found a stranger in the next bed, the answer was obvious: Call mom and dad. The youngster woke his parents at about 7 a.m. Sunday. ``There's a stranger in my other bed,'' he said. Indeed, a man was fast asleep - fully dressEd under the covers. The parents called police, who came to the apartment and woke the uninvited guest. The intruder, a 22-year-old Navy man, told police he had no idea how he'd gotten there, according to a report in Monday's San Jose Mercury News. Apologetically, the sailor confessed to having had too much to drink Saturday night. He climbed in an open window and went to bed, thinking he was sneaking into his Moffett Field barracks about half a mile away. The family didn't press charges and police let the sailor go. The newspaper did not identify the family or the sailor. Mountain View is about 45 miles south of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Court's Ruling Against CNN Creates Loophole For GAg Orders Against Press
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's handling of the CNN-Noriega free-press dispute creates a loophole for short-lived ``gag orders'' against the news media. Although the court 14 years ago told judges they almost never may bar the reporting of information already in news media hands, Sunday's 7-2 vote left intact such a restraint against Cable News Network. The high court's action, however, was not unprecedented and may not have set any lasting rule of law. CNN had asked the justices to lift an order by U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler in Miami forbidding the broadcast of conversations between Manuel Noriega, the imprisoned former dictator of Panama, and his lawyers. FEderal prison authorities monitor and tape record all inmates' telephone conversations except when told that inmates are talking to their lawyers. But CNN reportedly has seven tapes containing some conversations between Noriega and his defense team. When Noriega's lawyers rushed into court to prevent the tapes from being broadcast, the judge ordered CNN to let him hear the tapes so he could determine whether fair-trial rights would be jeopardized. And the judge ruled that CNN could not broadcast the tapes until his determination was made. The cable network, citing a series of Supreme Court decisions, carried its fight to Washington rather than surrender the tapes. Now, CNN will submit the tapes to Hoeveler and await his decision on whether they may be broadcast. The ordered delay is itself a prior restraint on reporting - something the Supreme Court in 1976 called ``the most serious and least tolerable infringement'' of free-press rights. In a key 1976 ruling, the court unanimously struck down a gag order barring the news media from publishing a Nebraska murder defendant's confession after it was revealed in a public court hearing. Two of the seven justices who voted against CNN Sunday said in 1976 they seriously doubted whether such prior restraints ever could be valid. Writing for himself in the Nebraska case, Justice Byron R. White said, ``There is grave doubt in my mind whether orders with respect to the press such as were entered in this case would ever be justified.'' In the same case, Justice John Paul Stevens wrote he might rule the press never can bE barred from reporting information it has ``no matter how shabby or illegal the means by which the information is obtained, how serious an intrusion on privacy might be involved, how demonstrably false the information might be, how prejudicial it might be ... and how perverse the motivation for publishing it.'' Those views could indicate Sunday's vote centered on some issue narrower than the constitutionality of Hoeveler's gag order. If the judge, after listening to the tapes, decides to continue his ban, CNN could return to the high court. The justices would not be precluded from ruling at that time that CNN's free-press rights were violated. To some, such a scenario might seem contradictory. But similar action was taken before the 1976 ruling - Justice HArry A. Blackmun rejected an emergency request to lift the Nebraska judge's restraining order pending the full court's decision. In 1971, the court ruled the government could not bar The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing stories based on the so-called Pentagon papers detailing U.S. involvement in Vietnam. But for five days the newspapers were barred by a high court order from publishing such stories pending its decision. And in 1979 the justices rejected an emergency request by The Progressive magazine, which was then under an order blocking publication of an article the government said would help other nations develop a hydrogen bomb. The high court refused to order a federal appeals court to speed up its review of a restraining order issued by a trial judge. The ban on publishing was in effect for more than seven months. Floyd Abrams, a First Amendment expert representing CNN, said Sunday's action ``left an opening through which defense lawyers and prosecutors may try to muzzle news articles.'' But if such tactics are allowed by lower courts, Abrams said, the Supreme Court might intervene. If CNN is not allowed to broadcast its tapes, such Supreme Court intervention may not be far off. --- EDitor's Note: Richard Carelli has covered the Supreme Court for The Associated Press since 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Back In Pittsburgh Hospital to Check for Organ Rejection
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old multiple-transplant patient suffered a setback and was undergoing tests Monday to determine if she is rejecting the liver and small intestines. Tracey Kay Gonzales of Corpus Christi, Texas, was admitted Sunday night to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh because she had diarrhea, said hospital spokeswoman Sue Cardillo. She was listed in fair condition. Doctors ordered a biopsy of the organs Tracey received on July 24. The tests will take up to two days, Ms. Cardillo said. ``DOctors don't know exactly what the underlying problem is,'' Ms. Cardillo said. ``Is it a virus, is it rejection or is it another problem? It could be something as simple as a cold.'' Despite the diarrhea, Tracey was ``up and around and being her spunky little self,'' Ms. Cardillo said. Transplants of small intestines have a poor success rate. Since 1983, one adult and three children have died within a year of their operations at Pittsburgh hospitals. ONe adult patient is still alive. Tracey has been doing well and living in Pittsburgh with her Mother, Pam, since her operation. Still, doctors are reluctant to predict what the future may hold for her. ``It sounds cliche to say we are in uncharted territory, but it's a fact,'' Ms. Cardillo said. ``You can't make long-term predictions.'' Tracey is taking the experimental drug FK506, which doctors say is safer and more potent than the common anti-rejection drug cyclosporin. She needed the transplant operation because she suffered from short gut syndrome, which left her small intestine unable to absorb nutrition. Her liver was damaged by a high-protein diet fed intravenously.

DOC.HEAD: Butchers Hand Out Free Ham Sandwiches To Protest Pork Sale Ban
DOC.TEXT: Butchers on Monday handed out hundreds of free ham sandwiches in downtown Jerusalem to protest government efforts to limit the sale of pork to appease ultra-Orthodox JEws. In Tel Aviv, left-wing protesters gathered in front of the Likud party headquarters and distributed black veils to women passing by, saying Israel was on the way to becoming a theocracy like Iran. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has promised to push the anti-pork law and other sweeping religious legislation through Parliament in exchange for the support of the small, ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel Party, which joined his ruling coalition last week. Observant Jews are forbidden to eat pork because it is not kosher, or permitted under Jewish dietary law. Shouting ``Pork! Pork!'' the butchers passed out the sandwiches in Jerusalem's pedestrian mall, Israel radio reported. The protest drew angry responses from some passers-by. ``We are in the middle of the most religious city in the world, and I think it's digusting that people have the gall and the nerve to hand out ham sandwiches,'' one woman said on the radio. With Agudat Israel's support, Shamir now has a 64-seat majority in the 120-seat Parliament. In the past, he governed with a 60-member coalition and a promise of support from two right-wing Legislators. But Shamir's agreement to back the religious legislation has prompted angry protests from some secular Israelis, a majority in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Scraps Tax-and-Spend Image With an Ax
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo, eschewing his tax-and-spend reputation, has proposed sharp spending cuts to eliminate a $1 billion state budget deficit even he thinks could affect his political future. ``All around us there are signs of fiscal collapse,'' Cuomo said Monday of the money problems facing New York, many other states and the nation. Cuomo's plan for plugging the hole in New York's $30 billion state budget calls for firing at least 2,000 state workers before the end of the fiscal year on March 31 and eliminating 4,000 other jobs through attrition and early retirement. Every other state worker - there are almost 250,000 - would have to take five days off without pay by the end of the fiscal year. Cuomo also called for reduced spending on schools and on poor people seeking health care. This is the state's third straight year of budget deficits. In the past two years, Cuomo and the Legislature have raised taxes by almost $3 billion, including a record $1.8 billion hike earlier this year, No more, Cuomo said. ``NEw taxes would damage our competitive position in a weakening economy,'' he explained. ``It is obvious that the problem is national, and will need national remedies,'' Cuomo also said. ``But we cannot wait for Washington.'' Cuomo, considered a potential 1992 Democratic presidential contender, unveiled his budget plan Saturday, less than two weeks after voters rejected his proposed $2 billion environmental bond issue and gave him a smaller than expected re-election margin to a third term. He got 53 percent of the vote, compared with a record 65 percent in 1986 when he won a second term. ``They said `No taxes,'' Cuomo said of the voters. Cuomo, who according to recent polls is the favorite among DEmocrats for the party's presidential nomination, has said that unless he puts the state's fiscal house in order, there's no point in even discussing a run for the White House. While Cuomo said there would be screams of protest because of his proposed cuts, business interests praised the action. ``Politicians often say that government must do more with less. Governor Cuomo's plan gives substance to that statement,'' said Daniel Walsh, president of the Business Council of New York State. Cuomo, who in past years often has said government must learn ``to do more with less,'' has been frequently criticized by the council for allowing state spending to grow at more than twice the rate of inflation. ``It's a major departure from the last couple of years,'' Raymond Horton, president of the NEw York City-based Citizens Budget Commission, a business-financed budget watchdog group, said of Cuomo's proposals. LEe Miringoff, head of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion that regularly tracks New Yorkers' sentiments about Cuomo, said Monday that the governor may have had an eye on the national scene when he prepared his budget plan. ``To some degree this could represent a political inoculation for him,'' Miringoff said of Cuomo's call for spending cuts instead of higher taxes. Nonetheless, Miringoff said Cuomo has to worry about alienating his own core constituency - liberals, labor and minorities - as he moves to a more fiscally conservative position. Miringoff noted that when Cuomo became governor in 1983, he told New Yorkers: ``We should have only the government we need, but we must insist on all the government we need.'' ``He's gone with `Only the government we need,''' Miringoff said of the latest budget plan.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Washes Out Marine Exercise
LaserPhotos DOD1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: Waves washed away the U.S. military's Marine amphibious assault on a beachhead MOnday, which Had been intended to show Iraq a possible opening scene in a war to free Kuwait. It was a glaring example of how the best laid plans can go awry in combat. In this dress rehearsal, cameras were ready to roll but the weather, which has been a key but fickle factor in wars through the ages, decided not to cooperate for the second day in a row. The Marines would have gone ahead with a landing Sunday in a real war, but it wasn't worth the risk to life and equipment in peacetime, said Maj. Gen. Harry W. Jenkins Jr., commander of the Marine Expeditionary Brigade. Footage of U.S. Marines storming a Saudi beach was supposed to be the visual centerpiece of the first joint U.S.-Saudi military exercise, named Imminent Thunder. In the broader combat exercise that ends Wednesday, the washout was relatively insignificant. But in the high-stakes game of psychological warfare, it was something of a dud. BEfore Sunday's attempted assault, Marine Maj. John Toolan said he spoke to his troops about ``the fourth dimension of warfare,'' How the media helps spread the message about the power of the U.S. armed forces. ``When Saddam Hussein sees the Marines and Navy working so well together, we'll make more money without ever firing a shot,'' he said. craft skim over the water at 50 mph because 14-foot waves and high wind made them difficult to launch. The American public, and undoubtedly some Iraqis, did get to see helicopter-borne Saudi and U.S. troops land on the beach Sunday and join Saudi and U.S. ground forces. A rendezvous Sunday between Saudi marines and a company of the Marine's 3rd Light Armored Infantry marked the first time a regular U.S. Marine unit was allowed close to the Kuwaiti border. ``This is the first time that any of us have been this far north,'' said another Marine officer, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Our objective is to locate the enemy, find gaps in his defenses and report back,'' said the battalion executive officer, Maj. Jeff Powers, 35, of Ridgefield, N.J. On Monday, the Marines participated in a simulated armored attack. For the most part, Marine officers said they were satisfied the invading Iraqi tanks would have been spotted and destroyed, although one unit briefly slipped past the defending force. No live ammunition or blanks were fired. The exercise was repeated later Monday to give aircraft a chance to spot the invading tanks and direct imaginary fire. The 1,100 U.S., British and French combat aircraft taking part in Imminent Thunder represent the largest use of aircraft in a training exercise since the multinational deployment. Jenkins said Sunday the mock aerial attacks were a success. But there was no media pool coverage of the aerial operation and it was impossible to assess from the groundconfusing and everybody needs to understand that,'' Brig. Gen. Mike Myatt, commander of Marine ground forces, said in a recent interview. ``We've trained Marine officers to deal with uncertainty. If you're used to having 100 percent of information before you act, you'll be defeated.'' Edward Foster, a researcher with the London-based Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies, said any exercise requires flexibility. The biggest amphibious landing ever undertaken, the D-Day landing on the Normandy coast on June 6, 1944, ``went ahead 24 hours later than planned because of the weather,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Lingerie' Show Broadcast at MCDonald's
DOC.TEXT: One Big Mac, hold the dressing. McDonald's workers trying to handle a noon-hour rush were confused when they started getting orders for pink teddies and black brassieres instead of Big Macs and fries. A glitch sent chatter from an emcee at a nightclub holding a lingerie ``fashion show'' Friday to the headsets worn by workers at the McDonald's next door. Confused order-takers at McDonald's heard the solicitations at Ziegfield's Restaurant and Bar. ``Gentlemen, you can invite the lovely models over to your table to investigate the quality of this sexy lingerie. I think it's perfectly OK to let those ladies know - with a little financial endeavor - if you would like to have them come over,'' the emcee said. Ziegfield's had been closed since August after a Johnson County district judge ruled its erotic dancing shows violated a city zoning ordinance that prohibits live entertainment in the area of the Kansas City suburb. But it reopened Friday, saying it now would offer a ``fashion show'' featuring ``girls, girls, girls'' in lingerie and bathing suits. Dan Eckman, the McDonald's owner, made a quick call to Ziegfield's and the problem was solved when the emcee moved to another microphone. But Ziegfield's problems didn't end there. A few hours after the show started, police arrived and closed it again. Police handed out 13 citations, 12 for allegedly violating a zoning ordinance and one For nudity.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Says Remains Of Eleven May Be Those Of Americans
DOC.TEXT: The Vietnamese government plans to repatriate 11 remains that may be those of Americans listed as missing in Southeast Asia, the Pentagon said Monday. A U.S. repatriation team is to receive the remains in Hanoi on Tuesday and fly them to the U.S. Army Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii to attempt to establish individual identification, it said. In recent high-level meetings with U.S. government representatives, Vietnam has pledged to speed up its efforts to account for the more than 2,200 Americans missing in Southeast Asia since the war in Indochina.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf to delete extraneous `we' from quotation.
DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Refuses To Endorse Use of Force
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, refusing to endorse the use of military force against Iraq, said today, ``We All need patience'' in the Persian Gulf crisis. Gorbachev made the statement as he began a meeting with President Bush during a 34-nation summit. It appears to dash U.S. hopes for winning immediate Soviet support for a United Nations resolution authorizing military action to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Asked whether he would endorse such a resolution, Gorbachev said, ``Well, I think we all need patience. But that does not mean that we are going to relax, that we are going to retreat.'' Bush tried to deflect questions, saying he was looking forward to their talks and a dinner tonight. ``I'm very pleased with the way the Soviet Union and the United States can work together in the United Nations. There continues to be very open-minded communications and I have no reason to be anything other than very satisfied,'' Bush said. Gorbachev told reporters, ``I think you must know we're not going to change our position. We certainly seek to resolve that situation and we must be firm in our position.'' As their meeting began at the U.S. Embassy residence, the lights in the building went dark. The room was lit by the lights of a camera team positioned in the room until the power returned several minutes later. The two leaders had been scheduled to hold a news conference at the conclusion of tonight's talks, but that session was canceled without explanation. Earlier in the day, Bush said he would be willing to provide emergency food supplies and humanitarian aid to the Soviet Union, saying, ``I worry about the Soviet people during the bleak winter coming up.'' Bush made his suggestion in advance of a two-hour meeting tonight with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose country is reeling under political and economic turmoil. The crisis in the Persian Gulf also was high on the agenda for their talks. GOrbachev appears far more reluctant than Bush to use military force to get Iraq out of Kuwait, insisting that diplomacy and an economic embargo against Baghdad be given more time to work. In his earlier comments, Bush said Gorbachev ``has been very solid in support of the United Nations'' and the resolutions approved by the Security Council to squeeze Iraq with financial pressure. Asked about Gorbachev's confidence that the gulf crisis can be resolved peacefully, Bush said, ``I'm anxious to know if there's something new that he's thinking of, but I can't think what it Is.'' Over the past month, Gorbachev has been touring EUropean capitals in search of financial and moral support for his embattled program of reforms. Secretary of State James BAker said Sunday the United States had not been asked for food or money. But U.S. officials said last week they were preparing contingency plans in case of a Soviet request. Bush, during a morning news conference with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, appeared sympathetic to the plight of America's onetime chief adversary. ``We would always be open-minded on humanitarian aid if there's a real need there,'' Bush said. Although U.S. law limits direct economic assistance to Moscow, Bush said the United States could help alleviate food shortages, For example. ``And that's the right and humane thing to do as a country moves towards us and relations are greatly improved. ANd I would want to try to help,'' he said. Food rationing will begin next month in Leningrad, the country's second largest city. Some smaller cities have been rationing for more than a year. In Moscow, some items such as sugar are restricted. The city council is debating whether to issue coupon booklets. ``I worry about the Soviet people during the bleak winter coming up if ... it proves to be as severe as some of the reports indicate,'' Bush said. He said, ``We want to try to help with the evolution of market systems and the evolution - the change that's taking place. And you also want to help new friends when you find them - if they're in jeopardy.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Protest; Refugees' Court Case Begins
DOC.TEXT: More than 5,000 Vietnamese boat people staged a peaceful sit-in at a detention center Monday as the High Court began reviewing the government's policy of screening refugees. GOrdon Tam of the Correctional Services Department said the Vietnamese outside the suburban Whitehead detention center chanted slogans decrying forced repatriation and carried banners saying they would rather die than go back to Vietnam. The protesters also said they opposed a new agreement reached in September by the U.N High Commissioner for Refugees, Britain and Vietnam under which Hanoi has agreed to accept boat people who do not object to returning. The U.N. agency has said it knows of more than 100 Vietnamese who do not object to returning home. Radio Hong Kong said the first such returnees are expected to head for Vietnam NOv. 29. Tam said no trouble was reported during the hourlong demonstration at Whitehead, which houses 24,000 Vietnamese boat people. He declined to say if the protest was directly linked to Monday's High Court review of the cases of nine Vietnamese refugees. The eight men and one woman are challenging the government's policy of screening refugees. Under the 2-year-old policy, Vietnamese who cannot prove they fled Vietnam because of religious or political persecution face repatriation. Daniel Fung, lawyer for the nine, said immigration officers responsible for screening refugees were intolerant, impatient and ignorant. He argued the screening process was flawed and said all nine should be granted refugee status. There are now some 54,000 VIetnamese in Hong Kong. ONly about 8,000 of them arrived before the screening policy was introduced.

DOC.HEAD: Railroads Pay More Than $8 Million In Fines In FIscal 1990
DOC.TEXT: Violations of federal safety regulations cost railroads and freight shippers more than $8.3 million in civil penalties during a recent 12-month period, the FEderal Railroad Administration said Monday. The penalties, the highest in a decade, included $3.2 million collected for violating regulations on the shipment of hazardous materials. They were assessed during the 1990 fiscal year which ended on Sept. 30. The railroad administration imposes civil penalties as a means of making management more aware of threats to rail safety, according to administrator Gil Carmichael. He said this approach has been effective, leading to significant safety improvements since 1978. The railroad administrator said these include: -A 73 percent decline in train accidents. -A 60 percent decline in hazardous material releases. -A 63 percent decline in on-duty employee injuries. -A 60 percent decline in on-duty employee fatalities. The agency also said that since 1978 the rate of train accidents per million miles has decreased from 15 to 4.96, a two-thirds reduction. The penalties were assessed for violations including those Involving track, locomotives, freight cars, signals and operating practices.

DOC.HEAD: Ten Deaths A Day Reported in Political Unrest This Year
DOC.TEXT: An average of 10 people have died each day this year in political violence, making 1990 the deadliest year in South Africa since widespread unrest erupted six years ago, researchers said MOnday. In a sign of the increasing bloodshed, the bodies of 19 men who had been hacked and shot were found scattered across a field in a black township Monday. Police said they did not know the motive for the slayings. Twenty-one other people died in unrest-related attacks over the weekend, including two white police officers and a black man ambushed in a township on the east coast Monday, officials said. The independent South African Institute of Race Relations said 3,038 people had been killed in political unrest since January 1, or about 10 each day. That was about three times the daily death rate for the same period last year, the institute said. ``1990 alone already accounts for more than a third of all the people killed in political violence over this six-year period'' since September 1984, the report said. Rioting broke out Sept. 3, 1984, in black townships near Johannesburg during a work stoppage to protest rent increases. THe unrest spread to other areas of the country as blacks began rising up against apartheid policies. Unlike the early years of racial unrest, when security forces caused most deaths, today's victims are usually blacks killed by other blacks, the institute said. It said the spillover of black factional fighting from Natal Province to the Johannesburg area accounted for much of the 1990 increase in deaths. Since August, more than 800 blacks have died in the townships around Johannesburg. Most were victims of clashes between the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on methods for fighting it and on their vision for a future South Africa. Some township residents said Zonkwezizwe, outside Johannesburg, had been hit by factional unrest, but the motive for the slayings of the 19 men found there Monday was unclear. Police said there was no report of fighting in Zonkwezizwe during the weekend, and patrols did not detect any trouble Sunday night, when the slayings apparently occurred. The bodies were in a field about 80 yards from the nearest houses. Heavily armed patrols moved into the township Monday to prevent further unrest. Also Monday, police announced they had detained six people, including three British subjects, in connection with an explosion near a black taxi stand in Pretoria on Aug. 11. The explosion injured a dozen people. There have been a series of bomb attacks in South African cities in recent months, and police have blamed most of them on right-wing extremists opposed to President F.W. de Klerk's racial reforms.

DOC.SECOND: Baltic Foreign Ministers Excluded From Summit
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of the three Baltic republics were barred entry Monday to the 34-nation European summit, apparently because of Soviet objections. The ministers from the breakaway Soviet republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia had been in Paris since Thursday, lobbying for a formal role in the three-day Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. They reported receiving encouragement from several participating countries, including the United STates, to attend either as official observers or as ``special guests'' of France. On Monday, the World Federation of Free Latvians said that France had withdrawn its invitation because of Soviet objections. Under the ground rules of the conference, all decisions must be made by consensus, and one nation can in effect veto actions supported by other participants. According to the federation, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze protested the FRench invitation and said the Baltic officials could participate as part of the Soviet delegation if they wished. Daniel Bernard, spokesman for the French Foreign Ministry, confirmed that the Baltic officials had been told they could not participate in the summit because of the consensus rule. He declined to discuss the Soviet role in the matter. The three Baltic officials were Lennart Meri of Estonia, Algirdas Saudargas of Lithuania, and Janis Jurkans of Latvia.

DOC.HEAD: PARIS: coming century.
DOC.TEXT: In the process, however, we must bear in mind that Europe is only a part of the world, a world whose destinies are shaped not only here but beyond the boundaries of our continent in places where the winds of change are also making themselves felt. The world's overriding objective is building a more secure and civilized world so that instead of military force our world order would be based on equitable dialogue, on a balance of interest, and on the ability to find a consistent path between sovereignty and the integrity of the human race where it stands today. Concern over the survival of the human race is no longer centered almost exclusively on removing the threat of nuclear war, as it was only a short time ago, but it is increasingly focused on non-military global problems, among them the environment, energy, food and water supplies, social ills, crime, mass poverty, foreign debt, and so on. What is particularly remarkable is the developing international solidarity that is emerging as we tackle all these problems. However, we would be succumbing to impermissible euphoria should we conclude that by achieving the great accomplishment, that having virtually eliminated the threat of a major war in Europe, we thought that we totally ruled out the possibility of conflict in the continent. At the moment, each country is in the process of a vigorous search for the place it could occupy in a future system. This search can be productive only if we remain aware of two major realities in our world. Namely, that multivalent social and political development is not only inevitable, but it's also fruitful, and that this cannot be ignored without rendering meaningless the principle of freedom of choice, because we all need and value the partnership and mutual accommodation that are incompatible with nationalistic selfishness, or parochial isolationism. Failure to take into account that multivalent or polyphonic aspect of advancement, or any attempt to impose any particular way of life on someone else as a precondition to be met before cooperation is envisaged, abound to breed suspicion, mistrust, militant nationalism and reckless separatism. That way like conflicts - animosity, the Balkanization or even worse, the Lebanization of entire regions, either of which would slow down the establishment of a shared Europe so essential to the European process. THerefore, it would seem desirable immediately after the Paris meeting to proceed to the establishment of structures and institutions that would be truly capable of shaping the economic, environmental and technological foundation for a new Europe. This would offer the only truly democratic chance of exerting a positive influence on internal developments in a number of countries and protecting them from dangerous outbreaks of nationalism and separatism. The claims to territorial changes that result from nationalism and separatism would seem particularly unacceptable, for once the process has begun, it may train a destructive snowball effect that would throw Europe back into the kind of situation which it knows only too well from its own history. While developing into a system of states, Europe remains a continent of countries and nations that are open to cooperation with one another in a variety of ways. These two factors balance each other, making for stability in these new conditions. THe notion of a European space covers more than the territory from the Atlantic to the Urals. It includes the Soviet Union as far as the Pacific, as well as the United States and Canada, inseparably linked as they are with the Old World by the bonds of common history. If the European process gains the necessary momentum, each nation will be able to rely in the foreseeable future, if we pool our assets, on the potential for an unprecedentedly powerful community of nations, spanning almost the whole of the upper part of the globe. structures, the first outline for a European home? We favor an active and prompt continuation of the Vienna negotiations, with the participation of all 34 states, which alongside further cuts in their armed forces and changes in the structure of these could proceed to the elaboration of new and comprehensive confidence building measures. It would be desirable to combine in the Vienna II framework the two negotiating components of the first phase. It's time we broadened their agenda through inclusion of other types of weapons, above all else naval armaments. Of course, the political and psychological changes we have noted and welcomed have brought to the fore the issue of tactical nuclear weapons in Europe. We would be prepared to start negotiations on that subject within another month or two. Our proposal jointly to give some thought to the concept of what exactly we mean by minimal deterrence, and where to draw the line beyond which nuclear retaliatory capability may develop into an offensive capability, is indicative of our willingness to proceed gradually towards the elimination of that capability, without overdramatizing existing differences of opinion on the role of nuclear weapons per se. We are also prepared promptly to set about substantive discussions of the open skies issue. The situation of Europe is in transience. It will apparently take some time before we're able to grasp all the changes taking place in our day. But what counts is our shared understanding that it must be a time of peaceful change. That is why starting work on institutionalizing the European process would be one of the major practical results to stem from this meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sets Himself on Fire at Capitol
DOC.TEXT: outside the U.S. Capitol, officials said. The man, who was not immediately identified, was pronounced dead at the scene, a District of Columbia Fire Department spokesman said. The incident occurred on the West Front of the Capitol, facing the Mall that stretches from the Capitol to the Lincoln Memorial. It happened shortly before 2 p.m. EST, according to fire department spokesman Capt. Ted Holmes. Officer Dan Nichols of the Capitol police said the man used ``some kind of accelerant'' to feed the flames. There was no immediate indication that the incident was connected to any political cause, said Nichols. Congress is not in session, reducing the amount of activity around the building. A tourist from Iowa who was coming out of the Capitol when the fire occurred said she saw black smoke and the man ablaze. ``He stood for quite a while,'' said the woman, who declined to give her name. ``A lot of people were watching. ... He laid down and was reaching out of the fire.'' Nichols said the man was burned too badly to identify by race or age. He said police made a sweep of the area with canine teams and were looking for something that would identify the victim.

DOC.HEAD: PARIS: this meeting.
DOC.TEXT: Among the trailblazing decisions to set up a three-tier mechanism, I would wish to single out the conflict prevention center designed to provide settlements, as it were, for political-military situations that might arise. We find it highly promising as it may gradually develop into a kind of all-European Security Council that would have effective means to extinguish the sparks of any possible conflict. The two years between now and Helsinki II will be a trial period to test the unprecedented mechanism for European interactions to be set in motion here in Paris. Understanding an agreement on the role played by the United States and the Soviet Union appear to be of the greatest importance during the transitional period. No matter what difficulties the Soviet Union may face today, it will remain a great world and European factor, playing an innovative and stabilizing role in line with its huge potential. On the subject of the military alliances, the Warsaw Treaty Organization and NATO; the Warsaw Treaty member countries are likely to take important decisions before the end of this year on transforming the organization and changing its character. It is, of course, for the NATO member countries to take any NATO related decisions. Hopefully, the transformation of the alliance as already announced will assume a bolder attitude in taking stock of the profound and apparently irreversible changes underway in Europe. The outcome of the decisions we're about to take here will to a great extent depend on the attitude and activity of existing international structure, which has proved effective and gained useful - (inaudible) - I'm referring here to the European Community, the Council of Europe, European parliamentary institutions, Western European and international economic organizations, non-government research and information centers, and of course inter-party and inter-labor associations. Both their ability to adapt in new developments and also the willingness and ability to cooperate with them of non-members constitutes a highly complex issue that needs time before it can be properly tackled, particularly in the light of the huge gap in the social, economic legacy of the various European countries and the critical situation prevalent in many of them today. Formulated imperative of solidarity is what we need and what this forum, convened in the interest of all of Europe, urges on those who will take part in the all-European process covering the areas I've outlined about. Profound changes in the Soviet Union will increasingly generate the necessary preconditions for rapprochement with the European Community I should also add that the arch of cooperation we're beginning to develop around the Northern hemisphere would be inconceivable without developing new relationships between the SOviet Union and Japan. ANd finally a word on yet another subject, which is not on our agenda. Iraq's aggressions have become the second serious test as we begin our movements towards a new period of peace in history. Our unity in condemning it and our shared concern over the outcome of the crisis are also indicative of the radical shift in our midst and the perception of the goals of and the meanings available to world politics. Any armed attack, wherever it may occur, now serves to unite us rather than scatter us on different sides of the barricade. Demanding that the aggressor withdraw from Kuwait, we are defending the hopes that millions of people have begun to pin on the ability of the international community to cope with even the most critical of conflicts. If we disappoint these hopes, much of what we have accomplished in the past few years would be in Jeopardy. We're prepared to show patience in the quest for a political solution, but we will remain firm and determined in implementing the will of the United Nations. Ladies and gentlemen, the peoples of Europe, the United States and Canada have resolved to create a common historical entity, based on shared principles and purposes, on democracy and humanism. May I congratulate you, therefore, on that major first step, and wish you all success. The revival of the spirit of international solidarity that was kindled during the war and that inspired the founders of the United Nations raises the hope that what we then conceived of will ultimately prevail. And it is most important for the United Nations and its Security Council to take up at long last the purpose for which they were originally designed, and I would like to welcome in our midst the most distinguished guest, Mr. Perez de Cuellar, who has done so much to revive the role of the United Nations. I would also like to express our gratitude to the leaders of France and personally to President Francois Mitterrand for their warmth and hospitality, as well as their excellent preparations for this meeting. Thank you. End text
