France had withdrawn its invitation because of Soviet objections. Under the ground rules of the conference, all decisions must be made by consensus, and one nation can in effect veto actions supported by other participants. According to the federation, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze protested the French invitation and said the Baltic officials could participate as part of the Soviet delegation if they wished. Daniel Bernard, spokesman for the French Foreign Ministry, confirmed that the Baltic officials had been told they could not participate in the summit because of the consensus rule. He declined to discuss the Soviet role in the matter. The three Baltic officials were Lennart Meri of Estonia, Algirdas Saudargas of Lithuania, and Janis Jurkans of Latvia.

DOC.HEAD: Bates College Makes All Admissions Testing Optional
DOC.TEXT: submit any standardized test scores for admission. BAtes, a small liberal arts college in Lewiston, Maine, thus became only the second highly-selective college in the nation with no standardized admissions test requirements. The other, Bowdoin, is also a small liberal arts college in Maine. Bates made the SAT optional in 1984. But entering freshmen who didn't submit SAT scores had to submit either three achievement test scores or the American College Test, or ACT. Bates' faculty earlier this month voted 94-1 to make all admissions testing optional, admissions dean William C. Hiss said in a telephone interview Monday. Starting with freshmen entering in September 1991, applicants can choose whether to submit any test scores. In a statement Monday, The College Board, which sponsors the SAT and numerous standardized achievement tests, called BAtes' decision ``curious'' in light of the ``emphasis being placed on subject matter knowledge in college admissions discussions.'' About a hundred colleges have made SAT and ACT scores optional for admission, according to FairTest, a Cambridge, Mass.-based organization that keeps tabs on those requirements. But many of those recommend taking those tests, or else require them for placement purposes. Some require applicants to take achievement tests in lieu of SATs. But a five-year study at Bates found that the optional SAT policy had no negative impact on the quality of its entering freshman, and in fact had improved the student mix, Hiss said. Minority enrollments increased from 5 percent to 10 percent, Hiss said. The optional testing policy also has helped the school attract bright students who can't afford SAT coaching courses, as well as bright youngsters whose minds aren't geared to standardized test-taking, Hiss said. He cited the case of a valedictorian from a rural Maine high school who nonetheless had poor verbal SATs and might have been rejected if Bates put a premium on test scores. ``The thing you had to know about this boy was that he was the nation's youngest Emergency Medical Service instructor at age 16. What does this tell you about his ability to think through complicated scientific questions and supervise people twice his age? As an applicant, I thought he looked just great for Bates. That's why we're doing this.''

DOC.HEAD: City Evicts Landmark Newsstand
LaserPhoto CX4
DOC.TEXT: A naked man strategically covered with straw peers out from the cover of Playgirl magazine on a rack outside the city's granite-pillared cultural center. But whatever culture Rick Graff's ramshackle newsstand offers is lost on city officials, who are evicting it after more than 70 years of business. You can't miss the place loyal customers call a landmark - a peeling grey-painted wood shack packed with thousands of publications ranging from Good Housekeeping to Revolutionary Worker. Graff says it's one of the nation's largest newsstands. Dozens of metal stands filled with magazines spill out onto the sidewalk. Magazines with more revealing covers than Playgirl are partially hidden behind a rickety wall inside the shack. Wearing dark glasses that prompt chuckles from passers-by, Graff's two dogs - an Alaskan malamute named Tasha and Rocky the shepherd-huskie - lie vigilantly on a soiled reddish carpet between the shack and the cultural center's steps. ``It's not very attractive,'' Commissioner Benjamin Reyes ofthe city's general services department said Monday. He sent Graff an eviction notice last week. ``The primary reason is the stand has no legal permit to operate out of that location,'' Reyes said. GRaff said permits were not needed when the stand opened more than 70 years ago. And even if he sought one now, ``We would not authorize any permits for vendors operating around one of our facilities,'' Reyes said. The policy is part of the city's new beautification effort, and Graff is not being singled out, the commissioner said. But Graff, 28, maintains the eviction is an effort to stifle the working class. ``They want to make this a party palace for the rich,'' Graff said, motioning toward the renovated block-long cultural center where lectures, poetry readings and art exhibits are held. Reyes said the city offered to lease a store to Graff in a nearby underground pedestrian mall, but Graff - who bought the stand for $50,000 seven years ago and pays no rent - said no dice. The city rejected his proposal to build a spiffier stand on the site, and Graff contends moving it would destroy the stand's major selling points - its unique atmosphere and strategic location between a commuter train station and the downtown subway and elevated train tracks. ``It's not only a great newsstand, but a family can come here and actually have fun. There's comics for kids, hundreds of magazines, and people can come here and pet my dogs,'' Graff said, ``You're not going to close down, are you?'' William Brady, a 36-year-old janitor, asked as he bought a paper. ``I don't think it's an eyesore, it's a landmark.'' Reyes said the case is closed, but Graff is seeking an attorney to fight the eviction. He doesn't have much time; the eviction orders him to leave by January 14. ``I sure would hate to see it go,'' said Shirley Goldman, a retired teacher who remembers shopping at the stand 30 years ago. ``It's real memorabilia.''

DOC.HEAD: Fannie Mae Raises Ceiling on Mortgages It Will Buy
DOC.TEXT: Slightly cheaper mortgages will be available to more home buyers next year because of an increase in the size of single-family-home loans purchased by secondary market agencies. The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) said Monday it will purchase mortgages as large as $191,250 starting Jan. 1, up from a $187,450 ceiling this year. In Alaska and Hawaii, the ceiling will be 50 percent higher. The board of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac) is expected to approve a similar increase when it meets in early December, spokeswoman Audra Capas said. Together, the two stockholder-owned but congressionally-chartered companies finance one in four of the nation's residential mortgages. They purchase mortgages from lenders, holding some and repackaging others into securities for sale to investors. Lenders are able to charge interest rates a quarter- to a half-point lower on mortgages they sell to the companies compared with loans they retain in their own portfolios. The ceiling increase won't mean much in most regions, but in high-cost areas such as California the Northeast, where the average mortgage is near the limit, it will help buyers a bit. A home buyer with a mortgage at the new ceiling would save $73 a month with a fixed-rate loan of 9{ percent, instead of 10 percent, for instance. Two-family-home residential mortgages will have a limit of $244,650; three-family, $295,650, and four-family, $367,500. ``The practical effect of this is positive,'' said James W. Nelson, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. He estimated that the higher limits will enable roughly 25,000 families to take advantage of slightly lower mortgage rates. ``In the Midwest and West, markets have tended to be a little stronger than elsewhere and, as housing prices go up, it helps make financing more available for a certain segment of the home-buying public,'' he said. The new single-family ceiling is based on data collected by the Federal Housing Finance Board, which said Monday that the average sales price for a single-family home was $139,600 in October, up 2 percent from $136,800 a year earlier. The loan ceilings increase proportionately. Through the 1980s, the Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac ceilings have risen rapidly along with housing prices, falling for the first time in 1990. The single-family ceiling was $187,450 in 1990, $187,600 in 1989, $168,700 in 1988, $153,100 in 1987, $133,250 in 1986 and $115,000 in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Nationalists Winning in Central Yugoslavian Republic
DOC.TEXT: Nationalists appeared headed for victory over Communists in Bosnia-Hercegovina's first free elections in more than a half-century, according to returns made public Monday. The Serbian Democratic Alliance, the Croatian Democratic Union, and the Moslem Union for Democratic Action were running well ahead of the Communist Party and federal Premier Ante Markovic's ALliance of Reform Forces. With 20 percent of the vote counted in the central republic, the Moslem party was leading in three Bosnian constituencies. The Croats and the Serbs were ahead in two each. The 240 seats in Bosnia's bicameral Parliament are divided among seven constituencies. Final results were not expected for several days, and no single nationalist party seemed likely to win a clear majority. At a news conference, leaders of the Serbian, Croatian and Moslem parties said they would cooperate on major political and Economic issues. Moslem party leader Alija Izetbegovic suggested the three parties form a government coalition. ``I'm delighted that Bosnia is finally free and that we can start working for the benefit of all nationalities living in the region,'' said Stjepan Kljujic, leader of the Croatian Democratic Union. ``The communists were rejected in Bosnia's elections because of the disastrous consequences of their 45 years of monopoly on power,'' said Radovan Karadzic, president of the Serbian Democratic Alliance. ``This is a victory for democracy.'' Zlatko Lajundzia, a member of the Communist Party's presidium, said, ``It is obvious that the nationalist parties are doing much better than we and they had expected.'' supporters well ahead. The two parties had claimed victory for a nationalist party could lead to civil war. Western observers said the elections, in which about 70 percent of the electorate cast ballots Sunday, were free and generally fair. It was the region's first free elections since 1938. ``Except for some isolated incidences, in general the elections seem to have been carried out fairly,'' said David Evans, a senior adviser for a U.S. congressional commission monitoring human rights and security in Europe. Bosnia-HErcegovina, whose 4.2 million people include Serbs, Croats and Moslems, is geographically and politically at the heart of Yugoslavia's bitter rivalries. Sarajevo, Bosnia's capital, is best known for the assassination of Austro-Hungarian Archduke Franz Ferdinand by a young nationalist in 1914. His killing sparked World War I. Serbia and Croatia are the two largest Yugoslav republics, and they flank Bosnia-HErcegovina. They have previously made territorial claims on the central republic. Serbia, under Communist rule pending elections Dec. 9, wants to keep power centralized in Belgrade, the Serbian and federal capital. Croatia, where the Croatian Democratic Union defeated the Communists in spring elections, wants Yugoslavia to become a confederation of nearly independent states. Bosnia has so far steered a neutral and independent course. Catholic Croats and the Orthodox Serbs since Yugoslavia was founded as a kingdom in 1918. During the Nazi occupation of World War II, Bosnia was the scene of a civil war among Croats, Serbs, Communists and the occupying Germans.

DOC.HEAD: Milli Vanilli Band Stripped of Grammy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, minor editing, adds nationality and ages.
DOC.TEXT: The band Milli Vanilli was stripped of its Grammy award today because the pop duo didn't sing on the ``Girl You Know It's True'' album, Grammy officials announced. The group won the Grammy for best new artist last February. The Grammy was rescinded by a telephone vote of the trustees of the NAtional Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, which gives out the music industry awards. It wasn't known if the award will be given to another artist. ``This action comes as a result of admissions and revelations by Milli Vanilli's producer, record label and the two performers Rob Pilatus and Fab Morvan that the label credit on their album... was incorrect,'' the academy said in a statement issued from its Burbank headquarters. Pilatus and Morvan said during the weekend they wanted to give up the Grammy and return it to the artists that actually sang on their hit album. The had planned to forfeit the Grammy during a Tuesday news conference. ``Fabrice and I want to give the Grammy back to the real singers,'' Pilatus told the Los Angeles Times. The lip-sync controversy erupted last week when Milli Vanilli's German producer, Frank Farian, disclosed that others actually sang on the record credited to Pilatus and Morvan. The duo also lip-synced their way through live performances, including one at the Grammy Awards show, Farian said. The duo's first and only album, ``Girl You Know It's True,'' sold 7 million copies and helped Milli Vanilli garner the Grammy. Music industry leaders were embarrassed and stunned by the deception. ``It was fraud and we're appalled by it,'' said Michael Greene, academy president. Pilatus and Morvan said Saturday they hoped their forfeited Grammy would be given to vocalists Johnny Davis, Charles Shaw and Brad Howell, who reportedly sang on the record. Pilatus is from Germany and Morva is from the Caribbean island of Guadeloupe. Both are 25. The two front men have alleged that Arista Records, the label that distributed ``Girl You Know It's True'' in the United States, knew they weren't really the singers. However, Arista officials have maintained that Pilatus and Morvan told them they sang on the album.

Here are excerpts of Monday's testimony by Sen. Dennis DeConcini before the Senate Ethics Committee: ``All of the evidence that has been admitted, as I understand now that lies over there - some 44 volumes. ... This information contains heresay. ... It contains rumors, unfounded allegations about all the senators, I dare say. ... ``Now, Mr. Chairman, I regret that I have to mention and make reference to Mr. Bennett (special counsel Robert S. Bennett) because of the manner in which he presented the case Thursday and Friday. ... HE wants a victory. He wants to nail somebody. He wants to get somebody, I'm sorry to say. HE wants another trophy on the wall. ... ``But it has been said many times, this is not a trial. This is supposed to be a fact-finding hearing where we get an opportunity to lay our case out for you and the AMerican public. ... ``Constituent service to me is very important. ... And when a constituent, someone from Arizona, walks in to my office, we have no discrimination, whether they are Republican, Democrat, liberal, conservative, rich, poor, even if they are not registered voters. If they've got a complaint, we listen to them. ... ``What is wrong with intervention from someone who sends you a check to your campaign? Nothing - no more different than what is wrong when American Continental or their employees sent checks to our campaigns. They didn't hand the checks to us and talk about it. ``We've handled 75,000 constituent cases in the 14 years that I have been a senator. And we haven't discriminated, and we don't talk money with them. ... ``Now, let me talk about the case of American Continental and Lincoln. They came to me, as they did to other people, argued their problem and their case, saying they were being mistreated. And I said to them, `Give me some evidence.' ... So what did they do? They got me some pretty powerful evidence - all us - pretty powerful evidence. ... I decided to intervene. That's right. I got in there, with my sleeves up, and decided to go for it. ... All the regulators pointed out ... we did nothing improper. ... There was no change made by what we attempted to persuade them to do, or bring to their attention. ... We didn't do anything wrong in any meetings. We acted as senators should have. They weren't intimidated until a couple of years later, when they got darn worried that they hadn't done their jobs. ... I was asked to make a status inquiry and I did. There were jobs involved. This was a major employer. ... I've had to say some things that are difficult to say about a brother lawyer, a fine prosecutor as far as I know, by reputation. But I've been mistreated by him in this process. ... To do other than dismiss the charges against me is unjust. I broke no law. I broke no rule. I broke no standard. I committed no improper conduct. ...

DOC.HEAD: Days Before Election, Lech Walesa Says, `I Was Born for Victory'
LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa, exuding confidence six days before the country's first popular presidential election, declared MOnday that he was ``borN only for victory.'' The Solidarity chairman, ahead in the polls against his former ally Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and four others, said his struggle has already been successful, because it has forced an acceleration of change in Poland. The 47-year-old electrician from Gdansk rose to international prominence more than a decade ago when he led the trade-union movement that sparked enormous political changes in Poland. The Solidarity movement also helped spark revolutions elsewhere in Eastern Europe that ended decades of Communist rule. But now the movement is splintered. Walesa, in an interview with The Associated Press, said one of his first moves as president would be to try to unite Solidarity again. But he said he would avoid abrupt changes until postwar Poland's first free parliamentary elections, expected within three months. Mazowiecki contends Poland's future depends on maintaining his course of determined but cautious reform, and that he will join the opposition if Walesa wins the presidency on Sunday or in a Dec. 9 runoff. Walesa has waged a pugnacious campaign against a government he largely created. He proposed Mazowiecki as the East bloc's first non-Communist prime minister in August 1989, and then found himself on the sidelines, chafing at what he saw as a too-slow pace of reforms. ``THen, when I said, `I'll take over power, I'll become president,' everything started moving,'' he said. ``SO didn't I accelerate everything?'' He launched his presidential campaign, initially criticized but then leading to former Communist Party leader Wojciech Jaruzelski's decision to step down early as president. dangerous policy that was on the edge of civil war. I made an attempt to save us ... to save reform,'' he said. Virtually all Walesa's former advisers have sided with Mazowiecki, leaving Walesa to assemble a new campaign team of unionists and lesser-known politicians. But now, victory appears within grasp. Walesa, a peasant's son with a trade-school education, said he differs from his former colleagues, most of them from intellectual circles, because he is not frightened by ordinary people and wants to engage them in the political process. ``If you fear the masses, then of course the masses will defeat you,'' he said. ``I am not afraid of the masses. I want to find work for them, and I want to show them what's possible or impossible, and then go on with what's possible and probable.'' He said that if some day he sees a demonstration in front of his presidential palace, ``I will come out and lead it.'' Walesa deflected a question about whether he would ask Finance Minister LEszek Balcerowicz, architect of Poland's shock economic overhaul, to stay on if he is victorious. Without naming names, he said part of Mazowiecki's present Cabinet could remain if he wins. BUt he said he would not be doing any ``begging.'' Asked why he had not done more to rebuke anti-Semitic questioners during his rallies, Walesa said he had reminded Poles in recent interviews that anti-Semitism is contradictory to their CAtholicism. OF his past and future political battles, Walesa said bluntly: ``I was born only for victory. So I have to win. ``Maybe you see it as over-confidence. But if so, let me remind you of my first statement (last summer) ... which today makes sense even if it didn't then:to be the president.' ``It could be seen as conceit, trickery or pride. But in fact it was the key with which I got the reform process moving.'' He said he dreamed of uniting Solidarity again. ``I have been struggling for nine months to regain Solidarity's position and to regain my position,'' he said. ``I do not know to what extent it worked, but from what I see, it did.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys: CNN Fines Should Pay for Noriega Defense
With AM-Scotus-Press Freedom, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Contempt fines levied against CNN should be used to pay for Manuel Noriega's defense against drug smuggling charges, an attorney for the deposed Panamanian dictator said Monday. On Sunday, the U.S. Supreme Court left intact a federal judge's temporary order that barred CNN from airing tapes of jailhouse phone conversations between Noriega and his defense team. contempt of court hearing against CNN in view of the U.S. Supreme Court's 7-2 decision. The defense has asked for fines of $300,000 per airing of the conversations, and May said it will ask that money be used for a Noriega defense trust fund. ``We're certainly going to suggest that might be one way of solving a lot of problems, and I think an appropriate one, considering the fact that GEneral Noriega's defense was damaged by CNN,'' May said. That could allow NOriega to keep his private defense team even though his funds have been frozen by federal prosecutors and foreign governments. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler said last week he would decide soon whether to replace Noriega's private attorneys with government-paid counsel. The private attorneys have said they cannot stay on the case without some money. STeven Korn, chief counsel for CNN's parent company Turner Broadcasting System Inc., said the network had no position on how any fines it might pay should be dispersed because it doesn't Expect to pay any. He said the network never aired privileged conversations under Hoeveler's order. ``I think that point has been lost in the hue and cry,'' Korn said. He noted that lead Noriega attorney Frank Rubino had identified and described the conversation on the air, and even pushed the button on the tape recorder. Hoeveler, meanwhile, has set a hearing for Tuesday on how to proceed with the prison tapes at the center of the CNN-Noriega dispute. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said Monday the tapes were being Blown out of proportion. ``This is not as grand an issue as it is described as being,'' Lehtinen said. ``I think the taping by the government will be found to be quite correct. Privileged conversations ... are not privileged when you get on a phone from a prison, and you know it is being taped.'' He said the judge may well rule the tapes are not prejudicial to Noriega's case. May said that such a ruling would neither keep Hoeveler from Finding CNN in contempt, nor end the gag order. between attorneys and a client,'' May said. Noriega has asked that the case be dismissed because of the taping, the freezing of his assets, and other alleged government misconduct, but Hoeveler has not ruled on the issue. Noriega is jailed outside of MIami on a drug-trafficking indictment accusing him of accepting bribes to turn Panama into a way station for U.S.-bound cocaine shipments. He has been held more than 10 months and his trial isn't expected to begin before next spring.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Study of 100 Cities Warns of Population Growth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, `Joining the ...'' to CORRECT city Atlanta, sted Detroit-Windsor region
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Crowded Cities-List
DOC.TEXT: Melbourne, Montreal and Seattle-Tacoma are the best cities in which to live, the private Population Crisis Committee said after surveying conditions in the world's 100 largest metropolitan areas. Lagos, Nigeria, is the worst, the group said Monday in an analysis based on two years of research. Sharon L. Camp, the organization's senior vice president, said the study wasn't a guidebook for retirement or business or vacations but rather a warning about the dangers of rapid population growth. ``MOre than half of these cities are sinking from the weight of too many people,'' she said. ``More than anything else, the numbers ... add up to human population overload.'' The committee analyzed living conditions in the metropolitan areas, awarding up to 10 points in each of 10 categories. Melbourne, Australia; Montreal, Canada; and the Seattle-Tacoma area each accumulated 86 of the possible 100 points. Lagos scored 19 points. Lagos averages 5.8 people per room in living space, only half the city's houses have water and electricity and there is only one telephone per 100 people. By comparison Melbourne and Montreal average 0.5 person per room in housing and Seattle-Tacoma has 0.4. All residences in those cities have water or electricity or both. Seattle-Tacoma has 106 telephones per 100 people, while there are 69 in Montreal and 45 in Melbourne. Joining the three first-place cities in making up the five most livable cities were Essen-Dortmund-Duisberg, Germany, and the Atlanta, Ga., area. Both rated 85. The Detroit, Mich.-Windsor, Ontario region finished sixth. With Lagos at the bottom of the list were: Kinshasa, Zaire, 29 points; Dhaka, Bangladesh, 32; and Recife, Brazil, Lima, Peru, and Kanpur, India, each with 33 points. Two of the world's 100 largest cities - Bucharest, Romania, and Rangoon, Burma - could not be ranked because of lack of data. Montreal Mayor Jean Dore said the city, ``like all other major economic and cultural centers in the world, has to deal with major social and environmental issues. But our city has an important advantage over other big cities - Montreal wants to preserve its heritage of the past while setting human scale development as the keystone of the future.'' Steve Morris, president of the Seattle-King County Convention and Visitors Bureau, said: ``We're always thrilled when Seattle get high marks in these kind of polls.'' And Melbourne Mayor Richard Wynne called his community ``one of the most convenient cities, a comfortable city and a safe city with good transport and rich cultural activity.'' Criteria for the rankings were: -Murders per 100,000 people: Capetown, South Africa, had the highest rate at 64.7. Rated at less than one were Madrid, Spain; Manchester, England; and BAndung, Indonesia. -Percent of income spent on food: Most expensive is Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, 80 percent. Residents of 23 communities spend more than half their income on food. Food accounted for 9 percent of income in Washington, D.C. -People per room: Lagos was most crowded at 5.8, while Canton, China had 5.7. All cities in the United States, Canada and Australia as well as Madrid and Birmingham, England, had fewer than 0.5 person per room. -Percent of homes with water or electricity or both: At least 70 percent of homes had water and electricity in 87 percent of the Metro areas, although the analysis didn't always take into account squatter settlements or illegal water and electrical connections. Kinshasa, Zaire and Johannesburg, South Africa, had two-thirds of residents lacking running water or electricity or both. -Telephone per 100 people: San Francisco-Oakland-San Jose has 151 telephones per 100 people. Lagos, Ho Chi Minh City and Kinshasa have less than 1. -Percent of children in secondary school: Moscow, Warsaw and Essen-Dortmund-Duisberg each reported that 100 percent of youngsters 14 to 17 were attending school. Johannesburg, Lagos and Lahore, India, had fewer than one-third in school. -Infant deaths per 1,000 live births: Taipei, Taiwan, and three Japanese urban areas (Osaka-Kobe-Kyoto, Tokyo-Yokohama and Nagoya) had five infant deaths per 1,000 births. Kanpur, India, had 157. -Levels of ambient noise: Dallas-Fort Worth, Singapore and Manchester were ranked as relatively quiet. Noisiest included New York; London; Karachi, Pakistan; Madras, India; Lahore, Pakistan; Madrid; Naples; Surabaya, Indonesia; and Monterrey, MExico. -Traffic flow in miles per hour in rush hour: Traffic managed more than 40 mph in Atlanta, Casablanca, Houston, Belo Horizonte, Brazil, and Detroit-Windsor. In Lima, it crawled along at 4 mph. -Air pollution: Taipei, Sydney and Melbourne were ranked as having clean air. Dirtiest were Calcutta and New Delhi, India; Jakarta, Indonesia; Tehran, Iran; Beijing and Shenyang, China; and Milan, Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Seek Mysterious Source of Pollutants in Sea Lions
DOC.TEXT: The cause of surprisingly high levels of chemical pollutants found in some North Pacific sea lions is a mystery, a federal official said Monday. Chemical runoff from as far south as the Washington and Oregon coasts could be responsible for contaminants found in two of eight Alaskan Steller sea lions tested in what is considered pristine Alaskan waters, said Roddy Moscoso of the National Marine Fisheries Service. But he said there was no evidence that points to an actul source and studies are continuing. ``Their diet, various fish species, do traverse a great deal of the West Coast down into Washington. It is possible through runoffs in Washington state and Oregon - in the migratory area - that they could have been exposed to such levels,'' Moscoso said. ``It is a mystery right now.'' The study of a small sample of 23 animals was conducted by Usha Varanasi, director of the service's Environmental Conservation Division in Seattle. High levels of contaminants have been found in pilot whales stranded on the coast of New England, but those levels were not surprising ``given the water quality in that area,'' Moscoso said. However, the contaminants in the Steller sea lions were cause for alarm. ``We would have considered where they live to be in a pristine environment so it was of concern because we just had not idea the contaminant concentrations would be that high,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Secretary Escapes Injury in Bomb Attack
DOC.TEXT: Four bombs exploded before dawn Monday at the suburban home of the Philippine justice secretary, but he and his family escaped injury. The official, Franklin Drilon, said he, his wife Violetta and two young sons were sleeping in the house at the time of the attack. There was no claim of responsibility, and Drilon said he did not know who the assailants were. But he said at least one of the bombs contained the plastic explosive C-4, often used by right-wing military extremists. The blasts heavily damaged a wall around the house, shattered windows, overturned furniture and blasted a hole three feet deep in the yard. vehicles killed a city official and three companions in Cabanatuan City, 60 miles north of Manila. The military said Andres Quibuyen, secretary of Cabanatuan Mayor Honorato Perez, was being driven to the city hall when about four men in a car and four others in a jeep opened fire, killing him, his driver and two other people. Another companion was injured in the attack. The motive for the attack was unknown. Meanwhile, published reports said military intelligence expects right-wing extremists to launch a new coup attempt between Nov. 30 and Dec. 10. The Manila Chronicle and The Manila Times on Monday quoted unnamed military sources as saying the plan called for coordinated uprisings in northern and southern provinces directed by renegade Commodore DOmingo Calajate, a leader of last December's failed coup. Last month, mutineers staged a three-day uprising in Mindanao island that the military said was to have been the trigger for a series of nationwide revolts. The mutiny ended Oct. 6 when coup leader Col. Alexander Noble surrendered. Drilon's department is responsible for prosecuting extremists including the military dissidents responsible for seven armed uprisings since PResident Corazon Aquino took office four years ago. Mrs. Aquino said she was shocked at the attack on her justice secretary. ``The important thing is for us not to lose heart because of what we are doing because we believe in democracy,'' Mrs. Aquino said at a news conference. ``We who believe in democracy should not be coerced into surrendering to these terrorists.'' Drilon was appointed justice secretary last Dec. 31 as part of a Cabinet shakeup following a bloody coup attempt earlier in the month. He had served as labor secretary since 1987. He also serves as chairman of the Cabinet Security Committee, which advises Mrs. Aquino on national security issues.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates On Short-Term Treasury Securities Rise
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction to their highest level in three weeks. The Treasury Department sold $10.0 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.08 percent, up from 7.05 percent last week. Another $10.0 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.05 percent, up from 7.02 percent last week. The rates were the highest since Oct. 29 when three-month bills sold for 7.12 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.13 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.31 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,823.00 and 7.41 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,645.50. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.30 percent last week, down from 7.35 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Holds Hostage 4{ Hours in Store Before Surrendering
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with surrender, hostages released; ADDS byline, picks up 7th graf pvs, `At the ...
DOC.TEXT: A gunman took several people hostage in a grocery store today, but released them unharmed and surrendered after a 4{-hour standoff, authorities said. Several shots were fired inside the Food Lion store, but no one was injured, said Lt. A.K. Shaban of the HAnover County Sheriff's Department. Seward McGhee, assistant commonwealth's attorney, said the Gunman held three or four hostages after initially allowing a number of people to leave the store. The man, who was not immediately identified, gave up at 3:50 p.m., said Jody Chance, a sheriff's dispatcher. McGhee said authorities were told by hostages that the man - armed with a semiautomatic handgun - robbed a nearby restaurant to get money for an operation needed by his daughter. The standoff began about 11:20 a.m., when the gunman entered the store at the Ashland Junction Shopping CEnter 15 miles north of Richmond. A rescue squad member at the scene said the gunman was seen running from a restaurant next door toward the shopping center with what appeared to be a bag of money. He dropped the bag near a dry cleaner's, ran inside, grabbed a customer and dragged her at gunpoint to the Food Lion about 150 yards away, said the squad member, who declined to be identified. One of the people who escaped from the Food Lion ran down the driveway of the shopping center toward the restaurant. The woman, who declined to be identified, said: ``I was trying to console him (the gunman), thinking it would help, and maybe it did. I don't know. The best thing I knew to do was stay calm.'' She said she went out the back door of Food Lion with two women shoppers who said they crawled behind boxes of bananas to escape. At the nearby Ponderosa restaurant, employee Carolyn Duvall said a man came in the back door about 10:50 a.m. and pointed a gun at her. ``He just came in and told me to get down,'' she said. ``So I got under the sink. He didn't say what he was here for. He just asked for the manager. ``It was a little scary, but I was more scared than anything that someone would have the nerve to do that,'' she said. ``Ino idea if he got what he came for. I don't know what he got.'' The man was inside about eight minutes and forced several employees into a stockroom before he left, Ms. Duvall said. They remained there for about three minutes, she added. POlice barred people from entering the shopping center.

DOC.HEAD: Army Calls up 20,000 More Combat Reservists
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Army on Monday ordered to active duty more than 20,000 National Guard and Reserve combat troops for the Persian Gulf crisis, and the Marine Corps said it was sending an additional 6,496 combat reservists to the gulf. The Army and Marine Corps call-ups brought to approximately 41,000 the number of combat and non-combat reservists put on active duty since President Bush last Wednesday raised the ceiling on the number of reservists that could be used. Bush has authorized a maximum call-up of 125,000 reservists from all services. Since the start of Operation Desert Shield Aug. 7, about 77,000 reservists have been called up - most in non-combat roles such as transportation and cargo handling. It is the biggest call-up of reservists since the Berlin crisis of 1961. Details of Monday's Army call-up, confirmed by Maj. Doug HArt, a Pentagon spokesman, were not immediately available. Hart said those being activated included members of three National Guard armored combat units - the 48th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Georgia, the 155th Armored Brigade of Mississippi and the 256th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Louisiana. The Army announced Friday that it had alerted those three combat brigades to be prepared for call-up. The Army also called up 14,006 reservists for support roles Friday. The Marine Corps said in an announcement Monday that it ordered 6,496 Marine Corps Reserve members to active duty with the 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force at Camp Lejeune, N.C., starting next week. The expeditionary force is scheduled to deploy to the Persian Gulf area with reinforcements ordered by Bush two weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dies After Setting Himself Ablaze at Capitol
DOC.TEXT: A man died Monday after setting himself on fire in front of the U.S. Capitol as dozens of bystanders watched, police said. The victim was burned beyond recognition and authorities said he had not been identified. The reason for the suicide was not immediately known. ``He stood for quite awhile,'' said a tourist from Iowa who saw the man on fire as she walked out of the Capitol. ``A lot of people were watching. ... It was pretty gruesome.'' The woman, who would not give her name, said the man lay down, turned on his back and reached to the sky before he died. ``It was awful,'' she said, adding that someone in the crowd yelled that the fire department should be called. Officer Dan Nichols of the Capitol Police said an officer at the door called for help. Nichols said the man used ``some sort of accelerant'' to feed the flames, which also were hastened by a brisk wind that was blowing. The man was pronounced dead at the scene. The incident occurred about 2 p.m. on an expansive landing part way up the steps of the West Front of the building, facing the Mall that stretches from the Capitol to the Lincoln Memorial. Though the Capitol is the scene of frequent protests, the incident did not appear connected to any political cause, Nichols said. Congress is not in session, reducing the amount of activity Around the building. Nichols said police made a sweep of the area with canine teams in an effort to find something that would identify the victim and to make certain the man didn't leave any dangerous devices or materials on the grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Corcoran Gallery Appoints New York Art Historian As New Leader
DOC.TEXT: The Corcoran Gallery of Art, in turmoil since the cancellation of a Robert Mapplethorpe exhibit, on Friday named a New York art historian and education administrator as its new leader. David C. Levy, chancellor of the New School for Social Research, was elected by the Corcoran board of trustees to become director and president of the gallery and the art school affiliated with it starting Jan. 1. Levy, 52, joined the Parsons School of Design in 1961. He initiated the merger of Parsons and the New School in 1970 and continued as Parsons' chief administrative officer until last year. Besides being an art historian and experienced administrator, Levy is also a photographer and an active jazz musician, performing on saxophone throughout the United States and abroad. Levy's appointment was announced in conjunction with a policy statement in which the board reaffirmed the Corcoran's commitment to freedom of expression. The Corcoran board said the gallery is ``solely responsible for the appropriateness or acceptability'' of its exhibits. Criticism or objections must not ``prevent an idea from being voiced, a work from being seen, or a performance from being held,'' the board said. The Corcoran, located only two blocks from the White House near Pennsylvania Ave., is 120 years old and the oldest museum in Washington. It attracted nationwide criticism when its former director, Christina Orr-Cahall, canceled a controversial exhibit containing sexually explicit photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. She said she canceled the show, two weeks before it was scheduled to open in the summer of 1989, to avoid getting embroiled in the emotional debate over federal arts grant policies. But the cancellation ignited an equally intense debate in the artistic community, and Orr-Cahall resigned last February. A federal grant had helped finance the traveling Mapplethorpe exhibit, which contained homoerotic and sadomasochistic images and pictures of nude children. THe exhibit appeared without incident in Philadelphia and Chicago before it was supposed to arrive in Washington. But in a subsequent stop in Cincinnati, the gallery owner was arrested and tried for violating obscenity laws. A jury acquitted him, but the debate over federal arts funding still rages. The Corcoran board had been searching for a director since Orr-Cahall announced last December she would be resigning. Levy issued a statement echoing the institution's renewed commitment to freedom of artistic expression. ``It is my unequivocal position that these freedoms must be jealously guarded, and I see it as my obligation... to put that belief into practice,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Significantly Lower Wheat Crop Expected Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Wheat production in 1991 will be down from this year's near-record harvest, an Agriculture Department report said Monday. Prospects now ``point to decidedly lower production'' next year, the department's Economic Research Service said. The report said the area planted for the 1991 wheat crop will be reduced, and ``there is no assurance that the 1990 record yield (per acre) will be replicated.'' However, analysts said the total U.S. supply of wheat in the 1991-92 marketing year, which will begin June 1, will be bolstered by much larger stocks left from previous harvests. The 1991 idling requirement was set in the new farm bill at 15 percent of a farmer's wheat acreage base, compared with a 5 percent requirement set-aside this year. No forecast of 1991 wheat production was included in the report. This year's output was more than 2.74 billion bushels, up 35 percent from the drought-reduced 1989 harvest. The report projected the total U.S. wheat stockpile next June 1 at 945 million bushels, up from 536 million bushels last June 1. A 15 percent level for the 1991 wheat Acreage Reduction Program, or ARP, would result in ``four to five times more wheat area idled'' than the approximately two million acres idled in 1990 under the program, the report said. Farmers must participate in the program and idle part of their acreage to qualify for price supports and other program benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Author Jean Rouaud Wins Prix Goncourt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS throughout to CORRECT surname of winner, ADD details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Jean Rouaud on Monday won the 1990 Prix Goncourt, France's most prestigious literary prize, for his first novel, ``The Fields of Honor.'' The 159-page story published by Editions de Minuit explores the mores of rural France through the memories of an old truck driver recalling the significant deaths in his family: grandfather, grandmother, father and aunt. The Goncourt jury awarded the prize on an 8-2 vote, with Philippe Labro's ``The Little Boy'' Labro taking second place. It marks the first time since 1950, when Paul Colin was honored for ``The Young Savages,'' that a first novel won. Rouaud, 38, continued to work in a Paris magazine shop. ABout 70,000 copies of ``The Fields of Honor'' are already in print and sales are bound to increase because of the prize, which is accompanied by a check for 50 francs ($10). An English translation is planned. The Renaudot Prize, a literary award traditionally given to budding novelists, went to Jean Colombier, 44, for his second work, ``The Romanc Brothers,'' published by Calmann-Levy. A separate jury awarded Colombier the prize to after a record 25 rounds of voting. His novel tells a story of love, betrayal and vengeance between two brothers.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Inspectors Visiting Iraq at Invitation of Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Two inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency are visiting Iraq at the invitation of the Baghdad government, which wants the agency to verify it is not developing nuclear weapons. The Iraqi News Agency quoted inspector Abdul Wahid al-Saji as saying he and the other inspector were on a Nov. 18-22 visit ``to Conduct their regular comprehensive inspection of the nuclear installations and materials in Iraq.'' Al-Saji said it was the second visit to Iraq this year by the Vienna-based IAEA. The agency has said it found no violations by Iraq during an April visit. The inspectors are apparently checking on a 27-pound mass of highly enriched uranium that Iraq salvaged from the Osirak nuclear reaction, which was destroyed by an Israeli air attack in 1981. Scientists say this uranium could be fashioned into a primitive nuclear bomb. The Iraqi government's invitation to the IAEA appeared aimed at stripping away one justification for an invasion of Iraq. Some Western officials have said that regardless of Kuwait's status, the Middle East will never be safe as long as President Saddam Hussein could threaten to use nuclear weapons. Researchers have claimed for years that Iraq is trying to develop a nuclear bomb. Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies published a report Sunday that Iraq is capable of developing such a wepaon within three to five years. Iraq is a signatory of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty that binds nations to renounce the possession or use of nuclear weapons and to submit to regular inspections of their uranium by IAEA officials.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Will Sell Helicopters, Missiles to South Korea
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said Monday it has notified Congress of plans to sell to South Korea 20 AH-1F Cobra attack helicopters and 42,000 rounds of artillery and anti-armor munitions in deals valued at a combined $356 million. The attack helicopters will include the TOW anti-tank missile system and will help South Korean officials ``continue their force modernization plans,'' the Pentagon said. The Pentagon said South Korea needs the additional rounds of 155mm artillery munitions and the anti-armor projectiles to establish a war reserve stockpile.

DOC.HEAD: Precede: WASHINGTON
Economy, Fuel Prices Won't Keep Folks Home This Thanksgiving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Expands throughout; version moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Despite economic gloom and higher fuel prices, American drivers plan to hit the road in higher numbers this Thanksgiving, but the nation's airlines aren't expecting a similar surge. The American Automobile Association reported Monday that more people are expecting to drive 100 miles or more for Thanksgiving, based on a survey of 1,500 adults. The airlines, meanwhile, are predicting no improvement over last year, a discouraging sign forsluggish demand and steady increases in jet fuel prompted by the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Historically, we have exceeded the previous year, but this year we think we'll be flat,'' said STephen Hayes of the Air Transport Association of America. Even though gasoline prices have risen by nearly 30 cents a gallon since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, AAA pointed out that an automobile that gets 20 miles a gallon can go 100 miles for less than $7. About 22.5 million people, 9 percent of the population, will drive to holiday feasts, AAA said. The number should be 3 percent higher than a year ago, although Thanksgiving travel is generally down from levels of the mid-1980s, the AAA said. When the economy suffers, people are less likely to plan trips, AAA spokesman Geoff Sundstrom said. But the auto club was surprised that higher gasoline prices don't seem to be having much of an impact. ``We often hear analysts talk about the psychological effects of higher gas prices, but we haven't seen it in holiday travel,'' Sundstrom said. AAA estimated that the number of people making Thanksgiving trips by airplanes and on trains and buses would stay the same this year, at about 3.5 million. ``I'm sure the fuel prices have had an effect,'' Hayes said air transport. ``There's no question but that we're suffering from both an economic slowdown and sharply rising jet fuel prices. Because of those two, we are seeing some fall-off in traffic.'' Hayes' association estimated a total of 9 million boardings will occur from Tuesday to Monday, for a rough total of 4.5 million people making round trips. The figures are for all boardings, so many of those travelers might not be taking Thanksgiving trips. Even though the overall figures are staying the same, numbers are off at some airlines. TWA, for example, anticipates some 22,000 passengers will go through its St. Louis hub Wednesday, and 26,600 will pass through Sunday. The comparable figures a year ago were 27,000 and 30,000 on those days, which are among the most heavily traveled, spokesman Jim Faulkner said. ``With the state of the economy, a lot of people are opting to drive who may have flown in years past,'' Faulkner said. ``Most of the airlines are cutting capacity, because many of them have too many seats out there.'' After the Gulf crisis sent oil prices spiraling, airlines responded with fare increases totaling about 15 percent. Even though many passengers took advantage of discount tickets offered before the increases kicked in, the higher fares might be Discouraging to some. Even in tough times, it's hard to keep people home on the holidays, according to the head of the American Society of Travel Agents. ``Thanksgiving travel is close to being a necessity,'' said the group's president, Philip Davidoff. ``Even when things are tight, people will go home anyway.'' Some travel agents agree. ``When I look back at a prior recession ... we had no reduction of people deciding to travel,'' said H. Wayne Berens, president of Revere Travel Inc., based in Trenton, N.J. Of course, you can't go to Grandma's if you've been shipped to the Saudi desert, and Berens thinks the troop buildup in the Middle East may be having an impact. ``It takes out another quarter million people from the potential traveling public,'' Berens said. ``But it means dependents aren't traveling, either.''

DOC.HEAD: Con Artist Sent to Prison for Bilking Priests
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - A man who bilked more than $133,000 from dozens of Roman CAtholic priests around the country by telling them hard-luck stories has been sent to prison for two years and ordered to pay Full restitution. Robert Riggio was sentenced last week and ordered to pay restitution of $133,606 to his victims. U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum also ordered Riggio, described as a compulsive gambler, to join GAmblers Anonymous. From May 1987 to last March, Riggio posed as a parishioner with family troubles and convinced nearly 50 priests nationwide to wire him loans ranging from $200 to $20,000. Riggio did most of his work over the telephone, persuading the priests to wire money or arranging for messengers to pick up the Cash, court records said. ``Obviously, he took advantage of peoples' better nature for his own gain,'' one victim, the Rev. Michael Huerter of St. Louis Catholic Church in upstate Pittsford, said in a telephone interview Monday. ``He's a thief. That's the long and short of the story,'' said another victim, the Rev. Charles Brady, of Cody, Wyo. Brady wired Riggio $2,000 after a late night telephone call in which Riggio poed as a local resident who needed money to keep his daughter from being kicked out of an East Coast university. FBI officials arrested Riggio, 44, of New York City, in April and he pleaded guilty to one count of wire fraud in June. He promised to repay his victims but never did, court papers said. Investigators said Riggio, who is separated from his wife and has two sons ages 25 and 15, apparently used the money to pay gambling debts. Because Riggio always seemed well-informed about each parish, Huerter said he believed that he had consulted a national directory of Catholic churches, which lists priests and other church officials. The Rev. Bryan Dalton of St. Richard's Catholic Church in Miami got his phone call last December. The caller, claiming to have met Dalton at a recent Mass, said he needed money because his mother had been mugged the night before. ``I had a suspicion when I went to Western Union, but I thought I'd give the guy the benefit of the doubt,'' said Dalton, who lost $650. The priest who lost the most was the Rev. Donald W. Simmons of St. Ann's Catholic Church in Bonners Ferry, Idaho. HE wired RIggio a total of $20,000 in 10 payments between Oct. 6, 1989, and Nov. 20, 1989. Simmons declined to be interviewed when reached by telephone on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle Being Fed for Slaughter at 12-Year November High
DOC.TEXT: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of Nov. 1 in the seven major beef states totaled a 12-year high of 8.74 million head, up 10 percent from a year ago and 7 percent more than two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Monday. Feedlot inventories were up from a year earlier in Colorado, Iowa, KAnsas, Nebraska and Texas. But they declined in Arizona and California. Overall, the report said it was ``the largest November number on feed since 1978.'' Marketings of ``fed'' cattle in October totaled 1.61 million head, down 1 percent from a year ago but 2 percent more than two years ago. month was reported at 2.75 million head, up 4 percent from a year ago and 12 percent more than in October 1988, the report said. State feedlot cattle inventories are listed here for the seven states, which account for about three-fourths of the nation's beef. The first number is the number of cattle, in thousands, as of Nov. 1, and the second number is the percentage of a year earlier.
Arizona 204 86 California 470 95 Colorado 965 107 Iowa 840 109 Kansas 1,780 114 Nebraska 2,150 110 Texas 2,330 117

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 16th graf, `For the ...' to UPDATE with Rocard narrowly surviving censure vote.
DOC.HEAD: For Some, Summit Offers Respite From Troubles At Home
DOC.TEXT: For some world leaders, the 34-nation summit here offers a welcome respite from troubles at home. Britain's Margaret Thatcher, Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, France's premier Michel Rocard, Poland's Tadeusz Mazowiecki - all would rather be in Paris acting statesmanlike than deal with domestic political challenges. But they needed go no further than sidewalk news stands for a reminder: ``Rocard facing censure,'' the influential Paris daily Le Figaro headlined. Further down on the front page, it carried a large article on Mrs. Thatcher's challenger as ``the man who scares Thatcher.'' The leaders feigned indifference. When asked whether she would like to be remembered for her role in the current summit, Mrs. Thatcher, not known for her love of European affairs, bristled: ``I think I'll be remembered for a lot more than that. But it's not time to write memoirs yet.'' Gorbachev, lauded by world leaders and applauded by a Paris crowd, looked every inch the statesman. Only his occasionally glum visage and a warning on the dangers of ethnic passions betrayed the woes that have him pounding the lecterns and hurriedly revamping his government at home. Like Gorbachev, many of the East European leaders in Paris are threatened by winter food and energy shortages that could combine with rising ethnic passions to stir violence and chaos. The glumness of bare stores and stoic queues, the dimness of cities like Bulgaria's Sofia, now suffering power cuts 50 percent of the time, are hard to imagine in the vibrant, gleaming French capital. Official lunches like that MOnday at the Elysee Palace, or Tuesday night's planned dinner and ballet soiree at Versailles are something beyond the imagination of millions of Soviets and East Europeans. Leaders like Romania's President Ion Iliescu, attending his first big European gathering, could try only to offer the folks back home the novel comfort of acceptance in the international community. Iliescu demonstratively put an arm round French host Francois Mitterrand when posing for pictures. Western leaders, too, could take solace in the Paris proceedings. Mrs. Thatcher on Tuesday faces the most serious challenge of her 11{ years in office in a contest with her former Defense Secretary, Michael Heseltine, for the leadership of the Conservative Party. President Bush helped out a little Monday morning, scheduling a breakfast with Thatcher that thrust her into the international Limelight Heseltine has lacked since he quit Thatcher's government in disgust in 1986. Yet Bush also needs the Paris proceedings to bolster his policy on the Persian Gulf and help fend off questions at home about whether or not the United States should contemplate war to get Iraq out of Kuwait. Bush himself has seen his popularity plummet in the face of newly enacted tax increases and a looming recession. Another Western leader under fire is the French premier, Rocard, buffeted by massive student demonstrations in the past two weeks and threatened Monday by a parliamentary motion of no confidence. For the first time, rightists and Communists were united in opposing the Socialist premier, but their effort fell five votes short of an absolute majority in the 577-seat National Assembly. The motion's failure allowed Rocard's 2-year-old government to survive, but his future remains uncertain. The drama of the leaders' sideshows barely penetrated the wall of security and protocol that serves to keep them isolated during the three-day summit. Gorbachev made only the most glancing of references to Soviet woes, then quickly pledged that any difficulties would not diminish his country's importance on the world stage. But leaders from both West and East seemed alert to the multiple dangers to the new democracy they gathered in Paris to celebrate. On Monday afternoon, speaker after speaker alluded to the dangers of nationalism, the poverty facing the East and the resulting mass migration to an unprepared West. Perhaps most striking was Gorbachev's warning that nationalism and separatism could have a ``destructive snowball effect'' if any government gives way to them.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Tempers Holiday Hostage Offer
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Monday tempered its plan to release all foreign hostages between Christmas and March and also declined to guarantee the safety of Westerners still hiding in Kuwait. Information Minister Latif Nassayif Jassim indicated a U.N. resolution authorizing a military offensive could jeopardize the hostage release. At the same time, the minister hinted the so-called ``hostage bazaar'' is still open for business in Iraq, that the country might Barter the release of some foreigners in exchange for medicine and other considerations from Switzerland. Later, the government announced that an unspecified number of Swiss would be allowed to leave ``in appreciation'' of a Swiss delegation's visit to Baghdad. Jassim also denounced the U.S. and British description of the hostage release as a ploy. ``The rulers of Britain and the United States do not want peace in the region, or resolution of its problems on a comprehensive basis,'' Jassim said. Iraq referred to its hostage release plan as a gesture for peace. But on Monday, the government announced new plans in case of war. Iraq's general command, after a meeting chaired by President Saddam Hussein, announced it was sending seven new divisions to Kuwait and calling up 150,000 reservists for eventual duty in the occupied country. The statement said the decision, taken in response to the recently announced addition of 200,000 American forces in the region, would add about 250,000 troops to the 430,000 already in Kuwait and southern Iraq. Hussein decided Sunday that all foreign hostages would be freed in batches beginning Dec. 25 if nothing happens to disturb the atmosphere of peace. ``If during the departure period an attack would take place, then of course the departures would be affected,'' said Jassim. But the minister declined to say if something short of an attack, such as passage of a U.N. resolution authorizing offensives, would be enough to disrupt the planned hostage releases. ``We are watching the situation,'' said Jassim when asked if such a resolution would block the plan. Jassim, at a news conference, also declined to guarantee that Westerners in Kuwait could emerge from hiding without risking arrest and relocation to a potential military target. Five Germans and two Americans reportedly were arrested Saturday in Kuwait. ``This is a procedural thing that is not related to the political attitude,'' said Jaseem. ``Every foreigner should report to Iraqi authorities so they can be registered and protected by Iraqi authorities. This is a matter of rules and regulations.'' Iraqi officials have detained hundreds of foreigners, whom they call guests, at strategic sites around the country to deter an attack by the allied forces in Saudi Arabia. Diplomats in Baghdad say there are at least 104 Americans and 353 Britons held at such sites. Hundreds of other foreigners are being kept in Iraq and Kuwait against their will by the Iraqi government. Jassim said that the release applied to all foreign hostages. Still, Western hostages interviewed in Baghdad said they were not optmistic. ``I think the timing is very cunning, stretching from Christmas to Ramadan,'' said one Westerner who asked not to be identified. ``I don't think they (the Americans and the British) will go for it.'' ``It didn't really generate any jumping up and down. Everybody is conditioned now to take just about everything with a great deal of thought,'' said Roland Burgheer, a 62-year-old American living in a diplomatic safe house with an undisclosed number of other Americans. ``It's nice to think about but it didn't really generate a lot of excitement'' said Burgheer. ``A lot of things have transpired here in the past that might have suggested the same thing.'' ``I don't personally care to be let go if it involves negotiations of some kind,'' he said. Jassim, however, showed no reluctance for certain types of negotiations. He said a deal to release 24 Swiss nationals, 25 employees of Swiss companies and up to 150 other foreigners depended on reaching agreement on medical supplies and other considerations from the Swiss. ``This question depends on several arrangements up for consideration ... they are dealing with arrangements for holding a peace conference in Switzerland and some medical supplies for Iraq,'' Jassim said. A delegation of five Swiss politicians, led by Edgar Oehler, a Christian Democrat, has been negotiating for the release. He said the Swiss, acting privately but still respecting the UN embargo on Iraq and Swiss policy, have offered Geneva as a site for an international peace conference and other unspecified concessions. Sources who declined to be identified hinted the deal may involve a shipment of up to 12 tons of medical supplies. Oehler said he had given the Iraqis a list of about 200 foreigners, including 36 Americans, that he hoped to take out of the country. The Iraqis, he said, had insisted that the arrangement be approved by the Swiss government. ``Everything is prepared,'' said Oehler. ``All I need is feedback from this government (Iraq) then everything is settled.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Wald Says She'll Step Down
DOC.TEXT: Judge Patricia M. Wald said Monday she will step aside as chief judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to allow Judge Abner J. Mikva to take the post. Wald, 62, said she plans to step down before Mikva's 65th birthday, Jan. 21. Under the law, federal judges cannot become chief judges of their courts if they have turned 65. ``That's the only reason I am doing it. I enjoy the job (but) there will be plenty to do just judging,'' said Wald, who will remain an active judge on the court. The chief judgeship is determined by seniority. Wald said both she and Mikva, then a Democratic congressman from Illinois, were nominated by President Carter on the same day in 1979. ``It's just the luck of the draw I got confirmed a couple of weeks before he did,'' she said. ``Under ordinary circumstances, I would be happy to serve out my term,'' said Wald, who became chief judge in 1986. The law allows judges to serve up to seven years as chief judges or until they reach age 70. The D.C. Circuit, along with the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New York, is considered one of the most important federal appellate courts in the nation. Because it's located in the nation's capitll, the court reviews judicial decisions affecting a wide range of government policies. It also has original jurisdiction to consider challenges to the actions of many federal regulatory agencies, such as the Federal Communications Commission. In recent years, the court has become at times bitterly divided between liberal judges appointed by Democratic presidents and a growing conservative faction, mostly appointed by President Reagan. Two judges nominated by President Bush, A. Raymond Randolph and Karen L. Henderson, recently took the bench. Wald denied speculation in legal circles that she was stepping aside to ensure that Laurence H. Silberman, a Reagan appointee known for his combative demeanor on the bench, does not become chief judge. ``I honestly can tell you I am doing it because of my friendship with Judge Mikva,'' Wald said. Nevertheless, Wald's decision to give Mikva a chance to serve five years as chief judge could prevent Silberman, 55, from becoming chief judge. Mikva could serve five years before being succeeded by Judge Harry Edwards, now 50, who could serve a full seven-year term. By then Silberman would be 67.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Acuse FDA Of Imperiling Supply Of French Abortion Drug
DOC.TEXT: Medical researchers accused the Food and Drug Administration Monday of imperiling their supply of a French abortion drug that shows promise in treating cancer and other diseases. Scientists are being ``whiplashed by the FDA decision'' to issue an import alert on the French drug RU-486, Dr. George P. Chrousos, of the National Institute of Child Health and Development in Bethesda, Md., said at a congressional hearing. ``I won't be able to initiate a new study'' because of the uncertain supply of RU-486, Chrousos said. He said the reluctance by the French company, Roussel-Uclaf, to supply it for research in this country was ``unethical.'' The FDA got ``carried away'' under pressure from the right-to-life movement and ``may have made a political decision,'' Chrousos added. The FDA issued an import alert in June 1989 barring the abortion drug for personal use after getting inquiries from right-to-life groups and a dozen members of Congress who oppose abortion, including Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and Rep. Robert Dornan, R-Calif. Since then, some U.S. researchers have had difficulty getting the drug from its French manufacturer, which fears its business could suffer if it becomes embroiled in an abortion controversy. The regulatory agency's import alert was not a politically motivated decision, the FDA's Ronald G. Chesemore told the House subcommittee on regulation, business opportunities and energy. And ``there was no intention'' of slowing down the supply of the drug for scientific research, said Chesemore, the FDA's associate commissioner for regulatory affairs. The drug has shown promise in treating breast and brain cancer, Cushing's Syndrome and other diseases. Cushing's Syndrome is a disorder of the pituitary gland. The FDA didn't consult leading U.S. researchers before issuing the import alert, testified Dr. Kathryn Horwitz, a professor of medicine at the University of Colorado. The FDA announced the alert 19 days after demands for it from members of Congress. ``This certainly must be a new land-speed record for an agency response to congressional inquiries,'' observed subcommittee chairman Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. He called FDA's action ``very irresponsible.'' Wyden suggested that Health and Human Services Department Secretary Louis Sullivan urge the French company to ensure adequate supplies of the drug for U.S. research. The FDA conceded that it issued the alert without evidence that there was a black market for the drug in the United States or that it was being brought here illegally. But Chesemore explained that publicity about the drug raised the possibility of ``clandestine distribution.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Militia Defies Deadline for Withdrawal from Beirut
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing Christian militia refused to evacuate Beirut before a midnight deadline Monday despite a government warning it would send troops to forceably evict the fighters. The (5 p.m EST) deadline passed with Samir's Geagea's Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia, holding out in the east Beirut districts they control. The militia served notice they would not withdraw unless the government curbs violations by Geagea's pro-Syrian rivals. The 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces and its allied Phalange Party also demanded the expulsion from Christian east Beirut of rival militiamen under Syrian-backed Maronite Catholic warlord Elie Hobeika. Lebanese President Elias Hrawi rushed to Damascus to discuss with Syrian President Hafez Assad whether to use force or further diplomacy to make Geagea leave east Beirut. Geagea's intransigence was the first major hitch in the implementation of Hrawi's plan to create a militia-free capital as he tries to end Lebanon's 15-year civil war, which has left 150,000 people dead. The largest Shiite Moslem militias - the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and the pro-Syrian Amal - have already agreed to withdraw from Beirut. Hobeika and his estimated 1,500 militiamen returned to parts of Christian east Beirut and the adjoining Metn mountains after Hrawi's troops and the Syrian army dislodged rebel Gen. Michel Aoun from the area last month. Aoun had been holed up in the presidential palace for more than a year, blocking Hrawi's efforts to end the militia war and establish an Syria-brokered peace place for Lebanon. Geagea, who deposed Hobeika in a 1986 power struggle, claims supporters of his archrival have kidnapped scores of his partisans and occupied and looted Phalangist offices in Metn province. The Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation, a televison station Geagea controls, said Hobeika's gunmen had kidnapped, beaten and tortured at least 30 civilian supporters of the Lebanese Forces. The station aired a report showing a man identified as Youssef Habshi, his back lacerated by whip lashes, moaning in pain in a hospital bed. It said he had been held captive by Hobeika's men for a week. ``Do they want us to spread this brutality to the rest of east Beirut?'' Geagea said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank President Sought in Apparent $13 Million Embezzlement
DOC.TEXT: Bank examiners investigating a possible $13 million embezzlement at a bank closed by the state studied the institution's murky records Monday while police searched for its missing president. A handful of angry depositors showed up at the Heritage Loan and Investment Co. demanding their money but were turned away by state police. Dozens more called, seeking reassurance their money was safe. The state obtained a judge's order putting the two-office bank into receivership Sunday after a four-day run drained $13.6 million of its $22.4 million in deposits and weakened a private bank insurance system. Police did not know the whereabouts of Joseph Mollicone Jr., Heritage's president and controlling stockholder, although ``our information is that he's still very healthy,'' state police Maj. Elwood M. Johnson said. He would not comment further because of a grand jury investigation. Mollicone, of Providence, disappeared Nov. 8, four days before the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corp. disclosed that Heritage's records were in disarray. The indemnity corporation is a $25 million fund that covers many credit unions and smaller banks. WJAR-TV reported last week that Mollicone last was seen taking a flight to New Jersey. ``It appears to us to be an embezzlement,'' said Peter A. Nevola, president and chief executive of the indemnity corporation, which took control of the bank Oct. 18. Almost 20 examiners and bank employees tried to reconstruct paperwork on loans that Nevola said apparently were made in the names of depositors without their knowledge. State regulators, in a Superior Court affidavit seeking the receivership, estimated the loss at $13 million, but Nevola said it could be higher. ``It appears the loans were created to plug a hole in the bank's assets to meet liabilities,'' Nevola said. Mollicone apparently served as a one-man loan committee for the bank with few controls. ``Regardless of what may have been required ... one individual disbursed the credit,'' Nevola said, though he stopped short of saying Mollicone took the money. Notices in the bank's windows told customers of the cloing. ``My company's money is in here,'' said an angry woman, who identified herself as a real estate broker. ``I need it now, not tomorrow. They shouldn't freeze it. It's wrong. It's my money, not the state's.'' Robert Goldberg, a Department of Business Regulation lawyer, answered a telephone at the bank for anxious depositors. By midday he had told about 50 callers only that the bank would reopen in a few days and that their money was insured up to $500,000 by the indemnity corporation. ``As soon as the bank opens, I expect all these people will be in'' to withdraw their money, he said. ``The last thing we want to tell them is that it will be three days and then have them banging down the door if it can't open in three days.'' Goldberg said there were a few abusive callers but most were just concerned. ``A lot of people have said they have their life savings (in the bank). It ranges from a woman with $50 in a Christmas club to one with $100,000 from the sale of a house. Frankly, the woman with $100,000 seemed less concerned than some of the others with $100,'' Goldberg said. RISDIC insures $1.6 billion in deposits at 35 credit unions and 10 banks in Rhode Island. Some of the credit unions have applied to join the federal insurance program. In a similar case in 1985, the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund collapsed after the failure of the much-larger Home State Savings Bank. Nevola said the Rhode Island agency was different because its members are obligated to replenish the fund and so far had been assessed an additional $5.5 million to do so. No other member institutions had reported large amounts of withdrawals, he said.

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Considers Challenge of Burma's Military
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. General Assembly took up a resolution Monday demanding that Burma free all political prisoners and challenging its military rulers to hand over power to the opposition. In the past, the assembly has been reluctant to delve into the internal affairs of a member state. However, many foreign countries have shown revulsion for the Burmese military's brutal suppression of the country's pro-democracy movement. Sweden introduced the draft resolution in the assembly's so-called Third Committee, which deals with human rights, free elections and other social and humanitarian issues. The committee will vote on it Nov. 28, and the entire General Assembly will do so around Dec. 18. Twenty countries co-sponsored the resolution - the 12 European Community nations along with Australia, Canada, Austria, Norway, Iceland, Poland, Sweden and Hungary. General Assembly resolutions have no binding effect, but they are a powerful expression of the international community's will. The draft resolution expresses concern over the failure of Burma's military rulers to obey ``the will of the people'' by turning over power to the opposition. Though the opposition won popular elections in May by a landslide, the military rulers of the Southeast Asian country have refused to step down. They say a new constitution must be drafted first, a lengthy process. The U.N. assembly's draft resolution also ``stresses its conviction ... that all citizens detained with respect to their political activities ought to be released immediately and restored to the full enjoyment to their right to participate in the government of their country.'' Amnesty International on Monday said Maung Ko, a senior Burmese opposition leader, had been found hanged in his cell Nov. 9. The-52 year-old leader had been detained for two weeks, the rights group said. Burma's government said he committed suicide. But Amnesty said the man's family believes he was tortured to death because his body was covered with bruises and one leg was broken. Many opposition members are imprisoned or detained. The leader of the opposition, Aung San Suu Kyi, is under house arrest. Amnesty says many hundreds, perhaps thousands, of suspected government opponents have been detained without trial or sentenced to prison terms by unfair military tribunals. At least 100 people have been sentenced to death, although it is not known if any sentences have been carried out, Amnesty said. In 1988, Burma was swept by pro-democracy protests. The military government cracked down, and hundreds of people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Reopened Into Crash That Killed Zia
DOC.TEXT: The government has questioned former ministers of deposed Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government about the 1988 plane crash that killed military ruler Mohammed Zia ul-Haq, police said Monday. No one has ever been officially blamed for the Aug. 17, 1988, crash of the C-130 transport plane that killed Zia, about a dozen of the country's top-ranking military officers and U.S. Ambassador Arnold Raphel. An inquiry by the Pakistan and U.S. military concluded it was ``an act of sophisticated technical sabotage.'' When Ms. Bhutto came into power in December 1988, further investigation was put on hold, although Zia's son, Ijaz ul-Haq, demanded a reopening of the inquiry. Some of Ms. Bhutto's opponents suggested terrorists allegedly led by her brother, Murtaza, had been involved in the crash. Her brother had been in exile in Syria.
