Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Nov. 12-19:
DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rejects CNN Bid To Broadcast Noriega Tapes
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court has refused to give Cable News Network permission to broadcast tape recordings of conversations between Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega and his lawyers. CNN, meanwhile, is demanding the FBI return a box of recordings and papers related to the case. The material was taken from an Atlanta hotel room where a CNN reporter stayed. The Supreme Court on Nov. 18 rejected an emergency request by CNN that was aimed at lifting a federal judge's order forbidding the broadcasts until he could determine what the tapes disclose. The vote was 7-2. The emergency request had called the Nov. 8 order by U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler in Miami an unconstitutional ``prior restraint'' of free speech. But only two justices - Thurgood Marshall and Sandra Day O'Connor - agreed with that assessment. Voting against CNN were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter. The Justice Department had joined Noriega's lawyers in opposing the request. CNN President Tom Johnson called the court's decision ``a loss of a battle in a continuing war against censorship.'' Johnson said the network would immediately turn the tapes in its possession over to Judge Hoeveler. He said CNN is ``confident that after he reviews them he will decide on the merits to deny the prior restraint.'' Meanwhile, many questions remained about the network material in the FBI's possession. CNN said the tapes and documents were taken by security officers from an Omni Hotel room that had been used by reporter Marlene Fernandez, who had been covering the Noriega story. Johnson said Fernandez had not checked out of the room, but the hotel staff, apparently mistakenly, cleared out her room. After taking the box from the room, the hotel's security guards saw that some of its contents were CNN property, he said. They turned the material over to Turner security officers, from whom the FBI took the box. Johnson said it was still unclear how the FBI was notified about the box. Turner Security, which provides security for the CNN Center complex, which contains both the hotel and the CNN offices, ``had a discussion with the FBI inquiring about stolen government property, and Turner Security told them they had a box that might fit that description,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said. CNN denied the material in the box was stolen. Haworth said Turner Security - a subsidiary of CNN's parent company, Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. - did not tell appropriate CNN officials it had the box. The New York Times quoted an unidentified CNN official as saying the actual Noriega recordings were not in the box. ``The FBI did not get the main course,'' the official said.
DOC.HEAD: Union Employees of UPI Accept Pay Cut
DOC.TEXT: Union employees of United Press International on Nov. 16 accepted a proposed 35-percent pay cut for 90 days. Chris Dahl, secretary-treasurer of the Wire Service Guild, said the pay cut was approved by 62 percent of those voting. The numbers voting on each side were not released. Dahl spoke by telephone from the union's headquarters in New York, where the ballots were counted. UPI vice president and spokesman Milt Capps said before the vote that if employees accepted the pay cut, the company would be in a financial condition to continue operating for 60 to 90 days while it seeks a buyer. The financially troubled, 83-year-old news service already has cut management salaries by the same percentage for 90 days. Capps had said if the pay cut were rejected, UPI might file for protection under federal bankruptcy laws within days. Union officers had recommended rejection, saying the employees could not afford the pay cut and it would not be enough to keep the company afloat. Dahl said about 310 UPI employees are members of the guild. He said the total work force covered by the union contract, counting those who are not members, is close to 400. Capps said the company does not give out information on how many bureaus or how many employees it has at home and abroad. UPI announced in September that it was closing bureaus in New Mexico, Wyoming, Montana, Michigan and North Dakota. It has since laid off an unspecified number of employees. The top scale for a newsperson at UPI is approximately $690 a week. The news service, founded in 1907 as United Press, became United Press International when it merged with Hearst's International News Service in 1958. In recent years, the company encountered financial difficulties and changed hands three times. The original owner, the E.W. Scripps Co., sold it in 1982 to Media News Corp. of Nashville, Tenn. It continued to lose money and was sold in 1985 to Mario Vasquez-Rana, a wealthy Mexican newspaper publisher. The present owner is Infotechnology Inc., parent firm to a number of high-tech ventures. Infotechnology announced this month it has retained an investment banking firm to negotiate the sale of its companies, and hopes to sell them by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Struggles To Lift Circulation
DOC.TEXT: Circulation remained a serious problem for the Daily News as it continued to publish in the third week of a strike. A spot check of news vendors around the city showed that many who have stopped selling the paper have no plans to take it back until the strike is over. The manager of a newsstand at 50th Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan said he was visited by ``some union guys, goons, who said they would put a chain around the whole stand and pull it off its foundation.'' Others threatened to pour gasoline on the stand and burn it. Daily News circulation representatives visited him Nov. 14. The manager, who would give his name only as ``Danny,'' said they offered him round-the-clock protection and a $25 daily discount on his pre-strike purchase of 350 papers a day, normally about $99. He declined. The Daily News, using management, replacement workers and about 150 Newspaper Guild members who are working, has published every day since the strike began Oct. 25. But circulation has been a major problem. The News said earlier that it was printing 600,000 papers a day and selling about 400,000, down from 1.09 million before the strike. It said 2,000 of its usual 12,000 outlets were selling the paper. At least 39 vendors have reported being threatened or harassed. Police said they had recorded 168 incidents and 81 arrests since the strike began. The News has hired hawkers, including homeless and other unemployed people in an attempt to fill the void. The Police Department said it has spent $4.2 million on straight pay and overtime for hundreds of officers and supervisors assigned to the strike - an average of $233,899 a day. Meanwhile, a striking Daily News truck driver was arrested Nov. 16 and accused of setting explosions at an all-night convenience store on Long Island. Charles Esposito, 47, was arrested in a car seen leaving a Seven-11 store in Westbury around the time two small bombs exploded, causing minor injuries to the manager and a customer. The day before, the municipal workers union offered to provide bus fare home for out-of-town replacement workers who leave. The New York Times reported that a security firm hired by the Daily News used unemployed veterans and other jobless men from the South to drive delivery trucks and collect money from vendors. Some of the men were reportedly unable to return to their homes as they wished, because they had no transportation. Two men told the Times that Daily News management wanted to videotape them and other guards being beaten by strikers, then use the evidence against the unions in court. News publisher James Hoge, in a letter to Times Executive Editor Max Frankel, said the story was distorted. He said one of the men never worked for the security company and the other worked for one day. In another development, Marcia Kramer, City Hall bureau chief for the News since 1986, joined WCBS-TV as a full-time reporter.
DOC.HEAD: Bay Area Papers Reach Agreement With Unions
DOC.TEXT: Marathon negotiations produced a tentative agreement Nov. 17 that averted a strike at the Bay Area's three largest newspapers. The 45-month pact calls for a 3.5 percent to 4 percent annual wage increase for the unions representing some 4,500 employees at the San Francisco Examiner, San Francisco Chronicle and the San Jose Mercury News. Union leaders indicated the votes on the proposed contract would be taken sometime after Thanksgiving. Employees had been without a contract since February. A strike deadline of 5 p.m., Nov. 16, had been set, but talks continued through the night. After 48 continuous hours of negotiations, union officials announced the tentative pact. The settlement would provide $89 per week more over the course of the contract, which expires in November 1993, for craft unions such as printers and engravers, and $95 for reporters, editors and drivers. Current top scale is $801 a week for reporters and editors, $669 for clerical and library workers and $675 for drivers. The unions had sought a 20 percent wage hike. The three papers have a combined circulation of about 1 million. Doug Cuthbertson, chairman of the Conference of Newspaper Unions, said, ``At this time of terrible economic difficulties for news and other businesses across the country, I think the employers have given us every last cent they could afford to.''

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Journal Shutting Philadelphia Bureau
DOC.TEXT: The Wall Street Journal says it is closing its Philadelphia bureau at the end of the year to save money and will transfer or lay off the office's 10 news workers. The number of layoffs wasn't announced, though a union official said six reporters would lose their jobs. Dow Jones & Co., which publishes the Journal, believes it can maintain the quality of its news coverage by transferring stories handled by the Philadelphia office to the New York staff, spokesman Roger May said Nov. 13. Ronald Chen, president of the 1,800-member Independent Association of Publishers' Employees, disagreed. Quality will suffer ``unless they're going to tell you people who are working 10 or 11 hours a day can heap two hours on top of that,'' he said. Dow Jones recently announced a 17.5 percent drop in third-quarter profit, reflecting declining advertising and the acquisition of the financial information service, Telerate Inc. Dow Jones has no plans to close any of its remaining 13 domestic news bureaus, May said. In another cost-cutting move, May said Dow Jones plans to relocate certain overseas editors to consolidate all copy editing in New York. Some of the overseas workers will probably lose their jobs, he said. The company also will close its newspaper composing operation in Naperville, Ill., leaving the paper with three other sites for newspaper makeup around the nation. Chen said that closing and other recent layoffs had cost 46 employees their jobs. May said he was unable to give precise figures for layoffs or the potential savings.
DOC.HEAD: Interest in Economic News Jumps Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis was the news story most closely followed by the American public last month, although interest in economic conditions jumped markedly, according to a poll released Nov. 14. Nearly two-thirds of a nationwide sample of adults questioned in a Times-Mirror poll said they were very closely following the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and the presence of U.S. military forces in Saudi Arabia. It was the fourth consecutive month the gulf situation has been the top story. Interest in the plight of U.S. hostages in Iraq and Kuwait was also high, with 49 percent saying they were following the story closely. Interest in the economy rose to its highest point for the year, 39 percent. That was 10 points higher than in September and only one point below the level of public interest the Times-Mirror poll found in the October 1987 stock market crash. And 38 percent of those polled said they followed news about elections and campaigns in their states - about on a par with this year's turnout level, estimated at 36 percent. A month earlier, only 18 percent reported paying close attention to election news. The budget negotiations on Capitol Hill intensified and concluded in October, but the level of public interest stayed the same as October - 34 percent. Only 46 percent of those questioned knew that Congress had adjourned after reaching an agreement, the poll found. Thirty percent thought it had adjourned without one and 24 percent had no idea. The Times-Mirror Center for The People and The Press questioned 1,208 people nationwide from Nov. 8-11. The margin of error for the poll was plus or minus 3 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Reporters Must Find Own Hotels in South America
DOC.TEXT: Reporters traveling with President Bush to South America will have to find their own accommodations at some stops on the trip. Hotel rooms will be arranged by the White House in Chile, Brazil and Venezuela, but reporters are on their own in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and in Montevideo and Punta del Este, Uruguay. White House officials said only that hotel rooms for White House staff and the full press corps could not be procured. Generally, the White House travel office canvasses the press corps to see who will accompany Bush and then takes care of all the travel and hotel arrangements, with news organizations paying the bills incurred by their employees.

DOC.HEAD: Price Relinquishes Day-to-Day Control at The National
DOC.TEXT: The president and publisher of The National has been relieved of day-to-day duties at the sports daily and three other top executives have been dismissed, a company spokesman confirmed Nov. 12. An executive associated with the Mexican media and entertainment concern that is the paper's biggest shareholder has been brought in to take greater control of operations at the 9-month-old newspaper. The newspaper has also laid off 18 news employees. Spokesman Steve Hammond said they were mostly support workers like layout designers and copy editors at sites across the country.. The moves come as the paper continues to absorb heavy losses in its bid to succeed as the United States' first national sports daily. Backers of the newspaper have run into a miserable advertising climate and skepticism about the potential audience for a daily publication devoted exclusively to sports. Peter O. Price will continue to hold the titles of president and publisher but will be involved with broad, non-operational issues, Hammond said. He said Price would be involved, for instance, in planning for the rollout into new markets. The National is available in nine markets with plans to expand into three more - Baltimore-Washington, Philadelphia and Atlanta - by early 1991. Hammond said the three executives dismissed were Diane Morgenthaler, circulation director; Timothy Lasker, assistant publisher, and Daniel W. Correa, finance and administration director. He said none of the three has yet been replaced. He described the changes as a ``business decision,'' but declined to elaborate. Hammond said Jaime Davila has been brought in to assume Price's operating responsibilities at the newspaper, whose biggest shareholder is Emilio Azcarraga, the Mexican media baron. Davila is a top executive at Univisa Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of Mexico's Televisa entertainment and publishing concern that Azcarraga heads. It was disclosed earlier that The National will cease publishing a Sunday edition after Nov. 25 and publish only on weekdays. The paper had been publishing six days a week, Sunday through Friday, since its launch Jan. 31. Editor in Chief Frank Deford also said earlier that there will be a handful of jobs cuts at the paper, which employs about 200 people, but that he hoped the cuts could be made through attrition rather than layoffs. The National was launched in three cities - New York, CHicago and Los Angeles - and has since begun publishing editions in San Diego, San Francisco, Detroit, Dallas, Boston and Miami.
DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Boosts Ad Rates by 7 Percent at Barron's
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said Nov. 16 it would boost advertising rates by 7 percent for Barron's National Business and Financial Weekly, effective in January. It was the latest in a recent series of announced increases at publications, including Time, Newsweek and U.S. News & World Report magazines, despite a recent slump in demand for print and broadcast advertising. The increase came two weeks after the weekly announced it would boost its cover price by 50 cents to $2.50 effective Dec. 3 and annual subscription prices by $10 a year - to $109 in 1991. Barron's last advertising rate increase was 5.5 percent a year ago. This year's 7 percent increase applies to national and regional editions. The national rate for a full-page ad will rise to $15,488. Barron's publisher Robert Paradise said the increase was fair and reasonable given the publication's efficiency in reaching top corporate executives, financial professionals and individual investors.
DOC.HEAD: Audit Bureau Gives Newspaper an Exemption
DOC.TEXT: The Philadelphia Inquirer said Nov. 12 it had been given permission to count about 33,000 subscribers that an industry panel had previously cut from its circulation figures. The newspaper said the Audit Bureau of Circulations' board had exempted it from an interpretation of rules that had disallowed 38,957 subscribers from its circulation figures. The Chicago-based bureau, citing its policy of confidentiality, declined to comment. The ruling means the Inquirer will report average daily circulation of 519,894 for the six months ending Sept. 30, a gain of 14,991 over the same period last year. The previous ruling would have cut the official Inquirer circulation to 485,973, and dropped it from 12th to 16th place among U.S. newspapers. At issue was a marketing effort that delivered newspapers to suburban readers two or three days a week. Only 87 percent of these newspapers were delivered, however, prompting the bureau to eliminate all 38,957 from the Inquirer's circulation. The Inquirer protested, noting that the marketing program had been in effect since 1985 in New Jersey and more than a year in Pennsylvania suburbs, and had been implemented in consultation with the bureau. The newspaper did not dispute the 87 percent figure, blaming missed deliveries on independent distributors. The Inquirer appealed to the bureau's board, asking that 87 percent of the 38,957 be counted. The board upheld its position that 100 percent delivery is required for special programs, but exempted the Inquirer and agreed to count 87 percent, or 33,392, Fancher said. ``Our circulation gains are real and were undisputed by the ABC staff, and we believe the board's decision serves the best interests of all concerned,'' Inquirer Publisher Robert J. Hall said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher To Start New Weekly in Fairbanks
DOC.TEXT: Alaska Rural Newspapers plans to start a weekly newspaper in Fairbanks beginning Dec. 10, company President John Lindauer said. The Fairbanks Tribune will join two other newspapers in the city, the Fairbanks Daily News-Miner and the All-Alaska Weekly. ``I think it's a good market,'' Lindauer said. ``I think with the development of (the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge) and the gas pipeline, the economy is going to boom.'' Lindauer, 51, was the Alaskan Independence Party's candidate for governor this year until he resigned after the primary and allowed Wally Hickel to head the ticket instead. Hickel, who favors opening the continental shelf of the ANWR to oil and gas development, went on to win the election. Lindauer said the newspaper will be an advocate for projects he thinks will be good for the community. ``You can count on the Fairbanks Tribune to be an advocate for expansion of the Alaska Railroad, opening of ANWR and construction of the gas line,'' he said. The Tribune, a tabloid, will be priced at 50 cents an issue, with 20 to 28 pages initially. The size of the staff wasn't immediately determined. Alaska Rural Newspapers publishes the Alaska Commercial Fisherman magazine and seven other weekly newspapers, in Barrow, Valdez, Bethel, Dutch Harbor, Dillingham, King Cove-Sand Point and King Salmon.
DOC.HEAD: Vancouver Sn To Go All-Day
DOC.TEXT: The Vancouver Sun hopes to boost circulation by switching from afternoon to all-day publication, Editor in Chief Nick Hills said. The change is expected to begin Jan. 28. The Sun's first edition, which now comes off the press at 8:15 a.m. PST, would be moved up to 6 a.m. The final edition would be updated until about 11 a.m., Hills said. The Sun has a weekday circulation of about 210,000. Hills said market research indicated an early-morning edition could boost the daily circulation by 15,000.
DOC.HEAD: Newburgh Paper Expanding to All-Day Format
DOC.TEXT: The Newburgh Evening News will publish morning and evening editions beginning Nov. 25, Publisher James Bartee said. The new will be known as the Hudson Valley Morning News and the Hudson Valley Evening News. Each will have two editions, one serving the area west of Newburgh, the other serving the region to the east across the Hudson River. The newspaper will feature color photos and graphics as well as expanded news coverage, Bartee said Nov. 13. The 105-year-old paper is owned by Thomson Newspapers Inc. and has a daily circulation of 9,750.
DOC.HEAD: Macon Newspaper Returns to Previous Name
DOC.TEXT: The Macon Telegraph and News has changed its name back to The Macon Telegraph, which it had been known by until a merger seven years ago. The Nov. 12 name change marks the disappearance of the last vestige of The Macon News, the daily afternoon newspaper that was merged with The Macon Telegraph in 1983.
DOC.HEAD: Yale President Changes Mind About Scrapping Literary Journal
DOC.TEXT: Yale President Benno C. Schmidt Jr. has reversed his decision to halt publication of The Yale Review after a campaign by more than 50 writers to save the 79-year-old literary quarterly. Schmidt announced his change of heart in a letter to some of the journal's supporters, including Chester Kerr, former director of the Yale University Press, which publishes the quarterly. ``I have reconsidered my conclusion about The Yale Review and intend to try to give it a bright future,'' Schmidt said in the letter dated Oct. 30. Schmidt said he would outline his plans for the Review later in November. In June, he announced the Review would be shelved, citing deficits that the university could no longer absorb and limited readership. He noted the Review doesn't have any direct ties to Yale academic programs. More than 50 novelists, poets, professors and critics, including Iris Murdoch, Joyce Carol Oates, Adrienne Rich, George Plimpton, Richard Wilbur and Susan Sontag, signed an appeal asking Schmidt to reconsider his decision.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Expects To Post Loss for Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. said Nov. 19 it expects to report a loss for the fourth quarter and decreased earnings from continuing operations for all of 1991 compared with this year. The media giant said its anticipated loss for the fourth quarter stemmed from unexpectedly large losses at the CBS Television Network from broadcasts of major league baseball and a slowdown in advertising. The last quarterly loss excluding onetime events at CBS was in the fourth quarter of 1986, when the company lost $20 million on continuing operations. CBS earned $59.5 million, or $2.31 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989. It said earnings from continuing operations are expected to be lower in 1991 than in 1990 because of the worsening climate for advertising and rising costs for entertainment programs and sports rights. The disclosures came as CBS senior exectives planned to meet with the CBS affiliates board. Earlier, the network said its decision to dismiss three producers from its ``60 Minutes'' program was a result of a staff restructuring and was not related to belt-tightening in the news division. The move was ordered after Harry Reasoner, one of the show's first correspondents, announced he would reduce his workload, said spokesman Roy Brunett. ABC News, meanwhile, said Nov. 16 it will close its Frankfurt, Germany, bureau and three Central American offices. ABC said last month it would close its Chicago, Boston and Dallas bureaus. The latest moves were part of an overseas reorganization, said a network executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ABC declined to comment on the Frankfurt closing. The network also said it would expand its Moscow and Berlin bureaus as part of a reorganization of its overseas operations. About nine people will be let go because of the reorganization, an ABC source said. ABC News said it also would close its offices in Panama, El Salvador and Honduras, but keep its Nicaragua office open.
DOC.HEAD: CBS Cuts Back Convention, Cites Lean Times
DOC.TEXT: CBS, citing difficult economic times, said Nov. 16 it's scaling back its usually lavish affiliates' convention next June, and moving the convention from Los Angeles to New York. Network conventions in past years have been three-day affairs, a mix of business, parties where guests include TV stars, and recreational events for station executives and their spouses. NBC said it is reviewing its convention plans, but has made no decision yet. ABC said its convention will be scaled back somewhat. Next June's CBS convention will last only a day and a half and concentrate on business, and no spouses are invited, said CBS spokesman George Schweitzer. ``We've substantially scaled it back and changed the venue,'' he said. The usual convention business, including the screening of new series, still will go on, he said, but ``minus the embellishments.'' ``It will be more of a business meeting than a three-day adventure.'' ABC still will hold its three-day convention in Los Angeles, and spouses of the executives still will be invited, said ABC spokeswoman Janice Gretemeyr. But there'll be ``more stress on business'' this time, she said.
DOC.HEAD: CBS Founder William S. Paley Gets Final Salute
DOC.TEXT: paid final tribute to CBS founder William S. Paley on Nov. 12. ``He was a master builder and CBS was his monument,'' said Frank Stanton, a former CBS vice chairman who was with Paley and CBS in the glory days of radio, then television, before he was forced to retire in 1973. Paley died Oct. 25 at age 89. About 2,500 people attended memorial services at Temple Emanu-El. Guests included former President Nixon and Carl Bernstein, whose Watergate reporting helped lead to Nixon's resignation. They and others heard Paley hailed by former CBS anchorman Walter Cronkite and Henry Kissinger, once on opposite sides of the fence. Both are now CBS board members. Cronkite said Paley had ``held steadfast'' to a conviction that only a strong news organization with ``a reputation for fairness and impartiality could withstand the inevitable charges of bias and prejudice and the inevitable attempts to corrupt.''
DOC.HEAD: Time, PBS' ``NEwsHour'' To Join Forces in Experiment
DOC.TEXT: In a print and TV experiment that could become permanent, Time magazine will provide ``The MacNeil-Leherer NewsHour'' with periodic documentary reports and occasional reports from Time correspondents. The experiment ``will determine the potential of an on-going relationship between the two organizations,'' said the Nov. 16 announcement by the weeknight public television news program. The test will start immediately, said Chris Ramsey, a spokesman for the one-hour PBS show. ``NewsHour'' now has 11 correspondents worldwide, with reports also contributed by reporters at PBS stations around the United States. Under the agreement, Time will supply the program with documentary reports co-produced with ``NewsHour,'' and will provide Time correspondents for live interviews ``when breaking news warrants,'' the program said.
DOC.HEAD: Battle Shaping Up Over HDTV Technology Choice
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission said it will start a year-long series of tests in April to determine which of five competing systems should be the U.S. standard for high-definition television. The FCC should decide the issue by June 1993. The applicants include the Japan Broadcasting Corp. and Europe's major TV manufacturers, which already are beginning to implement their own systems overseas. The commission also said Nov. 14 it will test a sixth proposal, a partial HDTV system being proposed by a David Sarnoff Research Center consortium that includes Thomson Consumer Electronics and NBC.
DOC.HEAD: Another 24-Hour Cable News Channel Planned
DOC.TEXT: A Washington communications company plans to start a 24-hour cable channel for local news, betting on the enormous appetite for information in the country's eighth-largest market. ``There is an enormous niche market on the county level waiting to be served,'' said John D. Hillis, president of Allbritton Communications. ``We hope to combine the best of the local daily And weekly newspapers and radio with the immediacy of TV.'' The cable channel, ALLNEWSCO, is to begin next spring and will provide separate programs for the District of Columbia, northern Virginia and suburban Maryland, Hillis said Nov. 14. He said five of the area's eight major cable systems, representing about 500,000 of the 625,000 Washington area cable subscribers, have already signed up for the service. Hillis was part of the team that launched Cable News Network and also helped establish Channel 12 on Long Island, a 24-hour, local-news channel. Allbritton Communications owns five television stations, including WJLA-TV in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Myhren Appointed Providence Journal President
DOC.TEXT: Trygve E. Myhren, former head of Time Warner's cable television subsidiary, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Providence Journal Co. Myhren, 53, is currently president of Myhren Media in Denver and Greenwood Cable Management, which owns and manages cable TV systems throughout the Southwest. The Journal Co. publishes The Providence Journal-Bulletin. Chairman Stephen Hamblett said Myhren will start Dec. 1. Myhren was chairman and chief executive officer of Time Warner's American Television and Communications for seven years. He left the company in 1988 when Time Warner moved it to New York City.
DOC.HEAD: Bureau Chiefs Named in Arizona, New Mexico
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press has appointed new bureau chiefs in Arizona and New Mexico. Charlotte Porter will head the Phoenix bureau and Dale Leach the Albuquerque bureau. The appointments were announced Nov. 14 by APBoccardi. In Phoenix, Ms. Porter succeeds Gavin Scott, who is retiring. In Albuquerque, Leach succeeds Mark Mittelstadt, who has been named chief of bureau for New Jersey. Ms. Porter, 36, joined the AP in Minneapolis in 1976. She worked in the Sioux Falls and Pierre, S.D., bureaus before transferring in 1979 to the General Desk at AP's New York headquarters. She was named news editor in Atlanta in 1988, and in 1989 was appointed assistant chief of bureau there. Leach, 39, joined the AP in Columbus in 1981. He was appointed news editor there in 1984 and assistant chief of bureau in 1988. Before joining the AP, he worked for the Beavercreek Daily News in Dayton, Ohio, and the Springfield Newspapers Inc., in Springfield, Ohio.
DOC.HEAD: John Cameron Named Editor in Selma
DOC.TEXT: John Cameron, a veteran newspaperman and journalism teacher, was named the new editor of the Selma Times-Journal on Nov. 4. The position was unfilled previously. Cameron replaces Managing Editor Jeff Stumb, who left to become publisher of the twice-weekly Brewton Standard. Cameron has owned and operated newspapers in the area for almost 20 years and has taught journalism at the University of Alabama, the University of South Alabama and Mobile College. He recently purchased the Sumter County Journal in York.
DOC.HEAD: Keirnan and Doctor Share Managing Editor Duties
DOC.TEXT: Mindi Keirnan, a Gannett News Service editor, and Ken Doctor, associate managing editor-features at the Saint Paul Pioneer Press, have been named co-managing editors at the newspaper. Keirnan was managing editor-days at the news service's Washington headquarters. She will direct news and Doctor will handle features, splitting the duties of former managing editor Mark Nadler, who left the paper in October to become executive editor and vice president of the Chicago Sun-Times. Doctor, 40, joined the Pioneer Press in 1986 after serving as managing editor-features at the Boulder, Colo., Daily Camera. Keirnan, 34, has also held editor positions at the Tallahassee Democrat, the Detroit Free Press and Crain's Chicago Business. The announcement was made Nov. 12 by Editor Walker Lundy.
DOC.HEAD: Downing Promoted to ME at Houston Post
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Downing, metropolitan editor of The Houston Post for the past two years, has been promoted to managing editor. She succeeds Charles Cooper, who was earlier named senior vice president and editor. Downing, 38, joined the Post in December 1980 as a reporter. She was also assistant business editor and assistant city editor. Downing previously worked at the Dallas Times Herald, the Beaumont ENterprise and Journal and the Corpus Christi Caller-Times.

Stan Z. Burns, whose clear voice was instantly recognizable to thousands of New Yorkers as a radio anchorman at the all-news station WINS-AM, died Nov. 16. He was 63. The cause of death was not disclosed. Burns, who lived in Manhattan, began working at the station in May 1944. During his 40-year career, Burns covered major news events, Including the New York blackouts and transit strikes. He was one of the first disc jockeys in the United States to play a Beatles record when WINS was a rock 'n' roll station. Burns is survived by his son, daughter and former wife.

Henri Deramond, founder of the French agricultural news agency Agra-Presse, died Nov. 8 in Pamiers, his hometown in southern France. He was 79. Deramond was trained as an agricultural engineer and became director of the industry journal Farmers' Liberation in 1944. Three years later he founded Agra-Presse and was president until 1978. From 1971-73, he was president of the French Federation of News Agencies and remained as honorary president. He was also honorary president of the Association of Agricultural Journalists. Deramond was married twice and had two daughters from his first marriage.

Don Duncan, news editor of The Brownsville Herald for more than 20 years, died Nov. 12. He was 58. Duncan had suffered numerous health problems since undergoing cancer surgery in January. He returned to the Herald on a part-time basis last month, and worked the day he died. Duncan joined the Herald in the early 1950s. After a U.S. Army tour of duty, he returned as a photographer. He later served as sports editor and then city editor before becoming news editor in the early 1960s. Survivors include his wife, mother, two daughters, a son, two brothers, two sisters and five grandchildren.

Robert Horwood, who wrote for The Daily Racing Form and The Morning Telegraph for 35 years, died Nov. 12 of cancer. He was 87. Horwood began writing for the Telegraph, a horse racing newspaper, in 1934 and became turf editor of the Los Angeles edition of the Racing Form in 1940. He covered tracks in New York and Florida before retiring in 1970. Survivors include his wife and granddaughter.
DOC.HEAD: Levin Houston
DOC.TEXT: Levin James Houston III, associate professor emeritus of music at Mary Washington College and arts reviewer for The Free Lance-Star for more than 50 years, died Nov. 12. He was 85. Houston taught music at the college for 35 years before retiring from teaching in 1972. He reviewed art, books, dance, theater and music for the newspaper, including opera and classical. EArlier, he wrote a gardening column. Houston is survived by a daughter.

John H. Johnston II, former general manager of The Times of Leavenworth, died Nov. 12. He was 82. Johnston worked for the newspaper for 37 years and was general manager and advertising manager for more than 20 years. He later served as a classification officer at the Kansas State Penitentiary. He is survived by his wife, son, brother, two sisters and two granddaughters.

Robert N. Lindsay, who served as a correspondent in AFrica for The Associated Press and later as an AP business manager in London, died Nov. 13 in Peterhead, Scotland, following a long illness. He was 80. Lindsay joined the news cooperative in London in 1945. In the 1960s, as black Africa gained independence from its colonial rulers, he served as chief of bureau in Nigeria, South Africa and the Congo, now Zaire. In 1967 he returned to London as business manager with responsibility for the United Kingdom, Africa and the Middle East. He retired in 1972. Survivors include his wife and son.

James J. McGiffin, president of the Fairfield Daily Ledger Inc., died of a heart attack Nov. 2 while in Spain. He was 66. McGiffin began work at The Ledger when he was 12, when his father was publisher. He was the fourth generation of the W.W. Junkin family associated with the newspaper since 1851. McGiffin worked as circulation and advertising manager, and in 1958 became publisher of the Daily Record in Ellensburg, Wash., which his family also owns. He died in Santiago deCompostela Spain, and was buried in that country. Survivors include his wife son, two daughters, five grandchildren and a sister.

NEW YORK (AP) David Toufic Mizrahi, publisher of an influential newsletter specializing in Middle EAst politics and economics, died Nov. 9. He was 64. Mizrahi, who lived in Tenafly, N.J., had been undergoing chemotherapy for cancer and died of complications resulting from pneumonia. He was editor and publisher of the New York City-based newsletter MidEast Report. Mizrahi appeared regularly as a guest on national tlevision news programs, including the MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour. Mizrahi was a newspaper editor in Beirut before he emigrated to the United States in 1960 and worked as a foreign correspondent in for several Middle East newspapers. In 1988, he helped establish International Commentary Service, a not-for-profit educational and media organization. Survivors include his wife and three daughters.

Murray Moler, a former associate editor of the Ogden Standard-Examiner and bureau manager for United Press International, died Nov. 8 of a heart attack. He was 74. Moler wrote more than 13,000 editorials and nearly a thousand columns during 19 years as editor of the newspaper's opinion pages. BEfore that he spent 25 years with UPI, most of that time as bureau manager in Salt Lake CIty. The stories he covered included the Japanese surrender at the end of World War II aboard the battleship Missouri. Moler retired in 1982. Survivors include his wife and four children.

Malcolm Muggeridge, a journalist who gained celebrity for his caustic commentaries on post-imperial Britain, died Nov. 14 in a Sussex nursing home, a laywer for the family said. He was 87. The lawyer, Vernor Miles, said Muggeridge never fully recovered from a stroke he suffered three months ago. Muggeridge was a correspondent in the Soviet Union for Britain's liberal Guardian newspaper from 1932-33. He was mainly a freelance journalist but also held high-powered staff jobs such as the deputy editorship of Britain's conservative Daily Telegraph, and editorship of the satirical magazine Punch. ``Life holds no more wretched occupation than trying to make the English laugh,'' was his verdict on Punch in a 1966 collection of Essays entitled, ``Tread Softly, For You Tread On My Jokes.'' Muggeridge is survived by his wife, two sons and one daughter.

Jack E. Swift, vice president and executive editor of the Columbus Ledger-Enquirer, was found dead at home Nov. 15 of what authorities said appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 46. Swift was a reporter, a sportswriter and assistant city editor with newspapers in St. Petersburg and Tampa, Fla., before coming to Columbus in 1973. He began writing a column for the Ledger-Enquirer in 1974. He became press secretary for Lt. Gov. Zell Miller in 1977 but returned to the Ledger-Enquirer in 1979 as associate editor and columnist. He became executive editor and vice president of the Ledger-Enquirer in 1987. He is survived by a sister and a brother.

Carl A. Vines Jr., a former newsman for United Press International and arts critic for The Knoxville News-Sentinel, died Nov. 19 after being ill for several weeks. He was 64. Vines worked as a reporter and editor for several newspapers in Georgia and South Carolina before joining UPI in South Carolina in the mid-1960s. In 1967, he became manager of the wire service's Knoxville bureau. A year later, he married Georgiana Fry, then a reporter for the News-Sentinel and now an assistant managing editor. Vines left UPI in 1978 to become a writer and editor for the Tennessee Valley Authority. He also was a symphony and theater critic for the News-Sentinel. Vines retired from TVA in 1988. In addition to his wife, survivors include his daughter, mother and four brothers.
DOC.HEAD: NOTES FROM
DOC.TEXT: Linda Ellerbee, who left NBC in 1986 after it canceled her ``NBC News Overnight,'' said she may return in a daytime information series. After leaving NBC, she was co-anchor of ABC News' ``Our World,'' which was dropped after one season. Ellerbee said she has taped a pilot for the new show, but won't say anything else. ... As CBS anchorman for 19 years, Walter Cronkite was often approached by well-wishers who urged him to run for office. Cronkite, lecturing at Harvard University, said, ``NOt once did any of them - and there were quite a lot - not once did they ask me where I stood on the issues. Not once.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev joined European leaders today in signing a historic treaty that cuts conventional forces in Europe and pushes the Cold War deeper into history. ``It is the farthest-reaching arms agreement in history and it signals the new world order that is emerging,'' Bush said in a glittering signing ceremony. The long-sought agreement to destroy tens of thousands of tanks, artillery and armored combat vehicles in Europe is the most sweeping arms accord in history. It was signed as prelude to a 34-nation summit originally called to discuss European security in the post Cold War era, but shadowed by the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We are putting an end to the previous age,'' French President Francois Mitterrand declared as he put his signature to the treaty documents. One by one the other leaders followed suit, with Gorbachev the last one to wield the pen. As the treaty was passed back to Mitterrand, the roomful of leaders applauded theirwork. ---= PARIS (AP) - President Bush demanded today that Iraq's Saddam Hussein ``turn tail 180 degrees'' and withdraw from Kuwait. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Saddam ``has to be removed by force'' unless he pulls out soon. The two leaders, meeting over breakfast before a 34-nation summit, underscored their hardline stand against Iraq's aggression. The president also dismissed Saddam's proposal to begin releasing foreign hostages beginning on Christmas. ``This cynicism of starting to release them on Christmas Day will be seen by the world as a total ploy,'' Bush said. Opening a joint news conference with Mrs. Thatcher, Bush said, ``Not surprisingly, we see eye to eye on the gulf.'' ---= UNDATED (AP) - President Bush today dismissed Iraq's new promise to release all remaining hostages by March as a cynical ploy and won the strongest endorsement yet from an ally for a U.N. resolution authorizing an attack on Iraqi forces. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said Saddam Hussein can avoid war only by withdrawing quickly from Kuwait. ``Most people understand evil has to be stopped. Either he withdraws, or the military option has to be used,'' she said after breakfast with Bush in Paris, where NATO and Warsaw Pact leaders signed an arms reduction treaty. But other key Western allies - GErmany and Italy - said all options short of war must first be exhausted. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Syria, a newfound U.S. ally against Saddam Hussein, has a chemical weapons arsenal at least as dangerous as Iraq's, U.S. experts say. The two nations are believed to be the biggest producers of chemical weapons in the Mideast, creating hundreds of tons of the deadly gas each year. World attention has focused on Iraq's chemical capability in the three months since its unprovoked invasion of neighboring Kuwait. Washington's relations with Damascus, strained for many years over Syria's support for international terrorism and its hardline positions against Israel, have warmed in recent weeks since the Syrians joined the anti-Iraq coalition. Syria has promised to send 15,000 troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Iraq in Saudi Arabia. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Supreme Court is condoning at least brief ``gag orders'' against the news media by refusing to let Cable News Network broadcast tape-recorded conversations of Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega, say free press advocates. They said the justices' action Sunday was extraordinary and poses grave risks to unfettered reporting of court proceedings nationwide. Attorney Floyd Abrams, who is representing CNN, said, ``The court has left an opening through which defense lawyers and prosecutors may try to muzzle news articles.'' The high court's 7-2 rejection of CNN's emergency request ``does seem to countenance brief prior restraints of a few days' duration based on almost no showing of need at all,'' he said. ---= TOKYO (AP) - Japanese companies have set their sights on doing business with Vietnam, which many avoided for years in order not to upset the United States. ``It's Vietnam fever,'' said Tatsuo Torigoe, an Asia division manager of Kanematsu Corp., Japan's major trading house. ``The time has finally come for us to make a move.'' Analysts in Tokyo believe Japanese televisions, refrigerators and other household goods will soon fill shops in Vietnam as they do in other nations around the globe. They also expect Japanese businessmen to buy more Vietnamese petroleum. Oil already accounts for more than half Japan's imports from the Southeast Asian nation, which is impoverished but rich in resource.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Monday PMs Nov 26 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Delaying Tactics Prolong One-Party Rule in Africa
An AP Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Promises have been made a year after Africans braved tear gas and gunfire to shout for democracy in more than a dozen capitals, but not a single one-party government has been unseated. Fifteen regimes have said they would accept multiparty rule, but there is no sign that democratically elected administrations will replace any of them soon. Leaders who could not crush protest movements with troops and arrests have turned to delaying tactics. While paying lip service to democracy with promises of free elections, critics say, they use a bag of dirty tricks to stay in power. Those who mimicked the communist system and told their people to look there for inspiration were taken at their word when East Europeans started demanding freedom. After the collapse of Communist parties in the Soviet bloc, the writing was on the wall for Africa's one-party governments. Western nations that helped corrupt leaders, in order to keep them from the Soviet orbit, found it difficult to justify more support. ``There is no true development without genuine democracy,'' Jacques Pelletier, the French minister in charge of relations with Africa, said recently. France is a staunch advocate of aid to Third World countries, but Pelletier's comments echoed those of African opposition leaders, not governments. At a conference on Africa, Herman Cohen, U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs, said governments that resisted their people's demands for democracy would find themselves ``in an increasingly disadvantageous position'' in the competition for aid. Bans on opposition parties have been lifted in six countries: Benin, Cape Verde, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Sao Tome and Zaire. Nine have agreed to move toward ending one-party government, but opposition parties are not yet operating. They are Angola, Cameroon, Congo, Guinea Bissau, Mozambique, Niger, Rwanda, Somalia and Zambia. The first show of unrest came from Benin, where protesters stoned a statue of Lenin. They blamed the nation's bankruptcy on the Marxist-Leninist ideology adopted by President Mathieu Kerekou, who gained power in a coup, and demanded his resignation. Kerekou renounced communism in response and said his government was writing a new constitution to liberalize the economy and guarantee human rights. In a move later copied by President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, he appointed a transition government but set no date for himself to step down. Mobutu shocked Zaire in April when, under intense pressure from the United States and other Western backers, he said he would give in to demands for multiparty democracy. Student unrest continued and Belgium, the former colonial power, accused Zairean commandos in May of killing more than 100 at Lubumbashi University. Mobutu's government claimed only one student was killed and blamed local government officials. In November, six months after Mobutu legalized opposition parties, soldiers still were breaking up their meetings. On NOv. 6, opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi said Mobutu had ordered him prevented from leaving the country to meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in the United States. Other leaders, like President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo and Joseph Momoh of Sierra Leone, have said no to change and often have called out soldiers to enforce the decision. Gabon moved closer to democracy than the others when President Omar Bongo was forced to conduct the first multiparty general election in 22 years. Several rounds of voting had to be held because voters smashed ballot boxes, burned government cars and attacked officials they claimed were rigging the election. Bongo emerged with a bare majority in the National Assembly, but his term as president does not expire for three years. Ivory Coast held its first contested presidential election in October. Police dispersed opposition campaign rallies with tear gas and clubs. On election day, voters smashed ballot boxes and claimed fraud. Government-controlled television and radio denied the opposition access until the campaign was nearly over, then censored their statements. Laurent Gbagbo, a history professor, was the only opposition candidate. Two others could not raise bonds equivalent to $80,000 each, which the government announced as a requirement one week before the 10-day campaign began. Everyone expected the victory of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the octogenarian who has ruled since independence from France in 1960, but many doubt he got the 81.67 percent of the vote his government claims. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Michelle Faul, now based in Abidjan, has covered Africa for 14 years.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday PMs Nov 26
For Release Wed PMs, Nov 21 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Shaped Note Singing Spreads Throughout Country
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In a hollow square at the front of the plain, wooden church, a group of singers wages musical warfare with a song's harmony. They bellow notes at the top of their lungs to ``put the tune in mind,'' singing a capella - without piano or other instrumental help. Their sparse, strong harmonies vibrate through the wooden pews in Chestnut Grove Baptist Church, as they read an oblong book in which each of the four musical notes is shown with a different shape - triangle, circle, rectangle and diamond - for easier reading of the music. The singing is called Sacred Harp, shaped note or fasola. It was common in the United States in the 19th century, but soon faded because it was considered too crude by churches which instead relied on imported compositions and a modern seven-note scale. Almost unknown outside Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia and Mississippi by the 1930s, it survived in the Deep South. Why? Because as singer Buell Cobb says, ``You didn't have anyone stomping around telling people it was no good.'' But survival is no longer a question. The four-part a cappella harmonies are claiming passionate converts from Chicago to California. They are drawn to the primitive, deep sounds, and to the sense of community ``old book singing'' brings to all who sing and who listen. In September, 400 ``shaped-note singers'' from 21 states gathered in Chicago for a two-day convention of the United Sacred Harp Musical Association. It was the first major fasola convention outside the South in 87 years. The Northern resurrection of the genre came as fasola declined in the South, where singing schools gave way to modern entertainments. The singers, whose churches no longer relied on circuit preachers, went to church each Sunday and attended singings less often. ``Every year you lose about seven or eight all-day singings in the South because there aren't enough singers to keep it up,'' said Ted Mercer, the unofficial leader of the Chicago singers. Some of the Chicago singers are so committed to preserving the music they want to retire in the South to sing more, he said. Kathleen Throw, a singer from St. Louis who was visiting Ider, a town in northeast Alabama, believes that urban Northerners are doubly appreciative of the sense of community that comes with fasola singings. Singers often speak of being ``grabbed'' or ``knocked off my feet'' when they first hear Sacred Harp signing. ``I was so stunned. ... They were singing at decibel levels I didn't think the human voice could reach. I have never in my life heard anything like it,'' Chicago singer Judy Hauff says of the first singing she attended. The Chicago singers began with photocopies of Sacred Harp music, searching out Hugh McGraw and his Sacred Harp Publishing Co. in Breman, Ga. The company is working on the first major revision of a Sacred Harp book since the 1930s, with 65 new songs. Hauff and Mercer returned to Chicago determined to have authentic note-singings and all that went with them: dinner, memorials and the singings. The all-day singing in Ider on the second Sunday each October, listed in church records as early as 1927, is the old style at its richest. Singers range from 87-year-old Leonard Lacy to 19-year-old Jeffrey Wootten, and a mouth-watering noon meal of fried okra, turnip greens, chicken and other favorites is set out. Unlike traditional choral music, Sacred Harp singing is not for the audience, said Cobb, who's written ``The Sacred Harp,'' a history of the music. ``We have become a society that watches television, that ... watches other people do things. This is something that you do yourself,'' he said. He believes the music represents an old rural way of life many Southerners tried to escape. But that way of life attracts non-Southerners, says Keith Willard, an AIDS researcher in Minneapolis. ``I think it's hard for people in urban areas to achieve a sense of community, to develop deep ties between neighbors. I'm a scientist, used to dealing with things rationally, analytically. This ... was like suddenly walking into a group of people and feeling at home,'' he said. Willard, who helped organize the first all-day singing in Minneapolis-St. Paul, appreciated the value of everyone's participation. ``There are lots of people who appear not to be too far away from death who are still coming and contributing and greatly appreciated by the other singers for what they can pass on,'' he said. Marcia Johnson, a Jewish lawyer from Chicago who concedes it's a bit odd for her to be ``singing the praises of Jesus,'' says the music has universal themes. ``I'm 52 years old and I sometimes used to think about whether my friends or family would die before I did. I know now that as long as there are singers, I will have people that I love and who love me,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Sunday, Nov. 25, the 329th day of 1990. There are 36 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Nov. 25, 1963, the body of President Kennedy, assassinated in Dallas three days earlier, was laid to rest at Arlington National Cemetery, following a requiem Mass in Washington. At her husband's grave site, Jacqueline Kennedy lighted an ``Eternal Flame'' that burns to this day. On this date: In 1758, in the French and Indian War, the British captured Fort Duquesne at what is now Pittsburgh. In 1783, the British evacuated New York, their last military position in the United States during the Revolutionary War. In 1881, Pope John XXIII was born Angelo Roncalli in a village near Bergamo, Italy. In 1920, radio station WTAW of College Station, Texas, broadcast the first play-by-play description of a football game, between the University of Texas and Texas A&M. In 1944, baseball Commissioner Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis died at age 78. In 1957, President Eisenhower suffered a slight stroke. In 1973, Greek President George Papadopoulos was ousted in a bloodless military coup. In 1974, former U.N. Secretary-General U Thant died in New York at age 65. In 1984, William Schroeder of Jasper, Ind., became the second man to receive a ``Jarvik-7'' artificial heart during a 6{-hour operation at Humana Hospital Audubon in Kentucky. (He lived 620 days on the device.) In 1986, the Iran-Contra affair erupted as President Reagan and Attorney General Edwin Meese III revealed that profits from secret arms sales to Iran had been diverted to NIcaraguan rebels. In 1987, Harold Washington, the first black mayor of Chicago, died in office at age 65. Ten years ago: The famous ``No Mas'' fight: Sugar Ray Leonard regained the World Boxing Council welterweight championship when Roberto Duran abruptly quit late in the eighth round at the Louisiana Superdome. Five years ago: Ronald W. Pelton, a former employee of the National Security Agency, was arrested on espionage charges. (Pelton was later convicted of selling surveillance secrets to Soviet agents.) One year ago: More than half a million demonstrators gathered in Prague, Czechoslovakia, where they scoffed at a Communist Party shakeup and cheered Alexander Dubcek, the reformer ousted in 1968. Today's Birthdays: Baseball Hall of Famer Joe DiMaggio is 76. Actor Ricardo Montalban is 70. Actress Kathryn Crosby is 57. Actor John Larroquette is 43. John F. Kennedy Jr. is 30. Singer Amy Grant is 30. Football player Bernie Kosar is 27. Actress Christina Applegate is 19. Thought for Today: ``My theology, briefly, is that the universe was dictated but not signed.'' - Christopher Morley, American author and journalist (1890-1957).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, Nov. 26, the 330th day of 1990. There are 35 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: Nov. 26, 1789 was a day of thanksgiving set aside by President Washington to observe the adoption of the Constitution of the United States. On this date: In 1825, the first college social fraternity, Kappa Alpha, was formed at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y. In 1832, public streetcar service began in New York City. The fare: 12{ cents. (The streetcar was the horse-drawn ``John Mason,'' unveiled 12 days earlier.) In 1940, 50 years ago, the half-million Jews of Warsaw, Poland, were forced by the Nazis to live within a walled ghetto. In 1949, India adopted a constitution as a republic within the British Commonwealth. In 1950, China entered the Korean conflict, sending troops across the Yalu River to begin a counteroffensive against soldiers from the United Nations, the United Sstates and South Korea. In 1965, 25 years ago, France launched its first satellite, sending a 92-pound A1 capsule into orbit. In 1973, President Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, told a federal court she had accidentally caused part of the 18{-minute gap in a key Watergate tape. In 1975, a federal jury in Sacramento found Lynette Fromme guilty of trying to assassinate President Ford. In 1983, gunmen robbed a warehouse at London's Heathrow Airport, making off with 6,800 gold bars worth $38.7 million. In 1986, President Reagan appointed a commission headed by former Republican Senator John Tower of Texas to investigate his National Security Council staff in the wake of the Iran-Contra affair. Ten years ago: Sen. Charles Percy, R-Ill., met with Soviet President Leonid I. Brezhnev in Moscow, and said afterward the Kremlin leader had a ``constructive'' attitude toward the incoming Reagan administration. Five years ago: The space shuttle Atlantis roared into the nighttime sky over Cape Canaveral, Fla., carrying seven astronauts on a seven-day mission. One year ago: Hungary held a national referendum in which voters decided that the country's next president would be chosen by Parliament, following free elections. Today's Birthdays: Playwright Eugene Ionesco is 78. TV commentator Eric Sevareid is 78. ``Peanuts'' cartoonist Charles M. Schulz is 68. Singer Robert Goulet is 57. Actress-singer Marian Mercer is 55. Singer Tina Turner is 52. Impressionist Rich Little is 52. Thought for Today: ``Happiness is a sort of atmosphere you can live in sometimes when you're lucky. Joy is a light that fills you with hope and faith and love.'' - Adela Rogers St. Johns, American journalist (1894-1988).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Tuesday, Nov. 27, the 331st day of 1990. There are 34 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: Twenty years ago, on Nov. 27th, 1970, Pope Paul VI, on a visit to the Philippines, was attacked at the Manila airport by a dagger-wielding Bolivian painter disguised as a priest. Although the pontiff appeared unhurt, it was revealed in 1979, a year after his death, that Pope Paul had in fact been wounded in the chest. On this date: In 1839, the American Statistical Association was founded in Boston. In 1901, Army War College was established in Washington D.C. In 1910, New York's Pennsylvania Station - at that time, the world's largest railway terminal - opened. In 1939, the play ``Key Largo,'' by Maxwell Anderson, opened at the Ethel Barrymore Theater in New York. In 1942, during World War II, the French navy at Toulon scuttled its ships and submarines to prevent them from falling into the hands of the Nazis. In 1945, Gen. George C. Marshall was named special U.S. envoy to CHina to try to end hostilities between the Nationalists and the Communists. In 1953, playwright Eugene O'Neill died in Boston at age 65. In 1973, the U.S. Senate voted 92-3 to confirm Gerald R. Ford as vice president, succeeding Spiro T. Agnew. In 1978, San Francisco Mayor George Moscone and City Supervisor Harvey Milk, a gay-rights activist, were shot to death inside City Hall by former supervisor Dan White. In 1978, 183 people were killed when a Colombian Avianca Airlines Boeing 747 crashed near Madrid's Barajas airport. In 1987, French hostages Jean-Louis Normandin and Roger Auque were freed by their pro-Iranian captors in west Beirut, Lebanon. Ten years ago: A Soyuz spacecraft blasted off from the Soviet Union, carrying three cosmonauts to the orbiting Salyut VI space station. Five years ago: The British House of Commons approved the Anglo-Irish accord giving Dublin a consultative role in the governing of British-ruled Northern Ireland. One year ago: 107 people were killed when a bomb blamed by police on drug traffickers destroyed a Colombian jetliner, minutes after the plane had taken off from Bogota's international airport. Today's Birthdays: Actress Mona Washbourne is 87. Broadway producer David Merrick is 78. Children's entertainer ``Buffalo Bob'' Smith is 73. Former Czechoslovakian communist leader Alexander Dubcek is 69. Former Treasury Secretary William Simon is 63. Singer Eddie Rabbitt is 49. Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg is 33. Actress Robin Givens is 26. Thought for Today: ``Nothing is more despicable than a professional talker who uses his words as a quack uses his remedies.'' - Francois Fenelon, French theologian (1651-1715).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Wednesday, Nov. 28, the 332nd day of 1990. There are 33 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Nov. 28, 1942, nearly 500 people died in a fire that destroyed the Cocoanut Grove nightclub in Boston. The exact cause of the fire was never officially determined, though many blamed a busboy who had survived the blaze. On this date: In 1520, Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan reached the Pacific Ocean after passing through the South American strait that now bears his name. In 1895, the first automobile race was held, over 52 miles of snowy roads from Chicago to Waukegan, Ill. The winner was James Franklin Duryea, who won $2,000 from the Chicago Times-Herald. In 1919, American-born Lady Astor was elected the first female member of the British Parliament. In 1922, Captain Cyril Turner of the Royal Air Force gave the first skywriting exhibition, over New York's Times Square. (Turner spelled out, ``Hello U-S-A. Call Vanderbilt 7200.'' Some 47,000 calls resulted.) In 1925, the Grand Ole Opry, in Nashville, Tenn., made its radio debut on station WSM. In 1943, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Soviet leader Josef Stalin met in Tehran to map out strategy during World War II. In 1958, the African nation of Chad became an autonomous republic within the French community. In 1964, the United States launched the space probe Mariner IV from Cape Kennedy on a course set for Mars. In 1975, President Ford nominated Federal Judge John Paul Stevens to the Supreme Court seat vacated by William O. Douglas. In 1979, an Air New Zealand DC-10 en route to the South Pole crashed into a mountain in Antarctica, killing all 257 people aboard. In 1983, the space shuttle Columbia blasted into orbit, carrying six astronauts who conducted experiments using the $1 billion Spacelab in the shuttle's cargo bay. Ten years ago: President-elect Reagan said former Treasury Secretary William Simon had told him he was not interested in accepting a new Cabinet position in his administration. Five years ago: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis celebrated Thanksgiving with a dinner of irradiated turkey and freeze-dried vegetables, and launched a satellite from the cargo bay. The Irish Senate approved the Anglo-Irish accord concerning Northern Ireland. One year ago: Romanian gymnast Nadia Comaneci arrived in New York after escaping her homeland by way of Hungary. Today's Birthdays: Recording executive Berry Gordy Jr. is 61. Actress Hope Lange is 57. Former Sen. Gary Hart. D-Colo., is 54. Singer Randy Newman is 47. CBS News Correspondent Susan Spencer is 44. Musician Paul Shaffer is 41. Actor Judd Nelson is 31. Thought for Today: ``Freedom is always and exclusively freedom for the one who thinks differently.'' - Attributed to Rosa Luxemburg, German socialist leader (1870-1919).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Thursday, Nov. 29, the 333rd day of 1990. There are 32 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: One hundred years ago, on Nov. 29, 1890, the first Army-Navy football game was played, at West Point, N.Y. Navy beat Army 24-0. On this date: In 1530, Cardinal Thomas Wolsey, onetime adviser to England's King Henry VIII, died. In 1864, a Colorado militia killed at least 150 peaceful Cheyenne Indians in what became known as the Sand Creek Massacre. In 1890, 100 years ago, the Imperial Diet, forerunner of Japan's current national legislature, opened its first session, four days after its members were summoned by Emperor Meiji. In 1924, Italian composer Giacomo Puccini died in Brussels before he could complete his final opera, ``Turandot.'' (It was finished by Franco Alfano.) In 1929, Navy Lt. Cmdr. Richard E. Byrd radioed that he'd made the first airplane flight over the South Pole. In 1947, the U.N. General Assembly passed a resolution calling for the partitioning of Palestine between Arabs and Jews. In 1952, President-elect Eisenhower kept his campaign promise to visit Korea to assess the ongoing conflict. In 1961, ``Enos'' the chimp was launched from Cape Canaveral aboard the Mercury-Atlas V spacecraft, which orbited Earth twice and landed off Puerto Rico. In 1963, President Lyndon Johnson named a commission headed by Chief Justice Earl Warren to investigate the assassination of President Kennedy. In 1964, the Roman Catholic Church in the United States instituted sweeping changes in the liturgy, including the use of English instead of Latin. In 1981, actress Natalie Wood drowned in a boating accident off Santa Catalina Island, Calif., at age 43. In 1986, actor Cary Grant died in Davenport, Iowa, where he had scheduled a public appearance, at age 82. In 1987, a Korean Air jetliner disappeared off Burma, with the Loss of all 115 people aboard; South Korean authorities charged North Korean agents had bombed the aircraft. Ten years ago: President Carter met with several top officials at the Camp David presidential retreat to discuss clarifications of the U.S. response to Iran's demands for release of the American hostages. Five years ago: Two spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis assembled a 45-foot beam and a pyramid-shaped structure in a test of techniques that might be used in future space construction. One year ago: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi announced his resignation following the failure of his ruling party to hold onto its majority in Parliament following general elections. Today's Birthdays: Sportscaster Vin Scully is 63. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., is 62. Musician Chuck Mangione is 50. Skier Suzy Chaffee is 44. Comedian Garry Shandling is 41. Actor-comedian Howie Mandel is 35. Actress Cathy Moriarty is 30. Thought for Today: ``Superstition is the religion of feeble minds.'' - Edmund Burke, British statesman (1729-1797).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Friday, Nov. 30, the 334th day of 1990. There are 31 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Nov. 30, 1782, the United States and Britain signed preliminary peace articles in Paris, ending the Revolutionary War. On this date: In 1803, Spain completed the process of ceding Louisiana to France. In 1804, the first U.S. Supreme Court justice to be impeached, Samuel Chase, went on trial. (He was acquitted.) In 1835, Samuel Langhorne Clemens - better known as author Mark Twain - was born in Florida, Mo. In 1874, British statesman Sir Winston Churchill was born at Blenheim Palace. In 1900, Irish author Oscar Wilde died in Paris. In 1936, London's famed Crystal Palace, constructed for the International Exhibition of 1851, was destroyed in a fire. In 1939, the Russo-Finnish War began as Soviet troops invaded Finland. In 1949, Chinese communists captured Chungking. IN 1954, Elizabeth Hodges of Sylacauga, Ala., was injured when an 8{-pound meteorite crashed through the roof of her house. In 1962, U Thant of Burma was elected Secretary-General of the United Nations, succeeding the late Dag Hammarskjold. In 1966, the former British colony of Barbados became independent. In 1981, the United States and the Soviet Union opened negotiations in Geneva aimed at reducing nuclear weapons in Europe. Ten years ago: Two strong aftershocks jolted earthquake-devastated southern Italy as snow and subfreezing temperatures added to the misery of survivors of the Nov. 23 quake. Five years ago: Commenting publicly for the first time on a recent spate of espionage arrests, President Reagan said in his Saturday radio address from his ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif., that the United States would ``root out and prosecute the spies of any nation.'' One year ago: President Bush left Washington for his first summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that would take place aboard ships off the Mediterranean island of Malta. Today's Birthdays: Actress Virginia Mayo is 70. Actor Efrem Zimbalist Jr. is 67. Former U.S. Rep. Shirley CHisholm, D-N.Y., is 66. Actor Richard Crenna is 63. TV personality and producer Dick Clark is 61. Convicted Watergate defendant G. Gordon Liddy is 60. Playwright David Mamet is 43. Singer Billy Idol is 35. Football and baseball player Bo Jackson is 28. Thought for Today: ``The real problem is what to do with the problem solvers after the problems are solved.'' - Gay Talese, American author and journalist (1932- ).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, Dec. 1, the 335th day of 1990. There are 30 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 1, 1955, a milestone of the civil rights movement occurred on board a city bus in Montgomery, Ala., as Rosa Parks, a black seamstress, refused to give up her seat to a white man. Mrs. Parks was arrested, sparking a year-long boycott of the buses by blacks. (The law that required blacks to sit toward the rear of buses was eventually struck down by the U.S. Supreme Court.) On this date: In 1824, the presidential election was turned over to the U.S. House of Representatives when a deadlock developed among John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William H. Crawford and Henry Clay. Adams was eventually declared the winner. In 1909, the first Christmas Club payment was made, to the Carlisle Trust Company in Carlisle, Pa. In 1913, the first drive-in automobile service station opened, in Pittsburgh. In 1919, Lady Astor was sworn in as the first female member of the British Parliament. In 1934, Sergei M. Kirov, a collaborator of Josef Stalin, was assassinated at the Leningrad party headquarters, resulting in a massive purge. In 1959, representatives of 12 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, signed a treaty in Washington setting aside Antarctica as a scientific preserve, free from military activity. IN 1965, 25 years ago, an airlift of refugees from Cuba to the United States began in which thousands of Cubans were allowed to leave their homeland. In 1969, the U.S. government held its first draft lottery since World War II. In 1973, Dvid Ben-Gurion, the founding father of Israel and its first prime minister, died in Tel Aviv at age 87. In 1982, Miguel de la Madrid was inaugurated as president of Mexico, succeeding Jose Lopez Portillo. In 1988, Carlos Salinas de Gortari was sworn in as president of Mexico. Ten years ago: The Commerce Department reported that the government's index of leading economic indicators had risen nine-tenths of a percentage point in October. George Rogers of the University of South Carolina footrball team was named winner of the Heisman Trophy. Five years ago: Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres apologized to the United States for any espionage that may have been committed on Israel's behalf by Navy intelligence analyst Jonathan Jay Pollard. One year ago: In an extraordinary encounter, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with Pope John Paul II at the Vatican. Today's Birthdays: Former CIA director Stansfield Turner is 67. Actor-comedian-director Woody Allen is 55. Singer Lou Rawls is 54. Golfer Lee Trevino is 51. Comedian-actor Richard Pryor is 50. Actress-singer Bette Midler is 45. Actress Charlene Tilton is 32. Thought for Today: ``The only people who attain power are those who crave it.'' - Erich Kastner, German author and poet (1899-1974).
