DOC.HEAD: Senators Advance a Familiar Defense in Ethics Case
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: From accused senators, a familiar defense: they broke no laws, no Senate rules, breached no guidelines because there were none. From an accuser, a suggestion that there is indeed a guiding standard, and that it should lead a senator to avoid conduct that would appear improper to a reasonable, intelligent person. That draws a line that could prove more important than the itemized inquiry into the conduct of five senators, under investigation for their dealings in behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. and his effort to fend federal regulators away from his now-failed savings and loan business. The Senate Ethics Committee and, eventually, voters will judge the acts of the men involved in this case. The broader question of congressional conduct will remain after those judgments have been rendered. It will persist even if Congress reforms its campaign finance system, writes regulations on dealings with and for constituents who seek intervention with a federal agency. That's one of the things members of Congress do for a living. The question in this case is whether it was done for Keating because of his campaign contributions to the senators involved. He once said he certainly hoped so. The senators insist they acted to make sure a constituent and an employer was being treated properly by government regulators. Sen. Howell T. Heflin, D-Ala., chairman of the ethics panel, summed up the dilemma in two observations as he opened the hearings Thursday. ``Many of our fellow citizens apparently believe that your services were bought by Charles Keating, that you were bribed, that you sold your office, that you traded your honor and your good names for contributions and other benefits,'' Heflin told the accused senators. But he also warned against a standard of conduct that could make Congress too timid in going to executive and regulatory agencies in behalf of constituents with grievances. Outlining the case against the senators, Robert S. Bennett, special counsel to the committee, said he agreed that members of the Senate can properly pressure regulators. The difficult questions come in defining what is proper and when. Bennett offered one answer in describing ``a well-recognized and established appearance standard'' to govern conduct. ``A senator should not engage in conduct which would appear to be improper to a reasonable, nonpartisan, fully informed person,'' Bennett said. ``Such conduct undermines the public's confidence in the integrity of the government ad is an abuse of one's official position. Such conduct is wrong in addition to appearing to be wrong.'' That has the ring of common sense. But it relies on the judgment of the beholder. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., one of the accused senators, said that under the guidelines Bennett wants applied, a senator would be afraid to act in behalf of any constituent who had contributed to his campaign, no matter how legitimate the issue. Then again, Keating was no ordinary contributor. He gave $49,000 for Cranston campaigns and $850,000 to voter registration funds the senator was pushing. Cranston, who is suffering from prostate cancer and has said he will not seek re-election in 1992, complained that Bennett wants to judge the accused senators ``on the basis of rules which have never been written and standards which have never been applied.'' He said that deprives the five senators of guarantees the Constitution grants every citizen. The other senators are Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. Bennett has recommended that the case against Glenn and McCain be dismissed. The complaint that there are no rules so none were broken has been heard before in congressional ethics cases. The late Sen. Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut raised it in defending himself against ethics accusations in 1967, saying he faced Senate discipline for rules formulated after the fact, by the very committee that considered his case. He was censured by the Senate for using funds raised through testimonials and campaign solicitations ``for his personal benefit.'' Later, there were rules on that conduct - it was sanctioned, so long as it was disclosed. When he quit as speaker of the House in 1989, Jim Wright claimed there was uncertainty in the rules under which he was accused of violating House restrictions on gifts and outside income. ``Members are entitled to know what the rules mean,'' Wright said, suggesting that the House set up an office of counsel to provide official advice on ethical questions. In the current case, the decision of the committee and of the Senate on the accused senators will draw lines for future conduct. Without the campaign finance reforms that so far have failed to pass Congress, there are sure to be more situations linking constituent favors and campaign contributions. ``Unless these trends are recognized and dealt with, we will have more cases like this,'' Bennett warned, ``and the reputation of this body and its members will be in utter ruin.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

For release Tues PMs, Nov. 20, and thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Motown actually turned 30 almost two years ago. But Sunday's two-hour CBS special, ``Motown 30: What's Goin' On'' is worth the wait. It's not the star-studded musical spectacle that was ``Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever,'' winner of a 1983 Emmy, an NAACP Image Award, a Directors Guild of America trophy and a George Foster Peabody award. It is full of stars and it is full of music. But this time, it also is full of ballet, opera, filmmakers, humor and a marching band. ``Motown 30'' is a retrospective of African-American contributions to every aspect of the entertainment industry. And while ``Motown 25'' gave us a moon-walking, one-gloved Michael Jackson, its successor gives us a long look at how far black women and men have come in this country. And how far we all have yet to go. The show was taped at the Hollywood Pantages theater on Oct. 22 before a formally attired, mostly black audience that included Motown founder Berry Gordy and Sammy Davis Jr.'s widow, Altovise. But the four-hour event was no pompous, Hollywood affair. This was a house party. And everyone was in the mood. The program opens with the Jackson State University marching band thundering down Hollywood Boulevard blasting a funked-out version of ``I Heard It Through The Grapevine.'' Trumpets and tubas blaring, the gyrating formation marches into the Pantages, down the aisles and onto the stage. The audience is ecstatic. It goes uphill from there. The talent lineup includes Smokey Robinson, Stevie Wonder, Terence Trent D'Arby, The Temptations, The Four Tops, Denzel Washington, Robert Townsend, Tracy Chapman, Natalie Cole, Keenen Ivory Wayans, Gladys Knight, Patti LaBelle and the Dance Theatre of Harlem. Comedian Whoppi Goldberg, impersonating Diana Ross, talks about the importance of Motown. Yeah, you could dance to it. Yeah, everyone knew the words. But, ``it's also about a whole lot of other things, too - a search for respect, a hunt for heroes, a pride in accomplishments, all that good stuff,'' Goldberg says. ``A lot of us wanted to be a whole lot of things. We wanted to be the Temptations, we wanted to be hip and cool and rich and happy and some of us wanted to be white. ``But we've gotten over that.'' Discrimination is a common thread through most of the show's segments, from comedy bits to musical numbers to tributes to black filmmakers. ``In 1960, TV Guide published an article called `What Does the Negro Want from Television,''' says Keenen Ivory Wayans, creator and executive producer of the hit Fox comedy series ``In Living Color.'' Retorts his brother and co-star, Damon, ``The same thing they want in 1990. To be on it and get paid.'' Singer, dancer, choreographer and TV director Debbie Allen offers her memories of what the world looked like to a little black girl who dreamed of being a ballerina. ``As a young girl, I had to have a great imagination to picture myself as a ballet dancer,'' she says, introducing the Dance Theatre of Harlem. ``Because in everything that I saw and in everything that I read, I didn't see anyone who looked like me.'' The music, from Gladys Knight fronting the 100-member Soul Children of Chicago choir to a showdown between the Temptations and the Four Tops, is a raucous blend of soul and gospel. Patti LaBelle and Michael Bolton team up (square off is more like it) for a salute to the partnership of Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrell, ending with sweat-dripping rendition of ``You're All I Need (To Get By).'' LaBelle, not known for being a shrinking violet onstage, may have gotten more than she bargained for with the equally unretiring Bolton. The white boy held his own. Executive producer Suzanne dePasse, who won an Emmy for ``Motown 25,'' says this is the last birthday special. Motown will not turn 40. At least not on television. ``That was it,'' said the longtime colleague of Motown founder Gordy, with whom she now heads Gordy-dePasse Productions (formerly Motown Productions). ``This show was meant to do something else,'' DePasse said. ``I will never be able to replace `Motown 25' in my own recollection. That was the first time I was on a solo flight. In a way, this is a wonderful farewell to that whole 22{-year segment of my life.'' In the program's crowded finale, Stevie Wonder leads the children's choir and every performer on the show through Marvin Gaye's ``What's Goin' On.'' Filmmaker Robert Townsend ends the night with this observation: ``We ain't where we should be. We ain't where we could be. But thank God we ain't where we used to be.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... IN THE OFFBEAT COP CATEGORY: Stephen J. Cannell just lost ``Wiseguy'' to the cancellation ax, but his new series, ``Broken Badges,'' debuts Saturday on CBS at 9 p.m. EDT. This one is about cops on psychiatric leave. ABC just announced that it was canceling ``Cop Rock,'' a Steven Bochco series about singing cops.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues PMs, Nov. 20

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP on TV-After the Warming, Adv21,0842
DOC.NOTE: For release Wed PMs, Nov. 21, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: James Burke's `After the Warming' - Prophetic, Scary and Entertaining
DOC.TEXT: It's very simple how James Burke, host of tonight's two-hour PBS special ``After the Warming,'' got involved with the project. Burke, after all, is the British TV journalist whose top-rated PBS series ``Connections'' and ``The Day the Universe Changed'' taught American TV audiences that science, culture and technology could fascinate. ``Maryland Public Television asked me to do a program on global warming and I said, `You mean the 175,000th program on global warming?' And they said, `Do you think you can do something different?' I said, `Yeah.''' That turned out to be a pretty big ``Yeah,'' even for Burke, who spent seven months researching ``After the Warming,'' which was filmed on four continents. At its heart is scientific opinion that it's likely the gases emitted by our civilization - carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and the artificial CFCs - are warming up the planet. ``No one can answer that question until maybe the end of the century,'' Burke acknowledged. ``If you think it's fractionally more than 50 percent likely, then the odds are infinitely worse than what you do when you spend money to insure your life and your health and your house. ``If it's more likely than less likely, then we should insure against it.'' Using advanced video graphics and special effects, Burke creates a ``virtual reality'' chamber of the 21st century. It is the year 2050, when the Planetary Management Authority celebrates its 50th anniversary as the Earth's environmental policy agency. Taking the greenhouse effect as a fait accompli, Burke lets us ``look back'' on history as a function of climate, and he does it in the witty, erudite style that has endeared him to his fans. ``2050 was a way of saying, `Look, if you insure yourself, you can end up with a world that isn't simply a result of the greenhouse effect, but is the kind of world you should have anyway,' '' Burke said. He chronicles ice ages, planetary orbital variations, the emergence of human life, civilization, art, architecture, culture, industrialization and colonialism as products of the influences of nature on humankind. Then, suddenly, man's use of the planet for the first time begins to influence nature and things get complicated. Burke ``looks back'' at how the nations of the world tried to cope with the phenomenon. It is a sad, bumpy kind of history, with human suffering, storms, floods, famine, political conflicts and a new generation of boat people. Burke sees a planetary authority - a supranational, consensual, non-authoritarian agency - as inevitable as ``carbon allocation rights,'' which would force factory nations to buy surplus carbon emission rights from non-industrialized nations. ``The greenhouse effect turns out to be the trigger for ... handling the problem in the relationship between us and the Third World and their economic aspirations,'' Burke said. ``Whether we like it or not, we did con them into taking all that Arab oil money. ``Whether we like it or not we did turn them into service agencies in the 19th century. And we did rape them and plunder and pillage them and we did pollute the planet in doing so. ``We've got to face the fact that we are guilty of all these things and do something straightforward about it.'' ``I want people to realize this and then make their decisions. They may just say, `Yes, we understand everything you say and they can go hang.' Well, fine, but rather let them go hang on the basis of a mature and informed decision.'' There's another reason Burke agreed to do global warming: He was in the midst of a financing hangup for ``The Complexity Effect,'' a seven-hour TV series on the effect of information as the basic force in evolutionary change. Here's a preview of that coming attraction: ``Information surges, in whatever form they come, always have the same effect on all life forms,'' Burke said. ``They either drive them to failure or they drive to success through increasing complexity. ``For seven long, crucifyingly boring hours, I'm going to try to prove that.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... PLEASE DON'T FEED THE ANIMALS!!!: The 15th Annual ``Circus of the Stars'' takes to the airwaves on CBS tonight. Ladies, gentlemen and television writers of all ages take note: This is yet another reason to get into show business. David Soul braves three Bengal tigers. Dick Van Patten tames three unmuzzled bears. Morgan Brittany works out with four African elephants. Other highlights include ``fly girl'' Lisa Marie Todd of ``In Living Color,'' who performs a comedy tumbling routine with Marlon (``Major Dad'') Archey, and weight loss guru Richard Simmons spinning plates.

DOC.HEAD: We Have to Push the ``Off'' Button
DOC.TEXT: Americans have been having a terrible time finding the ``stop spending'' button on the government's keyboard. The inability is astounding during a high-tech age in which one worker at a computer console can direct an entire factory operation or the flow of electricity through power lines, or raise almost any statistic known to man. But finding the ``off'' button on spending, even under the stress of an economy on the edge of recession, eludes them. The country seems unable to go on an austerity budget after a decade of spending and borrowing. The difficulty is more sharply defined each day in government, where taxes rise while the economy weakens; in business, where expenses rise but sales fall; in not-for-profit institutions, where services grow but funds shrink. Of course, it's an old, old story in the typical American household, which is being urged to spend more than before in spite of what the Conference Board says is the biggest decline in consumer confidence in two decades. Throughout the economy - among employers, employees, elected officials, investors, bankers, brokers, borrowers - everyone seems to be saying the same thing: stop spending. But few are able to find and click the stop button. To many people, the most egregious example of the phenomenon was in raising federal taxes while the economy flashed danger signs. Consider some of them: - The Federal Reserve's monthly report on economic conditions around the country showed each of the 12 districts reported either slower growth or an actual decline in economic activity through mid-October. - Construction contracts fell 2.8 percent in September, the sharpest monthly drop since 1982. Machine tool orders declined 4.6 percent in September from the month before, putting them 13 percent lower than the year-earlier level. - The National Association of Purchasing Managers' index of manufacturing activity declined to 43.4 percent in October, the fourth straight month of declines. Anything below 50 percent indicates a shrinkage of activity. - In the first nine months of 1990, manufacturing failures rose 20 percent, non-manufacturing failures 14 percent, and services 8.5 percent, according to Dun & Bradstreet. Big debt - overspending - played a large role, of course. - Since January, 600,000 manufacturing jobs have disappeared, and many thousands of jobs have been lost in banking, securities, accounting, management consulting, health care and government. Overspending had a lot to do wit it. - Initial claims of unemployment insurance have soared, and those who remain working are likely to have shorter hours than before. The average work week fell to 34.2 hours in October from 34.7 hours in September. But federal government spending, in spite of rhetoric to the contrary, continued to rise. Now, so also are taxes. John Sloan, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, comments that ``small-business owners feel betrayed by Congress raising their taxes.'' Main Street, he said, is not a happy place these days. Why can't the ``stop spending'' key be found? How can so many people call for the key to be tapped but then find it so difficult to find? Perhaps it is because minds were programmed during the 1980s, a decade of easy credit, free spending and low saving - and among those programmed, it seems, were the very ones who should have been taught to find the key.

DOC.HEAD: Former Ideological Opponents Become Trade Partners
DOC.TEXT: Less than two years ago, South Africa and Eastern Europe shunned each other as ideological villains. Today, the South Africans have diplomatic or trade arrangements with Poland, Romania and Hungary, and are expanding contacts with the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia. Dramatic political and social changes on both sides have made them eager to renew relations after decades of enmity over communism and apartheid. ``We were at the other end of the world, both geographically and ideologically,'' Foreign Minister R.F. Botha said on a trip to Czechoslovakia. ``After the changes in both parts of the world, there is nothing which divides our governments.'' Botha and Czechoslovak officials announced plans to establish low-level diplomatic ties after a 27-year hiatus. In August, Trade Minister Kent Durr became the first South African Cabinet member to visit the Soviet Union in 34 years. Ideology drove the two sides apart in the 1950s and 1960s. Economics is bringing them together in the 1990s. The South African government invoked the threat of a communist takeover for decades as justification for suppressing the black opposition. This year, President F.W. de Klerk legalized all opposition groups, released African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela from prison after 27 years and promised to end the apartheid system of racial segregation. which have isolated South Africa economically and politically. East European countries supported the sanctions and backed the ANC and its ally, the South African Communist Party. Then, in 1989, came the upheaval that dismembered the Soviet bloc and swept Communist parties from power in Moscow's former satellites. Those nations are struggling to rebuild their crumbling economies and have found a willing trade partner in South Africa. Although they still oppose apartheid, East European countries have switched from being the main financial support of the ANC to dealing with the white government it sought to destroy. Delegations from Eastern Europe visit South Africa regularly. Permananent representatives have been exchanged and trade agreements signed. Thousands of Eastern European and Soviet citizens have applied to South African embassies in Western Europe for permission to immigrate. ``I am pleased that the dynamics of late 20th century political transformation are bringing our two nations once again closer together,'' Durr said in opening the first Polish trade fair in South Africa. Poland dropped trade restrictions against South Africa on March 9, the day after Durr completed a visit. In late October, the governments signed an agreement to establish reciprocal offices of interest. Polish government and trade officials traveled to South Africa for the two-week trade fair, which featured nearly 50 manufacturers of products ranging from heavy machinery through textiles to vodka. Organizers said contracts worth $60 million were signed. The visitors emphasized their continued opposition to apartheid, but it was clear that relations had been made more palatable by Poland's economic problems and South Africa's reforms. ``Poland is heavily in debt'' and is beginning to make its economic relations with the rest of the world ``much more active,'' said Andrzej Zawislak, an economist and member of Parliament. Zawislak said some Western countries had urged Poland not to establish ties with South Africa, but did not identify them. Romania and South Africa signed an agreement last month for a joint trade committee that would meet annually, and specific trade contracts are expected. South Africa has opened a permanent office in Hungary to represent its interests and Hungary plans to reciprocate. Hungarian officials said their country still opposes apartheid, but wants the office because about 20,000 people of Hungarian descent live in South Africa. African nations also are warming to South Africa's reforms. Only Malawi has full diplomatic relations, but several have trade missions in Pretoria and de Klerk has visited seven African countries since taking office in August 1989. His government says it trades with every African country, mostly in secret. Mandela has sought funds for the ANC in Africa, Western Europe, the United States and Asia, but has yet to visit Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union, which provided most of the movement's military aid while he was imprisoned.

DOC.HEAD: `Godfather III' Heads Christmas Movie Season in a Year Without Usual Glut
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The film crowd expects ``The Godfather III'' to climax a near-record year in a holiday season without the usual glut of big-budget and possible Academy Award movies. Francis Ford Coppola's continuation of the bloody Corleone saga arrives on Christmas Day, giving it only one week to augment the 1990 box-office total. ``If `Godfather III' had been released on Nov. 21 as scheduled, it might have contributed to another record year,'' says Daily Variety's Art Murphy. ``Barring a miracle, the year's total will be $4.9 billion, only $100 million behind 1989's record. The spring was sensational, with three $100 million-films. The summer was the second-best ever, and so was the fall. It has been a good year.'' This holiday season will bring only 12 films in wide release, compared to 20-25 in the early 1980s. About 10 others will receive limited releases to enhance their prestige and Oscar chances. Some of the pre-Thanksgiving movies will remain in the marketplace through New Year's. ``Dances With Wolves'' will certainly be among them. Other possibilities: ``Rocky V,'' ``The Rescuers Down Under,'' ``Three Men and a Little Lady,'' ``Predator II.'' Here are the attractions seeking big audiences in December: - ``Kindergarten Cop'' features Arnold Schwarzenegger returning with his ``Twins'' director Ivan Reitman in a comedy with kids and action. - ``The Bonfire of the Vanities'' stars Tom Hanks, Melanie Griffth and Bruce Willis in Tom Wolfe's novel of urban corruption, directed by Brian DePalma (``The Untouchables''). - ``Awakenings'' is another change of pace for Robin Williams, based on a real-life story of a doctor who revives catatonic patients. With Robert De Niro and directed by Penny Marshall (``Big''). - ``Misery'' has Rob Reiner (``When Harry Met Sally...'') turning serious with a Stephen King novel, starring James Caan and Kathy Bates. - ``Mermaids'' represents Cher's return to films after the Oscar-winning ``Moonstruck.'' With Winona Ryder and Bob Hoskins. - ``Look Who's Talking Too'' is a reprise of last year's hit, with Roseanne Barr joining Bruce Willis as a baby's voice. - ``The Rookie'' features Clint Eastwood returning to the police force after bombing as ``White Hunter, Black Heart.'' - ``Almost an Angel'' teams Paul Hogan and new wife Linda Kozlowski in a comedy unrelated to the ```Crocodile'Dundee'' films that introduced them. Here are other films that will have less impact on the 1990 total because of limited releases, but will be heard from in 1991: - ``Havana'' reunites Robert Redford and Sydney Pollack (``Out of Africa'') for a love story against the backdrop of the Cuban revolution. - ``Russia House'' stars Sean Connery and Michelle Pfeiffer in the John le Carre spy thriller. - ``Green Card'' offers the American film debut of Gerard Depardieu as a French immigrant in a marriage of convenience with Andie McDowall (``sex, lies and videotape''). - ``Edward Scissorshands'' is another fantasy from Tim Burton (``Batman,'' ``Beetlejuice''). - ``Alice'' has Woody Allen writing and directing but not acting. William Hurt, Mia Farrow and Alec Baldwin do perform. - ``The Sheltering Sky'' is a love story by Berardo Bertolucci (``The Last Emperor'') with Debra Winger and John Malkovich. - ``Hamlet'' stars the commercially viable Mel Gibson and Glenn Close, directed by Franco Zeffirelli. - ``Come See the Paradise'' is an interracial romance during the wartime internment of Japanese-Americans. - ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge'' stars Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward as an aging Kansas City couple. political story directed by Bruce Berensford (``Driving Miss Daisy''). Even with a lesser number of films in wide release, that's a carload of movies to be considered by audiences, critics and, importantly, Academy voters. But the six-week year-end market comprises 13 per cent to 14 per cent of the year's box office, and companies save some of their best attractions for this period. ``Like any producer I think it's bad to be playing all your cards at once,'' comments veteran filmmaker Howard W. Koch (``The ODd Couple,'' ``Airplane''). ``Many of the films will open big, but can they hang in there? The secret to big grosses is the repeat trade. That's what has happened with `Ghost' (which Koch helped produce). People are going back again and again.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - There is a widespread disease of the brain that most doctors fail to diagnose in adults because many of its symptoms are so vague. Even its victims have trouble defining them. But progress is on the horizon that will help doctors identify and treat the symptoms.

AS many as 7 million American adults may be suffering from a brain disorder they don't know they have. It's an affliction first described in the medical literature in 1902, but its name is still being debated. The disorder, once thought to affect only children, is best known as the hyperactive child syndrome. It is now called Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, Residual Type (ADHD,RT), when it persists into adulthood. ``Most of these adults know something is wrong, but they don't know what,'' says Dr. Alan Zametkin, a psychiatrist and researcher at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. ``The attention deficit is like a fever. It tells you something is wrong, but it doesn't tell you what. A lot of things disrupt attention - depression, anxiety, schizophrenia.'' Up to 85 percent of those afflicted could be helped with medication, if they knew they needed it. It was once thought that a hyperactive child treated with a mild stimulant, Ritalin, would outgrow the disorder by puberty. That is still true in some cases. But researchers now believe the disorder persists into adulthood in 40 percent to 60 percent of all cases. The disorder is the most common reason for a child to be referred to mental health professionals. Scientists now know that outward hyperactivity is not always a symptom, but that is the most common manifestation among children. A child appears motor driven, cannot concentrate, cannot stay in his seat, acts impulsively, cannot wait for his or her turn, speaks out in the classroom, cannot cope with stress, bullies classmates, has few social skills and an insatiable need for attention. It is generally accepted that five times more boys than girls suffer the disorder, but one Yale pediatrician feels that girls are greatly undercounted. The disorder, untreated, can destroy lives. One married woman, now in her 50s, always knew something was wrong, but her doctors could never pin it down. She knew she wasn't stupid, or depressed, or anxious, or whatever the diagnosis was. It was something she just couldn't describe, the difficulties of her life. Everything was too hard, required too much effort. She had to concentrate intently to perform such rote chores as making a bed. She chose to remain childless for fear of passing this disability on to a baby. But science is making progress toward helping people like her. IN mid-November, Zametkin announced in the New England Journal of Medicine a new finding that defines a specific abnormality in the brains of attention deficit victims. ``This is the first large study of hyperactivity that shows some sort of metabolic abnormality,'' he said. The brain is essentially two brains, the primitive brain below and the cognitive brain above, sometimes referred to as the horse and rider. Zametkin's study of 50 hyperactives and 50 normal people found brain metabolism significantly lower in 30 of 60 specific brain regions among the hyperactives. Commenting on the study, Dr. Paul H. Wender of the University of Utah said that the basic cause may not be in the lessened activity in the cortex or upper brain. ``If the more primitive centers don't tell the guys upstairs to wake up, they won't have attention. But the problem is not in the cortex, it's the guys downstairs.'' Dr. Ivan Goldberg, a New York City psychiatrist specializing in psychopharmacology and treating some adult cases, says, ``The reason the diagnosis is often missed is that it is never even considered.'' One who agrees is Dr. Barry Garfinkel, director of child and adolescent psychiatry at the University of Minnesota. He is chairman of the committee that will seek to redefine and perhaps rename the disorder for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, the next diagnostic bible due out 1993. ``We trained doctors to believe Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder disappeared with adolescence,'' Garfinkel says. ``The patients knew better.'' The absence of hyperactivity makes diagnosis less likely. SUch was the case with one man blessed with extraordinary intellectual gifts. ``I claw for every word in reading, writing and speaking,'' says the man, who asked not to be identified. He appears laconic as he struggles for precisely the right word. His brain is cursed by a chemical imbalance. It moves at the anguished gait of a tortoise. For him, to utilize his mental gifts requires great effort. ``With medication, I've had visions of things as they might be,'' he says. ``There were brief periods when I could hear myself think, where the competing thoughts were drowned out and I could focus on one thing.'' To add to his woes, he is one of the few whose response to medication isn't satisfactory.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
NEW YORK: isn't satisfactory.
DOC.TEXT: With an IQ at the genius level, the best he can do in the marketplace is to hold down a job in a mail room. ``I feel I let my whole family down,'' he says. ``I should have been an honor to them and to myself, almost in an Oriental sense. I feel a voice that says, `You had this great gift and you did nothing with it.''' This man had seen about 20 psychiatrists and psychologists and received a variety of diagnoses - from obsessive compulsive to depression to anxiety. He jokes that he talked his current psychiatrist into what he feels is probably the correct diagnosis. He probably suffers from Attention Deficit Disorder without being hyperactive. Although in the medical literature for nearly 90 years, the disorder has gone through a variety of names: minimal brain impairment, minimal brain dysfunction, hyperkinesis (the hyperactive child), Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD) in the DSM III, a name some prefer to the name given in the 1987 revision which calls it Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), making the hyperactivity a core of the syndrome. Researchers say the affliction strikes 3 percent to 6 percent of all children and in about two-thirds of the cases it is coupled with specific developmental disorders, the most common warships, barges, freighters - more than 5,000 ships dead at the bottom in water so deep and cold and black that a scuba diver can lose sense even of which way is up. These antiquities of the inland seas are in jeopardy, made vulnerable by technology. Cold water diving is safer, cheaper than it used to be. The wrecks are easier to fid, easier to loot. Now the Great Lakes graveyards have become battlegrounds in an underwater war. On the one side are divers who believe in finders-keepers, an accepted notion to many ever since diving became a common man's sport in the 1970s. On the other are those who regard the relics as a national trust, a well-preserved chronicle of America's history. Enforcement officers from Michigan to Ontario say the laws to stop such looting are impossible to police. There are too many wrecks, too many divers. So some preservationists have taken matters into their own hands. On the western shore of Lake Huron, for instance, amateur archaeologists have become a band of undersea vigilantes. After work, the unlikely crusaders - three schoolteachers and a county sheriff's detective - strap on heavy air tanks and roll backward into the Lake Huron surf to visit the wreck of the North Star. The freighter went down on Nov. 25, 1908, impaled upon the bow of its sister ship, the Northern Queen. The Queen took on the Star's crew, broke free of the ships' death embrace and made it to shore. The Star, with its cargo of flour and wheat and shingles, burbled to the bottom. This time the divers take with them a reporter. Cold water streams in beneath the skin of neoprene dive suits, so shocking the reporter curses. The weight of the water drills like a spike into a tender eardrum. The divers descend, fading into the green dark. The reporter hangs back, waiting for the pressure to equalize and relieve her aching ear. She hangs alone on a line stretched from ship to shipwreck, bouncing wildly as the topside vessel, the Sand Dollar, rolls with the growing swells. Then, hand under hand, she slides along the rope. Sixty feet down, the North Star emerges, disappears, emerges again, ghostlike in a snowstorm of algae and muck. In the cold and the dark, the reporter pulls upward, measures her breathing, then drops onto the giant engines of the 1908 wreck. Three stories deeper, Sanilac County Sheriff's Sgt. Garry Biniecki, one of the first to descend, moves along the 300-foot hull, taking pictures, making measurements. They have 23 minutes to scour the wreck before the gases dissolving in their bloodstreams force them up. All the while, nitrogen in their air tanks transforms into a drug and they feel the titillating but deadly rapture of the deep. Biniecki and his comrades will bring back nothing more tangible than exposed rolls of film and scribbled measurements. They have a new ethic. What goes down stays down. Nothing is for the taking. ``We want to keep our artifacts down there,'' says team member Jim Stayer, a high school science teacher and the Sand Dollar's captain. Skirmishes between followers of the new ethic and the old have taken some unusual turns. A researcher for a museum, a professional, stole an artifact from a wreck when one he took legally for the museum broke. He was caught. A team of divers, amateurs all, chained and padlocked the steering wheel of another wreck to prevent its theft. It remains in place. One LAke Michigan charter captain enforces his no-souvenirs policy by searching customers when they surface from wreck dives. Steve Harrington, a writer about shipwrecks who has converted to the new ethic, confesses he still feels unclean because he once took spikes from a wreck. ``It sounds corny, future generations and all,'' he says, ``but it's hard to look young divers in the eye.''

DOC.TEXT: The Great Lakes - Huron, Erie, Ontario, Michigan and Superior - were for a period rich in history and lore, the main American arteries of commerce. Timber to build cities floated down from the Canadian shores. Iron ore to make steel sailed out of Superior. Grain, stone, coal and copper filled cargo holds, but the ships also carried human cargo and their belongings, fur traders, immigrants, pioneers, laborers, homesteaders. The wooden boats and steel freighters never were a match for the sudden fury of the inland seas, where unexpected west winds in an afternoon can drive up waves three stories high. The Great Storm of 1913, a six-day blow, sank 10 ships and killed 235 seamen. Gales from 1878 to 1898 ravaged nearly 6,000 ships and sank more than 1,000 of them. Modern ships have fared little better. In 1964, a Huron storm tore the ore freighter Daniel J. Morell in half. Only one of its crew of 29 survived. Eleven years later the freighter Edmund Fitzgerald and its crew of 29 went down in Superior seconds after the captain radioed that he was holding his own. The Great Lakes have become an archaeologist's paradise. Where the water is deep and cold, decay is arrested and each wreck remains a frozen moment of history. The preservation is so remarkable that bodies can last for years, skeletons for centuries. Archaeologists excavating the wreck of the Rockaway in Lake Michigan found the remains of salted meat in the galley and rope made from corn leaves still sitting in a pot used to mix caulking. The schooner went down in 1891. ``The sort of Hollywood concept of what a shipwreck looks like actually exists in the Great Lakes,'' said Rockaway archaeologist Ken Pott from his museum in South Haven, Mich. ``Short of a skeleton lashed to the wheel, it's all there.'' For example, the Hamilton and the Scourge, two Canadian battleships from the war of 1812, went down in 300 feet of water in Lake Ontario. Pott says a searcher using submersible cameras found the ship intact, replete with cutlasses, cannons, guns, bones and masts. But the conservation work of maritime archaeologists such as Pott is up against an army of black marketeers and souvenir seekers. Simple wood blocks that litter wrecks by the hundreds fetch $500 in an antiques store. COllectors will pay $10,000 for a ship's bell or a wood steering wheel. A carved ship's figurehead is almost priceless. Such stripping was legal in Michigan until 1980, when the state passed a law allowing salvage only under permit. Wisconsin only recently toughened its law. All of the Great Lakes states and Ontario outlaw stripping to some degree. But some, such as Michigan, are willing to grant salvage permits, especially to divers picking up things for museums. Archaeological surveys take years. The pillage can occur overnight. Witness the fate of the U.S. Coast Guard cutter Mesquite. That crippled buoy tender was buried at sea last July, dropped intact to the bottom of Lake Superior. The stripping started immediately: dinner plates from the boat's galley, tools from the work rooms, hard hats from lockers, dress jackets out of the closets of crew members. ``I am appalled at what happened,'' says Michigan archaeologist John Halsey in Lansing. ``It was like a feeding frenzy. We're talking in hours, in days.'' Because of that, many explorers go to great pains to hide their discoveries. Charles Feltner, an engineer for Ford Motor Co., found the 1856 wreck of the brig Sandusky in the Straits of Mackinac. He dove on it for years in secrecy. Then he made the find public. ``People stripped the thing in a couple of months,'' Feltner says. ``Things like dishes, tools, all the blocks, belaying pins, deadeyes, you name it.'' The ship's rams head figurehead remains. Divers bolted it back down after someone tried to steal it, too. That was 10 years ago. Feltner thinks the advent of divers such as Biniecki signals a change in ethic. Today, Feltner feels, the looting would take years, not months. ``It's still bad enough to where divers 25 years from now aren't going to have much to look at,'' Feltner says. ``The whole idea of seeing a virgin wreck will be gone.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - George McGovern, professor turned politician, has returned to his roots. At 68, he's back on a college campus, teaching once again. The one-time presidential candidate says the campaign trail still has its lure. That forum, he believes, can be an attractive classroom itself.

Heads turn and passers-by smile in recognition when George McGovern walks along the stone paths of the Cornell University campus. ``You probably get this all the time, but when I turned 18, you were the first person I voted for,'' says a faculty member, beaming as he shakes hands with the former senator from South Dakota and 1972 Democratic presidential nominee. McGovern smiles, thanks the man and chats briefly before moving on. He does get that all the time, ever since his unsuccessful bid for the presidency. ``It's nice,'' he says. Since losing his Senate seat in 1980, McGovern has been teaching at colleges across the nation. This semester he is at Cornell, where hundreds of students vied for spots in his once-weekly class on American foreign policy. Teaching is a return to his roots for McGovern. He began his career in 1949 as a history professor at South Dakota's tiny Dakota Wesleyan University. He spent most of the next three decades outside the classroom, making a name in state and national politics and challenging the United States' role in the war in Vietnam. But McGovern says he never stopped considering himself a teacher. ``That historic perspective has frequently given me a different view of events,'' he says. ``I really knew quite a lot about Vietnam before we ever got involved. And I always thought if you looked critically and closely at the history of Vietnam, we might never have gone in there.'' McGovern is 68 now. His hair and eyebrows have turned almost white, and the creases on his forehead have deepened in the years he has been out of the national spotlight. Dressed in a dark blue pinstripe suit and wearing thick black plastic-rimmed bifocals that he takes on and off as he speaks, he looks more like an elder statesman than a maverick politician who challenged the establishment throughout his tenure in office. The tall ex-senator cuts an imposing figure at Cornell. His steady voice with a hint of Midwestern twang easily hushes the 300 young people crowded into Statler Hall, a blue and purple-toned auditorium in the college's hotel administration school. McGovern lectures in a conversational style, sprinkling his talk with references to his own involvement in shaping the nation's history. He tells students he doesn't want to be too partisan - although he leaves little doubt where he stands - and he sounds more regretful than angry when he speaks of policies he opposes. In a lecture on the Cold War, McGovern traces Republican attacks on the Democrats for ``losing'' China and being soft on communism to the GOP's frustration over having lost five consecutive national elections. ``It set off a kind of political fury on the part of the Republicans,'' he says. ``I can understand that,'' he adds, laughing. ``After you've lost so many times you get to the point where you want to get somebody - you just want to hit anybody.'' He says the public had an exaggerated fear of the communist threat that dogged him throughout his political career, he says. He and others that called for negotiation, not confrontation, were labeled appeasers, or worse. ``I have no doubt at all I'd still be in the Senate if not for this fear,'' he says. Most of the students filling the lecture hall were still in diapers when McGovern ran for president and not yet in high school when he left the Senate. But they say they knew his name and the views he represents. ``I knew that he was a big liberal,'' says Audrey Van Voden, a government major from Syracuse. ``I just knew he ran for president,'' says Julie Brof, a policy Analysis major from New York, adding that she thinks his class is ``fabulous.''

ITHACA, N.Y.: is ``fabulous.''
DOC.TEXT: At the end of class, McGovern allows time for questions. No one leaves the auditorium. A student asks about political role models, and McGovern mentions Adlai Stevenson, a fellow would-be president. ``Stevenson got me into politics, and that's probably enough to persuade some people that he had an evil influence,'' he says, chuckling. opposition to the Vietnam War. ``It just so happens I had dinner with Sen. Fulbright last week,'' McGovern says. Fulbright, he adds, is most proud of the student exchange program he established in his first year in office in 1942, not the Vietnam hearings he presided over. Responding to another student's question, McGovern dismisses the impact of communism in the United States. ``Anyone here ever meet a real livemember of the Communist Party?'' he asks. One student raises his hand. ``What did he look like?'' McGovern asks, joining the audience in laughter. After class, McGovern lingers for one-on-one conversations with the eager students who swarm around him. Brof asks him to meet with the campus Democratic organization and leaves delighted when McGovern offers to have breakfast with the group. ``I wish I had been around when he ran for president,'' she sighs. ``I was 2 years old.'' After class, over lunch in the hotel school's restaurant, McGovern says he hasn't ruled out running for president again if the opportunity presents itself. He misses the national forum of the Senate and, especially, of a presidential campaign. ``Whether you win or lose, tens of millions of people hear you,'' he says. ``I do miss that. If I really thought in any given campaign that I could get across certain ideas to the American public, I might run for president just to make the case.'' McGovern blames recent leaders for failing to set a more altruistic example for the next generation. The Reagan-Bush years, he says, ``reassured people that greed is all right, that raw competition with one's fellow human beings is the way things should be.'' He sees the effects of that leadership on students, he says, reluctantly criticizing the young people who have always been among his biggest fans. ``There's still a little too much materialism and not enough idealism,'' he says. ``I don't want to say that in any harsh way. It's just a mild disappointment on my part, that material values still seem to dominate much more than any idealism.'' But that materialism may be waning, McGovern says. He hears it in the questions students ask and sees it in their growing activism on issues such as the environment. He says he senses a growing desire for leaders who will put the interests of the public first. ``I think there's a quickening of interest now,'' he says. ``It isn't as strong as it was in the '60s, but I do think there's a modest comeback. The trend is in the right direction.'' McGovern looks out the restaurant window at students rushing across the campus below. He has high hopes for the future those young people represent, and for the history that is yet unwritten. Perhaps, he says, the dramatic crumbling of East-West differences over the past year means that the world is finally going to figure out how to live in peace. Even the Persian Gulf crisis may have a silver lining, in that the United Nations is emerging as an effective forum for resolving international problems, he says. ``For many years I have believed that what is now happening could have happened,'' McGovern says. ``I guess I've always been an optimist. I don't know how you can live any other way and get much out of life.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - The struggle between the Inkatha Freedom Party of Zulu chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi and African National Congress of Nelson Mandela has claimed some 6,000 lives since 1986. Some fear the struggle is the prelude to a full-fledged civil war in South Africa. Here's a look at MAndela's enigmatic rival, a chieftain who extols Zulu warrior traditions but advocates non-violence in dealing with the white government.

Zulu chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, one of South Africa's most powerful black leaders, is an enigma, equally comfortable in various guises. One moment he is in sharp business suits discussing free enterprise with world leaders, the next he is attired in leopard skins with spear in hand, leading Zulu war dances. Buthelezi, leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party and head of the Kwazulu black homeland, portrays himself as a moderate, but his views are rejected by growing numbers of blacks. He advocates non-violent resistance to apartheid and working with whites, but his followers battle black opponents. He advocates free enterprise, although many blacks favor socialism. He has alienated many blacks by saying that ending apartheid won't solve their problems. Supporters, including many whites, see Buthelezi as the one black leader who can find a way for whites and blacks to live together in peace. Followers hail him as a pragmatist who refuses to make empty political promises. Critics, who are more numerous, denounce Buthelezi as a tribal warlord, a sellout to apartheid who wants power at any price. They equate Buthelezi with the dictators who rule many black African nations and accuse him of inciting black factional violence that has claimed thousands of lives. Patrick Lekota, a senior official of the rival African National Congress, accuses Buthelezi of being a pawn of the ruling National Party. ``Buthelezi is the National Party's dog. ... De Klerk must rein in his dog,'' he told a recent meeting. President F.W. de Klerk's government, which has promised to end apartheid, has toyed with the idea of an alliance with Inkatha, a ``rainbow coalition'' of blacks and whites that would be a formidable political force. Some observers say ambition and personality differences are the root of Buthelezi's conflict with other black groups. Disillusioned former supporters accuse Buthelezi of being despotic and unable to accept criticism. ``His goal is to amass as much black support as possible so he becomes the leader of black South Africans,'' says Zwelake Sisulu, a top black journalist. Buthelezi hits back at critics who accuse him of inciting tribal warfare. ``I am accused of murderous warmongering, which I strenuously refute. I loathe the sickening murder and mayhem that is causing untold suffering,'' he said in an Oct. 4 letter to The New York Times. Whatever the truth, most observers agree Buthelezi will play a major role in deciding South Africa's future. The struggle between Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party and the African National Congress of Nelson Mandela has claimed some 6,000 lives since 1986. Some fear the struggle is the prelude to a full-fledged civil war. Independent observers say both sides have helped incite the violence. One of several hereditary chiefs and princes of the Zulu royal house, Buthelezi says he is determined to destroy apartheid, but he is ready to compromise with whites for peace. For years, Buthelezi has said only peaceful negotiation and non-violent resistance can end apartheid. He insists the white minority must be assured their future is secure, even if it means blacks have to settle for less. ``My ideal is one person, one vote in a unitary state,'' he said in a published interview. ``But I have always said we cannot afford to destroy the country in seeking that.'' It is a message that appeals to many whites, fearful of losing their wealth under any future black government. But Buthelezi's message enrages many blacks, who have lived in poverty for generations with no political rights, and they accuse him of toadying to whites. While other black opposition groups tend to blame apartheid for most of the suffering endured by blacks, Buthelezi warns that the end of apartheid will just be the start of their struggle for emancipation. He warns blacks that they can only be free when they liberate themselves as individuals by hard work. ``Many people have nurtured illusions that will never come about. Once the euphoria (of freedom) passes, we will return to the real world where the problems remain the same,'' he said in an interview. The ANC and other groups call for redistribution of wealth from whites to blacks and favor some form of socialism. Many blacks equate capitalism with apartheid, saying it has only benefited whites.
