DOC.TEXT: Buthelezi says socialism will ruin South Africa and only free enterprise cas a popular getaway for the Hollywood film community. Pelican Bay was the setting for several silent films, including ``Peter Pan,'' ``Pearls of Paradise,'' ``Diamonds in the Sky,'' ``Sirens of the Sea'' and ``Adam and Eve.'' Conservancy Ranch manager Welborn, one of six permanent residents on the island, says about 4,000 to 5,000 visitors came out here last year, mostly by permit aboard private yachts or charter boats. The Conservancy eventually would like to install a campground to permit educational tours of the island.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: James Garner says he liked the script for ``Decoration Day'' so much it prompted him to break his rule of preparing for a role. He read the book from which the TV movie was adapted. Garner plays a retired judge in the two-hour drama, set in Georgia in 1975. The judge comes to the aid of a black man who refuses to accept a Medal of Honor for heroism won 31 years earlier in World War II. ``I hardly ever read the book after the script,'' Garner says. ``You lose so much between the book and the script. ``The problem is that when you're doing it you remember something from the book that's not in the script. You don't want to fall into that trap. It was probably left out for a reason.'' The drama, a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation on NBC on Sunday, was adapted by Robert Lenski from the novella by the late John William Corrington. ``I was familiar with the author's work,'' Garner says. ``I'd read several of his books. He lived in New Orleans until he died about a year ago.'' Garner says that at this point in his acting career he looks for quality scripts. ``I want things that have to do with people and the human condition,'' he says. ``I don't think you have to blow up cities and kill people to entertain. It's a pleasant script. `Murphy's Romance' was pleasant. ``I had an opportunity to buy `Rambo.' This guy blows up a whole town and kills half the National Guard because a cop offends him. What kind of morality is that?'' In ``Decoration Day,'' the Defense Department suddenly realizes it has overlooked giving the medal to the black veteran. He refuses the medal on principle. And when his former employer writes the letter of refusal a government lawyer fears a white conspiracy to block the presentation. Garner's character is Albert Sidney Finch, who retired from the bench after the death of his wife. Bill Cobbs is Gee Penniwell, a black veteran of World War II and a boyhood friend of Finch's until they grew apart. Judith Ivey is a legal secretary who becomes close to Finch when she prepares his case for Penniwell. Ruby Dee is Finch's housekeeper, Norm Skaggs is his nephew, Jennifer Robertson is his nephew's wife and Larry Fishburne is the government lawyer. ``You wait for something wonderful to come along,'' says Garner, who starred in the TV series ``Maverick'' and ``The Rockford Files'' and such movies as ``The Great Escape,'' ``The Americanization of Emily,'' ``Grand Prix,'' ``Victor-Victoria'' and ``Murphy's Romance.'' ``Decoration Day'' is the third Hall of Fame drama for Garner, who previously starred in ``Promise'' and ``My Name is Bill W,'' and the eighth for producer Marian Rees. Robert Markowitz directed on location in Georgia, although the original story was set in Louisiana. ``I wear an `Indiana Jones' hat that was given to me years ago by Stuart Margolin,'' Garner says. ``I had the brim cut down. It's one of those things you pull out of the closet. Most of the wardrobe is mine. The pants, the fishing vest. It works better if you wear things that are yours.'' Garner, who was wounded in combat in the Korean War, says he can identify with a veteran offered a medal years later. ``When I was doing `Tank' I mentioned that I had never received the Purple Heart,'' he says. ``I was with the 24th Division. Our position had been overrun and all the records had been lost. So as a PR thing the Army gave me the medal. So the fact that they want to give this man the Medal of Honor 31 years later makes sense to me. It happened to me.'' Garner's first major movie after the war was ``Sayonara,'' a 1957 film in which he played a Marine pilot. ``I was doing `Sayonara' when Warner Bros. was looking at every actor in Hollywood for `Maverick,''' he says. ``Then they noticed me in the dailies and said, `Let's use him. He's already under contract.' I did the pilot, and when I got back from Japan I started `Maverick.' ``I got $500 a week the first season, with no residuals. I got $600 the second year, $1,250 the third year. My competition was Ed Sullivan, who got $25,000 a week.'' Both ``Maverick'' and ``The Rockford Files'' are considered television classics. ``It's all luck,'' Garner says. ``No, it's not all luck, but there was a lot of luck involved.'' He doubts he will do another series. ``People have no idea how hard an hour-long series is,'' he says. ``Even if I did a half-hour show I'd have to work hard, especially to maintain the integrity of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Adv02
AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 4 b&w photos.)
DOC.TEXT: The daunting challenge of playing Shakespeare - and Shaw, O'Neill, Chekhov and others of the classic theater - is proving irresistible to big-name American actors willing to take big risks in big stage roles. In the past year on and off Broadway and in regional theater, such movie and television stars as Dustin Hoffman, Kevin Kline, Stacy Keach, Brian Dennehy and William Hurt have tried roles as challenging as Shylock in ``The Merchant of Venice,'' Hamlet, Richard III, Hickey in Eugene O'Neill's ``The Iceman Cometh'' and the title character in Chekhov's ``Ivanov.'' Three other well-known actors - Hal Holbrook, Philip Bosco and Jason Robards - are all tackling different productions of ``King Lear'' this season. Holbrook currently stars as the raging monarch at off-Broadway's Roundabout Theater, while the others plan to do the role next spring, Bosco at the Folger in Washington and Robards at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass. The pay is poor and the work is hard. Why do they do it? ``When an actor does the classics, he uses every muscle he has - all of his imaginative, physical and emotional resources,'' says Michael Kahn, artistic director of the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger. ``It's like the Olympics.It's testing yourself against this great material, and if you emerge triumphant, you feel pretty good about yourself.'' In England, the switch from commercial to classical roles happens all the time, mostly because the television, movie and stage production centers are concentrated around London. In the United States, actors must shuttle between the East and West coasts - and points in between - to work. A British star like Diana Rigg can chew the scenery in popular escapist material like ``Mother Love,'' a pyschological thriller shown here recently on public television's ``Mystery,'' and then play Cleopatra in the 17th-century play ``All for Love'' by John Dryden. The actress will star in the rarely seen Restoration tragedy next April at the Almeida Theater, a small, 300-seat theater in London. Glenda Jackson did Bertolt Brecht's ``Mother Courage'' last summer and performers like Ian McKellen, John Wood, Joan Plowright and others appear regularly on stage while fitting in work on television or in the movies. One reason American actors do less classic theater is that they have to plan their careers so far in advance. Hurt did ``Ivanov'' for only six weeks at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, Conn., but the commitment required juggling and rejuggling of the actor's schedule. ``It is a luxury to be able to carve out the time from a busy schedule of television or movies to do the classics, but for me, it is absolutely essential,'' says Keach, whose Richard III at the Folger was cheered by Washington critics and audiences. ``I started in the classics. I've always had to try and plan as best as I can to get back and do them.'' Still, until he played the evil, humpbacked ``Richard III,'' Keach hadn't acted in a Shakespearean play for 15 years, although he had starred in ``Hamlet'' three times - once at the Long Wharf Theater in Connecticut, then in Central Park for the New York Shakespeare Festival and finally at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. Part of the excitement is the element of risk. ``You're making yourself extremely vulnerable because somebody might tell you that you're lousy,'' Holbrook says. ``And it's not like being lousy in an inconsequential part. You're standing up there on the high board, taking a big swan dive.'' Sometimes, those dives can bomb. Al Pacino, using a Brooklyn accent, limped through a disastrous production of ``Richard III'' on Broadway 11 years ago. He wasn't much better playing Mark Antony in ``Julius Caesar'' at the New York Shakespeare Festival in 1988, an ill-conceived production that also dragged down such other usually fine actors as Edward Herrmann and Martin Sheen.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT: When Charles Dickens wrote ``A Christmas Carol'' in 1843, he had no way of knowing that his simple truths would provide creative fodder for filmmakers, animators, lyricists and playwrights for generations to come. Many holiday-themed movies take their cue from Dickens' wonderful story of Ebenezer Scrooge and his change of heart. Here is an alphabetical list of some, but certainly not all, of some holiday-spiced videos for the Thanksgiving-Christmas-New Year season. Many are versions of ``A Christmas Carol'':

- ``Alice's Restaurant'' (1969): It's the Thanksgiving Dinner that couldn't be beat, and the generation that just said ``no'' to the draft. From Arlo Guthrie's song. - ``Auntie Mame'' (1958): Christmas despair leads to Christmas joy and a new marriage for Auntie Mame in this delightful romp. - ``Babes in Toyland'' (1961): A terrible Disney version (if there is such a thing) of the Victor Herbert operetta, starring Annette Funicello, Tommy Sands and Ray Bolger. - ``The Bear Who Slept Through Christmas'' (1983): Animated story about a bear who skips hibernation to find out what Christmas is all about. Not bad, but certainly not great. - ``Caspar's First Christmas'' (1987): Any parent who inflicts this dud on a kid should be arrested for child abuse. Horrible animation and terrible Caspar voice (it's not the one in the original Caspar the Friendly Ghost cartoons) help make it unbearable. - ``A Charlie Brown Christmas'' (1965): If you ever wondered what CHristmas was all about, wonder no more. A magical treat from the Peanuts characters. - ``A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving'' (1973): Linus explains the true meaning of Thanksgiving. Another Peanuts gem. - ``A Child's Christmas in Wales'' (1987): Dylan Thomas' wonderful story, somewhat lamely done. - ``A Christmas CArol'' (1938): A compassionate look at Scrooge, starring Reginald Owen and GEne Lockhart. - ``A Christmas Carol'' (1951): The better version, with often scary sequences. Stars Alastair Sim as a more broken and evil Scrooge, whose transformation is all the more poignant. - ``Christmas in Connecticut'' (1945): A phony family for an advice columnist. FAst-paced fun, starring Barbara Stanwyck and Sydney Greenstreet. - ``Christmas Lilies of the Field'' (1984): Sequel to Academy Award-winning movie that starred Sidney Poitier. This one is rather Lame, but has its heart in the right place. Stars Billy Dee Williams. - ``A Christmas Story'' (1983): Jean Shepard's marvelous memory of Christmas in the 1940s and the ultimate gift, a regulation Red Ryder air rifle. - ``A Disney Christmas Gift'' (1982): A real treat. The best of Disney, with special holiday shorts. - ``Dr. Seuss: Horton Hears a Who''; ``The Grinch Who Stole Christmas'' (1974): Made-for-television animated shorts from the cartoon master himself, Chuck JOnes. - ``A Dream for Christmas'' (1973): A minister moves to California to start a new church. A slice of American pie, but not as tasty. Stars Hari Rhodes and BEah Richards. - ``Ernest Saves Christmas'' (1988): Ernest P. Worrell, that down-home obnoxious TV pitchman, helps Santa. You have to be a true Ernest fan for this one. - ``Happy New Year, Charlie Brown'' (1985): That old gang again. And great as always. - ``Holiday Inn'' (1942): With music by Irving Berlin, and memorable performances by Fred Astaire and Bing Crosby, who could go wrong? - ``It's a Wonderful Life'' (1946): Frank Capra's black and white marvel, starring JAmes Stewart as the man who made the wrong wish and was saved from it. - ``March of the Wooden Soldiers'' (1934): Wonderful fantasy feature starring Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy, who save the land of Old King Cole from the horrible boogeymen. - ``Meet Me in St. Louis'' (1944): Family entertainment from Judy Garland, Margaret O'Brien and Tom Drake. - ``Mickey's Christmas Carol'' (1984): That resourceful little rodent plays Bob CRatchit in this spin of the Dickens' classic. - ``Miracle on 34th Street'' (1947): Do you believe in Santa Claus? A delightful tale, starring NAtalie Wood. - ``Mr. Magoo's Christmas Carol'' (1962): The near-sighted one plays Scrooge. - ``Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (and Other Wonderful Christmas Stories)'' (1944): Four animated featurettes. All black and white, and all classics. - ``Santa Claus - The Movie'' (1985): Dudley Moore plays an elf in this enjoyable film. How fitting. - ``Night and Day'' (1946): CAry Grant portrays Cole Porter. - ``The Old Curiosity Shop'' (1975): A British-made version of ``Scrooge,'' the musical adaptation of ``A Christmas Carol.'' This one is pretty good. Stars Anthony Newly and David Hemmings. - ``Scrooge'' (1970): Musical of Dickens tale. Stars Albert Finney and Alec Guiness. - ``Scrooged'' (1988): One of the more disastrous versions of the Dickens story. Saved by CArol Kane as the ghost of Christmas Present. Stars Bill Murray doing his usual. hilarious, as is the entire movie. Co-stars Eddie Murphy, Ralph Bellamy, Don AMeche and Jamie Lee Curtis. - ``A Tree Grows in Brooklyn'' (1945): A sentimental portrait of a working class family - in Brooklyn. - ``White Christmas'' (1954): AN inferior redo of ``Holiday Inn,'' but it makes good use of the title song. Stars Bing Crosby again.

Donald Trump and investors in his Taj Mahal casino agreed to a restructuring of the gambling parlor's debt that will briefly put it under bankruptcy-court protection and give bondholders half ownership of the glitzy Atlantic City property. Some details of the arrangement were still to be worked out, but bondholder representatives said it contained several incentives for Trump to improve the performance of the Taj Mahal, which has been unable to break even since its April 2 opening. The deal was reached Friday, more than 12 hours after Trump missed a $47.3 million interest payment on $675 million worth of high-yield junk bonds used to finance the Taj Mahal. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The Manville trust fund will make staggered payments to victims of asbestos diseases based on severity of illness under a tentative settlement of tens of thousands of claims nationwide, lawyers said. The agreement, announced Friday and expected to be completed over the weekend, would mark a major breakthrough in a two-decade-old effort to compensate workers made sick by inhaling asbestos fibers in products made by U.S. companies. The deal would have to be approved by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who earlier this year ordered the Manville trust overhauled. The trust has 130,000 claims pending. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Consumer inflation slowed slightly in October and the country's trade deficit narrowed, but economists attributed these seemingly upbeat developments to the near certainty that the nation has slid into a recession. Also on Friday, President Bush wrapped up a week of hastily called meetings with his economic advisers and leading U.S. business executives as the administration scoured for ways to alleviate the pain from any economic downturn. Bush received a generally bleak assessment of the economy's prospects from the executives, leading the president to acknowledge the possibility of a recession for the first time. --- NEWYORK (AP) - CBS' ``60 Minutes'' will fire three producers at year's end, and ABC News will close its Frankfurt, Germany, bureau and three Central American offices, network officials said. CBS will make the ``60 Minutes'' cuts to restructure the top-rated series' staff, not because of economic conditions that have forced what the network calls ``a belt-tightening'' in its news division, a spokesman said Friday. The move was ordered after Harry Reasoner, one of the show's first correspondents, announced he would reduce his workload, said spokesman Roy Brunett. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Union employees of United Press International have accepted a 35 percent, 90-day pay cut in what company and union officials described as an effort to keep the financially troubled news service going while its owners seek a buyer. Chris Dahl, secretary-treasurer of the Wire Service Guild, said 62 percent of those voting on Friday approved the reduction.Milt Capps, a UPI vice president and spokesman, said the guild members approved the pay cut ``in order to keep UPI alive while we seek a buyer.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Phone company stocks took a pounding after MCI Communications Corp. said its financial performance could falter due to stepped-up competition from AT&T, the economic slump, a cost-cutting program and a recent acquisition. The decline on Friday was accelerated by a number of Wall Street stock analysts, who lowered their earnings forecasts for the nation's No. 2 long-distance phone company. MCI stock lost more than a quarter of its value. Though the news appeared to favor American Telephone & Telegraph Co., the stock price of the dominant long-distance company also suffered. --- ST. PAUL, Minn. (AP) - Northwest Airlines Chairman Alfred Checchi reportedly is exploring a buyout of Eastern Airlines using up to $150 million in pension funds of Eastern's union pilots. The Saint Paul Pioneer Press said Friday that officials of the Eastern Air Line Pilots Association have said union leaders are agreeable to a Northwest acquisition. The officials also said their leaders are willing to pitch the idea of lending Checchi the pension funds, the paper reported. --- LONDON (AP) - Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd. is seeking a $600 million bridge loan to help alleviate a short-term liquidity squeeze brought on by tough market conditions, bankers said. Murdoch and other senior News Corp. executives presented their proposals to creditors earlier this week in Sydney and at a meeting Thursday in London with British and European bankers. Australian-based News Corp. is trying to line up support for a new credit facility of $6.5 billion to replace much of its existing debt, bankers said on Friday, speaking on condition of anonymity. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - BEverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest nursing home chain, has been found guilty of unfair labor practices in a ruling organized labor called a major victory that could affect other corporate giants. The Fort Smith, Ark.-based chain said the ruling, handed down by an administrative law judge on Friday, would be appealed to the National Labor Relations Board. At issue was a 1987 NLRB case in which the government accused the company of engaging in 40 illegal acts ``designed to defeat'' workers' rights to unionize. ---

The stock market eked out a small gain Friday in an advance restrained by selling pressure on long-distance telephone issues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 5.20 to 2,550.25, stretching its gain for the week to 61.64 points. Bonds rose sharply amid clear-cut signs that the Federal Reserve has moved to lower interest rates. The dollar declined broadly and gold prices were mixed. Oil fell below $30 a barrel on the futures market.

DOC.HEAD: More Gloom: Profits Weak as Industry Enters Fourth Year of Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Profits in the nation's ailing securities industry were an anemic $200 million in the first six months of 1990 and have deteriorated since then, Wall Street's leading trade group said Sunday. The Securities Industry Association said Wall STreet is starting toslash expenses beyond the nearly 50,000 job cuts since the 1987 stock market crash. The outlook remains gloomy. Trading and underwriting of stocks and bonds has been depressed by drastically fewer mergers, concern over the economy, the year-old collapse of the junk bond market and reduced activity by individual investors. The SIA report said first-half 1990 profits ``barely reached $200 million, a sum not equivalent to a single decent bond issue a few years ago, and indications are third-quarter results will deteriorate further.'' The industry made $1.8 billion last year, $2.5 billion in 1988, $1.1 billion in 1987 and a record of more than $5 billion in 1986. Annual profits haven't been below $1 billion since the 1970s. The SIA said industry revenue will not increase this year for the first time since the 1970s. It said profit margins are below 1 percent, return on equity is under 2 percent and brokerage commissions are off 11 percent with no prospect for improvement by the end of the year. George R. Monahan, the group's director of industry studies, said with the exception of the top 10 firms, the industry ``has been doing an excellent job of cost reduction.'' Broker compensation is off about 6 percent from 1989, while commission revenue is down about 7 percent. But at the 10 largest firms, broker compensation is down 8 percent while commission revenue has slumped 16 percent. Wall Street is notorious for its high compensation levels, particularly during boom cycles such as the mid-1980s when young investment bankers and other professionals quickly commanded six-figure salaries. Stockbrokers, on the other hand, tend to receive less pay. The SIA said that when expenses are adjusted to exclude gross interest expenses, compensation in the first six months of 1990 accounted for 57 percent of total costs. Overall, pay was down to a third of all expenses from 41 percent in 1987, the group said. Further compensation cuts are occurring. Year-end bonuses this year for highly paid investment bankers - an important indicator of compensation trends -are expected to be slashed 30 percent to 50 percent at top firms. That would bring compensation for investment bankers down to 1985 levels, Wall Street executives say, still considered high. Many firms in recent weeks have laid off investment bankers, including senior-level professionals, because of declining business. Despite several rounds of cutting since the 1987 crash, Wall Street pay last year still averaged more than $82,700 per employee, including clerks and secretaries, the SIA reported, almost double the level a decade ago. Nearly 50,000 jobs have been eliminated from the securities industry's peak employment of more than 260,000 nationwide in 1987. Apart from compensation, other cost-cutting appears to be more successful, the SIA said, as expenses in all other areas are below 1989 levels. But Monahan said even that may not be enough. ``Although long-standing practices are now being changed, some firms still make payments to both profitable and unprofitable departments on the premise that business cycles will even this out in the end, which may not happen,'' he said. Separately, the SIA announced that Thomas A. James, president and chief executive of Raymond James & Associates Inc., a St. Petersburg, Fla., brokerage, was nominated as chairman-elect. He is to serve as an SIA officer and director in 1991 and become chairman in 1992. The SIA represents about 600 brokerage and investment banking firms in the United States and Canada that account for about 90 percent of securities activity in North America.

DOC.HEAD: Few Guarantees in Czechoslovakia's New Capitalism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: As a child, Josef Dundr would stroll with his father past the snug Three Ostriches Inn, a buff-colored 17th-century building that had belonged to the family until the communists came. ``My father would say, `This used to be ours; maybe it will be again some day','' said Dundr, who was born there 44 years ago. ``I didn't see that day coming, I was so downtrodden by that time.'' The communists no longer run Czechoslovakia and the day may come after all. On Dec. 1, the government will start selling or giving back to private owners 100,000 restaurants, small shops and other businesses. The return of many factories and other large enterprises will begin next year. In the new, no-frills capitalism of Czechoslovkia, however, individuals may lose out to economic expedience. They risk losing their jobs, as well as the chance of ownership, but the winners can get rich. Officials cite the Soviet Union's many false starts in their argument against moving slowly. All East European countries have lost time since their communist regimes fell last year, but Czechoslovakia now may be poised to outpace the others. For people with money, the switch to private enterprise ``is a golden opportunity not to be repeated in this century,'' said Miroslav Zamecnik, spokesman for Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus. There are few guarantees in the new system. Dundr may not get the Three Ostriches back. Alena Kubistova is not sure she will have a job when a private owner takes over the meat market she manages just off Wenceslas Square. Down the street, Ctirad Fuchs, 30, looks for a compromise between his wish to own the music and book store he manages and the interests of the building's new owner. President Vaclav Havel has warned that failure to protect such people as Fuchs and the others could lead to unrest, but appears to have yielded to Klaus's desire for quick reform. When Parliament approved the privatization law Oct. 25, the finance minister acknowledged it would not ``satisfy all completely.'' Dundr, now assistant manager of the joint-venture Palace Hotel, considers the Three Ostriches a sure moneymaker. It nestles at the foot of the Charles Bridge on the royal route to Prague Castle, and enjoyed a good reputation even under state ownership. He estimated its worth at 25 million to 70 million crowns, or from $1 million to nearly $3 million. Emotion is deeply involved in the desire to get the inn back. Dundr said his father, now 81, ``wants to feel that he can pass this on to his children and grandchildren.'' His likely rival for the Three Ostriches is the man who runs the restaurant and the 18-room hotel the state made from the family apartments above it. Dundr fears the manager's connections in the bureaucracy give him an edge. ``In a case like this, millions are involved,'' he said. ``Stamps can be issued, documents can be signed.'' If he gets the inn back, Dundr said, he will fire the manager and staff of about 20 for inefficiency and rudeness. Zamecnik, the Finance Ministry spokesman, sees nothing wrong with such action. ``The sooner they kick these people out, the better,'' he said. Under the privatization law, property must be returned to former Owners or their heirs, or be auctioned. LOcal governments will set bid prices, and any small business can be bought for a minimum of half the asking price. Even before the law was approved, managers of state-run stores held brief strikes to express concern that Czechoslovaks who got rich on the black market or through past Communist Party connections would have an advantage. According to Zamecnik, the government will not examine buyers too closely because a quick change to private enterprise offers a way to put ill-gotten wealth back into legal circulation. Dundr's position is that the Three Ostriches should be returned to the family rather than auctioned. It falls into a gray area, however. The family acquired the restaurant in about 1930 and was nationalized after communists took power in 1948. The Dundrs kept the building until 1962, then turned it over as a cultural monument they could not afford to preserve. To protect consumers, the law requires that any shop going private must continue selling the same goods for one year, but privatization is much farther along than efforts to cushion its effects. There are no requirements for private owners to retain current employees or even to pay a minimum wage. Ms. Kubistova, like most working Czechoslovaks, has no experience of market economics. She was 3 years old when the communists took over. After her first talk with the new owner of the meat market, she said, she is about 80 percent sure he will keep her on as manager, at least for now. Her current salary of about $110 a month is above the national average, but she said more important than pay is ``whether you will have a job.'' Fuchs would like to reach an agreement to own his music and book store, and perhaps others of the approximately 100 in Prague. The store manager said he should have the chance not by right, but because Prague needs such stores managed by competent people. ``Culture as a commodity will not be very attractive when the price of paper and food go up,'' he said wryly.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Cigarette Machine Ban, Teens Still Puff Away
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Advocates of Utah's pioneering statewide ban on cigarette vending machines claim a victory in their war on tobacco, citing statistics that show a modest decline in teen-age smoking. But in downtown Salt Lake City, youths defiantly puff away and mock the ban. ``I buy them at the store. They never ask'' how old you are, said Dean, who at 17 is two years under Utah's legal smoking and drinking age. ``If you're going to smoke, you're going to smoke.'' Penni, 16, gets cigarettes from friends or her parents. ``If you can't get them that way, you just rip them off or walk in and buy them. Nobody cares,'' she said, making her point with a long drag. For 11-year-old Racheska, it's only slightly more difficult. Sometimes, she says, her mother buys them for her. Other times, she buys them in convenience stores. The image of Racheska is a haunting one for Chris Chalkley, a chief advocate of the state's 15-month-old prohibition on cigarette vending machines in public places, the first such statewide ban in the nation. ``Everyone has their source, I know. It's sad. That's our challenge now, tighter controls. ... The vending machines were the first step,'' said Chalkley, manager of the Utah Department of Health's tobacco prevention and control program. She insists the ban has, coupled with anti-smoking education, had some effect - enough to spark similar efforts elsewhere. Minneapolis has banned cigarette machines, and the New York City Council this month voted to ban them in most public places. Pittsburgh has approved a requirement that cigarette machines accept only tokens, whose sale would be controlled, but it hasn't gone into effect yet. Chalkley cites student surveys showing that from 1987 to 1989 - the first year the ban took effect - smoking in the 12-to-17 age group declined from 13.1 percent to 10.5 percent in Utah. A 1988 National Institutes of Health study estimated that on average, 11.8 percent of America's adolescents smoke. Chalkley says that when legislators meet in January, their agenda will include further proposals to shut off the tobacco pipeline to Utah's youth - including requiring stores selling cigarettes to post signs reading: ``We I.D. for tobacco sales.'' Other possibilities include requiring that tobacco products be placed behind sales counters, and providing stiffer penalties for stores that sell to minors, including revoking sales licenses. Little opposition to the measures is expected in this state, where seven out of 10 people are Mormons taught to abstain from tobacco, alcohol, coffee and tea. Currently, selling tobacco to a minor is a misdemeanor carrying a maximum $500 fine and 90-day jail term on the first offense; $1,000 fine and six months behind bars on the second; and $2,500 fine and a year in jail for a third offense. ``Really, we need to put the screws on the convenience store operators or anyone else who sells cigarettes to people under 19. We want to go after them,'' said Republican state Rep. Hugh Rush, who sponsored the ban.

DOC.HEAD: Is Help Ahead For Casino Industry?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic City's gambling industry wants the state to loosen regulations, introduce sports gambling and allow other changes that casino operators hope will help them last through the weak economy. The most visible example of the downturn in Atlantic City's gambling fortunes has been Donald Trump's Taj Mahal casino. In a deal reached with bondholders this past week, Trump gave the investors half ownership in exchange for allowing him to delay a $47.3 million interest payment. Also, the interest rate on the bonds was cut 2 percentage points to 12 percent. The casinos want round-the-clock gambling, instead of the current 18-hour limit on weekdays and 20 hours on weekends. They also want to be able to take wagers on sports and open more than 30 percent of their casino floors to slot machines. Casinos have also asked for relief from state regulations they consider onerous and costly in both time and money, and the ability to easily introduce variations of existing games. ``We have to get away from the idea that whenever a casino proposes something new, it's something bad,'' said John Sweeney, the new director of the state Division of Gaming Enforcement. ``We can't be looking at everything they do in a suspicious manner.'' The prospects for 24-hour gambling are less certain than those for regulatory relief, but industry executives are clamoring for it anyway. The likelihood for sports gambling also is uncertain. A bill that would allow sports betting in the casinos has been proposed by state Sen. Louis Bassano. Casinos do not anticipate benefiting much from the action, but think it would bring new business to the city. Sen. William Gormley, a Republican senator who represents Atlantic County, home of the gambling resort, doubts that New Jersey is ready to emulate Nevada and adopt legal sports betting. ``Given the current tenor after Pete Rose when people hear about betting and athletes and athletic competition, it still gives them a certain hesitancy,'' Gormley said. ``Right now, it's something I don't have a high comfort level with.'' A measure to open up more of the casino floor to slot machines appears to have the best shot of clearing the Legislature. Assemblyman Fred Scerni has proposed raising the current percentage of floor space casinos are allowed to devote to slot machines from 30 percent to 40 percent. The 30 percent limit is a holdover from the beginnings of gambling here when the founding fathers envisioned a traditional betting parlor emphasizing blackjack and craps. But the slots have become increasingly popular among patrons, and now account for 60 cents of each $1 gambled at the resort's dozen casinos. ``It's something we'd really like to see,'' said John Belisle, vice president of marketing for Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel. ``The slots just continue to grow.''

DOC.HEAD: Floor Traders Halt Stock Markets For Second Day
DOC.TEXT: Floor traders, protesting government inaction on long-awaited regulatory reforms, halted stock trading in Italy on Monday for a second consecutive session. The strike, by about 1,000 floor traders, began on Friday and was scheduled to last through Wednesday. Picket lines outside the two largest Italian markets in Milan and Rome prevented trading in equity and bonds. Only foreign exchange quotations by bank officials were completed. The traders are protesting 30 percent capital gains tax proposed by the finance minister. They have also long complaining that the failure of the government to implement reforms hurts Italian markets' competiveness. They specifically want to see swift implementation of a legislation regulating public tender offers, insider trading and financial intermediaries. ``We don't want to see that Italian markets are bypassed and that investors increasingly resort to London and other European markets,'' said a Milan floor trader, who spoke under condition of anonimity. Several Italian blue chip companies are traded in London and quoted closing prices despite the markets strike in Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Union Accepts Three-Year Deal with General Dynamics
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the largest union at General Dynamics Inc.'s jet-building plant say the new three-year contract that was approved Sunday was the best they could get considering the soft economy and the downturn in the defense industry. ``We felt it was the best we could do without a long dispute,'' said Pat Lane, president of the 10,000-member International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers' Lodge 776. ``I know a lot of people would have had to suffer to (greatly) improve the contract.'' ``We are still short on insurance and the bonuses ... but I feel it is the best contract we could get at this time,'' Lane said. Sunday's vote came a week after the union, which represents about one-third of the plant's workers, narrowly rejected a contract proposal nearly identical to the one that was approved. The vote was 5,835-1,013 in favor of the new agreement, said General Dynamics spokesman Mike Hatfield. The contract took effect at 12:01 a.m. today. The union, after narrowly defeating a proposed contract Nov. 11, agreed to extend the deadline to midnight Sunday rather than strike. Negotiations resumed Thursday, with both sides refusing public comment until Sunday's vote. Hatfield said the contract's terms include a 5.5 percent general wage increase the first year and 3 percent increases each of the next two years. Hatfield said General Dynamics also will pay a $1,100 ratification bonus to each union member and cost of living adjustments projected to equal about $1.66 an hour by the end of the three years. ``We set out some weeks ago when negotiations began with the intent to strike an agreement that would be equitable for both sides and I think we achieved that,'' Hatfield said. The agreement could be considered a setback for the union, which had originally sought a wage increase of 10 percent in the first year of the contract and 5 percent in each of the following two years. But union leaders say the deal is the best they could negotiate, given the soft economy and coming downturn in the nation's defense industry. ``In this day and age it's a pretty good contract,'' said union attorney Rod Tanner. ``Many members were hoping to obtain ratification bonuses in the second and third year, but there just wasn't the money. If it had the bonuses, it would have been an excellent contract.'' ``The negotiation committee worked very hard to try to obtain a better proposal,'' Tanner said. ``Although there were some aspects that were disappointing, it was in the best interest of the union to accept the contract. Workers also told The Dallas Morning News that a temporary restraining order obtained by the company against pickets in the event of a strike may have intimidated workers. Despite the vote on the new contract, union members seem uniformly pessimistic about the plant's future. From a peak employment of about 31,000, the work force could fall to 25,000 by 1995, Fort Worth Division general manager Charles Anderson said last week. General Dynamics has given notice to about 150 hourly workers that they will be out of a job by Dec. 14 and has said it will lay off 700 to 1,000 salaried employees in the research and engineering department in January.

DOC.HEAD: EC September Jobless Rate Steady At 8.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's seasonally adjusted average unemployment rate held steady at 8.3 percent in September for the sixth consecutive month, the EC executive Commission said Monday. For comparison, the jobless rate in the United States rose to 5.7 percent in September from 5.2 percent in June. The unemployment rate held steady at 5.7 percent in October. Within the EC, sharp variations among EC countries persisted, the Commission said. Unemployment remained highest in Ireland with 16.5 percent, followed by Spain at 15.5 percent, Italy at 9.9 percent and France at 9.0 percent. Rates elsehere in the EC included Denmark at 8.3 percent, Belgium 8.2 percent, Great Britain 6.4 percent, West Germany 5.0 percent, Portugal 4.9 percent and Luxemburg 1.5 percent. The EC gave no September jobless figures for Greece and the Netherlands. at 0.5 percent increase, while unemployment rose by 0.2 percent in Belgium and the Great Britain and by 0.1 percent in France. Unemployment sank since April by 0.4 percent in Spain, 0.3 percent in West Germany and 0.2 percent in Portugal.

DOC.HEAD: Subsidiary Investors Seek Provisional Liquidator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollars are U.S. unless otherwise noted.
DOC.TEXT: Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd.'s struggle to stay afloat was complicated Monday when investors in its JN Taylor Holdings Ltd. unit sought to have a provisional liquidator appointed for JN Taylor. The application was made in the Supreme Court in South Australia state by 28 investors holding about 21 percent of JN Taylor preference shares. The move throws doubt on Bond Corp.'s proposed debt-for-equity swap with its creditors which would put 90 percent of the company's stock in the hands of European bond holders. JN Taylor's assets are a $139 million loan to another Bond Corp. subsidiary, Bond Corp. Finance, and a $74.5 million loan to Alan Bond's family company, Dallhold Investments Pty. Ltd. On Friday, Bond Corp. released a letter written by Bond Corp. executive chairman Peter Lucas to JN Taylor, in which he said neither Bond Corp. nor Bond Corp. Finance was in a position to repay all or part of the debt. An application to liquidate Bond Corp. could be an avenue that a liquidator to JN Taylor would pursue if Bond Corp. did not repay its debt. However, Bond Corp. executive Peter Lucas played down this threat Monday and said if a liquidator were appointed to JN Taylor, he may well choose to take part in the debt-for-equity plan. He also said a liquidator would not necessarily threaten Bond Corp.'s restructuring. However, in the letter released Friday, Lucas said Dallhold had advised Bond Corp. that if it were required to repay loans from JN Taylor, support for the plan could not be provided. The orders being sought by the preference shareholders also ask for an auditor to investigate inter-company advances and agreements among JN Taylor, Bond Corp. and Bond Corp. Finance.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Network Dismisses 100, Freezes Executive Salaries
DOC.TEXT: The troubled Channel Seven television network announced Monday it would cut 100 jobs and freeze executive salaries for two years. The job eliminations hit four of the network's five stations in Sydney, Melborne, Perth and Brisbane, chief executive Bob Campbell said. The Adelaide station was spared because of previous cutbacks, he said. In a statement, Channel Seven said economic conditions had become considerably worse in recent weeks and forced the network to act to ensure its economic viability. The job cuts are the network's first large-scale job losses since David Crawford and John Allpass were appointed receivers to Qintex Australia Ltd., operators of Channel Seven, a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Expects to Post Loss for Fourth Qtr
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. said today it expects to report a loss for the fourth quarter and lower earnings from continuing operations for all of 1991 compared with this year. The media giant said its anticipated loss for the fourth quarter was due to unexpectedly large losses at the CBS Television Network due to broadcasts of major league baseball and a slowdown in the growth of national advertising. The last quarterly loss excluding onetime events at CBS was in the fourth quarter of 1986 when the company lost $20 million on continuing operations. CBS earned $59.5 million, or $2.31 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989. It said earnings from continuing operations are expected to be lower in 1991 than in 1990 because of the worsening economic climate for advertising and rising costs for entertainment programs and sports rights. The disclosures came as CBS senior exectives planned to meet today with the CBS affiliates board. The board represents the network's 200-some television stations affiliated with the CBS TV network. It was reported last week that CBS may propose a cut in what it pays affiliates to carry the network's programs. CBS has refused to comment. This was the first year of CBS's four-year baseball contract which allows it to carry several regular season games along with the league championship series, World Series and All-Star game. While the network reportedly expected to lose about $35 million in the first year of the $1.06 billion contract, the losses are said to have run migh higher. CBS Sports President Neal Pilson has said only that the loss on baseball was under $100 million. In today's announcement, CBS said losses on baseball were ``higher than anticipated'' as the result of soft demand in the ad marketplace for time on sports programs and because the World Series and one of the two league championships were settled in four games instead of the maximum seven. The short series meant CBS had fewer nights of baseball on which to sell advertising. Games later in a series also tend to draw bigger audiences, making them more valuable to advertisers. CBS said its TV network would have had a loss for the fourth quarter even without baseball, however, because of the soft ad marketplace. It said the marketplace weakness has dampened demand for Network, local TV and radio advertising, and said network ad prices have been particulartly soft for National Football League and primetime broadcasts. Another reason for the anticipated decline in earnings from continuing operations next year is that the 1990 figures include profits on the coverage of the NFL Super Bowl and the National Basketball Association playoffs and championship that the network will not have rights to in 1991. ``As a result, the CBS Television Network is currently expected to show an operating loss in 1991,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Venezuela Plans Vast Increase in Oil Output
DOC.TEXT: The state oil monopoly plans to increase its capacity for oil production, from the current 2 million barrels daily to 4.2 million barrels daily by 1996, a newspaper reported Monday. Petroleos de Venezuela's ambitious expansion plans would cost about $20 billion, according to the daily El Diario de Caracas, which quoted oil sources it did not identify. The newspaper said that while Venezuela's production capacity would rise to 4.2 million barrels a day, the country would have a production target of just 3.7 million barrels a day. The oil monopoly had previously been planning to raise production to 3.5 million barrels a day by 1995. Venezuela believes its increased capacity would be useful in dealing with international emergencies, such as the current Persian Gulf standoff that initially cut off some 4 million barrels per day and drove up oil prices, the newspaper reported. Increased production from various nations, particularly Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, have virtually erased that shortfall. The Saudis have also recently considered vast expansion of their production capacity, in what analysts view as a move to develop enough capacity to avoid future run-ups in oil prices. Venezuela's expansion plans depend heavily on attracting foreign investment in oil, which is largely prohibited by the laws that nationalized oil in 1976. Carrying out the plans would probably require congress to approve changes in the law.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Drops for Second Week
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped for a second week, with a reported loss of 21 rigs since last week to 1,103, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. The decrease followed a drop of 20 rigs last week, but remained above the count a year ago when there were 1,040 rigs operating nationally. Two weeks ago, the number of working rigs reached 1,144 - a high not seen since Dec. 28, 1987. Of the total rigs running as of Monday, 109 were offshore, 26 were in inland waters and 989 were on land, the toolmaker reported. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count - the widely watched index of drilling activity - since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Wyoming and Louisiana led the list major oil producing states reporting rig losses for the week, with drops of 10 and eight rigs, respectively. Other losses were reported in Colorado, down by four; and Michigan, New Mexico and Oklahoma, each down by three. North Dakota led the major oil producing states with gains for the week, reporting an increase of five rigs. Other states reporting increases include Kansas, up by four; Texas, which rose by two; and Ohio and Pennsylvania, each of which picked up a single rig for the week. California was unchanged for the week.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Ratifies Chrysler Pact, Last of Big Three
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union has ratified a new three-year contract with CHrysler Corp., tying up the last of three agreements with the nation's Big Three automakers. Union members at Chrysler plants ratified the new agreement by a margin of better than 4-to-1, the UAW said Monday. Contracts with General Motors Corp. and Ford MOtor Co. were ratified by slightly smaller margins. A date for signing the new UAW-Chrysler contract hasn't been set. IN all, more than 450,000 active workers at Big Three factories, warehouses and offices in the United States are covered by the contracts, which provide manufacturing flexibility for automakers and wage security for their workers. The contracts expire at midnight, Sept. 14, 1993. Each one provides for a 3 percent base wage increase in the first year and 3 percent lump-sum payments in the second and third years, and increases for current and future retirees. The contracts also provide for income guarantees for workers laid off from factories shut down because of slumping sales for more than 36 weeks during the next three years. As in all negotiations, both sides scored some wins and some losses. For the union, perhaps the biggest win was bargaining nearly the same agreement with each of the automakers. A pattern contract seemed probable for GM and Ford, but questionable for Chrysler because of its weaker financial position. However, less than three hours after UAW President Owen Bieber met Oct. 30 with Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca, the union and the company announced a tentative agreement fitting the GM-Ford pattern. The automakers failed to gain any immediate reduction in health-care costs. The UAW and the Big Three did agree in side letters to each agreement to work on cutting health-care costs, including exploration of a national health care system. The companies, faced with continued competition from Japanese automakers and an overcapacity problem in their U.S. factories, did retain the ability to ``idle,'' or effectively close, unprofitable factories. BUt it could come at a price. Each of the automakers agreed to set aside money - as much as $4.1 billion by GM - to bring unemployment benefits for workers displaced at idled factories to 100 percent of their pre-shutdown levels.
