DOC.HEAD: Asbestos Victims To Receive Less in Overhaul of Ailing Trust
With BC-Asbestos-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of workers made sick by asbestos will receive sharply reduced compensation payments from the Manville trust under a plan unveiled Monday to resolve the nation's biggest product liability case. The long-awaited restructuring is designed to insure payments to victims of lung cancer and other respiratory ailments, clear a court backlog and create a model for companies facing huge liabilities for asbestos products. The plan includes up to $520 million in new contributions to the trust by Manville Corp., which was driven into bankruptcy court in 1982 by mounting asbestos lawsuits. The trust was formed in the company's 1988 reorganization and faces more than 130,000 claims. ``These steps ... will more effectively, efficiently and Equitably compensate those injured by asbestos exposure,'' Manville chairman and chief executive Tom Stephens said in a statement. The plan was expected to be approved by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who is leading efforts to resolve asbestos litigation. The judge Monday began a process to declare a class action to settle trust claims. A restructured trust would pay asbestos victims according to the severity of illness, rather than when a claim is filed. The plan slashes plaintiffs lawyers' fees to a maximum 25 percent of settlements. It also includes dismissing tens of thousands of lawsuits against the trust pending in state and federal courts nationwide. Asbestos health claims form the biggest product liability issue in U.S. history. Manville trust payments have averaged about $43,000, but are forecast to fall more than half for serious diseases and even more for less severe ailments. Claimants are to receive a maximum 45 percent of settlements until all claims are partially met. ``It is a terrible compromise,'' said Heather Maurer, executive director of the Asbestos Victims of America, an advocacy group representing 18,000 people. ``I$3,000 or $4,000 is in any way just compensation for their diseases and deaths.'' But architects of the plan said it was fair way to compensate victims given the limited funds available. The restructuring was ordered by Weinstein after the trust ran out of cash to pay new claims and said some would be deferred until long into the 21st century. ``Everybody is getting an (equal) share of the fair value of their claim,'' said GEne Locks, a Philadelphia plaintiffs lawyer. ``Some people are going to get it a little faster than others.'' Asbestos is a white mineral with natural insulation and heat resistance used widely for decades in shipbuilding, construction and other industries. A high incidence of lung cancer and other respiratory ailments attributed to asbestos began appearing in the 1970s. Under the Manville plan, payments would be made annually to claimants based on a percentage of the trust's available resources. Claims are split into two groups: cancer and other serious ailments, and lesser diseases. Payments would be made only to claims in the first group during the plan's first two years. An estimated 23,000 such claims are expected to get some money. The group includes relatives of workers who died before being compensated. The more than 100,000 claims in the second group would begin receiving payment in the plan's third year. Payments are to be made first to those with hardships, then according to disease severity, then to claimants over 70 years old and finally to those who filed first. Despite the progress, payments will not resume until Weinstein holds hearings and reviews the plan, or until expected court appeals by plaintiffs lawyers and other defendant companies are Heard. Lawyers estimate that payments might not resume for a year or more. The trust, formed in 1988, has paid out more than $1.1 billion to settle nearly 26,000 claims. A total of 163,000 claims have been filed and more arrive daily. The trust has $434 million in settled but unpaid claims, which will be met in full under the plan. Trust officials have blamed the cash crunch on more claims and bigger settlements than anticipated and faster case resolution. Critics have said the trust was badly managed, doling out too-large payments for minor ailments. The reduction in plaintiffs lawyers' fees from about one-third of settlements followed sharp criticism by Weinstein. ``The 25 percent limitation will over time provide the victims hundreds of millions of dollars that otherwise would have gone to their attorneys,'' Leon Silverman, the court-appointed adviser for the restructuring, said in his report to Weinstein. Dismissing lawsuits against the trust - primarily over the size of or delay in settlements - also should lead to savings. The trust expects more than $50 million in legal defense expenses this year. The plan establishes maximum settlements for specific diseases. They range from $350,000 for mesolthelioma, a fatal respiratory ailment, to $30,000 for pleural disease. Expected median settlements are about 40 percent of the maximum. Payments to all Manville claimants except those with urgent health or financial needs were suspended in July. The Washingon, D.C.-based trust originally was funded with about $3 billion in cash and Manville securities. Its main asset is 80 percent stock ownership of Manville, a Denver manufacturing and natural resources company.

DOC.HEAD: EC, US Officials Have Impromptu Meet on Farm GATT Issue
DOC.TEXT: Top U.S. and EC officials held a hastily scheduled meeting Monday to try to narrow their differences on farm subsidies and rescue world trade talks from collapse. Ray MacSharry, the European Community Agriculture Commissioner, were scheduled over the weekend to discuss technical details of their respective farm proposals for the Dec. 3-7 conclusion to the Uruguay Round of global trade negotiations. NO details of the talks were made available. The talks offered a glimmer of hope that progress could be made after a week of high-level talks that left both sides sticking to their positions, putting the successful conclusion of the trade talks in doubt. An EC official, who asked not to be named, said it was the first time the two sides discussed the U.S. and EC proposals in great detail. ``They have gone away from rhetoric and are looking at the details of the EC proposal,'' the EC official said of U.S. negotiators. ``That is an important development.'' Meanwhile in Geneva, the head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said he believed a ``substantial package'' of agreements was still possible at the Dec. 3-7 session. GATT is sponsoring the trade talks. Arthur Dunkel told a press conference that although talks were still deadlocked on farm subsidies, progress had been made in other important areas such as efforts to reduce restrictions on trade in textiles. The sticking point in agriculture is the amount of cuts in subsidies and export subsidies. The EC has offered a 30 percent subsidy cut in the 1986-1996 period, while the United STates wants a 75 percent reduction in the 1990s plus a 90 percent cut in export subsidies. YEutter gave the Uruguay Round talks a less than 50-50 chance of success on Friday after he and senior U.S. officials held talks at the EC head office. But MacSharry has insisted the two proposals are ``broadly similar'' when only the overlapping time frame is considered. On Monday, the EC source said such technical issues were at the heart of Monday's meeting. The trade talks cover more than a dozen other negotiating areas ranging from textiles to services and intellectual properties. In Geneva, Dunkel said negotiators had agreed on a single framework text on trade in textiles. A trade source said the text provides for the phasing out of existing restrictions in textile trade, but added there was no consensus on how fast the barriers should be eliminated. Dunkel also said there were still wide rifts over rules to prevent goods from being ``dumped'' on world markets at artificially low prices.

DOC.HEAD: Kmart Reports Third-Quarter Profits Up 1.7 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Kmart Corp. said Monday its third-quarter Income rose 1.7 percent as strong sales of basic merchandise overcame soft demand for big-ticket items. The discount retailer said it earned $105.9 million, or 53 cents a share, for the 13 weeks ended Oct. 31, up from $104.1 million, or 52 cents a share in its fiscal third quarter of 1989. Sales for the period rose 11.7 percent to $7.49 billion from $6.71 billion a year earlier, said Kmart, the country's second-largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck and Co. Joseph E. Antonini, Kmart's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement the firm's basic merchandise sales were strong enough to offset weakness in more expensive lines such as electronics. Kmart's third-quarter earnings were in line with forecasts, and the discount chain has been trimming inventories to prepare for what retailers expect to be a lean Christmas season, said analyst Stacy Dutton of Morgan Stanley & Co. For the first three fiscal quarters, Kmart said its net income was up 3.1 percent to $354 million, or $1.77 a share, on sales of $22.32 billion, from $343.2 million, or $1.71 a share, on sales of $19.78 billion in the same period of 1989. The company operates 2,336 Kmart discount stores in the United States, Puerto Rico and Canada, and is the parent company for Pay Less Drug Stores, Builders Square, Waldenbooks, PACE Membership Warehouse Clubs and The Sports Authority.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Pensioners Reach Partial Settlement With Chevron
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Chevron comment in one graf after 5th pvs, ``We are. Picks up 6th graf pvs, The settlement.
DOC.TEXT: Chevron USA COrp. on Monday reached a partial settlement with Gulf pensioners in a class-action suit, agreeing to pay benefits and claims of about $25 million to terminated employees. The San FRancisco-based petroleum company agreed to vest the pension benefits of all employees fired by Gulf between Jan. 1, 1984 and June 30, 1986. Chevron acquired Gulf in 1984. Chevron has agreed to pay claims for severance, early retirement benefits and post-retirement medical and life insurance made by various employees working at operations sold by Chevron. In addition, Chevron agreed to pay 25 percent of the litigants' attorneys' fees. ``We are pleased that Chevron has agreed to pay these claims,'' said Lee Godfrey, lead counsel for the plaintiffs. ``Many class members who will be vested by this agreement have no other vested pension rights.'' Robert J. MALinak, a Houston attorney representing Chevron in the proceedings, termed the settlement ``a reasonable resolution of the claims.'' The settlement was announced as a month-long trial resumed Monday in federal court in Houston in which the plaintiffs want nearly $600 million restored to the Gulf pensioners plan. The plaintiffs claim surplus money in the Gulf pension plan should not have been lumped into a merged fund with money from the Chevron pension plan when Chevron merged the two pension plans in 1986. The suit was filed on behalf of more than 40,000 former Gulf Oil Corp. employees, retirees and CHevron employees who previously Worked for Gulf and their family members.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Shoots Up On Iraqi Troop Buildup
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rallied sharply Monday on news that Iraq will send another 250,000 troops into Kuwait. Light sweet crude oil, the benchmark blend, had dropped about $1 a barrel in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders focused on prospects of peace in the gulf. But prices shot up after Iraqi President Saddam HUssein announced the military buildup. Crude settled at $31.50 per barrel for December delivery contracts, up $1.72. Analysts said part of the run-up occurred as traders who had sold oil on the speculattion prices would drop scrambled to buy it back when prices began strengthening, a phenomenon known as short-covering. But the overall movement of oil prices was based on the Iraqi mobilization of additional troops. Contracts for delivery in January were up $1.13 at $30.72, and other months were mostly higher. ``Obviously, the market's spooked a little bit by Saddam's comments,'' said Randall Rothenberg, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The traders seem to be tied on to the last statement from Iraq, the next statements from Washington and so forth,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``No real fundamental change, but there's a lot of emotions.'' As oil rose, so did contracts for refined petroleum products and natural gas. Wholesale home heating oil went up 2.34 cents to 86.76 cents a gallon on December delivery contracts, with later delivery months all moving higher. Wholesale unleaded gasoline was up 2.73 cents at 80.36 cents a gallon for December delivery, with later months all moving up. Natural gas contracts were all higher, with December delivery up 1.5 cents at $2.35 per 1,000 cubic feet. Oil had opened $1.18 lower as it stayed briefly beneath $30 a barrel for next-month delivery. Crude had moved that low Friday, for the first time since Oct. 23, but it didn't take long MOnday for traders to push oil back above the $30 mark. Crude made an immediate reversal on the news of the Iraqi troops. The mood of the market stayed bullish for the rest of the session, even though many traders doubt hostilities will break out in the Gulf before President Bush winds up his Thanksgiving visit to the U.S. troops in the Saudi desert.

DOC.HEAD: Reader-Produced Sassy Magazine Hits Newstatands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST - time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Sassy, an often controversial magazine for teen-age girls, let the readers do it in the December issue. Sassy's editors put out the call last summer for readers who would create their own issue and selected 81 people from among more than 10,000 applicants. The issue goes on sale Tuesday. ``Every single little thing in this issue is totally reader-produced,'' the magazine boasts on the latest cover, which carries a photo of three readers. Led by designated editor Summer Lopez, a 17-year-old high school student from Los Gatos, Calif., about 40 readers visited Sassy's office in a building overlooking Times Square this past August to select story ideas, write and edit features and columns, shoot photos, lay out pages and devise catchy headlines. The others selected for the assignment did their jobs from home. ``I learned talking and writing like a teen-ager can be hard, even if I am one myself,'' wrote Ms. Lopez in a signed column that leads the issue. Cover stories included ``Eight teens who fought for their rights,'' ``Living with cokehead parents'' and ``Why we don't like our bodies.'' ``I'm real happy with it,'' said the Sassy's editor in chief for the 11 other issues a year, Jane Pratt. ``They wrote a little older than we do, a little straighter ... But the design is younger in some ways.'' Sassy was launched in March 1988 and has occasionally generated controversyhomosexuality and incest. But the magazine's editors said that boycotts mounted by religious groups over the content of the magazine have been resolved and they say advertising pages were up 53 percent this year compared with a year ago. The December issue contained about 55 pages of ads in a 100-page book. Its guaranteed circulation is 550,000 and is scheduled to rise to 650,000 next year. But it still trails other magazines aimed at teen girls such as Seventeen at 1.75 million, Teen at 1.1 million and YM at 1 million. Alx Mironovich, publisher of YM, said he thinks the reader-produced issue was ``a gimmick to get attention from advertisers.'' benefit by comparison. ``The photography was poor. The fashion layouts were not appealing. The cover was amateurish. I don't think this is what a consumer looks for in a magazine,'' he said. Ms. Pratt, on the other hand, said the issue helped Sassy editors better understand their readers and how to communicate with them. intends to make regular features. One is a comic strip. The magazine intends to run one from different readers of every month. But it also had some problems. A fiction piece on the end of the world was dumped because ``it wasn't as good as the other stuff,'' Ms. Pratt said, and some photographs were too dark because of poor lighting techniques. NOnetheless, Ms. Pratt said she intends to have another reader-produced issue next December. ``We are the only magazine that could do this and make it work,'' she said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market gained ground Monday, picking up where it left off in last week's advance, even though oil prices and interest rates turned upward. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 61.64 points last week, rose 15.10 to 2,565.35. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by nearly 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 902 up, 624 down and 475 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 140.95 million shares, down from 165.44 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 171.84 million shares. On Friday the Federal Reserve took the latest in a series of steps toward a gradual easing of its credit policy. Stock prices still seemed to benefit from that development Monday, despite an upturn in open-market interest rates and oil prices. Crude oil for December delivery climbed $1.72 a barrel to $31.50 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In the government securities market, prices of long-term Treasury bonds dropped more than $5 for each $1,000 in face value, pushing their yields back up to around the 8.5 percent level. However, brokers said investors in stocks seemed to view developments in those other markets as temporary, influenced by shifts in the fickle tenor of news reports coming out of the Middle East. In any case, a generally quiet week is expected on Wall Street, given the Thanksgiving holiday on Thursday and a light schedule of economic news. Trading will take place on Friday, but the session after Thanksgiving is often one of the slowest of the year in the financial world. USF&G fell 2] to 7} as the most active Big Board issue. A Wall Street Journal article quoted analysts as saying the company's recent woes might worsen further. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up ~ at 49; International Business Machines, up 1[ at 114}; Eastman Kodak, up 1 at 43, and Exxon, up \ at 50|. Claire's Stores fell 1{ to 11\. The company reported that earnings in the third quarter ended Nov. 3 edged up to 18 cents a share from 17 cents a share in the corresponding period a year earlier. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $14.52 billion, or 0.49 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.04 to 174.34. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.08 to 374.31, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.22 at 319.34. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 1.88 to 352.73. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 296.47, down 1.05.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle Futures Pushed Higher by Record Cash Prices
DOC.TEXT: Record high cash prices for cattle prodded the futures market upward Monday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cash cattle reached a record 82.50 cents a pound at Kansas City and there was talk that buyers were paying 83 cents at some markets, said Charlie Richardson of Lind-Waldock & Co. in Denver. On other markets, soybean and grain futures were mostly higher, as were oil and gold. While cattle futures followed an upward trend, they were somewhat restrained by fears that cash prices might be too high and by uncertainty generated by the government's seven-state cattle-on-feed report, released after the close. That report showed the number of cattle on feed as of Nov. 1 - 8.74 million head - at the high end of what the market was expecting. ``This may put a little pressure on the deferred months, but maybe not too much pressure since futures prices are already so far under cash,'' said Richardson. The runup in futures prices has been restrained because ``people keep expecting more fed cattle to come to market, but it just hasn't happened,'' he said. Live cattle futures settled .08 cent to .38 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at 79.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .40 cent higher with January at 87.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent lower to .22 cent higher with December at 53.60 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .08 cent to 1.43 cents higher with February at 72.20 cents a pound. Grain traders at the Chicago Board of Trade, keenly aware of the food shortages in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, are watching for signs that point toward increased exports. Strong commercial buying of grain and soybean futures last week gave some substance to rumors that a huge U.S.-Soviet grain pact was in the works, said William Biedermann, research director of Allendale Inc., of Crystal Lake, Ill. Prices edged upward again Monday, but with restraint. ``The market's saying, `I hear you, but I want to see it,''' he said. This is reflected in the cash market, too, where supplies are extremely tight because farmers are sitting on their harvests. ``The farmers locked it up and threw the key away,'' Biedermann said. They ``know that come springtime, they'll be the only store in town.'' Wheat settled 1{ cents to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.52} a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents higher with December at $2.27{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with December at $1.11{ a bushel; and soybeans were { cent lower to 2\ cents higher with November at $5.69 a bushel. Gold futures at the Commodity Exchange in New York responded to the fluctuations in the crude oil market, but within a more narrow range. The weekend offer by Iraq to release Western hostages sent oil futures into a decline on the opening, but this softness was quickly overtaken by the unfolding events in the Mideast and Washington. ``Gold made its lows for the day on the opening, but then the rhetoric rallied oil, and then gold followed,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst in New York with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. First came word that Iraq plans on sending an additional 250,000 troops into Kuwait, followed by Iraq's annoyance at the cold reception the Bush administration gave to its hostage-release offer. Gold settled $1.70 to $2.50 higher with December at $382.30 a troy ounce; silver was 9 cents to 10 cents lower with December at $4.14 a troy ounce. Light sweet crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange settled 5 cents lower to $1.72 a barrel higher with the December contract at $31.50; heating oil was .15 cent to 2.34 cents higher with December at 86.76 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was 1.26 cents to 2.73 cents higher with December at 80.36 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar traded mostly lower Monday, but it was boosted above its lows of the day by news that Iraq was moving more troops to Kuwait, traders said. Gold prices rose. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $381.40 a troy ounce, up $2.50 from Friday. Republic National Bank also quoted a late bid of $381.40, up $2.40 from Friday. The dollar was mixed against major currencies in European trading. Traders said it was hurt by the Federal Reserve's decision Friday to ease interest rates, which tends to make the dollar less valuable in relation to other currencies. That downward pressure on the dollar continued when domestic markets opened, said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange at PaineWebber Inc. ``And then we had the news that Iraq was sending some more troops on the border with Kuwait. The dollar strengthened a bit,'' Troni said. He said there was no economic news of substance Monday ``and so the political news was what moved the market.'' The dollar traditionally is viewed as a safe-haven investment in times of international turmoil. The dollar lost ground against the British pound and the Japanese yen, but strengthened somewhat against the German mark. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 128.95 yen, down 0.78 yen from Friday's finish of 129.73 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 128.20 yen. In New York it was quoted at 128.75 yen, down from 129.50 late Friday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9745 from $1.9655 late Friday. In New York, one pound cost $1.9750, more expensive than $1.9660 late Friday. The dollar bought 1.4745 marks in European trading, up from 1.4715 Friday. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.4717 marks, from 1.4705 late Friday. Friday's figure was a post-war low for the dollar against the mark. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.2450 Swiss francs, down from 1.2465; 4.9645 French francs, down from 4.9685; 1,108 Italian lire, down from 1,109.50; and 1.1634 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1633. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday, included: 1.2465 Swiss francs, up from 1.2445; 4.9745 French francs, up from 4.9690; 1.6628 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6595; 1,110.25 Italian lire, unchanged; and 1.1628 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1643. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $379.60 a troy ounce, from $376.75 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $378.75, from $376.20 bid late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $2.56 an ounce to close at $377.55. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.14 a troy ounce, down from $4.15 late Friday. In London, silve rose to a late bid price of $4.15 a troy ounce from $4.11 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: National System Could Save Billions, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to show that groups seek nationalized health system. RECASTS grafs 5-6 to clarify that savings would be 2 percentage points, not 2 percent. SUBS 8th graf, inserts new grafs 9-10 with comments on private system. Picks up 9th graf pvs, It estimated. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government could save $274.1 billion in medical costs in the year 2000 by regulating fees and replacing private insurance companies with universal public coverage, consumer groups said Monday. ``We can guarantee affordable, high-quality health care for all Americans,'' said Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA Foundation. ``We can do it by controlling doctor and hospital costs and by cutting the red tape that really is the only thing the insurance companies produce.'' The Health Insurance Association of America, an organization representing private insurers, said the groups wanted to drum up support for health care funded and administered by the government. ``Such a system would lead to health care rationing, which most Americans will not accept, and would cost an estimated $245 billion annually, which most Americans will not abide,'' association spokesman Donald B. White said in a statement. A report by Families USA Foundation and Citizen Action said the government should limit fee increases levied by doctors, hospitals and other health care providers. Such controls, similar to those now imposed in the Medicare program, would reduce from 8.6 percent to 6.6 percent the projected annual health care inflation rate and save $245.7 billion nationwide by the year 2000, the report said. Doctors and hospitals could achieve the required savings without reducing quality by eliminating unnecessary treatment and holding down increases in providers' income, the report said. Unnecessary high-tech equipment purchases and facility construction should be avoided, it said. Replacing the nation's 1,500 private insurers with a single provider would save another $53 billion in the year 2000, the report said. Under a national system, health care could be administered by the federal government, the states or a ``quasi-public entity,'' Families USA Foundation spokesman Arnold Bennett said. ``You're getting rid of an industry that is pencil pushers,'' Bennett said. The report said examples of the private insurers' administrative waste include diverse and duplicative payment rules; differing rates; high advertising costs; and excessive profits. It estimated that providing medical insurance to all Americans would require additional spending of $24.3 billion at the turn of the century. High administrative costs are borne disproportionately by small businesses and individuals who must purchase their own coverage, the report said. For every dollar of health care costs paid by groups of one to four people, 40 cents goes for administration. Groups of 100 to 150 pay 16 cents per dollar for administrative costs. White, the industry spokesman, agreed that 25 to 30 percent of health care services in the United States are unnecessary. But he described as ironic the criticism of administrative expenses, which he said cover ``systems that clamp down on unnecessary spending and help make health insurance more affordable.'' Costs can best be controlled by giving private insurers more flexibility to cover smaller businesses and granting those businesses tax breaks so they can better afford group coverage, White said. Also, public coverage for the poor and near-poor should be expanded, he said. The consumer groups said they calculated their figures using the latest available government statistics on private and public health care spending in each state and estimates of future spending based on age, income and other demographic information.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T To Let Soldiers Make Free Holiday Calls
DOC.TEXT: AT&T said Monday it would allow U.S. military personnel stationed in Saudi Arabia to call home for Thanksgiving at the company's expense. Each soldier will be permitted a three-minute call anywhere in the United States from Tuesday through Nov. 27, the company said. AT&T said it expects to handle more than 100,000 free calls. AT&T spokesman Dave Bikle estimated the program will cost the company more than $1 million. A three-minute call from Saudi Arabia costs $7.90 for calling-card holders, and $11.40 for others, he said.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Expects to Post Loss for Fourth Qtr
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. said Monday it expects to post a loss in the fourth quarter because of a weak advertising market and unexpectedly large losses on its television broadcasts of major league baseball. The company also said it expects lower earnings from continuing operations for all of 1991 compared with this year. The glum forecast comes as CBS reportedly planned a meeting with its affiliates board to propose a reduction in the estimated $160 million the network pays about 200 affiliated stations for carrying its shows. Media analysts said they expected CBS would post a loss for the last three months of 1990 and an earnings decline in 1991. Analyst Jeff Russell of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. said CBS would lose about $35 million in the quarter and earnings will fall to about $205 million in 1991 from about $230 million in 1990. In reaction to the news, CBS shares dropped $4 to close at $159.75 in trading of New York Stock Exchange issues. CBS isn't the only media company suffering because of a slowdown this quarter in national ad spending growth. Capital Cities-ABC Inc., which operates the ABC Television Network, said last month as it reported a decline in profit in the third quarter that it expected a decline in earnings for the fourth quarter as well. Like CBS, Capital Cities-ABC has been hurt by losses on major league baseball coverage at its 80 percent-owned ESPN cable TV network. The third major network, NBC, is owned by General Electric Co. which does not report separately on its broadcasting subsidiary's performance. CBS's unspecified loss projected for the fourth quarter would be its first excluding special items since the company lost $20 million on continuing operations in the fourth quarter of 1986, spokesman Kewith Fawcett said. CBS earned $59.5 million, or $2.31 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989. This was the first year of CBS's four-year baseball contract which allows it to carry several regular season games along with the league championship series, World Series and All-Star game. While the network reportedly expected to lose about $35 million in the first year of the $1.06 billion contract, the losses are said to have run much higher. CBS Sports President Neal Pilson has said only that the loss on baseball was under $100 million. On Monday, CBS said losses on baseball were ``higher than anticipated'' as the result of soft demand in the ad marketplace for time on sports programs and because the World Series and one of the two league championships were settled in four games instead of the maximum seven. The short series meant CBS had fewer nights of baseball on which to sell advertising. Games later in a series also tend to draw bigger audiences, making them more valuable to advertisers. CBS said its TV network would have had a loss for the fourth quarter even without baseball, because of the soft ad marketplace. It said the marketplace weakness has dampened demand for network, local TV and radio advertising, and said network ad prices have been particulartly soft for National Football League and primetime broadcasts, where CBS ratings have improved. In projecting a decline in earnings from continuing operations in 1991 compared with 1990, CBS cited the worsening economic climate for advertising and rising costs for entertainment programs and sports rights. Another reason is that the 1990 figures include profits on the coverage of the NFL Super Bowl and the National Basketball Association playoffs and championship that the network will not have rights to in 1991. ``As a result, the CBS Television Network is currently expected to show an operating loss in 1991,'' the statement said. Russell said his firm expects the CBS TV Network will post a profit of about $10 million for 1990 and lose about $35 million next year.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Policy Makers Must Address High Business Costs
DOC.TEXT: Government policy makers must help bring down the cost of doing business in New England in order to turn around the region's slumping economy, according to a report issued Monday. The report from Bank of Boston Corp. says some costs, such as wages and housing, will drop naturally as the economy continues its slide. But government officials can assist in other areas where economic cycles play a smaller role, such as health care costs and workers compensation. ``Two weeks after the election of four new governors in New England, we want to point out that the current debate has yet to focus on the issue of the cost of doing business,'' said Wayne Ayers, chief economist for Bank of Boston, who helped prepare the report. ``So much attention during the election was understandably focused on fiscal problems,'' he said. ``But the (state) budget to any extent is a reflection of the underlying health of the economy.'' Ayers said high business costs not only threaten to further erode New England's shrinking manufacturing base, but also could hurt the region's services sector. He said the services sector cannot prosper when attorneys, accountants and other vendors have nothing to service. ``We need a core manufacturing base, and therefore lowering the cost of doing business is critical,'' he said. According to the study: - Housing prices, although declining, are still above the national average and make it difficult to recruit new workers to the region. - Medical care costs have raised health insurance premiums in New England by 13 percent a year, about 3 percentage points above the national average. The effect has raised the cost of doing business in New England, compared to the rest of the nation, by about $1,000 per employee per year. - Workers compensation is more expensive in New England than elsewhere, and the problem is worse today than at the height of the economic boom of the mid-1980s. Ayers said the weak economy would ``take its toll'' on housing prices and wages. ``As painful as the process is, it is necessary for any kind of recovery,'' he said. Ayers also said the region's business costs have been exacerbated by the Persian Gulf crisis, which has increased higher oil prices and added to the high bills paid by companies. Despite the gloom, the region has many strengths, the report said, including emerging technology companies, a strong research and education base, foreign trade and a skilled work force.

DOC.HEAD: NASD Sanctions First Fidelity Capital Corp.
DOC.TEXT: A New York stock brokerage and its president were fined $650,000 and permanently barred from dealings with the National Association of Securities Dealers Monday for allegedly overcharging customers. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Ted Lawrence Rubin and his firm, First Fidelity Capital Corp., settled the NASD allegations. The NASD charged that Rubin and the firm charged fraudulently excessive markups totaling $510,000 on the securities of Resource Network International, for which First Fidelity Capital Corp. was the underwriter of the initial public offering. The NASD is a self-regulating organization empowered by Congress to oversee the over-the-counter market for securities which are not traded on stock exchanges. It can fine and suspend firms and inviduals, expel firms from the NASD or bar individuals from associating with any NASD member firm. As part of the settlement, Rubin is barred from associating with any NASD member in any capacity. The firm was expelled from NASD membership.

DOC.HEAD: F.W. Dodge Reports 20 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Housing construction fell 20 percent in the third quarter, with the Northeast suffering the largest decline, a survey released Monday said. F.W. Dodge, the construction information division of McGraw-Hill Inc., said starts on new houses, condominiums and apartments totaled 299,299 units in the July-September period, down from 371,792 in the same period in 1989. Only three of the nation's 25 largest homebuilding areas showed gains in the period, F.W. Dodge said. They were Phoenix, Dallas and Indianapolis. All five major regions of the country reported declines from third-quarter 1989 totals. ``The Northeast, with its 36 percent setback, continued to set the downward pace,'' said George A. Christie, vice president and chief economist at Dodge. ``The North and South Central regions, with smaller than average cutbacks, dampened the general collapse,'' he said. ``Closest to the 20 percent national average decline in housing starts were the Southeast and Southwest.''

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of N.Y. Mercantile Exchange Sued by Ex-Partner
DOC.TEXT: The head of one of the world's biggest futures exchanges is being sued for $3 million by an ex-partner for allegedly failing to repay money he borrowed to cover losses on commodities deals. New York Mercantile Exchange Chairman Z. Lou Guttman's losses mounted as he conducted trades in cotton, copper, sugar, crude oil, coffee, cocoa and currencies, according to the attorney for Harold Magid, a futures trader who claims to have set up a joint venture with Guttman in 1987. Guttman was losing money through his personal account, which at times did not contain enough cash to meet the requirements of exchanges he was trading on, so he borrowed money from the joint venture after promising it would be repaid, lawyer Neal Schwarzfeld said Monday. Guttman referred inquiries to his lawyer, David Yeres. ``The allegations are bogus and contrived,'' Yeres said Monday. He said he plans to respond in detail through his own court filing. Magid and Guttman became partners in the joint venture through which they would equally share profits and losses from futures trading, according to Magid's lawsuit filed in state Supreme Court, which is a trial-level court in New York. Their brokerage functions were performed by an entity known as Harley Futures Inc., which they jointly owned, the lawsuit said. They also hoped to share commissions and management fees from business they were able to generate for a separate trading firm, Gerald Commodities Inc., the lawsuit said. Guttman was to supervise Harley's business and use his status as chairman of the Mercantile Exchange to solicit additional business, the lawsuit said. The joint venture, set up with $300,000 deposited by Guttman and Magid, immediately began turning a profit of $30,000 to $40,000 per month. Eventually, it had made millions, the lawsuit said. But Guttman began losing money through a personal account, and Magid agreed to let him borrow hundreds of thousands of dollars from the partnership. The money was lent with the understanding that Guttman would repay it, but payments never came and eventually the joint venture fell so short of cash it had to liquidate many of its futures positions, the lawsuit said. After Magid stopped doing business with Guttman in August, Magid found that he was temporarily ``blackballed'' in the commodities trading community because of his dispute with Guttman, Schwarzfeld alleged. A Mercantile Exchange spokeswoman said the exchange would not comment on whether it was looking into the allegations contained in Magid's lawsuit. The exchange's policy is to comment only when alleged wrongdoing is found.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Largest Chain to Buy Erol's Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Blockbuster Entertainment Corp. announced a $40 million deal Monday to buy Erol's Inc., which owns and operates 208 videocassette rental and sales stores in five states and Washington, D.C. Blockbuster, the nation's largest video chain, will acquire Erol's operations in exchange for cash, a note, Blockbuster common stock and debt assumption, the Fort Lauderdale-based company said. H. Wayne Huizenga, Blockbuster's chairman and chief executive officer, said the agreement in principle ``provides an outstanding opportunity for Blockbuster and its franchise owners to broaden the base of our stores.'' ``The proposed acquisition is in the best interest of Erol's, its employees and customers, particularly in view of Blockbuster's significant financial resources,'' said Erol's founder and principal stockholder, Erol Onaran. The sale is contingent on the execution of a definitive acquisition agreement and the approval of lenders. Blockbuster also opened its 1,500th store Monday, in Vancouver, British Columbia. In all, the chain has stores in 44 states, the District of Columbia, Guam, Puerto Rico, Canada and England.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Company Posts Third-Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy in August, posted a third-quarter profit, according to results released Monday by the casino company. For the three months ended Sept. 30, Resorts recorded a net gain of $6.9 million on revenues of $109.0 million, compared to a loss of $2.2 million in the third quarter of 1989 on revenues of $124.3 million. The plan that took Resorts out of Chapter 11 reduced its outstanding bonds by $429.8 million from $911 million. Bondholders received 78 percent ownership in the company in exchange for the reduced debt. That reduction of $429.8 million was recorded as an extraordinary credit this quarter. Balanced against a $153.2 million downward re-evaluation of Resorts' assets, the company recorded a skewed net gain of $259.7 million. ``The changes in accounting as of August 31 make it difficult to precisely compare the 1990 numbers to the 1989 numbers,'' Resorts president David Hanlon said in a news release. ``However, we have definitely shown an improvement in our earnings from operations.'' Resorts owns Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel and the Paradise Island casino in the Bahamas. The company hopes to sell the Bahamian property before the end of 1991. In its quarterly report filed with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission, Resorts said that revenues may suffer from the recession, rising fuel costs' effect on airfares and increased competition in Atlantic City from the Taj Mahal casino and in the Bahamas from Crystal Palace.
